HEADLINE: Brazil's Environmental Plea Appears to Be Aimed at U.S.

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 23

 BODY:
In a speech before the General Assembly highlighted by his implicit criticism of the United States, the President of Brazil, Fernando Collor de Mello, said today that there was "an inescapable obligation" for nations to accept mandatory measures to protect the environment.
"Just as the question of development has yielded to other issues on the international agenda, I am concerned that the issue of the environment may also yield to other aspects of the day-to-day life of the world," said Mr. Collor, whose country is to be the site of the first Earth Summit in June. 
 The first day of general debate of the 46th General Assembly featured few surprises from the 14 speakers who went before the 166 member nations.
Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati of Iran delivered a speech almost totally devoted to discussion of the "New World Order." He ended his 30-minute speech with brief mentions of what he called the three major crises of the last several decades, the "Iraqi aggression" against Kuwait, Afghanistan and the issue of a Palestinian homeland.
 
Harking Back to the Environment
 Iran has privately been at the center of efforts brokered by the United Nations to release Western hostages in Lebanon, but Mr. Velayati made no reference to that issue.
The speeches today were filled with prescriptions for peace and references to the "New World Order." But the environment was a recurring theme, from Mr. Collor's lightly veiled chastisement of the United States to an impassioned plea by President Bailey Olter of Micronesia to industrialized nations that use tiny South Pacific islands as dumping grounds.
"Our region cannot be considered by the larger nations as a convenient empty space for the disposal of toxic and hazardous waste and chemicals and radioactive materials," Mr. Olter said.
Leading off the speakers, Mr. Collor's comments increased pressure on the United States to end its opposition to a series of proposals dealing with global warming and other environmental issues.
The third of five international meetings called to formulate a host of agreements to be voted on in Brazil at the Conference on Environment and Development ended last Friday in Nairobi, Kenya. The United States was still resisting efforts to set mandatory cuts in emissions of carbon dioxide. Scientists say carbon monoxide is the main manmade gas contributing to global warming.
 
Tracing the Responsibility
 The European Community and Japan favor reducing carbon-dioxide emissions to the levels of last year by the year 2000. But the United States, the biggest producer of carbon dioxide, argues that too little is known about the warming threat to justify the costs of trying to adhere to mandatory limits.
In comments seemingly directed toward the United States, Mr. Collor said, "Lasting solutions to global problems require the commitment of the international community as a whole, each country according to its responsibility relating to the origin of these problems and to their management, as well as to its economic and technological capacity to overcome them."
The United States' objections could impede chances for a treaty at the meeting in Brazil. There are also other obstacles like demands by the United States and other developed nations for language to reduce the depletion of forests and waterways in many underdeveloped nations.
"The conference should not set the stage for grievances and recrimination," Mr. Collor said. "It should, on the contrary, provide the framework for mature and feasible proposals."
Mr. Collor, who said the Brazil meeting would allow a debate as broad and profound "as the political will of the participants will allow," was supported by New Zealand, whose Prime Minister, J. B. Bolger, said, "Next year's United Nations conference in Brazil will be the real test of our ability to cooperate in the endeavor to find the proper balance between development and environmental protection."
Other speakers included the Foreign Ministers of Angola, Australia, Burkina Faso, Iceland, Mexico, Norway and Sri Lanka.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Goes To a Hearing On Police Pay

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In an unusual move, Mayor David N. Dinkins testified yesterday at the final day of arbitration hearings on a new contract for New York City police officers, arguing that the city cannot afford a raise greater than the 4 percent it has offered unless the union agrees to save money in other ways.
Municipal labor experts said they could not recall a similar appearance by a mayor in an arbitration dispute and they saw Mr. Dinkins's testimony as a sign of the administration's deep concern about holding down the cost of a new 15-month contract with the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, to replace the one that expired in June 1990. 
 That the contract would have expired by the time it is awarded is a sign of the complexities of the situation. In effect, Mr. Dinkins is trying to squeeze back into a bottle the genie he let loose a year ago by granting a substantial raise to the teachers' union just as the depth of the city's fiscal problems was becoming apparent.
Negotiations with the P.B.A., one of the city's most powerful unions, were thrown into arbitration after the union and city could not agree on a new settlement. Like other uniformed services, the police have traditionally won wage settlements higher than other municipal employees, and its settlement could set a pattern for firefighters, correction officers and sanitation workers.
 
'Precarious at Best'
 "If our fiscal integrity is compromised even to the smallest degree, then our ability to meet the needs of our people in public safety and in all areas is compromised as well," Mr. Dinkins said in remarks released after the closed hearing. "It is no secret that our economic situation remains precarious at best."
The police have sought a raise comparable to the 5.5 percent wage increase Mr. Dinkins granted to teachers. But the city contends it cannot afford that, since much of the teacher raise was financed by changing earnings calculations for its union's pension fund, allowing the city to reduce its annual contribution to the fund and use the money for raises instead. Over the years, the police pension fund has been invested differently and its union has regularly drawn from it to supplement wages and it could not produce as much extra money now.
The city says it is prepared to give the police a 1.5 percent raise in each of two fiscal years, for a total of 3 percent directly from the city budget (as it did for other unions this year), and about another percentage point from pension recalculations. But it says anything above that must come from concessions by the union, such as changes in salary step-ups based on seniority or a reduction in the amount of "wash-up" time allowed.
The union contends that it deserves bigger raises to stay competitive with officers in Nassau County, who can earn nearly $10,000 more a year than officers in New York City can earn. Keeping teachers' salaries competitive with the surrounding region was one of the Mayor's chief reasons for granting them raises last year.
Joseph Mancini, a spokesman for the P.B.A., said he had no comment on the Mayor's testimony, but he repeated the union's contention that it deserved competitive wages, the city's fiscal problems notwithstanding.
Before the talks went to arbitration, the city had relatively little leverage over the police union, since the Mayor's ambitious anti-crime plan means that the city is continuing to hire thousands of officers, while laying off other employees. So the police had little incentive to make concessions.
Yesterday, the Mayor repeated that he would lay off no police officers, whose union chose to endorse no one in the 1989 mayoral race rather than support him. That is a pledge he has been unable to make to unions that did support him.
Arbitration is unpredictable, but generally gives great weight to past practice and patterns set in bargaining with other unions. The current situation is especially complicated, because the raises granted to other unions have come from a variety of sources and because the police are not comparably situated. But experts said the police also have a strong case that they are entitled to raises comparable to those given other unions.
Mr. Dinkins said the arbitration panel could not ask the city "to spend money we don't have."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST DIPLOMACY;
Bluegrass Supporting Bush on Israel

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOREHEAD, Ky., Sept. 21

 BODY:
Jobs, tobacco and taxes are the essence of Bluegrass politics, but when Representative Larry J. Hopkins brought his longshot Republican gubernatorial campaign here this weekend, he tested a new issue: the proposed $10 billion in loan guarantees for Israel.
Speaking before a sparsely attended fund-raiser, Mr. Hopkins hinted that he would support President Bush's request that Congress delay consideration of the loan guarantees. Such a position is an expression of his own opposition to all foreign assistance programs. 
 "I can tell you that in 14 years I haven't voted for a single foreign aid bill yet," he said. "Why? I think we have to help our people first."
Afterward, Republicans at the fund-raiser expressed enthusiasm for Mr. Hopkins's position.
"We need to solve problems here, and we shouldn't use our money as a means for keeping peace in the world," said Terry LeMaster, a 37-year-old construction contractor. "We shouldn't buy off allies."
 
Israel 'Must Follow Suit'
 John O'Cull, a 35-year-old dentist, said. "The Israelis have to follow suit with our demands before we give them the money."
The loan guarantees, meant to help Israel house and otherwise accommodate its flood of Soviet Jewish emigres, are controversial because the issue is linked in the minds of many with the Israeli policy of building Jewish settlements in the occupied territories.
The Bush Administration, which opposes the settlements policy, argues that Congressional consideration of the loan guarantees now would jeopardize Arab participation in a proposed Arab-Israeli peace conference scheduled for October. Pro-Israel organizations and Israel's many supporters in Congress contend that the loan guarantees are a strictly humanitarian issue and that the proposed 120-day delay of the matter would only weaken Israel's bargaining position at peace talks.
Here in Kentucky, the issue has touched a raw nerve for a different reason. The loan guarantees package is commonly viewed in the populist terms of helping America first, even though no money from the Federal Treasury need ever be spent; Washington would only be guaranteeing $10 billion in commercial loans to Israel over the next five years, a step that gives Israel the advantage of lower interest rates.
 
Support for Bush Stand
 In dozens of interviews in small towns around the state, Kentuckians indicated that there is resounding support for Mr. Bush's request for a delay. The interviews suggest that whatever political damage the President may suffer with American Jews may be neutralized in areas of the country where there are few Jews.
The Kentucky public's apparent sentiment against the loan guarantees seems to have helped persuade several of the state's members of Congress, including its two traditionally pro-Israel senators, to remain largely silent on the issue.
"What the drumbeat is about is a $10 billion donation for Israel, but once people understand that we're only co-signing a note, I think you'll find some softening," said Senator Wendell H. Ford on a flight to Kentucky for a weekend of parades. As the Democratic whip, Mr. Ford would be expected to be a crucial player in opposing the President and in overriding a possible veto of legislation including the loan guarantees.
But Mr. Ford, who is up for re-election in 1992 and remains undecided, said, "This is an issue you have to explain, and my dad used to say never cast a vote you have to explain."
Kentucky's Republican Senator, Mitch McConnell, who is publicly undecided and quietly trying to forge a compromise between the White House and other pro-Israel Senators, called himself "the man in the middle." On the one hand, Mr. McConnell's traditional support for Israel drew more than $120,000 in campaign contributions from Jewish interest groups last year, more than any other Republican Senator attracted for the 1990 campaign. On the other hand, he is one of the Senate's strongest promoters of Mr. Bush's foreign policy.
 
'Better Way to Go' Unclear
 "You can make a persuasive argument on this issue either way," Mr. McConnell said. "It's not clear strategically which is the better way to go."
Noting that less than 1 percent of the Kentucky population is Jewish, he added, "If you were going to make a purely political decision on this, you'd have to go with Bush."
While Mr. McConnell was attending Hopkins fund-raisers around this state on Saturday, a reporter's conversations with more than 30 people elicited only two responses unequivocally supporting the Israeli position.
As he watched Mr. McConnell crown this year's queen at the Harrodsburg Horse Show, Gary Gibson, a 39-year-old plumbing factory worker, said, "I feel Israel ought to get whatever it needs."
As a Baptist, Mr. Gibson said he believed that "the United States is based on being a God-fearing country," adding, "So if we're willing to help all those heathen people, we should help Israel, where Jesus Christ came from."
 
2 Reasons for Opposition
 But the overwhelming majority of those interviewed were divided between those who said the Government should spend more money on creating jobs at home and less on foreign aid and others who said Mr. Bush's judgment on foreign affairs was superior to that of Congress.
Several people mistakenly thought that the credit guarantee was an outright grant. But even when their misconception was corrected, they said they feared that the United States would have to pick up the tab eventually anyway.
A typical remark was made by Sherry Keller, a 29-yar-old Morehead grocery store owner, who said: "We ought to see how the peace conference works out before we give away our money. But still, you have no guarantee you'll ever get the money back."
Roger Moore, a 38-year-old unemployed Morehead geologist and a Democrat, said he would vote against Mr. Ford next year if he voted for the Israeli loan guarantees.
"I wouldn't send it at all," he said. "We already have loan guarantees around the world, and we might as well write them all off. I believe Kentucky could use the $10 billion a lot better."
 
Several Are Knowledgeable
 While some of those interviewed had only a vague idea of the issue, several people spoke about the subject knowledgeably and said it came up in conversations at home and at work. Several said they valued Israel as an important ally, but believed that this was no time for the United States to expose itself to more debt.
At the Black Gold Festival in the southeastern town of Hazard, the weak coal economy seemed to sharpen negative sentiments toward the loan guarantees.
Charles Reynolds, a 52-year-old mine worker, said the issue of the loan guarantees came up in a discussion last week among his crew while they were laying some track for transporting coal out of their mine.
"I think a lot of people here care about foreign aid," he said. "People wouldn't be against foreign aid if their needs were met."
A 47-year-old mine worker, who would identify himself only as A.J., said: "We have real hunger in the United States, and here in eastern Kentucky we have high unemployment right now. If anybody needs help, we ought to help them, but you have to help your people first."

HEADLINE: U.S. Could Cut Defense Spending By More Than 33%, Report Says

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
An authoritative study of American defense needs by the Brookings Institution concludes that the United States can reduce military spending by more than a third over the next 10 years and still maintain the world's preeminent military establishment capable of dealing with any likely emergency in the post-cold war era.
The Brookings Institution estimates that cumulative savings of $316 billion to $619 billion could be realized. 
 The study, which will be published later this month, challenges the Pentagon's assessment of future military threats as unrealistic. It says the Pentagon's assumptions about war-fighting strategies and the need for more sophisticated weapons will mean that the military budget will begin to swell again by mid-decade after being on a downward path since 1985.
"The view from the Pentagon is of a scaled-down version of the cold war," the study says.
 
A Critical Outside Review
 The 80-page document, co-written by Dr. William W. Kaufmann, professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and John D. Steinbruner, who heads Brookings's Foreign Policy Studies Program, is the most extensive and critical outside review to date of the Bush Administration's military strategy and spending plans for the rest of the decade. As such, it is likely to provide ammunition in a Congressional debate that has already begun over how to divide the Government's resources better between military expenses and domestic programs.
Challenging the five-year, $1.2-trillion military spending plan submitted last year by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, the study argues that the Pentagon sought to pre-empt Presidential decision making by categorically defining the absolute minimum level of national risk -- and therefore spending -- that the country should accept.
Defense Department officials said they had not seen the study but expressed strong reservations when told of its recommendations. Since the abortive coup in the Soviet Union, Mr. Cheney has been particularly sensitive to calls for speeding up the pace of cuts in the military budget.
"I think a little caution is in order before we automatically assume, based on one week's news, that we can now dismantle our own defenses," Mr. Cheney said recently.
The study suggests, among other things, that traditional definitions of military threat, American national security interests and military spending should be adjusted in a way that places more emphasis on economic power in a world where the probabilities of major conflicts involving the United States are seen by many as substantially reduced by the end of the cold war.
"The future ability of the United States to maintain the conditions of its security will depend as much on its moral authority, diplomatic skills, and economic assets as on its military capabilities," the study asserts.
It also recommends that the United States seek to engage potential adversaries and competitors in cooperative security ventures to minimize the risk of sudden military conflict.
"With regard to the Soviet Union in particular, the U.S. military would have to subordinate traditional objectives of deterrence and containment to the strategic principle of cooperative engagement that was successfully used with the German and Japanese military establishments following World War II," the study recommends.
The study was commissioned at the outset of 1991, and its major conclusions were drawn before the new and more sweeping changes in the Soviet Union that followed last month's attempted coup against Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But Dr. Kaufmann, adviser to a number of secretaries of defense during the cold war era, said the changes in the Soviet Union only deepened his conviction that greater reductions in military spending could safely be made.
The study formulates a plan it calls the "low option," defining future American forces that would be adequate to protect American interests while shifting resources to other parts of the economy. By projecting a moderately lower level of risk, the plan envisions spending $2.2 trillion over the next decade. It says that Mr. Cheney's spending plans would cost a minimum $316 billion more, and as much as $619 billion more if the production costs of a new generation of high technology weapons balloon as predicted by the Congressional Budget Office.
Noting that these weapons were based on assumptions of Soviet threats that now seem far less likely, backers of the low option estimate that $50 billion could be safely cut from military spending from now to 1996 by freezing many of those weapons in the "advanced development" stage.

HEADLINE: Duke Softens Past in Louisiana Race

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COVINGTON, La., Sept. 20

 BODY:
First came the warnings. State Representative David Duke told a crowd of supporters gathered in a rural meeting hall here that their way of life was threatened by racial quotas and welfare babies.
Then Mr. Duke, a 41-year-old former grand wizard of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, promised that if he was elected governor he would save Louisiana by giving poor blacks his own version of "tough love." 
 With a month to go before the voting in Louisiana's open primary, Mr. Duke's past has not emerged as a major issue in the campaign. Poll takers, political analysts and even aides to rival candidates agree that Mr. Duke has succeeded in presenting himself as a legitimate candidate for governor, and he is widely credited with putting his message into language that has a potentially broad appeal among white voters.
With public opinion polls showing that he has a fair chance to win a place in a runoff, Mr. Duke has become the wild card in an election that will provide this year's most prominent test of racial issues in American politics.
 
Appeal to Racial Identity
 Although much of his message is framed in terms of budget cuts and changes in the welfare system, Mr. Duke still makes a direct appeal to his supporters' racial identity.
"If you are white these days you are a second-class citizen in your own country," Mr. Duke said at his rally here on the shore of Lake Pontchartrain, drawing loud applause.
Within the next 10 days both President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle are scheduled to campaign in Louisiana for the incumbent, Buddy Roemer. The Governor was wooed by the White House last spring when he switched parties and became the Republicans' prize catch to date in their long effort to convert Democratic officeholders in Southern states.
The other major contender for a spot in the runoff is a populist Democrat, Edwin W. Edwards, who previously won three terms as governor with strong support from black voters and is now trying to rally his party's traditional constituencies.
The operatic qualities of Louisiana politics, with larger-than-life personalities and melodramatic plots, are reinforced by the state's election laws. All candidates regardless of party affiliation appear on the same ballot in an open primary, which will be held on Oct. 19 this year. If no one wins a majority, the top two candidates will meet in a runoff on Nov. 16.
 
'A Very Dicey Contest'
 "It is virtually a three-way race and it is certainly a very dicey contest for second place," said Edward Renwick, of the Loyola University Institute of Politics.
The race is further complicated by the candidacy of United States Representative Clyde C. Holloway, who has the endorsement of the state Republican Party. Mr. Roemer did not seek the endoresement. Nor did Mr. Duke, who calls himself a Republican even though he has been disavowed by both the state and national party organizations.
In a poll made public last week by the Loyola institute for several Louisiana television stations, Mr. Renwick found that Mr. Roemer was preferred by 26 percent of the electorate, Mr. Edwards by 25 percent, Mr. Duke by 10 percent and Mr. Holloway by 9 percent. The poll of 750 registered voters had a margin of sampling error of nearly four percent.
But taking into account what has come to be known as Mr. Duke's "hidden vote" -- people unwilling to admit their preference for him except in the privacy of the voting booth -- Mr. Renwick recalculated Mr. Duke's share at 25 percent.
This hidden vote came out massively for Mr. Duke last year in his unsuccessful effort to unseat Louisians's senior Senator, J. Bennett Johnston, a Democrat who has been an influential voice on Capitol Hill for 20 years.
Just days before the election, public opinion polls were predicting that Mr. Duke would win from 20 to 30 percent of the vote. His actual total was 44 percent, including about 58 percent of the white vote.
 
Duke Attracts Protest Vote
 Charles and Sandra Wagoner are examples of Mr. Duke's hidden vote. Mr. Wagoner is a 29-year-old economist, and Mrs. Wagoner, 30, is a paralegal. They concede they are uncomfortable with Mr. Duke's involvement with the Klan and with several of his positions on specific issues.
But they came to Mr. Duke's rally here because, as Mrs. Wagoner put it, "He strikes a very sympathetic chord in those of us who are working to death, who are taxed to death and don't see much for it."
Mr. Wagoner said, "There is a protest vote out there of people who will go for Duke in the end because even if they don't like everything he stands for, they are even more unhappy with the way things are going."
A major factor in determining the size of the hidden vote this year is Mr. Duke's apparent ability to overcome the less savory aspect of his past.
In last year's Senate race the electorate was constantly reminded of Mr. Duke's past as a Klansman and a neo-Nazi by the news media and by Senator Johnston's television advertisements. This year, for the first time in his political career, Mr. Duke's past is rarely mentioned.
For example, Mr. Duke appeared before a political science class at the University of New Orleans this week and took several hostile questions from students on issues like his proposal to give welfare mothers cash payments if they agree to be implanted with long-term contraceptives. But no student ever referred to his past.
"It's been gone over and over and now it's old news, said Alan T. Leonhard, the professor who taught the class. "People in Louisiana are used to him. The shock value has worn off."
Douglas Rose, a professor of political science at Tulane University, said: "Duke is now following a relatively well-trod Republican trail. He is saying some things we've heard from George Bush and certainly from Jesse Helms," the Republican Senator from North Carolina.
In his campaign appearances Mr. Duke bemoans excessive government spending and rising taxes. He also deplores crime, drug trafficking and the high costs of welfare. He frequently stresses the charge that affirmative action programs are unfair to whites.
 
Drawing a Battle Line
 Like other politicians who raise the same issues, Mr. Duke refrains from outright appeals to racism. But he is more explicit than others in drawing a battle line between his constituents, white voters, and his scapegoats, poor blacks, who are blamed for everything from rising crime to rising taxes.
"The rising welfare underclass is taking more and more from the working class," he says. "They are overwhelming us."
Mr. Duke was on his home ground in Covington, a community about 40 miles north of downtown New Orleans. Addressing an all-white crowd, he said, "It is time to reform the liberal welfare system because it is not helping the poor escape poverty, and it's not helping the people who are paying for it."
Then, in tones heavily laden with sympathy, he added: "We have not helped these people by giving them our money. We have not been very Christian. I want to help them."
 
'It's Called Tough Love'
 Mr. Duke, who is divorced, compares welfare recipients to his teen-age daughters, saying it would be wrong to give them everything they want. "It's called tough love," he said.
In an interview, Mr. Duke said he has had a change of heart. "I used to blame minorities for a lot of the conditions in their communities," he said. "Now I blame the liberal social welfare system for creating those conditions, and I feel sorry for the people."
But he cautions against making too much of this change.
"I have not given up the basic conservative values I started out with," the candidate said. "I've become more moderate, but I'm not afraid to say I believe in white rights. I do say that because I believe in protecting our nation's western, Christian culture, but now I can also say I believe in black rights, in equal rights for all."

Mr. Duke, a former grand wizard of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, campaigned recently in the Louisiana countryside. (Tomas Muscionico/Contact Press Images for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PERU CHIEF'S VISIT HELPS AID CHANCES

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
A visit to Washington last week by President Alberto Fujimori of Peru has started the wheels turning in Congress for a compromise in which Peru would receive $94.9 million in military and economic aid that has been blocked because of human rights abuses.
Congressional aides said yesterday that it now seemed likely that Peru would receive all of the $60 million in economic aid that had been requested by the Bush Administration and most, if not all, of $34.9 million in military assistance. 
 "Clearly, the visit helped Peru's case," one aide said. "People came away from meetings with Fujimori feeling he wants to help Peru and that he's trustworthy."
Mr. Fujimori, who returned to Peru on Friday, told the legislators that he would provide access for civilian prosecutors and representatives of the International Red Cross to military and police detention centers where many tortures and rapes have been reported.
 
Meeting Coca Farmers
 He also said he had been meeting with Peruvian coca farmers, who produce 60 percent of the raw material for the cocaine that reaches the United States, to help them switch to other crops.
Representative Robert G. Torrecelli, Democrat of New Jersey, and five other congressmen who had been among the leading opponents of the aid package are proposing that the money be released in three stages based on progress in improving the human rights situation and in countering cocaine production and trafficking.
Mr. Torrecelli said he remarked in his meeting with Mr. Fujimori that Peru was "a nation facing an almost complete security, economic and health collapse" and that "some different standards need to be applied for our own interests."
About 80 percent of Peru's work force is unemployed or underemployed, a third of the country is malnourished, the Shining Path guerrilla movement is terrorizing the highlands and many of the cities, and a Latin American cholera epidemic has hit Peru the hardest of any country, with 240,000 reported cases.
Most of the $60 million in economic aid is to be used to help Peru meet payments on its $23 billion foreign debt, which must be made to keep new loans and other aid flowing. Approval of the economic aid will also permit Peru to spend $50 million in Peruvian currency from a joint United States-Peruvian fund for several projects aimed at the country's 250,000 coca growers.
 
Uses of Military Aid
 The military aid is to be used for equipment and for sending up to 50 United States military advisers to serve as trainers in noncombat zones.
The Inter-American Development Bank announced during Mr. Fujimori's visit that it was giving Peru a loan of $425 million. A special Japanese fund that is administered by the bank added $4 million more.
Mr. Fujimori, a former college rector with no previous political experience, impressed the legislators as well as business people and diplomats he addressed at a luncheon of the Americas Society in New York "with his sincerity and willingness to deal with problems that concern us," a senior congressional aide said.
"He represents a real balance between the legitimate interests of the United States and his own people," Mr. Torrecelli said.
Part of Mr. Fujimori's appeal to Americans is his contrast to his predecessor, Alan Garcia, who often attacked the United States, led a rebellion in Latin America against payment of foreign debt and largely ignored Peru's prominence in the supply chain for cocaine.
Mr. Fujimori said he believed that his best chance of success against cocaine production lay in a total reorganization of Peru's economic structure, which, among other things, would give the country's coca growers land titles, access to credit and means of getting alternative crops to market.
After a meeting at the White House, President Bush said Mr. Fujimori had "made progress" on human rights.
Juan Mendez, the executive director of Americas Watch, a human rights group that monitors Peru, said Mr. Fujimori had outlined "a policy that is to be implemented in the future, and some elements are very postive." He added, "But this doesn't by itself constitute progress right now."
Representative Charles B. Rangel, the New York Democrat who heads the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, said he expected the aid package to be approved shortly, adding, "It is imperative that we go forward because we are asking Peru to do a lot, and we need to follow through on our commitment."

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Question on Jobless Bill: Can It Survive a Veto?

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
Sometime in the next week or so, Congress will almost certainly send President Bush a Democratic bill that would spend about $6 billion to help 3 million people who have been out of work for at least half a year.
Before then, Republicans will denounce the bill as a "budget buster," as President Bush did in killing a similar measure last month. They will say, as Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said Friday that the Democrats are more interested in an issue than in helping the unemployed with as many as 20 more weeks of jobless benefits. 
 The Democrats will say that opposition to this bill shows that Republicans care more about Kurds or Bangladeshis, for whom Mr. Bush has approved deficit-busting spending, than about Americans.
The issue will probably come down to whether Congress can override a Bush veto for the first time. The votes seem to be there in the House. In the Senate, Mr. Dole predicts that Mr. Bush can be upheld. But he is supposed to say that, and the question will be just how many Republicans facing re-election in suffering states vote to override.
If Mr. Dole is wrong, the long-term jobless will get the benefits. If he is correct, the Democrats will have an issue. Indeed, one lawmaker deeply involved with the bill said he hoped Mr. Bush signed it so the unemployed would be sure to get the money, but if that did not happen, "I wouldn't mind having the issue."
This partisan tangle raises several questions about the way Congress and the White House do business.
The Republicans raise one of them: If this is an "emergency," as the Democrats insist, why did they wait to force the issue until more than a year after the recession began?
Republicans criticize the Democrats for waiting this long, and Richard G. Darman, Mr. Bush's budget director, insists the extra benefits are unnecessary because the recession is over. Put forth by the Republicans, that is just a debating point; they would have opposed the bill with as much energy in April as now.
In late April, House Democrats were ready to try to pass a bill, even if it let Republicans label them as big spenders. But so tentative was their commitment that when the April unemployment totals dipped, they backed off --although the decline was recognized as a statistical quirk and although some 300,000 people a month continued to exhaust their benefits.
That fear of a "tax and spend" label caused most Democrats' refusal, last week, to vote to offer Mr. Bush a choice between a higher deficit now or higher employers' taxes in 1993.
Democrats did bring the issue to the floor in mid-summer, fearing to look especially foolish if they went on vacation without doing anything. But they sent Mr. Bush a bill he killed with minimum risk, because he could sign it to assert his sympathy for the jobless and then refuse to declare the emergency required to increase the deficit under the 1990 budget act. That declaration was required to release the money. The same approach is in the Senate bill this time, but it is expected to be dropped in conference with the House, so that Mr. Bush would be sent a bill that specifically waives the budget act and which he must sign or veto.
An equally serious question is why neither side is trying to reach a compromise. Mr. Dole, who thinks being against the unemployed is bad politics, has an alternative -- a bill that would help fewer jobless for shorter periods of time. It would cost much less, and it would be paid for, not by raising the deficit, but by auctioning off unused radio frequencies and tightening student loan repayments. Mr. Bush said today that he wanted the Dole bill. But there are too many Democrats for it to have a chance.
Yet if both sides wanted to, they could cut a deal. For the Democrats, dealing now would impose two high costs. One would be that they would give up their best chance yet of overriding a Bush veto. And the consequence would be giving the unemployed less than they have promised.
For the Republicans and Mr. Bush, dealing now might invite other attempts to bypass the budget agreement for domestic spending. For the President, even the Dole bill is a step away from insisting that there was no real economic problem out there.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Meet With Major Health Insurers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23

 BODY:
The Bush Administration announced today that it would bring together major insurers for a meeting to find ways to reduce administrative costs in the nation's health care system.
But Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said that while some savings could be achieved by streamlining administrative costs, recent studies showing large savings were unrealistic. 
 Some studies have shown administrative costs account for at least 20 percent of the more than $600 billion spent annually in the United States on health care.
"We think these studies are flawed and that the public is being misled," Dr. Sullivan said in a speech at a health care conference. "Nevertheless, we do believe an examination of administrative burdens is long overdue."
 
Bush to Get Recommendations
 The Secretary, who said the meeting would be held "in the next month or so," has been conducting a study of the problems in the nation's health care system and is to recommend to President Bush changes to improve access to care and to reduce the costs of medical care.
He has proposed no major changes. He has said he favors continuing the current system, which includes public and private insurance coverage.
In his speech today Dr. Sullivan criticized the "play-or-pay" approach supported by many Democrats in which employers would be required to provide health coverage for their workers or pay to support a public program. He also repeated his opposition to a centrally run national health care system.
He said these proposals would accelerate health care inflation, hinder competition and innovation and would lead to rationing and waiting lists for care. Instead, the Secretary said, the most practical options include making health insurance more affordable for small businesses and increasing the use of managed care.
Dr. Sullivan's remarks were criticized by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia and chairman of a commission named for former Representative Claude Pepper of Florida, which has recommended broad changes in health care, including a national insurance system.
"Unfortunately, the Secretary's speech indicates that Administration officials have done little more than read the Pepper Commission's table of contents and pull out a few isolated ideas -- outcomes research, managed care and an expanded National Health Service Corps," Mr. Rockefeller said. "Had they read further, they would understand that to give Americans the kind of health care they want and deserve, we must implement all the interdependent ideas in the Pepper plan."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Outlines Fiscal Blueprint For Recovery of New York City

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo drew an ambitious blueprint for New York City's fiscal recovery yesterday, outlining an array of high-visibility public works projects aimed at creating tens of thousands of jobs, improving the city's long-term competitiveness and, perhaps most importantly, lifting morale.
In a speech delivered to business and civic leaders in Manhattan last night, Mr. Cuomo said his plan to build mass-transit links to the city's airports, accelerate the construction of huge housing developments and explore the potential for high-speed water ferries on the city's rivers would "help rebuild the city from the ground up, putting people to work and pumping blood into our economy."
 
Easing the Medicaid Strain
 The Governor also announced his proposal for easing the strain placed by rapidly growing Medicaid costs on the budgets of New York City and other local governments. Under his plan, which was first reported on Sunday, the state would assume the local share of Medicaid costs while taking some of the taxing authority now held by the city and county governments. 
 Whether the third-term Governor is being driven most by a desire to secure his place in New York history or by the need to preserve his national reputation, he clearly has decided to become more of a protagonist in the city's fiscal drama. It is a high-risk strategy, for as Mr. Cuomo becomes more closely associated with the struggle for fiscal recovery, his political future will increasingly be linked to its success or failure.
Elements of Mr. Cuomo's public works blueprint were brand new, while others were resurrections of dormant projects or accelerations of work already in motion. Because many of his proposals would require approval by the Legislature or by state authorities, their success is not guaranteed.
But the Governor suggested that it was vital to create the perception, both inside and outside the city, that momentum was being generated.
"Every hour we spend on this is time we don't have to spend being defensive," he told an audience of about 80 people, including Mayor David N. Dinkins, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller. "The psychology of it is very important. We haven't had a whole lot of things to grab hold of."
Unlike the city's last fiscal crisis in 1975, Mr. Cuomo said, the city's current plight must give birth to a more lasting recovery. He also said the city and the state must seek a more activist approach to ending the recession than the Federal Government. "While Washington chooses to offer up prayers to the cyclical god of the economy, which appears to be all they're doing, we must choose to act," he said.
Those listening to Mr. Cuomo seemed to embrace his speech warmly. "This is a statement to people who say New York has no future that New York City has a grand and glorious future," Mr. Dinkins said.
 
A High-Tech Slide Show
 Mr. Cuomo unveiled his plans at a dinner sponsored by the New York City Partnership on the 50th floor of the Equitable Life Assurance headquarters in midtown. Against the backdrop of tall arched windows that presented a stunning view of the city skyline, he spoke for about an hour and illustrated his plan with a high-tech slide show.
The dinner was closed to the press, but Mr. Cuomo's office released a copy of his text. He is to repeat the presentation at a breakfast meeting today.
The public and private cost of the projects he outlined would total $7 billion, according to the Governor's office, but the state's actual investment would be only a fraction of that amount. The Governor said the projects would create 54,000 construction jobs and 25,000 permanent jobs and would generate an estimated $8.2 billion in economic activity by the turn of the century.
While the prospect of 54,000 new construction jobs sounds enticing on its face, many of those jobs would most likely be filled by people who had previously lost jobs. As of August, the city's construction industry employed about 100,000 people. But that was 13,000 fewer than one year earlier, and without new spending, analysts had been expecting the industry to lose 10,000 to 15,000 more in 1992.
So as much as half of that 54,000 could be replacement jobs, rather than new jobs added to the economy. Still, economists figure that with the $40,000 to $50,000 in average income that would come to those 54,000 people, their spending would, in turn, generate another 27,000 jobs.
Among the public works projects proposed by Mr. Cuomo were these:
*The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey would spend $1.6 billion to build automated people movers, a form of light rail, to connect the airports with mass-transit stations in Queens. They would travel above ground in the medians of the Van Wyck Expressway and Grand Central Parkway, linking La Guardia Airport to the Sunnyside subway station and Kennedy International Airport to the Long Island Rail Road's Jamaica station. The money would be generated by a new $3 fee imposed on passengers departing from the city's airports.
*As part of a five-year, $10 billion capital plan proposed by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, new money would be dedicated to renovation of Grand Central and Pennsylvania stations. In addition, the authority would begin construction on a subway line that would link the Queens Boulevard line to the 63d Street line.
*Design work would start anew for a Second Avenue subway line on Manhattan's East Side, which was started and abandoned more than 20 years ago, and the possibility of a new East River transit crossing between Manhattan and the Bronx would be explored.
*Money from the state and Port Authority would rejuvenate construction of a 1.8-mile freight rail connector at Oak Point in the Bronx. It would enable modern freight cars to roll from the Bronx through Queens to Long Island.
*A new subsidiary of the state's Urban Development Corporation would be formed to generate financing for a huge development of housing, office buildings and commercial space at Hunters Point in Queens. The project would be similar in scope and structure to the successful Battery Park City project in lower Manhattan.
*State funds would be used to study the feasibility of moving an 18-block stretch of the West Side Highway inland in an effort to "jump start" the Riverside South development.
Mr. Cuomo's also suggested how the city should use up to $1 billion that may be generated from a proposed refinancing of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds. Mr. Cuomo said some of the money should be used to create a tax stabilization reserve fund to help the city in times of fiscal emergencies.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has presented a $7 billion blueprint for New York City's fiscal recovery. Mr. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins arrived last night for a meeting in Manhattan. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Crack Hits Chicago, Along With a Wave of Killing

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 23

 BODY:
For most of the 1980's, street gangs kept crack out of Chicago, fearing that it could open the way for small dealers to challenge their control of the drug trade. Now crack has arrived and those same gangs are warring over territory.
With the eruption of the same kind of turf wars that marked the arrival of crack in Washington and elsewhere, 1991 is shaping into the deadliest year in Chicago history, surpassing the rate during the bloody years of the Al Capone era and even the record year of 1974, when 970 residents were killed. 
 By the end of August, Chicago had recorded 623 murders, as against 593 by that date in 1974. The city declared last month the deadliest ever with 120 killings, more than the previous record of 117 in November 1974. As of today, the 1991 toll is 686.
"It's out of control," said Frances Sandoval, president of the Chicago chapter of Mothers Against Gangs, a support and advocacy group. "People are in agony. People are being held hostage in their own neighborhoods. One mother said to me: 'What do we have to do? Do we have to get on our knees to stop this?' "
The problem has pitted alderman against alderman and community leaders against the police superintendent. It has touched off neighborhood marches and candlelight vigils and even prompted Mayor Richard M. Daley, out of frustration after a security guard was killed in sniper fire at a public housing project last month, to liken Chicago to Colombia.
"It's becoming much more violent," Mayor Daley told reporters recently. "It's becoming like Colombia. That's what it is."
The Mayor has also gotten political heat over the killings, partly because of his unfulfilled campaign promise last spring to hire 600 police officers.
 
South Side Hit Hard
 Unlike drug distribution networks in New York, Washington and other cities with fairly diffuse trafficking systems, the network in Chicago has traditionally been tightly run by a group of major street gangs who enjoyed a longstanding monopoly on drug sales and were not inclined to introduce or -- allow anyone else to introduce -- a volatile new product they could not easily control, criminologists say.
"Everybody had their share of the market and there was just not room for entrepreneurs to get in like in New York," said Dr. Jeffrey Fagan, an associate professor of criminal justice at Rutgers University, who has studied the evolution of crack in this country. "Distributors acted like every other business and kept out the product. The fear in Chicago was that once the taste got out, it would be extremely difficult to control."
The pact between street gangs, whether formal or tacit, made it more difficult for small-time outsiders to infiltrate the market with crack, a drug that lends itself to independent sales because customers make more frequent purchases of smaller amounts than they do with other drugs. But the agreement did not keep it out for good. No one is certain who was the first to bring crack into Chicago, but now that it has arrived, distributors large and small are angling for their slice.
 
'More Active Market'
 "What this did was create a more active market," said Ronald Allen, a professor of law at Northwestern University. "There is more money changing hands. Dealers want to get in on the market and want to get a bigger share of the market. But rather than cutting prices and putting out a better product, they kill each other."
The violence is taking its greatest toll on the South Side community of Englewood, a jumble of worn two-family apartment buildings and burned out apartment buildings, where 71 people have been killed so far this year, higher than the annual murder toll in many American cities.
There, 40 percent of all homicides are tied to drugs or gangs and the percentage of drug arrests at which crack is confiscated has gone from zero to 70 percent in two years, said Comdr. Ron Watson of the city's Seventh District.
The city deployed 100 additional police officers to Englewood over the summer, and it seems even now that every other car on Halsted or Racine Avenues is a police cruiser. The police have made 3,000 arrests since early August and confiscated 379 guns. Still, residents say they are afraid to go out after dusk or dawdle on street corners.
"No way, shape or form do I go out at night," said Andrew Allen, a retired postal worker and longtime resident. "It's the worst I've ever seen it. Just going out at night to get something, I can't tell you when I last did that. If I ain't got it by nightfall, I don't get it."
Residents who had only read about crack or watched movies about it are now living the nightmare themselves. They are adjusting to sight of discarded crack vials and ominous gatherings of drug buyers and sellers on street corners.
"We're at the zenith of this murder situation," said Cecil Davis, who coordinates citizen patrols in Englewood. "People are worried about who's next and 'How close is it going to be to me?' "
People have become so afraid that it has become difficult to get them to report what they see.
James O. Stampley, executive director of the Englewood Economic Development Corporation, a local civic group, said he and others had watched helplessly as more and more fellow residents were robbed on buses or otherwise victimized by the violence.
"We were afraid to open our mouths," Mr. Stampley said. "You're dumbfounded. You're numb."
At the core of much of the violence is the new and expanding market for the highly addictive drug here and and the turf wars it has set off, community leaders and several ranking members of the Police Department said.
The headlines and handwringing have produced a minor political crisis for Mayor Daley, who promised to hire 600 police officers during his election campaign last spring. But the officers have not yet materialized, the mayor's office has said, because of delays created by a change in the entrance examination for police recruits. Still, aldermen whose wards have been hardest hit are blaming the Mayor for inaction.
The Mayor has deflected such criticism by saying that the real problem is the failure courts to put criminals away and the failure of the Federal Government to stop drugs from entering the country in the first place.
The Mayor is promising new police officers by November. But LeRoy Martin, the police superintendent who has been the focus of the most vehement criticism in the crisis, has said that with the proliferation of guns and a gang culture, that new police recruits may not be enough.
"You can give me 2,000 police officers," he said at a City Council hearing last week, "and you can see them walking and talking. But until you start addressing the root causes, we'll be living with this high crime."

HEADLINE: Cosmetic Surgeons Seek New Frontiers

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
To camouflage her skinny calves, the 30-year-old film producer from southern California always wore long skirts and "felt like a freak" when she played tennis or ran. For years, she lifted weights to improve the contour of her legs, to no avail.
"Doctors told me it's just the way your muscle is formed," she said in a recent telephone interview. "But I was always self-conscious. I thought someday they're going to develop some way to help this." 
 A year ago, someday arrived.
At a Beverly Hills Clinic, a plastic surgeon made a tiny incision behind each of her knees and slipped silicone implants into her calves. "My mother said, 'Oh God, do you have to do it?' " the woman said. "But it's great. I've been really pleased."
Welcome to the frontiers of cosmetic surgery. To achieve the ideal form, a growing number of patients are undergoing implants to enlarge their calves, chests and even buttocks; they have liposuction to siphon fat from their cheeks or necks, and they get lips plumped up with tissue borrowed from their own scars.
Although face lifts were once the province of older women, cosmetic surgeons say there has been a huge increase in patients from 35 to 45. "Ten years ago, surgeons used to think it was frivolous to operate on people under 50," said Dr. Ronald Iverson, chairman of the public information committee of the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons. "Part of the change has been induced by better results, but mainly it's what people want."
Men, too, are demanding equal time, seeking younger faces, bigger chests and "correction" of cleft chins. One plastic surgeon tells of a man who, envious of a spouse's breast augmentation, demanded a new set of pectorals to keep pace. Next month's edition of the series Clinics of Plastic Surgery is devoted to cosmetic surgery for men, and Dr. Brian Novack, a plastic surgeon in Beverly Hills who estimates that 65 percent of his patients are male, predicts that half of all patients will someday be men; the current figure is slightly over 10 percent.
"It's a big change to see good-looking guys in their 40's asking for face lifts," said Dr. Fritz E. Barton, a professor of plastic surgery at the University of Texas Southwest Medical Center in Dallas. "We are seeing more men, but we are also seeing more people. There used to be a stigma, but now it's just considered another method of being productive longer in life."
Although the trend is consistent all across the country, the epicenter is, of course, southern California. "It's a combination of people who are very body-conscious and a group of very interesting and innovative surgeons, and they feed off each other," said Dr. Norman Cole, the president of the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons. "Some of them are plowing new ground."
While some of the techniques, like facial liposuction, are now widely offered by plastic surgeons, others, like pectoral implants, are regarded by many with a snicker, and surgeons worry that patients seeking what are permanent changes may be overly influenced by current fashion.
"I don't pretend to understand southern Californians, but I do understand competition among plastic surgeons when there are so many plastic surgeons per square mile," said an East Coast doctor who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Patients sometimes travel to California to take advantage of the local expertise. They say the pain of surgery and its cost -- up to $5,000 for a pair of calves, rarely covered by insurance -- are well worthwhile.
But those who are less body-conscious may have a hard time believing that skinny legs can ruin a life or that women still having children should be contemplating face lifts.
The motivations of patients who seek out these most cosmetic of cosmetic operations are diverse.
 
Pressure on the Job Front
 Surgeons say that the typical implant patient is young and extremely athletic but has been unable to achieve an ideal body contour through weight lifting. In fact, pectoral implants tend to produce better results if the patient continues to exercise, since the implant sits deep under the skin and the patient's own muscle provides the skin texture.
For men and women seeking face lifts at 40, the motivation is often to look and feel a bit younger in a society that has put an increasing premium on youth. And so cosmetic surgery has flourished in the midst of a major recession.
"In a tight job market people see a face lift as an investment in their competitiveness for jobs," said Dr. Barton.
"For many people it's just another way to spend discretionary income," Dr. Iverson said. "That's unfortunate in some ways since it is surgery, with pain and potential complications."
Even among plastic surgeons, the growing popularity of implants has been a source of some concern.
Many of the implant procedures first achieved popularity in the body-building gyms of southern California in the middle of the last decade but have moved into the general population in the last two years, said Dr. Adrien Aiache, a Los Angeles surgeon who has pioneered calf implants.
In these operations, carefully sculpted solid silicone pieces are inserted under skin and sometimes muscle to enhance normally curvaceous portions of the body. Implants made of the same material have been used successfully for decades to restructure chins and are thought to be far safer than liquid silicone breast implants, which have recently come under scrutiny by the Food and Drug Administration because they can cause deforming scars and serious allergic reactions.
 
Severe Pain at First
 More than 100 buttock and pectoral implants were performed by members of the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons in 1990, the first year the society kept tallies, and close to 300 calf implants were performed. Many surgeons predict that the number will rise dramatically once more patients learn about the procedures.
The incisions are generally inconspicuous, hidden in the armpit for pectoral implants and in the crease behind the knee for calf surgery. Although some patients experience severe pain for weeks, particularly those with calf implants, once the tissue heals they say they are not aware that the implant is in place.
Patients generally work with their surgeon before the operation to express their preferences about the size and shape of a reconstructed body part, hopes that the surgeons find they frequently dash.
"Like a typical male, I wanted the biggest size," said a 49-year-old insurance executive from Pennsylvania who had calf implants two months ago. "The ones he put in were two sizes smaller. They look natural and are a much better balance with the top of my leg."
With pectoral implants, "if a person has small shoulders and arms and you build them up too much they just look silly," said Dr. Novack, who said that patients bring in surfing magazines and Calvin Klein ads. "And the implant has to fit under their normal chest muscle."
Dr. Iverson said that there was "no reason to think that these implants were not safe and effective," but noted that they had not been used for very long and that surgeons could not predict for certain how they would wear for 50 years under the skin of a 20-year-old.
 
Buttocks Data Lacking
 Some plastic surgeons are particularly worried about the calf and buttock implants, since -- unlike chins -- these areas of the body are constantly in motion with large powerful muscles sliding by. The doctors worry that movement and gravity could cause the implants to travel under the skin over time. And then, people sit on buttocks all day long, and no one knows how the implants, which provide no additional cushioning, will wear over time.
Other surgeons say that the lower leg is frequently plagued by poor circulation as the body ages, which they fear may make calf implants an ideal breeding ground for serious infections.
"I'm interested, but these haven't been used long enough by a credible number of people to know their long-term effects," said Dr. Cole. "If my son or daughter wanted them, I'd say push hard with exercise."
But, he added, it still might be a reasonable procedure if "they had done toe curls until they were blue in the face" and it hadn't helped. "If they were still self-conscious and understood that the procedure might fail and even potentially lead to scarring, then I'd say go ahead," he said.
The push to do cosmetic surgery on younger faces has met with far wider acceptance. By the age of 35, plastic surgeons say, many a face has started to sag and could benefit from some restructuring.
Face lifts on the young generally focus on different areas and involve somewhat different techniques from those performed on older people. Most faces show signs of age first around the cheeks and eyes and only later around the mouth and neck.
In the traditional face lift, loose skin is drawn back at the hairline and removed. But in the 35-to-50 crowd, surgeons more commonly beef up or otherwise meddle with the underlying bone or fat and let the skin settle back on its new frame.
 
'People Do Look Refreshed'
 They say that liposuction of fat necks or puffy cheeks creates a more tailored and rested appearance and that the placement of implants under the skin to enhance cheek bones or chins can make these relatively young patients appear even more youthful.
"We see a lot more people coming in now with minimal deformities, a subtle fullness around the jaw line rather than a real turkey gobbler," Dr. Iverson said. "It's not the dramatic change in the over-50 group, but people do look refreshed. And we believe that if you tighten the skin up early you look better than you would otherwise forever."
As testament to this wisdom, Dr. Cole noted that most plastic surgeons' wives are now having their face lifts in their early 40's.
Some surgeons have tried to perform minimalist operations for patients showing the first signs of age, filling out gaunt cheeks hollowed by age with crescent-shaped implants inserted through the mouth at the upper line of the gums. The procedure takes 45 minutes under local anesthesia and costs about a quarter as much as a typical $5,000 face lift.
Dr. Geoffrey W. Tobias, a head and neck surgeon at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, thinks of the 45-minute procedure as a "missing link in facial surgery for people who want a more youthful look, but are not ready for a real face lift."
But others are wary of this approach. "I'm not sure I'd call it experimental, but we don't have any long-term follow up," Dr. Iverson said.
As the age of plastic surgery patients creeps downward for this and other operations, many surgeons stress that there are limits. Although about 1,000 women under the age of 18 had breast implants or liposuction in 1990, the American Society for Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons has recommended against both procedures for teen-agers.
 
The Forgotten Cary Grant
 Their adult body-fat distribution has not been established, and some women have breast development into their early 20's, Dr. Iverson said. Also, he said, because of the possible risks associated with breast implants, "we really need an adult to make an informed decision."
Experts urge patients eager to improve on an imperfect body part to avoid succumbing to fads or fashion. Patients are now calling on plastic surgeons to "correct" thin lips for women and cleft chins for men, having apparently forgotten Myrna Loy and Cary Grant.
Recently, doctors have devised numerous methods to plump up narrow mouths, most of which produce, at best, transient success. Lips injected with collagen tend to revert to their past form over time, and the substance is now under scrutiny by the Food and Drug Administration because of other undesirable side effects.
Recently, Dr. Linton Whitaker, the chief of plastic surgery at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, has reported better staying power in a small group of patients whom he treated by tunneling strips of tissue, borrowed from scars or the buttock, under the lip. He has had one patient return three times for surgery, each time wanting more pout.
"It's hard for me to believe that she's going to want those full lips when she's 70, but if people understand that this is for keeps I'll do it," Dr. Whitaker said, reflecting that 15 years ago he far more commonly treated women who wanted their lips reduced.
Patients who feel they are lacking in certain body parts must often wait until surgeons catch up with their desires. Dr. Harold M. Reed, a urologist from Bar Harbor Island, Fla., has for several years performed an operation to extend the length of the penis by about an inch; he cuts a ligament that in some men constrains the organ from attaining its full potential length. Each week he receives four or five inquiries about the operation. Some things never go out of style.

HEADLINE: ON HORSE RACING;
All the Stars Come Tumbling Down

BYLINE: By Joseph Durso

 BODY:
What odds would you give that Meadow Star, who won the Eclipse Award last year as the country's best juvenile filly, would run sixth in a field of seven on Saturday? Or that Lite Light, who outran Meadow Star by seven lengths in July, would run sixth in a field of seven on Sunday?
The two fillies took their artistic tumbles 1,500 miles apart, Meadow Star falling from grace in the $200,000 Ruffian Handicap at Belmont Park and Lite Light taking the plunge in the $1 million Super Derby at Louisiana Downs. 
 Remember: They were the prima donnas among fillies, the superstars, the ranking contenders for this year's championship. But now Meadow Star is a fallen star who has lost 4 of her last 6 races; Lite Light has lost her last two starts and hasn't even come close.
Nobody is trying to line them up for a match race anymore, and you wonder if anybody can win the Breeders' Cup championships in six weeks.
They are not alone, either. Strike the Gold, who won the Kentucky Derby, has lost five in a row since then. Hansel, who won the Preakness and the Belmont, lost his next two and then was retired with a torn ligament in the leg. Mane Minister, who ran third in all three races in the Triple Crown, has run once since then. And Best Pal, second in the Santa Anita Derby, second in the Kentucky Derby and first in the $1 million Pacific Classic, ran fourth in the Super Derby just when racing people were figuring that he looked like the main survivor among this year's star-crossed class of 3-year-old horses.
Other horses in other seasons have fallen by the wayside. But this year's bunch looks like horses on a merry-go-round, nobody going anywhere in particular, everybody going in circles. They are asked to make the big move into the homestretch, but they don't fire.
Things are this freakish: In the Super Derby the other day, Best Pal and Lite Light, two of the marquee stars of racing, ranking contenders for the 3-year-old championships, finished out of the money while a million-dollar race was won by a 28-to-1 longshot, a largely unknown Louisiana-bred colt named Free Spirits Joy.
"When I asked my horse to move," said Pat Valenzuela, the rider aboard Best Pal, "he moved up to them. But he couldn't get them in the last eighth of a mile."
"I asked her to run," said Corey Nakatani, the rider aboard Lite Light. "But she got tired. I got no response at the head of the lane."
John Veitch, the trainer of Alydar and other champions, sat in his box seat at Belmont Park yesterday afternoon and fielded the question: Why are they demolishing one another this year?
"This is probably an ordinary bunch of horses, that's No. 1," he said, skipping the diplomacy. "They can't cope with the pressures that all race horses feel as the year goes by: time, fatigue, injury, competition, whatever. Extraordinary horses face the same challenges, but surmount them. Forego, Kelso, Secretariat, Alydar.
"It's also more dramatic these days than in the past because of public perceptions. The Breeders' Cup, for one thing, creates stars late in the year. Then we try to extend them into the following year at the same level. They're almost famous before their time.
"After that, we try to keep them going for the next Breeders' Cup. So, we keep them in training longer and harder to get there. And we do that because of the prizes and the prestige. We try to keep a horse together when ordinarily we might have let him taper off the season earlier."
"Another thing," John Veitch said, "some horses are better at 2, with the shorter distances and shorter season. But at 3, they may get caught up in pressures of the Triple Crown, and they can't handle it."
John Frato, a pedigree consultant to some of the leading stables in the country, sat a few feet away from Veitch and agreed that both the perceptions and the demands of racing were putting more strain on the stars of racing.
"The business is ever-demanding, in terms of the economics," he said. "Purses keep increasing, so you keep a horse in training longer in the year. There is no doubt we are putting more demand on our horses. And maybe even the good ones can respond with one or two ultimate efforts before showing the strain."
He was reminded that Meadow Star had won her first nine races, so she must have been doing something right.
"Yes," he replied, "she was better than her contemporaries last year. But she really didn't beat anybody of significance during that streak."
"Speed is misunderstood," Frato said, marveling at the strange season of 1991 at the race track. "People were saying earlier this year that Meadow Star ran as fast as she had to. That's nonsense. She probably ran as fast as she could."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Assistant trainer John Jenkins with Lite Light, who ran sixth in a field of seven on Sunday in the Super Derby at Louisiana Downs. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)
