HEADLINE: As Biosphere Is Sealed, Its Patron Reflects on Life

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
THE largest private sponsor of environmental research in the United States is not Amoco, the Environmental Defense Fund, Exxon, the MacArthur Foundation, the National Geographic Society, the Nature Conservancy, the New York Botanical Garden or the World Wildlife Fund.
It is Edward P. Bass, 46, maverick son of the multibilliondollar Texas oil family.
His main effort is a $150 million, eight-story, glass-and-steel structure in the Arizona desert that holds a miniature ocean, savanna, marsh, desert and rain forest as well as 3,800 species of plants and animals. On Thursday, four men and four women plan to seal themselves inside Biosphere 2, as it is known, for a two-year experiment in recreating the earth. 
 Mr. Bass's "job," as he put it in an interview last week, involves financing and helping direct a dozen other projects, including a $20 million Institute of Biospheric Studies at Yale, a 20-acre research farm in southern France, a 1,042-acre tropical rain forest preserve in Puerto Rico, a 82-foot ocean research vessel and big ranches in Australia and Texas; his Australian lands comprise nearly 900 square miles. [Excerpts on page C6.]
In a more orthodox vein, he is also on the boards of the World Wildlife Fund, the New York Botanical Garden, the African Wildlife Foundation and the Jane Goodall Institute for Wildlife Research, Education and Conservation.
His own ecological projects are unusual in that many are meant to turn a profit. He calls himself an "ecopreneur." Biosphere 2 has already been visited by thousands of paying tourists, many of whom profess astonishment at its scope and audacity. Some experts have called it the greatest venture since man landed on the moon.
On the other hand, critics like Marc Cooper, writing in the Village Voice, have charged that some of Mr. Bass's projects are inspired by doomsday dogmas and new-age flakiness disguised as science. Scientists like Dr. Arthur W. Galston, a Yale University botanist, and Dr. Charles F. Hutchinson, an ecologist at the University of Arizona, say that at best, Biosphere 2 is a scientific crap shoot.
On the rare occasions Mr. Bass has spoken with reporters, he has vigorously defended his projects as creative endeavors meant to forge a new environmental ethic.
A native of Fort Worth, the second of four sons who are heir to the Bass oil fortune, and a bachelor, Edward Perry Bass went to prep school at the Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., and to college at Yale, where he graduated in 1968 with a degree in administrative sciences. After a stint in the Coast Guard, he studied architecture at Yale, but left before his got his master's degree.
What captured his interest in the early 1970's was New Mexico, with its eclectic mix of art, architecture, off-beat characters and rural splendor. "He designed and built adobe structures, dabbled in pottery, and sold Indian jewelry and handicrafts," reported the Texas Monthly.
He also met an unusual counterculture group at Synergia Ranch, 15 miles south of Santa Fe. It was named in honor of Buckminster Fuller's concept of synergy, where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. The guru of Synergia was John Allen, who encouraged experiments in gardening, theater and Buddhism and preached the virtues of Fuller's view of "spaceship earth."
Born in Oklahoma and raised, as he once put it, "in the lingering traditions of the frontier," Mr. Allen received a B.S. degree from the Colorado School of Mines and a M.B.A. from the Harvard Business School. After managing a uranium-processing plant, his interests turned unconventional. He traveled across North Africa on foot. He founded an acting troupe, the Theater of All Possibilities. In the 1960's in the Haight-Ashbury district of San Francisco, he directed theater and wrote poetry under the name Johnny Dolphin. He studied the teachings of the mystic G.I. Gurdjieff. He preached the imminence of nuclear Armageddon and held that Western civilization had already collapsed. What was needed was a new civilization, he said, based on a more enlightened relationship among man, machine and nature.
In New Mexico, Mr. Bass became a regular visitor to the Synergia ranch and participated in the group's drama workshops. He was struck by Mr. Allen's philosophy and hired Synergia ranch hands to help him build condominiums in central Santa Fe. He became a director of the Institute of Ecotechnics, founded by Mr. Allen and other Synergia veterans to carry out bold ecology projects. Most importantly, he bankrolled their work and began his own along similar lines.
His most ambitious venture to date is Biosphere 2, which got under way in 1984 and is being carried out with extensive aid from Mr. Allen and other veterans of the Synergia ranch.
Some of the discord around it has been stirred by Mr. Allen's vision of biospheres as refuges for a small elite from nuclear war or other disasters. In "The Biosphere Catalogue," a 1985 publication of Mr. Bass's London-based Synergetic Press, Mr. Allen outlined a vision of how "higher forms of life" could survive the destruction of civilization in biospheres he called "Refugia."
"A hundred Refugia protected by their own energy resources in mountain caverns could release full-scale life" back into the Earth environment "after the skies begin to clear," he wrote. "Perhaps even the existence of the Refugia," he added, "could bring home to people and states the gigantic risks they run and thus alter the behavior itself."
Biospheres were also originally seen by the group as a way to form human settlements on Mars and to design a new civilization, although of late Mr. Bass has stressed more of the commercial and educational aspects.
 
Bass on Biosphere 2 and 'Walden Two'
 EDWARD P. BASS, a major patron of environmental causes, discussed his work in a rare interview during a business trip to Manhattan last week.
Q. What is the philosophical basis for your interests?
It's something that has grown from many sources, more or less organically. There are people who I much revere and have helped me. I'm not a scientist myself. I deal with the interface of science and politics and economics and I have great interest in the philosophy of science. E.O. Wilson is a wonderful thinker and I've sought his advice. Tom Lovejoy of the Smithsonian is someone I much admire. Buckminster Fuller has been an influence through his writings. And there's the circle of people I've worked with in Biosphere 2, many of whom I've known for 15 years or more.
Q. Why Biosphere 2?
It's a project that appealed to my interest in science and ecology. I thought it had tremendous potential to develop technologies, know-how, data, and could have great use in environmental matters on all scales, from the fairly small to the planetary. And in a business sense, I saw that these technologies would have a very significant commercial application.
Also, as to the why of Biosphere 2, there was very definitely a decision made to put an architectural element into it, to make it accessible and, if you will, symbolic, so that people could look at Biosphere 2 and gain an understanding of the biosphere, this operating system of the Planet Earth.
Q. Will Biosphere 2 turn a profit?
With the biosphere structure itself and the associated infrastructure, that's a long-term proposition, on the scale of 10 years or more. But as an operating entity, with the investment and apparatus in place, within a couple of years we'll turn a profit because we already have revenues.
Q. From tourists?
The visitors are a very significant part of that. It has been said in an accusatory fashion that this is not science or research, that this is a Disneyland. Well, it certainly is. It's built to attract people, to be accessible to people, to be fun, but also to be educational. And I think that's a very important aspect.
Q. What about news reports that Biosphere 2 is basically a survivalist cult built around the magnetic personality of John Allen, whom The Village Voice characterized as "much more the Jim Jones than the Johnny Appleseed of the ecology movement?"
That's entirely bunkum. I've never found anything to contradict the notion that he is a fine human being. He's an exceptional thinker, an exceptional intellect. He can take a lot of seemingly unrelated phenomena, disparate data, and put it together in meaningful patterns.
Q. At the end of one of his books, he talks about the feasibility of a Biosphere-based colony on Mars whose members conduct their debates under Robert's Rules of Order.
Yes, but that's no more far out than "Walden Two." Actually it has a little bit happier ending.
Q. It's said that the Biosphere 2 people maintain silence while they eat, meditating on the metaphysics of it all. Doesn't that suggest some kind of cultism?
There was a NASA cult that got us to the Moon in the 60's. If what's at work is mindless conformity, manipulation and so forth, that would be frightening, that would be shocking. But as far as dedication to a project, discipline, hard work and so forth, I would say NASA's effort that got us on the Moon and Biosphere 2 have a lot in common.
Q. Should Mars be colonized?
It's an interesting concept. It's certainly a potential enterprise for the next century. It's not something I occupy myself with greatly today. How you would apply a concept of closed biospheric system to Mars is yet to be worked out. You would not build something that necessarily looked that much like Biosphere 2. You would not transport steel and glass ad infinitum to build something there. But as far as the utilization of biological systems to produce food and continually recycle your material resources, yes, that makes sense.
Leonardo da Vinci talked about flying machines. Centuries later the Wright brothers built one. Biosphere 2 may prove to be the Kitty Hawk of biospheric life-support systems. Then again it may prove to be one of those airplanes everybody sees in the movies and laughs at that had 16 wings flapping at the same time.

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Can the Brain Provide Clues to Intelligence?

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
THE inner sanctum of the K.G.B. seems an extraordinary place for a brain laboratory to elucidate the structure of great minds.
But, according to the CBS News magazine "60 Minutes," Russian scientists, watched carefully by the Soviet secret police, peered through microscopes for decades to scrutinize tens of thousands of slides made from scores of brains, including those of Lenin, Stalin and other prominent Communists. 
 The search for biological and physical correlates of intellect has taken many strange turns, like phrenologists' attempts to relate the bumps on the head to mental abilities. But more sophisticated methods are now available for analyzing the brain and may one day produce some jewel of discovery from this muddy arena.
The K.G.B. effort was probably as misdirected as phrenology and many other earlier studies conducted in the United States and elsewhere. Saving neurons from smart Russians may have been as futile a scientific effort as Communism was an economic policy, American experts say. They note that if the Russians found anything of significance, not a word has been communicated in any standard scientific journal. It is not known whether Western scientists will be allowed to examine the brain specimens or whether an invitation, if extended, would be worthwhile to accept. American experts say that if the K.G.B. did not use modern techniques to preserve the brains within an hour or so after death, little could be learned.
Many experts dismiss as pseudoscience the task of examining brains for evidence of genius and mental prowess, largely in the belief that even experts do not know where and what to look for in the three-pound organ. Indeed, experts say no study similar to the K.G.B.'s is on the drawing boards in this country.
However, a growing number of Americans are leaving their brains to science in Federally financed tissue banks devoted to the study of nervous system disorders, particularly those with suspected hereditary links.
And a few scientists believe they are on the brink of finding clues to the most fundamental questions of human intelligence.
"We are just coming into the time when we can begin the studies to try to tell what it is about the ability and talents of the way certain people used their brain tissue when they were alive," said Dr. Arnold B. Scheibel, director of the brain research institute at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Not that scientists plan to ask former Presidents of the United States for permission to examine their brains after death, although Dr. Scheibel's team, including his wife, Dr. Marian C. Diamond, has examined a tiny portion of Einstein's brain. In that study, Dr. Scheibel's team found a significantly larger number of certain cells, called oligodendroglia, than was found in the brains of 11 less gifted individuals that were used as scientific controls.
"The findings said nothing about causality or whether Einstein was born with his magnificent use of his brain," or whether the cells increased in response to the way he thought, Dr. Scheibel said in an interview.
Studying the brains of geniuses and gifted people has not received much scientific attention, but attitudes are changing, and Dr. Scheibel said that up to a few dozen scientists are exploring ways to do such research, though they have not held a formal meeting.
Techniques for studying the most fundamental aspects of the cell and genetics are rapidly advancing. Scientists hope that someday they will be able to develop them to probe for anatomical and biochemical correlates of gifted minds and various kinds of intelligence.
The difficulty of the task cannot be overestimated. Even the most optimistic among such scientists say they are not even close to separating the interplay of genetic and environmental factors on the maturation of the brain.
In a broader context, they point to a widely publicized recent report about previously undetected anatomical differences between the brains of homosexual and heterosexual men.
Dr. Simon LeVay at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, Calif., reported that one of four groups of nerve cells in the hypothalamus was smaller in gay men than in the brains of heterosexual men. But the controversial finding has not been confirmed in larger studies, and Dr. LeVay's team has not determined whether the finding is one of cause or effect.
Cerebral exercise apparently can improve an animal's intellectual capacity, according to earlier studies at the University of California at Berkeley by Dr. Diamond. Although animal studies can yield some clues about intelligence, the human brain is the most meaningful model. Yet many concepts about evaluating human intelligence are vague. For example, what is intelligence and how is it measured?
Earlier studies have tried to correlate human intelligence with overall brain size, the number of convolutions and subdivisions and other crude measurements.
But many such studies have been discredited because the investigators started off with a preconceived notion and then found what they sought. The results were often confusing, and sometimes dangerous when they fed erroneous beliefs of racial superiority.
Still other findings were never confirmed, in part because the nature of the question asked was too complex and the studies too crude to provide meaningful answers.
Scientists have learned that overall brain size is critical to intelligence, but only up to a minimal point, arbitrarily 800 to 900 grams.
Great variation in brain size did not appear to affect the literary abilities of two famous novelists, Jonathan Swift and Anatole France. Neuroscientists frequently cite figures of 1,000 grams for France's and 2,000 for Swift's, Dr. Scheibel said.
Recognizing the remote possibility of solving the riddle of human intelligence simply by looking at brains, scientists suspect that answers are more likely to be found by using the microscope and other techniques.
CAT scans, magnetic resonance and other recently developed imaging techniques allow examination of the living brain in greater detail than ever before. Such studies can be used to screen for certain large abnormalities and findings. But they cannot provide the fine anatomical and cellular detail that can come only after chemicals are applied to brain tissue so the stains can highlight microscopic and immunologic features.
Studying human brains for clues to intelligence and genius will require long-term cooperation from gifted individuals and their families. Among the needs would be good documentation of I.Q. and other mental status exams throughout life. A complete set of medical records would also be needed to exclude damage that could be produced by disease late in life, said Dr. Edward D. Bird, a neuroscientist who heads the brain bank at McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass. Tissue from the bank for the study of nerve disorders is not being used for studies of human intelligence, but could be by qualified investigators, Dr. Bird said.
Microscopic studies can usually be done only after death. The detail that can be obtained is critically dependent on how soon after death the brain is preserved. The technique is also critically important because the standard fixative, formalin, destroys proteins in the brain.
The techniques vary. At McLean, Dr. Bird divides the brain; one half is studied with standard techniques to confirm a diagnosis, and the other half is frozen for research studies.
At the Wadsworth Veterans Adminstration Hospital, Dr. Wallace Tourtellotte quick freezes the entire brain and stores it in liquid nitrogen.
But even when brains are properly preserved, experts recognize that they still have a long way to go before understanding enough about brain function to ask the really searching questions.
If they count cells, which cells? If they weigh specific areas of the brain, which ones?
Nevertheless, they are guided by a long history of research experience that has shown that scientists who look long and hard at microscopic slides from a wide enough selection often detect new and important patterns. The first attempts are often crude and the moment of recognition often comes unexpectedly. But those can be the moments that create new branches of science.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Israel: 'Not for Sale'

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
This is a passage from a personal letter sent to the Prime Minister of Israel by a particularly sophisticated and experienced American supporter of his Government and country:
"If it should develop that the availability of loan guarantees should be conditioned upon a change in the principles you have adopted regarding participation in the proposed international peace conference or upon a change in the settlement policies established by the Government of Israel, I would urge that Israel forgo the loan guarantee instead of compromising your principles. . . . Policies and principles . . . should not be for sale." 
 The letter was written by Kenneth J. Bialkin, president of the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York and former president of the umbrella group of American Jewish organizations. Some other American supporters of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir are telling him or each other much the same thing.
They know the loan guarantees to build homes and jobs for Soviet Jews are enormously important. But they are coming to believe that it would be better for Israel to withdraw the guarantee request to the U.S. until it is free of conditions that could distort the peace process, and the future. Instead Israel would have to look even more to itself and its friends.
It is not the guarantee issue alone that troubles them but what it shows about the Bush Administration's intentions about Israel. In Israel, there is the same concern among centrists in the Shamir Government that Mr. Bush is not only setting the price for guarantees unaffordably high now but that he and the Arabs will keep raising the ante on one issue after another.
Put as bluntly as it should be, more American backers of Israel and officials in Jerusalem believe that if the Bush Administration could have its way, Israel would lose Jerusalem as its capital and would be pushed back to pre-1967 borders. That would make it a tempting target once again, 10 miles wide from the enemy to the sea.
Before the talks even begin, Israel is asked to give up its West Bank settlement plans. Obviously that involves such questions as who should run the West Bank, whether one side or the other, and whether it be shared territorially or administratively.
Important questions -- but until Mr. Bush started his political blitz against Israel, the assumption was that those things were supposed to be what the talks with Palestinians would be all about, not settled in advance.
Also strange: Mr. Bush asks nothing of the Arab states except to sit down and chat. Did the idea never cross his mind that maybe Syria should also agree in advance to land for peace? One way would be to get out of Lebanon, whose colonization by Syria was accepted by Washington with a silence that shouted America's acquiescence.
Now that Mr. Bush has vividly shown his obsession with Jews in the West Bank, the Arabs will make that a theme from the beginning of the talks. They had not intended to do that until he reminded them how important it was.
Despite the booby traps, it is still worthwhile for Israel to talk directly with Arab states and Palestinians. Withdrawal of the request for guarantees might persuade Arab rulers that Israel could not be delivered to them.
But Israel cannot answer the guarantee problem by closing its doors to Soviet Jews and still keep its national purpose. For help it would have to look even more to Jews abroad, and to itself. That would mean more sacrifices for Israeli taxpayers.
Maybe then Israeli politicians would finally be forced to privatize the draining, patronage-fat enterprises run by the Government, a relic of Israel's Socialist days. Government holdings in land should be sold off and every government business put on the market -- chemical companies, transportation and communication giants, all of them. That would bring in about $2 billion at least, and help the economy raise even more.
Israeli politicians are no better than most at brave economic leaps -- and worse than some. But perhaps the President's policy, and his deliberately unpleasant message of delivery, will shock them enough to do what is needed now to protect Israel's security, independence, economy and its dignity, all four.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: ELECTRICITY COSTS DIP UNEXPECTEDLY IN 2 AREAS OF U.S.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Wholesale electric prices rose in the 1970's and were stable in many places in the 1980's. But now, contrary to expectations, they are doing something new: declining in the Northeast and Southwest.
Some reasons for the drop, like lower oil prices and the collapse in the price of natural gas, are temporary and likely to reverse themselves eventually. The sluggish regional economies, which will presumably also reverse at some point, are a factor, too, lowering demand for power and thus leaving high-cost generating stations idle more often than usual. 
 But another factor is probably longer lasting: more efficient use of electricity, spurred in part by utility subsidies for new light bulbs and electric motors. This has cut demand, idling expensive generators.
 
Utility Rates Hold Steady
 Taken together, the crosscurrents running through the power industry mean that electricity supplies, which some analysts had predicted would tighten rapidly and cause prices to rise in the next few years, will shrink more slowly, delaying price increases.
For residential customers, the lines on their monthly bills where utilities adjust rates for changes in fuel costs have shown a small number, or even a negative one. Because the price of wholesale electricity that companies buy from each other is down, utility rates have mostly held steady when they might have been expected to rise.
Whatever the reasons, the balance has shifted. "It's a buyer's market," said Barry Abramson, an analyst at Prudential Securities. "It's good for anyone who is consuming electricity, any utilities that are short of capacity and need to buy."
Another analyst, Mark Luftig of National Economic Research Associates, said: "The cost is certainly down on a real basis. It's not clear how long it's going to last, but it's lasted longer than anyone would have predicted a few years ago."
The effect is clearest in New England.
"New England as a region may be unique in that virtually all the states in the region are aggressively promoting demand-side management," said Michael Foley, an electricity expert at the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, an organization of state officials based in Washington. "In other regions of the country, it's a state here and a state there, but it's not a religion like it is in New England."
In addition, the six-state New England region has been hit hard by recession.
If prices in the Northeast are falling, it would only begin to redress a huge imbalance. A recent survey by the National Utility Service, a consulting concern in Park Ridge, N.J., found that of the five most expensive utilities in the United States for commercial and industrial customers, four were in the Northeast.
First and second, respectively, were the Long Island Lighting Company, at 11.1 cents a kilowatt-hour, and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, at 10.6 cents a kilowatt-hour. Fourth was the Philadelphia Electric Company, at 8.8 cents, followed by the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, at 8.6 cents. In between, at third, was the Louisiana Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of the Entergy Corporation, at 9.8 cents.
Around the country, one factor that drove electricity prices higher in the 1970's is rare now: the construction of new power plants. In most states, utilities build power plants with their own money and then, when the plants are put into service, apply for large rate increases to pay for them. But Mr. Foley of the utility commissioners association pointed out that few utilities were building big plants these days; instead, they are signing contracts to buy power from small producers.
 
Shopping for Power
 Within the utility industry, there are other signs that prices are down.
For example, one way to buy electricity is to purchase a generating station, or shares in a generating station, or to sign a contract for the right to the output of a power station for a fixed number of years.
Northeast Utilities, which serves much of Connecticut and western Massachusetts and is the largest utility in New England, has been in a "long" position for several years, with more capacity than it needs for its own customers. If another utility wanted to buy capacity today, said James R. Shuckerow, Northeast's director of intercompany arrangements, "the price we'd sell for today would be considerably below what we'd have sold for in '87, '88 or '89."
The reason, he said, was that the deep recession in New England had cut demand just as the Seabrook nuclear reactor in New Hampshire came into service, adding to supply and turning a tight market into a loose one.
 
Less Valuable Capacity
 William Balet, the director of the New York Power Pool, a utility consortium that manages electricity transfers among utilities, agreed that the price of buying a share of a generating station was down because of reduced demand. "If you need 10 snow shovels and you have 14, it's enough," he said. "The capacity is less valuable than it would have been three or four years ago."
Another way to buy power is on an hour-to-hour basis, and that, too, seems to show a decline. Power pools use a system called economic dispatch to run generating stations in order of their cost for a kilowatt-hour; thus, at any given moment, controllers know that if power demand increases they will turn on the next-most-expensive generator, and if demand declines, they will turn off the most expensive then running.
The New England Power Pool recently calculated that its 12-month cumulative average for the price of the most expensive plant in operation at any given moment was $24 a megawatt-hour, or 2.4 cents a kilowatt-hour. This was not a record low, but it was down from $25 for the prior 12 months.
 
Troublesome Contracts
 The Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company, a consortium of small publicly owned power companies, reported in the June issue of its newsletter that in part because of low fuel prices, the region was losing money on a contract to buy hydroelectric power from Quebec that began in 1986. The cost of that electricity was set at 80 percent of what the electricity would have cost if it were made from oil, gas and coal, but the price of oil and gas are down. At the same time, a drought in Quebec has cut deliveries, spreading the cost of the transmission lines over fewer kilowatt-hours.
Meanwhile, a second contract with Hydro-Quebec, which began this summer, is losing economic value, the newsletter reported, because it, too, was based on the value of the oil and gas displaced.
Analysts blame the trend toward lower prices for one bankruptcy, that of Eastern Utility Associates, a Massachusetts company that increased its capacity by buying shares in the Seabrook reactor from other companies that wanted to bail out. Eastern Utility expected to sell the resulting power in a tight market, said Mr. Abramson, the Prudential analyst. but that market never developed.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 6, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 24 about national trends in wholesale electricity prices misstated the charge to industrial and commercial customers of the Louisiana Power and Light Company for each kilowatt-hour. It is 5.7 cents, not 9.8 cents. A public relations firm that provided the erroneous figure issued a correction on Oct. 23, but it was not called to The Times's attention until Monday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Cement Shoes For Venezuela

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
TRADE dumping: the words conjure up scenes of wily foreigners plotting to drown American businesses in a torrent of cut-price goods.
But what Washington calls dumping bears only a passing resemblance to the image. In fact, some economists think that illegal dumping should often be celebrated rather than prosecuted. A new case, involving sales of Venezuelan cement in Florida, illustrates their point. 
 According to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, dumping means selling goods abroad for less than they are sold at home. Consumers gain -- cheaper, after all, is better -- but economists agree that dumping is pernicious if the intent is to drive local competitors out of business and then sock it to hapless customers.
The parallel (and more familiar) problem in domestic markets is predatory pricing. Nobody objects when a Pittsburgh bakery sells pastry for less in Peoria -- unless, of course, the idea is to wait for Peoria's bakers to run out of dough and then raise the price of a sugar fix.
But laws against dumping, notes Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University, do not address intent. What counts in United States law (which favors the home team more than the GATT) is whether foreigners price below "fair market value," meaning either the price they charge at home or the cost of production. Exporters who give consumers a good deal simply to meet the competition are thus vulnerable to penalties if the lower prices injure American companies.
In a recession, injury is generally not hard to establish. By no coincidence, American companies have already filed twice as many dumping complaints in 1991 as they did in all of 1989. One of them involves Venezuelan cement in Florida.
Local Florida cement makers, including a subsidiary of Texas-based Southdown Inc., supply half to two-thirds of Florida's cement. The balance comes from abroad because ocean transport is much cheaper than moving the stuff by rail or truck from other states. Venezuela, with easy access to Florida by water, currently has about 10 percent of the Florida market.
The price of cement is roughly equal in Florida and Venezuela -- $60 a ton. Since transportation and storage adds $10 to $15 a ton to the cost of delivering Venezuelan cement to Florida, Southdown contends the Venezuelans are undercutting their home-market price by a like amount.
It is clear why Southdown and two other Florida cement makers are suing. If they win -- and, in the process, inhibit competition from Greek, Spanish and Colombian suppliers to Florida -- they will probably be free to raise prices by as much as the dumping margin. Local supplies of limestone, a key ingredient in cement, are very limited, and potential competition from out-of-state suppliers is constrained by high transport costs.
It is far from clear, however, that a Southdown victory would serve consumers. Kenneth W. Clarkson of the University of Miami and Stephen O. Morrell of Barry University estimate that Florida consumers would pay an extra $664 million for cement over the next five years if the company won.
The two economic consultants for the Venezuelans note, moreover, that two of the three petitioners are their own best customers, supplying cement to subsidiaries that use it as the primary ingredient in ready-mix concrete. If foreign companies are driven out, they argue, independent producers of ready-mix will be easy prey for the two vertically integrated companies with secure access to low-cost cement.
The Venezuelans may yet beat the rap. The Commerce Department has considerable discretion in determining fair market value. And the legal definition of injury is so vague that the United States International Trade Commission could decide that lean times for Florida cement makers are solely due to the depression in local construction.
But they may not: Southdown has already successfully used anti-dumping suits to knock the Mexican cement makers out of the Southern states and drive the Japanese out of California.
Mr. Bhagwati suggests that one route to reform would be to narrow the definition of fair market value and force complainants to meet tougher tests for injury. Michael Knoll, a law professor at the University of Southern California who was a special assistant to the International Trade Commission, would just as soon drop the law as patch it up. Predatory pricing would still be illegal under domestic antitrust laws.
Do not hold your breath. The European Community, which might have been expected to favor reform, now seems intent on using its own anti-dumping weapon against the Japanese. In the politics of trade, consumers do not seem to count.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Higher in U.S. After Declining in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher in domestic trading yesterday after falling in Europe. Gold prices advanced.
The dollar gained in early trading but turned lower after the Conference Board business research group said its consumer confidence index fell sharply in September. The index was seen as yet another indicator of weakness in the United States economy. 
 Dismal auto sales figures for mid-September also took the dollar lower.
The figures "substantiated the belief that the recovery is at best anemic and at worst not there at all," said John McCarthy, chief dealer with Algemene Bank Nederland.
The dollar tends to fall on negative economic news as traders speculate that the Federal Reserve will push interest rates down to stimulate business activity. Like all currencies, the dollar is supported by higher rates, which raise demand for American investments.
The dollar later recovered as technical market influences of supply and demand dominated subsequent dealings.
Mr. McCarthy said one large buyer had come into the market and bid the dollar higher. Other traders who had sold holdings during the dollar's recent decline suddenly found themselves short and scurried to cover their positions, he said.
The dollar rose in New York to 133.45 Japanese yen, from 132.84 on Monday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to 132.97 yen from its Monday close in New York. Japanese markets were closed Monday for a national holiday. In London, the dollar fell to 132.85 yen.
The British pound fell to $1.7290 in New York, from $1.7425 late Monday. In earlier London trading, sterling fell to $1.7430 from $1.7435.
Other late dollar prices in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.6865 German marks, up from 1.6735; 1.4690 Swiss francs, up from 1.4580; 5.7455 French francs, up from 5.7045; 1,261.00 Italian lire, up from 1,252.25, and 1.13375 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13415.
Gold for current delivery picked up $2.90 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to close at $353.70 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $353.65, up $3.25.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $351.75, up from $350.05. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $351.70, up from $349.60.
Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.45 to close at a bid $351.56.
Silver for current delivery rose 8.2 cents on the Commodity Exchange and closed at $4.250 a troy ounce. In London, silver rose to a late bid price of $4.23, up from $4.12 late Monday.
Dealers said the jump had followed a bout of buying overnight in Asia.

HEADLINE: Money Market Accounts And C.D.'s Drop in Yield

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts showed further declines in the week that ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication in North Palm Beach, Fla., that focuses on interest rates.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said there had been considerable impact from recent cuts by leading banks in the prime lending rate to 8 percent from 8 1/2 percent. 
 "New York institutions continue to cut rates at a rapid pace," he said. "While the recent drop in the prime rate did little to affect loan rates, it is having a big impact not just on certificates of deposit but also on money market accounts as well."
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction on Monday, three-month bills were auctioned at an average discount rate of 5.18 percent, only slightly lower than the 5.19 percent the previous week, while six-month bills averaged 5.23 percent, compared with 5.22 percent.
But the rates that bank offered customers showed larger declines. According to The Monitor, the largest change among New York area banks was made by the Chemical Bank, which lowered its money market rate by 26 basis points, to 4.60 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Another substantial cut was made by Chase Manhattan, which lowered its money market rate by 21 points, to 4.60 percent. Marine Midland lowered its rate on three-month certificates of deposit by 16 points, to 4.86, the largest cut in that category.
As for six-month certificates, four major banks -- European American, Connecticut National, Bank of New York and National Westminster -- cut their rates by 11 basis points.
Among commercial banks in New York , the average yield was cut to 4.78 percent, a decline of 5 basis points, for money market accounts, and three-month certificates are down 5 basis points, to 5.02 percent.
For depositors at savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut an average of a basis point, to 5.34 percent, for money market accounts and 3 points, to 5.44, for three-month certificates.
Nationwide, according to The Monitor, the average money maket account yields of 20 major banks outside of the New York area were cut by 5 basis points, to 5.03, and the six-month certificate rate was cut a point, to 5.28.

HEADLINE: Fed Bank Regulator Wins Support for Seidman Posts

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
William Taylor, the Federal Reserve Board's top banking regulator, won broad Congressional support today to succeed L. William Seidman as chairman of the the sister agencies managing the bailouts of the nation's banks and savings and loans.
Senator Donald W. Riegle, the Michigan Democrat who heads the Senate Banking Committee, said after a hearing today on Mr. Taylor's confirmation that he did not see any impediments to his nomination to head the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation. He also expressed satisfaction with Mr. Taylor's answers to questions about his supervision over the last six years of some of the banks involved in the scandal of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. 
 "I have not found anything there that is a barrier," Mr. Riegle told reporters, adding that committee and floor votes on the nomination would probably take place within a few weeks. But he again expressed doubts about the prospects of Robert L. Clarke for another term as comptroller of the currency, strongly hinting that Mr. Clarke's confirmation hearing on Thursday would be acrimonious.
"The Administration should think long and hard about this one," Mr. Riegle said.
For the most part, senators at today's proceeding lobbed softball questions to Mr. Taylor, eliciting no significant new revelations about the B.C.C.I. case.
In many ways the hearing offered a vivid contrast in styles between the circumspect Mr. Taylor, who appeared to go out of his way to say nothing controversial, and the outspoken Mr. Seidman, who had a penchant for using committee hearings to make splashy news announcements.
Without offering specifics, Mr. Taylor vowed to search for "a new methodology" for resolving the plight of failing banks.
"We must do all that we can to keep bank assets from being liquidated," he said.
 
Points to Merger
 He held up as a model for handling more failing banks in the future the proposed acquisition last week of the Southeast Bank by the First Union Corporation, which had been engineered by the F.D.I.C.
In a highly unusual move, regulators used liquidity rather than capital as the standard for seizing Southeast, taking it over before it was technically insolvent, on the ground that it was short on cash after the Federal Reserve called $568 million in loans. And as part of the deal, First Union agreed to assume all of Southeast's loans and to take 15 percent of any losses from those loans. In most other large bank failures, the F.D.I.C. guaranteed all of the losses of bad loans.
Mr. Taylor said he agreed with the plan to have a new chief executive, Albert V. Casey, run the trust corporation on a day-to-day basis. He also supported the proposal by Mr. Seidman -- who has disagreed with the Treasury Department -- that legislation should be introduced formally separating the F.D.I.C. from the trust corporation and creating different chairmanships for each agency.
"Separating them from me would be reasonable," he said.
 
Against Industrial Ownership
 Breaking ranks with the Bush Administration, which has proposed as part of the bank overhaul package now working its way through Congress that industrial enterprises be permitted to own banks, Mr. Taylor said that he did not think that would be appropriate. He agreed that banks should be allowed to diversify into the securities and insurance industries, which the Administration has also proposed. Congress is divided.
Facing a handful of hostile questions from several Republicans on the committee, Mr. Taylor defended the role of examiners, disagreeing with the proposition that they had caused the tightening of credit by discouraging legitimate loans by overreacting to charges that they had been lax in the past.
"There's bound to be, among all of the examiners, someone who overreacts," Mr. Taylor said in response to a question by Senator Jake Garn, the Utah Republican and ranking minority member of the committee. "The worrisome part is that the banker is intimidated to lend not just by the examiner, but by economic circumstances."

Riegle, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, yesterday before the start of the confirmation hearing. (George Tames for The New York Times) (pg. D7)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
From the J. Press Fold To the Top of Tripler

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
After 31 years, Richard Press has bid adieu to his family's retail business and walked around the corner and up Madison Avenue to assume his new post as president of F. R. Tripler, the crown jewel of the Hartmarx Corporation's specialty store division.
"You can decide whether this is fact or fantasy but when I left J. Press, I looked up at the picture of my grandfather on the wall," the 53-year-old Mr. Press said on Monday, his first day at his new job. "He winked at me and said, 'Richard, go for it.' " 
 He is going for it at a time when the recession has cut deeply into the market share for traditional classically styled men's wear, the core of Tripler's business. But Mr. Press said he had no intention of abandoning that segment.
"There is a vacuum that exists now," he said. "The number of people in the trade who have served this type of clientele have moved in other directions, and we are in a good position to capitalize on that."
That is not to say that Tripler's customers, many of whom populate the board rooms and executive suites of America's blue-chip corporations, are hidebound. Mr. Press said that he was eager to attract younger managers, male and female, to the store, and that he planned to make some interior changes to move away somewhat from the atmosphere of a well-heeled men's club.
"We want to lighten the store; air it out a bit," he said. "We want to make it more hospitable to the young men and women who might look up to the C.E.O.'s and senior executives who shop here."
At J. Press, Mr. Press had been a vice president of the parent company, Kashiyama, a Japanese company that in 1986 bought the store founded by his grandfather in 1902. The parting was "cordial," he said.
He had worked at J. Press, one of the haberdasheries that inhabit the corners of Madison Avenue near Grand Central Station, since he graduated from Dartmouth College, where he developed an avid passion for skiing.
Mr. Press is also a graduate of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. He had acting roles in Off Broadway plays and later had financial roles in the production of Broadway plays, including Athol Fugard's "A Lesson From Aloes."
Mr. Press lives in Old Greenwich, Conn., with his wife, Vida.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Many Avoid Dealers in Note Sale

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
In an apparent reaction to the shadow the Salomon Brothers scandal has cast on Wall Street, many participants at yesterday's auction of two-year Treasury notes chose to bypass dealing with the 39 institutions that are primary dealers in Government securities. Instead, they placed bids directly wih the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
In releasing the auction results, the Treasury Department said 79 percent of the bids submitted by New York primary dealers for the $13 billion issue were accepted, compared with an average of 90 percent in past auctions. 
 With the exception of four concerns -- the First National Bank of Chicago, Harris Trust, Fuji Securities and the Bank of America -- all the primary dealers, a collection of big banks and securities houses, are in New York.
"I can't ever remember seeing that before," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
And Stephen A. Wood, director of financial market research at the Bank of America, said, "The bids suggest that people are pulling away from the dealers."
"It seems that customers are probably making a collective decision to go directly to the Fed in order to avoid any chance of a problem," said a trader at a primary dealer, who asked not to be identified.
Bids at the auction produced an average yield of 6.14 percent, well below the 6.46 percent average yield at the last two-year note sale on Aug. 27.
Yesterday's auction was the second sale of two-year notes since the Salomon scandal erupted on Aug. 9. The first auction went smoothly, as did yesterday's. But at the Aug. 27 auction, just under 89 percent of the bids made by New York dealers were accepted by the Treasury.
At yesterday's sale, unusually large competitive bids were submitted through a number of regional Federal Reserve Banks, most notably the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, which was awarded more than $860 million, and the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, which was awarded nearly $550 million.
Dealers said that bids from those two institutions alone were $1 billion higher than usual.
 
More Complicated Process
 The process of placing a competitive bid through a regional Federal Reserve Bank is somewhat more complicated than doing business directly with a primary dealer.
In working through the regional Federal Reserve banks, a client wishing to bid on securities needs to submit either an automated or written tender form. Through primary dealers, a telephone call specifying the size of the bid and the price is all that is necessary.
Results of an auction of $12.5 billion of one-year notes last week gave little sign that this sort of shift would occur. At that auction, 93 percent of the bids submitted by New York dealers were accepted.
"A month ago, it would have made sense to stay with the dealers," said Louis v. B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm. "But given what's happened since, you would have expected to see some of this shift at the one-year bill auction.
"The fact that something changed between that auction and this one is surprising, and makes me wonder if this is an aberration," Mr. Crandall continued. "It is certainly something people will be watching at the five-year auction tommorrow."
 
5-Year Note Sale
 The Treasury is expected to sell $9.5 billion worth of new five-year notes today. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the securities were offered at a price to yield 7.06 percent.
Demand for the two-year notes sold yesterday remained strong after the auction results were announced, and by late in the day the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.12 percent.
The auction was the highlight of an otherwise slow day in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds.
After moving higher early in the session on news that the Conference Board's index of consumer confidence declined for the third straight month in September, prices of Treasury securities staged a reversal and ended slightly lower on the day.
Analysts said that car sales data for the middle 10 days of September were a bit stronger than anticipated, showing a seasonally adjusted annual selling rate of 6.4 million vehicles.
Though far from robust, the rise from the 5.4 million annual rate for the first 10 days of the month provided traders with an excuse to take profits after the recent run-up in prices.
 
30-Year Bonds Off
 By late in the day, the Treasury's benchmark 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 102 25/32, down 1/8 point, to yield 7.88 percent, compared with 7.87 percent late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 10/32 in late trading, down 3/32, to yield 7.55 percent. And the outstanding 7 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 26/32, unchanged from late Monday, to yield 7.05 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.17 percent late yesterday, up one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bills were unchanged at a late offered rate of 5.21 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager on an offering of $175 million of 10-year securities for the Masco Corporation.
The 9 percent notes, which mature Oct. 1, 2001, were priced at $100, or par, 1.44 percentage points higher than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mexico Pries Open Its Oil Industry

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
The transformation of Mexico's economy has filled a graveyard with old myths: the inviolable power of big labor unions, the need for trade protection, the importance of state ownership. The lone survivor would seem to be the sanctity of oil.
Mexican officials still speak in almost mystical terms about the relationship between oil and sovereignty. And in free-trade talks with the United States, Mexico has done its best to keep the issue of foreign involvement in its oil production off the table. 
 Little wonder that to most outside analysts, Petroleos Mexicanos S.A., Mexico's biggest company, remains one of its most insular -- and least efficient.
While continuing to to loom as a nationalist symbol, however, the giant state monopoly known as Pemex has begun to change and open up at a quickening pace.
Driven to expand production by an economy that is projected to grow as much as 4 percent a year through the rest of the decade, Pemex is gathering investment dollars by the billions. Last week, it secured a $1.3 billion loan guarantee from the Export-Import Bank of the United States to call in American companies for four big new exploration projects.
Meantime, as the Mexican Government is loosening other rules on foreign participation in the petroleum industry, Pemex is trying to impose order on the chaotic organization of its various lines of business.
"What is happening with this economy has to happen in all parts of it," a senior economic official here said of the changes sweeping Mexico. "Oil cannot remain apart."
The changes coming to Mexico's oil industry are clearly more evolutionary than revolutionary, and some economists and industry analysts criticize the measures so far as woefully insufficient. Nonetheless, the tentative steps toward opening the industry represent a remarkable break with the past.
As recently as a few years ago, Pemex seemed to be as much a social service agency as an oil company. It ran hospitals and schools, and handed over more revenue to the Treasury than all corporate and individual taxpayers combined.
From the few cases that came to light, though, corruption appeared to be rampant. And the oil workers'union, which maintained a stranglehold on Pemex contracts, was a business empire in its own right, with assets valued at more than $1 billion.
Perhaps most significant in a technology-intensive industry, Pemex's capital spending, which reached $6 billion in 1981, dwindled to barely $1 billion as the 80's drew to a close. Mexico, with twice the reserves of the United States, was producing barely one-third the oil.
 
Soldiers as Agents of Change
 Upon taking office in December 1988, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari hinted that all of this would change. Weeks later, he sent soldiers to storm the home of the powerful oil union chief, Joaquin Hernandez Galicia, and haul him off to jail.
Since 1988, Pemex has shrunk its labor force from 213,000 employees to 171,000 Yet such has been the momentum of economic reform, that when Mr. Salinas stunned many Mexicans earlier this year by closing a major oil refinery to curb pollution in Mexico City, some union officials even mumbled words of support.
Pemex officials say the company has cut its operating costs by 17 percent over the past five years, saving about $1 billion. With the help of MacKinsey & Company consultants, Pemex has also rationalized its system for trading goods within the huge, vertically integrated operation.
In hopes of streamlining Pemex's ponderous bureaucracy, executives are now at work on a sweeping reorganization in which the company has been divided into independent sectors. Exploration and production, for example, has been separated from refining and distribution. Hundreds of mid-level management positions have been eliminated, and lower-level managers have gained more responsibility for productivity and cost containment.
One new division, petrochemicals, has emerged as the laboratory for many of the management and investment innovations being discussed companywide. The petrochemical division has also pioneered a more receptive stance on foreign participation. Among other strategies, the unit has hired foreign companies to build new plants and paid them from the factories' proceeds.
Still, for all of the changes that Pemex has undergone during the first half of Mr. Salinas's six-year term, oil stands as the Mexican industry that has most conspicuously remained closed. Opening it, some economic officials said, would be more politically sensitive than even the planned changes in the communal agriculture system, a land-tenure system that the Government has long defended as one of the remaining prizes of the Mexican Revolution.
Last spring Pemex, for the first time contracted out an entire drilling job, paying a Houston-based company, Triton International Inc., an estimated $18 million for an exploratory well in the Gulf of Campeche, west of the Yucatan Peninsula. The contract was the first under a 1989 law that frees Pemex from the traditional requirement to use Mexican labor.
The 113 new wells that Pemex will have American companies drill and service in the Gulf of Campeche, thanks to the Export-Import Bank guarantee announced last Thursday, are part of a five-year, $19 billion plan to expand exploration, production and refining.
The chief Mexico loan officer for the Export-Import Bank, Marian M. Hinchman, said in a telephone interview from Washington that Pemex was ultimately looking to secure as much as $5.8 billion in guarantees for 16 projects contemplated in the expansion plan. Mexico has also worked out similar arrangements with 25 other national export-import banks around the world, the company's top official, Francisco Rojas, the director general, said in an interview.
Ms. Hinchman described the United States bank's program as a boon to American suppliers. "My phone has been ringing off the hook with oil drilling companies that want a piece of the business," she said.
But several analysts suggested that the loan guarantees might work at cross purposes with attempts by United States trade negotiators to persuade Mexico to open its oil production to foreign equity partners.
According to a Pemex spokeswoman, the company's capital investment will rise this year to $3.07 billion from $2.14 billion in 1990. By 1995, Mr. Rojas said, Pemex hopes annual investment will rise to about $4.5 billion.
 
Rising Domestic Energy Demand
 But after eight years in which domestic demand stagnated and oil exploration and development were sharply curtailed, industry analysts say Pemex will have to invest heavily merely to meet Mexico's domestic energy needs. Gasoline consumption already is rising at an annual rate of more than 5 percent.
Pemex plans to increase its daily crude oil production from 2.64 million barrels in 1990 to 3.1 million barrels by 1995. While domestic use is expected to rise from 1.36 million barrels a day to 1.7 million over the same period, exports are projected to grow by only about 120,000 barrels to 1.4 billion a day.
What incentive Pemex might have to expand more quickly is open to debate. Mexico already has had difficulty selling its heavy, hard-to-refine crude abroad. While some experts insist that Mexican oil would be more valuable out of the ground sooner rather than later, global prices in recent years have not provided much of an incentive.
And even as finance ministry officials say the oil industry has little difficulty securing outside financing, critics insist that politics, not economics, holds foreign equity capital at arm's length.
 
The People's Oil
 Mexico's Constitution defines the nation's hydrocarbon resources as the property of the people. And, in an interview last month, Mr. Salinas said that Mexico, unlike other developing nations, had no intention of inviting foreign exploration companies to share the profits from its oil.
The strongest, and apparently prevailing, arguments against foreign equity partnerships is the relative lack of risk in so-called risk contracts. So confident are Mexican officials in the richness of their oil fields that they see little reason to bring in outsiders to share the risk of exploration.
According to a recent issue of International Petroleum Finance, Pemex data show average production per well in the Gulf of Campeche at 9,933 barrels a day, compared with 250 barrels a day from Louisiana offshore wells.
But the counterarguments go beyond Mexico's need for drilling money. Pemex requires deep-water exploration technology, say the analysts and, even more pressingly, huge investments in its refineries.
 
The Free-Trade Test
 The next big test of Mexico's resolve to keep full control of its oil production will come in negotiations over the proposed North American Free Trade Agreement involving Canada, Mexico and the United States. American negotiators have fought hard to put the subject of Mexican oil on the table, and officials say it will ultimately be discussed.
But American officials and oil executives have not been the only ones to argue for greater flexibility at Pemex. "The situation is ripe for important changes in Mexican oil policy," Mr. Ramirez, the economist,said. "The domestic opposition to changing oil policy has been grossly exaggerated."
Even if Mexican officials were to determine that ownership of oil resources was negotiable, it would remain unclear what the United States might offer of commensurate value at the bargaining table.
"What could the United States possibly trade that's equivalent?" a former Pemex official asked. "There's nothing."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Vehicle Sales Fell 16.3% in Mid-September

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Sales of American-made cars and trucks dropped 16.3 percent in mid-September compared with a strong period a year earlier, but the annual selling rate improved in recent weeks because of higher sales to rental fleets. Car dealers and analysts said consumer demand remained sluggish.
For the 10 days that ended on Sept. 20, cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.4 million, compared with 7.8 million a year earlier. Still, the latest rate is up from the 5.4 million reported for early September. By category, domestic car sales were off 21 percent in the latest period, to 162,949; domestic truck sales dropped 7.9 percent, to 106,653. 
 Maryann N. Keller, the automotive analyst for Furman Selz in New York, said the increase in fleet sales masked the fact that "consumer confidence is not very good."
Several analysts agreed, noting that consumers were worried about the security of their jobs and regarded the economy as shaky. "People are unwilling to step up to the plate and spend discretionary income," said Philip Fricke of Prudential Securities in New York.
Analysts said lean inventories had led to spot shortages that hurt sales. Some dealers said they were not getting as many 1992 models as they needed to meet demand. "If you don't have ready availability in dealer lots, it's going to limit consumer enthusiasm," said Jack V. Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody in New York.
Several dealers reported that showroom traffic had been uneven in recent weeks. "I have a good week, then a bad week," said Richard J. King, general sales manager of Continental Motors in Stamford, Conn. "I can't seem to put a good total month together." Mr. King added that changes in his advertising budget had so far had no effect on the number of customers who pass through his doors.
Dealers added that consumer confidence remained the biggest obstacle to better sales. "They still have a wait-and-see attitude through the winter months," said Ramsay Gillman, president of a number of dealerships in Houston, San Antonio and Austin, Tex. He added that credit approval remained a problem for some customers, but said that it was not signficantly hurting business.
 
G.M. Car Sales Down 24.1%
 The General Motors Corporation reported a drop in car sales of 24.1 percent for the 10-day period, to 75,805. G.M.'s light-truck sales fell 14.6 percent, to 43,505.
The Ford Motor Company sold 40,453 cars, a decline of 22.6 percent. The No. 2 auto maker posted sales of 34,687 light trucks, a drop of 10.5 percent. The Explorer four-wheel-drive vehicle had the only sales increase in its light-truck lineup.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales, based on estimates by Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication, declined 37.2 percent in the period, to 15,500. But light-truck sales were estimated to have increased 11.5 percent, to 22,500. Chrysler reports sales only once a month.
 
'Transplants' Take 19% of Market
 Among the Japanese auto makers with American manufacturing operations, known as "transplants," the Honda Motor Company reported that sales jumped to 16,786 American-built cars, an increase of 25.6 percent. The Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales dropped 24.5 percent. Honda manufactures cars in Marysville, Ohio, and Toyota operates plants in Fremont, Calif. and Georgetown, Ky.
Over all, the Big Three lost ground in mid-September, as their share of the market for North American-built cars fell to 80.9 percent, from 85.7 percent a year ago.
The Japanese transplants picked up almost 5 points of market share, growing to 19.1 percent of the domestic car market, compared with 14.3 percent in the period last year.

HEADLINE: Bell Atlantic to Buy Metro Mobile

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In one of the largest deals ever in the cellular telephone industry, the Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Metro Mobile CTS Inc. for nearly $2.5 billion in Bell Atlantic stock and assumption of debt.
Metro Mobile is considered a well-managed company whose business has been severely hurt by the recession, and analysts say it is one of the last large properties that is likely to come on to the market in desirable urban areas. The price represents $202 to $206 for each potential subscriber, depending on circumstances at the deal's closing. 
 That price is just below the company's asking price of $215, according to John E. Brennan, president and chief operating officer of Metro Mobile. "It's worth a lot more than what we paid for it," said Raymond W. Smith, Bell Atlantic's chairman and chief executive.
 
Period of Consolidation
 The Metro Mobile acquisition is the third-largest deal ever, after McCaw Cellular Communications Inc.'s acquisition of Lin Broadcasting and the GTE Corporation's purchase of Contel Cellular. In recent months, Ameritech Inc. and the BellSouth Corporation, which, like Bell Atlantic, are regional Bell companies, have also bought big cellular concerns. But their acquisitions, Cybertel Cellular and Graphic Scanning, respectively, are together only half the size of Metro Mobile.
The acquisition of the cellular telephone properties of Metro Mobile continues the consolidation of the cellular telephone industry. More than 1,000 companies provide such service, but 25 companies cover more than 80 percent of Americans.
 In the fast-growing cellular business, it was not immediately clear how large the Metro Mobile acquisition would make Bell Atlantic. But the deal is likely to make it at least the sixth-largest cellular service in the country, up from ninth. Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, would have at least 33.6 million potential subscribers, the standard measure of size, up from 22.1 million as of June 30.
Bell Atlantic, already the biggest provider of local telephone service, said the deal would further consolidate its lead as the largest provider of cellular phone service on the East Coast. Its revenues last year totaled $12.3 billion. It has experienced slow growth in highly regulated businesses like local telephone service, but faster growth in lightly regulated new technologies like paging services and cellular telephones.
"Bell Atlantic absolutely had to do this deal," said Joel D. Gross, a telecommunications analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "Unless they want to wind up in the buggy whip business, they had better get more cellular franchises."
Because the deal is a stock swap, increasing the number of Bell Atlantic shares outstanding, the company's earnings will be hurt for the year after the close of the deal, Mr. Gross said. He cut his 1992 earnings estimate from $4 a share to $3.70, equal to the profit for 1991.
Metro Mobile, a New York City company whose revenues in the year ended Sept. 30, 1990, totaled $224 million, took on huge debts as it acquired smaller cellular franchises. It reported losses throughout the 1980's, including its largest loss, $80.1 million, last year. Metro Mobile also distributes propane, a business also acquired by Bell Atlantic in the deal.
As of June 30, Bell Atlantic had about 22.1 million potential subscribers, spread over 8 Northeastern states, including Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey. Metro Mobile had about 11.5 million potential subscribers in 8 states in the Northeast, South and Southwest, including Massachusetts, North Carolina, South Carolina and Arizona.
The industry measures growth in potential subscribers known as P.O.P.'s, or "points of presence," which includes children and teen-agers as well as adults. The industry considers itself a fast-growing business whose expansion would not be accurately gauged by actual subscribers.
Bell Atlantic has 283,000 actual subscribers, and Metro Mobile 180,000 actual subscribers. Nationally, there are 6.4 million subscribers, according to the latest June 30 figures from the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association.
Bell Atlantic stock closed at $46 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, off $1.625.
Cellular telephones are mobile radiotelephones that can be carried in cars, briefcases or shirt pockets. They connect, through fixed radio transmitters known as cell sites, to conventional providers of local and long-distance service.
 
Hurt by Expansion
 Metro Mobile has been especially hurt by its expansion strategy and the recession. The company's negative cash flow has put it in technical default on a big bank loan. Metro Mobil projected average monthly revenue per subscriber of $85, but was recently getting only $60.
Mr. Brennan of Metro Mobile said practices that had helped the company grow had also hurt it. It paid agents a $300 commission for each subscriber, but when the recession hit, these additional customers tended to use their cellular phones rarely, spending $15 a month or less for calls.
Many of the customers bought service for second phones for family members who are light users. It will take four years or more for some of these new subscribers to pay back in future revenue the original $300 agent's commission.
The latest deal is one of many that are consolidating a fragmented industry. In 1989, hundreds of thousands of applicants clamored for billions of dollars worth of cellular telephone franchises. The Federal Communications Commission assigned the franchises by lottery, many of them to private citizens with no intention of operating a phone company but eager to sell the franchise rights to the highest bidders.
Analysts likened the resulting Balkanization of the cellular market to Humpty-Dumpty's great fall. Since then, big cellular companies have been buying the smaller franchise holders, as well as each other, in an attempt to put things back together again.
Many in the industry believe that only then will they be able to provide the kind of national service similar to the familiar residential and business telephones wired into walls. Cellular service is now unavailable or difficult to use in many places.
Bell Atlantic plans to pay $1.65 billion worth of Bell Atlantic stock, or 33 million shares. for Metro Mobile, under terms that would make the deal tax-free. Bell Atlantic also plans to assume about $800 million in Metro Mobile debt.
The deal is expected to close in March or April 1992, partly because of the need for a special order from Federal Judge Harold H. Greene, who oversaw the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company into the regional Bells.

HEADLINE: Senator Assails Drug Prices

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Prescription-drug prices jumped by almost three times the rate of inflation during the first half of 1991, continuing the pattern of the 1980's, a Congressional report released today said. Congress needs to do more to curtail the "despicable behavior" of the prescription-drug industry, a Democratic Senator said.
While inflation for consumer goods during the decade was 58 percent, prescription drug prices rose 152 percent, said Senator David H. Pryor, chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging, releasing a report by his panel's Democratic majority staff. "The findings in this report point to an industry whose despicable behavior can be characterized as nothing short of repulsive," Senator Pryor, who is from Arkansas, said at a news conference. 
 The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association responded by saying "prescription drugs are the best bargain in health care" because they help hold down total health-care costs.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Falls Further, Index Shows

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Consumer spirits, which wilted this summer, continued to droop after Labor Day -- one more sign that the recovery in consumer spending continued to be unusually weak.
"The prime worry is jobs," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center. The closely watched Conference Board index of consumer confidence, released yesterday, logged its third straight monthly decline in September, to 72.7, from 76.1 in August, on a 1985 base of 100. 
 The trouble, said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, is that anxiety over layoffs in key industries -- services, computers and weapons, among others -- is overwhelming the good news from lower interest rates and inflation. "There's not enough income and too much insecurity," he said.
Nonetheless, there are scattered signs that spending, which probably dipped last month, may actually be holding up a bit better this month. The University of Michigan Survey of Consumer Sentiment -- whose preliminary results for early September showed a slight improvement -- indicates a slightly less worrisome trend in consumers' mood.
Richard T. Curtin, who conducts the University of Michigan survey, said: "Over the last several months we've been drifting sideways. That's very different from six months of decline."
And some retailers are more optimistic.
"Our store sales have been better in September, said Ira Silver, chief economist for J. C. Penney.
Carl Steidtmann, a retailing consultant at Management Horizons in Columbus, Ohio, who works with apparel chains, said, "Most people are telling me that September is a little better than August, although not much,"
Merchants continue to count on a better Christmas sales season than last year's, which was dreadful. "Most people are still hopeful about Christmas and most plan to have more inventory," Mr. Steidtmann said.
The Conference Board's index, basically, has retraced more than one-third of its surge immediately after the Persian Gulf war. The board's Survey of Consumer Attitudes, conducted in the first weeks of every month, covers 5,000 households in the United States.
The board's most striking finding is that consumers are getting more, not less pessimistic about job prospects. More than 40.2 percent of survey respondants thought jobs were hard to get versus 35.5 percent in April.
