HEADLINE: Market Place;
For Steel, Small Means Healthier

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
BIG steel companies, which saw some of their brightest days before the recession took hold, are once again faced with plunging profits and outright losses. But the smaller, second-tier steel producers have generally not seen the profound losses of their bigger counteparts.
Companies like the Nucor Corporation, Birmingham Steel and the Quanex Corporation have been holding their own during the recession, with only a little sagging. And analysts say their prospects are brighter than those of big steel once the economic recovery takes hold. The reason, analysts say, stems from fundamental differences between the cost structures of the smaller competitors and those of big producers like the USX Corporation, Bethlehem Steel and the LTV Corporation, which have billions of dollars in sales to many industries and an array of products made in several plants. The big companies typically have expensive, large headquarters and produce raw materials -- iron ore and coal -- in mines they own outright. 
 "Some of the smaller steel companies are big fish in a small pond," said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. "They cast their lot with a small set of industries and concentrate on a small number of markets."
Smaller steel companies generally have lower overhead, too, as well as nonunion labor forces that work under far more flexible work rules. "A maintenance worker in a big steel mill does mostly that," Mr. Jacobson said. "But a worker in a small, non-union shop does a little of everything."
Heading the list of smaller steelmakers whose stocks are currently in favor is Nucor, the giant of the so-called mini-mill companies. Nucor has departed from the tradition of mini-mills -- which produce steel from scrap, mainly for construction -- by making a bold foray into the market for sheet steel, which is used by automobile and appliance makers. By producing sheet steel by a process that is cheaper and less labor intensive than its big-steel rivals', Nucor has been praised by analysts, who expect the company to show robust growth for the next few years. Nucor's stock, which traded around 60 at the beginning of the year, closed yesterday at $81.25, up 62.5 cents.
Not everyone agrees on Nucor's prospects. "Nucor is a great company from its potential and it is well managed," said Charles Bradford, an analyst with UBS Securities. But he questions the timing on buying Nucor stock.
"The company's primary market is in commercial construction such as thrift stores and shopping centers," he said. "It is not a buoyant business and I don't expect it to be for another year and a half or more." Mr. Bradford said he expected Nucor's earnings to rise to $4 next year, from a depressed $2.75 for the current year and $3.50 a share in 1990.
Analysts are also giving high marks to Birmingham Steel, a mini-mill company based in Birmingham, Ala., that is a significant producer of steel bar products used in the construction industry. While that industry has been deeply affected by the recession, Birmingham Steel has made its mark by acquiring small steel companies, cutting operating costs and improving efficiency.
"They are able to make money because they acquire old plants at low prices, and develop a labor force with incentives like a good profit-sharing program," Mr. Jacobson said.
The company's earnings have been hurt by the drop in the construction industry, but analysts expect sales and earnings to rise this year because of higher prices, increased volume and the absence of restructuring charges.
Mr. Bradford said Birmingham "is doing a lot of things to become efficient, and I look at the company as an improvement stock." He added that he expected earnings of $1 a share for the current fiscal year and "perhaps as much as $1.75 in the following fiscal year."
Aldo J. Mazzaferro Jr., a metals analyst with C. J. Lawrence Inc., praises the Quanex Corporation's prospects, saying he expects the company to double its earnings in the next two years. Quanex, based in Houston, is a producer of high-quality bar products used in engine components and machinery. But the company's success will have less to do with increased efficiencies in steel production than with expansion into the aluminum fabrication business, Mr. Mazzaferro says. Quanex has said that in the next two years it will increase its annual production capacity of aluminum to 300 million pounds, from 50 million pounds.
While many of these companies have the same kinds of problems of their larger counterparts, they are nonetheless better off because "it takes a lot to happen in the economy for big steel to rebound," Mr. Jacobson said. "It's not at all clear that integrated steel will be a good investment any time soon."

HEADLINE: Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Fraud

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
A prominent Manhattan divorce lawyer pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing more than $1.28 million from well-known matrimonial lawyers through a series of fraudulent investment schemes.
The plea from the lawyer, Alvin Ashley, was unexpected, coming just a week after his indictment on grand larceny charges. 
 Acting Justice Herbert J. Adlerberg of State Supreme Court said he would sentence the 57-year-old defendant on Dec. 3. As part of a plea bargain, Mr. Ashley faces 1 to 9 years in state prison. He also faces disbarment. Had he gone to trial, he would have faced 5 to 15 years if convicted.
Although the indictment charges Mr. Ashley with stealing $1.28 million, Manhattan prosecutors said he stole more than $4.75 million from unsuspecting clients and others over six years.
They said he ended up broke because of a sagging economy, bad business decisions, and a luxurious style of living that included gambling sprees to Atlantic City, $400 bottles of wine and a regular table reserved at Le Cirque.
"His victims included his clients, former clients, and colleagues, relatives and neighbors," said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney. "Unfortunately, it appears that the stolen money has all been spent, mostly on high living."
Mr. Ashley pleaded guilty to making a counterfeit copy of $900,000 in Pepsico stock owned by Herbert Feinberg of 138 Madison Avenue and then offering the forged stock certificate as collateral for an investment loan from Halsley Investments.
In three other instances, he pleaded guilty to stealing from matrimonial lawyers: $90,000 from Julia Perles, $164,000 from John Vassallo, and $38,000 from Elliot Samuelson. He also admitted to stealing $92,000 from Georg Heine, a Greek businessman.
Mr. Ashley, who lives in White Plains, is the former president of the New York chapter of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers.

HEADLINE: U.S. EXTENDS DEAL FOR SOVIET LOANS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan announced today that he was changing loan guarantees for the Soviet Union to make them more attractive to commercial banks.
In response to an urgent request from the Soviet authorities, President Bush made $315 million in loan guarantees available immediately in late August. But the Soviets have only been able to obtain loans with $104 million of the guarantees, using the credit lines set up before the unsuccessful hard-line coup in the Soviet Union last month. 
 Commercial bankers have been especially concerned for the last month that they would never recover the unguaranteed portion of any new loans if the Soviet Union rescheduled its debt or if the Soviet Union disintegrated and the republics refused to honor foreign debts incurred by the central Government.
Until now, the loan guarantees have covered 98 percent of the principal and the first 4.5 percentage points of interest on the 98 percent of principal.
 
'There'll Be More Takers'
 Mr. Madigan said he had increased the guarantees on the remaining $211 million to 100 percent of principal and interest equal to the prevailing rate for 52-week Treasury bills. That interest rate is currently 5.2 percent.
A senior official at an American comercial bank who insisted on not being identified said the expanded guarantees should be more than adequate to insure that they are used.
"I suspect there'll be more takers than available loan guarantees," he said. "They've cleared a major hurdle."
Mr. Madigan's action came after several members of Congress at a House Agriculture Committee hearing this morning criticized the absence of new Agriculture Department programs to help the Soviet Union.
"I think the inertia of the Soviet bureaucracy is being quickly overtaken by the inertia of the U.S.D.A.," said Representative Timothy J. Penny, Democrat of Minnesota.
But Mr. Madigan said in a telephone interview this evening that the decision to expand the loan guarantees had been made at a meeting on Monday afternoon. The meeting ended too late to announce the decision, which was released after the close of trading today, he said.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Ideas for New York City: Some Are Old, Some Are New

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's plan to prime New York City's economy with public works, an expansive vision of new high-tech "people movers," subway lines and huge housing complexes, is actually a melange of proposals, some bold and new but many old and languishing.
The Governor presented his plan yesterday, backed by stirring music and an elaborate, handsome film, offering a $7 billion wish list to restore the city's luster. 
But some of the projects will require money that state legislative leaders fear is unavailable. The fate of other proposals will depend more on a turnaround in the region's economy, and in particular on its real-estate market, than on any encouraging words from Mr. Cuomo and other public officials.
Mayor David N. Dinkins and his aides had mixed reactions to the Governor's proposals, praising their promise but still trying to sort out what they would mean and expressing wariness about how much they might help the city.
"It's a great vote of confidence in our city," Mr. Dinkins said. "How much we get done, and how soon, is another question." He added, "Just because a proposal's old doesn't mean it's not a good idea."
At the same time, City Hall was grappling with its own proposals for cutting costs further in the hope of winning more help from the state. [Page B4.]
Two projects account for $4.5 billion, or 64 percent, of the Governor's $7 billion plan: huge housing and office developments that have been proposed for years at Hunters Point, on the East River waterfront in Queens and at what had been known until recently as Trump City, along the Hudson River on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
Almost all the money to develop the sites would come from private investors, not the city or the state, and both projects have long been stalled. New York has a glut of office space and market-rate apartments, and investors have been unwilling to put up the capital to make the visions reality. The relatively small changes proposed by Mr. Cuomo are not likely to jump-start either project, many public officials said privately yesterday.
 
One Project Under Way
 The bulk of the Governor's proposals have existed, in one form or another, for some time. One of them -- a plan to renovate the Long Island Rail Road's terminal at Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan -- was approved long ago and is actually under way.
Others, like a renovation of Grand Central Terminal and a new $612 million link between the overcrowded Queens Boulevard subway line and the new 63d Street tunnel under the East River, are part of a $10.6 billion five-year capital plan that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been crafting for a year.
Perhaps the foremost innovation proposed by Mr. Cuomo is a light-rail train line connecting La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports with mass-transit lines in Queens. Many experts said they thought this project had an excellent chance of being built because it could be financed by a new airport tax.
Even if the Governor was not offering large new amounts of state money, his commitment and zeal could be of more than psychic value, some city officials contended. "Grand vision and strong reassurance are sometimes what it takes to trigger the private investment we need," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President.
These are the major elements of Mr. Cuomo's plan:
 
Airport Rail Lines
 The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey would be the prime mover behind this project, which would connect all three of the region's major airports with mass transit. While virtually all details must still be resolved, the concept calls for Kennedy and La Guardia Airports to be linked by an automated people-mover or other kind of light rail line that likely would run down the medians of the Van Wyck Expressway and Grand Central Parkway. The line would connect Kennedy with the Long Island Rail Road terminal in Jamaica, Queens, and would run from La Guardia west to other railroad or subway stations in Long Island City, Queens.
The Port Authority would finance a similar line to link Newark International Airport with mass-transit lines in downtown Newark.
Unlike most components of Mr. Cuomo's plan, the $1.6 billion rail line proposed for Queens would be backed by a specific financing source: a $3 tax for departing passengers at the airports, which was approved last year by Congress for airports that want to expand or improve safety. The tax would generate about $100 million a year in new money, Port Authority officials estimated, and that could be used to finance the light rail line. The proposal must go to the Port Authority's board for approval.
 
Queens Subway Lines
 The E and F subway lines that run under Queens Boulevard are the most congested in the city. The lines cannot handle additional trains during rush hours because their tunnel under the East River cannot accommodate more trains. Planners have wanted for years to ease the overcrowding by connecting some trains on the E and F lines with the Q line that runs in a new tunnel from 63d Street in Manhattan to Long Island City in Queens. That would allow 15 more trains to be run under Queens Boulevard during rush hours.
A proposal to connect the two lines, at a cost of $612 million, is in the five-year capital plan that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has developed over the last year. It will be presented to legislative leaders in Albany next week. The fate of the $10.6 billion proposal -- the authority's third five-year capital plan -- is uncertain. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller said yesterday that he could earmark only $6 billion for the M.T.A. "Beyond the $6 billion, I don't really see where we get more money," he said.
 
Renovating Rail Stations
 Rebuilding the L.I.R.R. terminal at Pennsylvania Station is part of the five-year capital plan that was passed by the Legislature years ago and that the M.T.A. is to complete this year. About $157 million will have been spent in all. Among the renovations, on which ground is about to be broken: a new street entrance at 34th Street and Seventh Avenue; new elevators, escalators and stairways; a new waiting area and a new cooling system.
The five-year plan that the M.T.A. will soon take to Albany includes $126 million to rebuild parts of Grand Central Terminal, including new wiring, plumbing, ventilation and some structural work. After legislators had complained about a $11.5 billion capital plan that the transit agency presented last spring, the M.T.A. scaled back its proposal by $900 million two weeks ago. Among the items dropped was a $20 million proposal to reconfigure the station's interior to improve the flow of passengers during rush hour.
 
Second Avenue Subway
 Twenty years ago, the city spent $87 million to dig sections of tunnel for a Second Avenue subway, the first new line in decades. It was abandoned in 1975, during the fiscal crisis, after the structural shell of three sections that covered a total of slightly more than 20 blocks was completed.
The Governor proposed spending $22 million to design and plan the possible completion of the line in the next five years. Actual construction, whose cost is unknown, would not begin until at least 1997 under Mr. Cuomo's plan.
 
Hunters Point
 This $2 billion development, with as many as 6,000 apartments and more than 2 million square feet of office space, has been planned for years on a site in Queens, just across the East River from the United Nations Building. Three government agencies are behind it, including the State Urban Development Corporation, the city and the Port Authority. The city pledged long ago to spend $30 million and the Port Authority promised $125 million, to be used to help prepare the site and to buy some of the land.
The city's Board of Estimate formally approved the project in August 1990, at its final meeting before the board was dissolved. But the project has languished for a lack of private investors, who would finance virtually all of it. Mr. Cuomo proposed yesterday that the Urban Development Corporation create a subsidiary that would be solely responsible for Hunters Point. He offered no new money.
But some elected officials and some developers interested in participating in the Hunters Point project said they thought there was value in the Governor's commitment. "We see a renewed emphasis in moving the project forward," said Richard L. Higgins, vice president of the Trotwood Corporation, a subsidiary of the Dreyfus Corporation that is interested in developing part of Hunters Point.
"That the Governor is putting it at the top of his economic development agenda is a wonderful thing," said Mr. Higgins, who served until last year as Mr. Cuomo's Housing Commissioner.
 
Riverside South
 Over the last six years, this project was known first as Television City and then Trump City, named after the developer who had hoped to make it a landmark of contemporary urban planning on the Upper West Side. Donald J. Trump failed to attract NBC to the site in 1987, and then, after his financial reversals last year, he agreed in March to scale back significantly his planned apartment and office complex, in return for support from civic groups that had fought the project.
The proposal has not yet gone before the appropriate city agencies for public approval, and it too faces a very troubled real-estate market. Mr. Trump has indicated he would still like to build part of the development, whose overall cost the state estimates at $2.5 billion. All would come from private sources.
Mr. Cuomo proposed yesterday to spend $1 million to begin examining the feasibility of moving an 18-block stretch of the West Side Highway eastward to permit a large public park to be built on the site along the Hudson River waterfront.
Proponents of the project would like the highway moved. But several real-estate executives said the Governor's initiative, by itself, could not possibly overcome the project's serious financial problems.
 
Science and Business Library
 Mr. Cuomo proposed that the New York Public Library create an international center for information on science, industry and business in the building that was once home to the B. Altman department store on Fifth Avenue at 34th Street. He said the center would cost $82 million, to be split equally by the library, private contributions and the city and state. The Governor also proposed that the city and the state each donate $7.5 million to start raising funds for the center.

HEADLINE: Senate Votes to Extend Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The Senate tonight passed a bill 69 to 30 providing extended unemployment benefits for about three million people who have been out of work for more than half a year.
President Bush opposes the $6.1 billion measure, which is similar to one he killed last month, because it would be financed by adding to the deficit. He urged support of a less expensive bill sponsored by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. But the $2.4 billion Dole measure was defeated earlier, with only Republicans in support. 
 Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, sponsored the bill that passed tonight. It is expected to be quickly reconciled with a similar, $6.3 billion bill passed last week by the House.
The issue is expected to provide the Democrats with a serious chance to override a Bush veto for the first time, as senators from both parties complained that the economy was not recovering from recession very quickly, if at all.
 
Sterner Bill Expected
 Tonight's vote, with 13 Republicans joining 56 Democrats to defeat the 30 Republicans who opposed the measure, was not a clear test of the veto override prospects because the bill that comes back from conference is expected to be tougher for Mr. Bush to kill than the Bentsen bill.
The Bensten bill, like the House bill, would provide up to 20 weeks of additional benefits for jobless workers who have exhausted regular benefits, which stop after 26 weeks in most states. The Dole bill would have provided up to 10 weeks of additional benefits and would have been financed by selling unused radio frequencies and tightening up on student loan repayments.
The Bentsen bill, like the one Mr. Bush killed in August, requires Mr. Bush to take two separate steps before extended benefits are paid. First he must sign it and then sign a separate declaration of emergency under last year's budget act before the benefits can flow. Last month he signed the bill but did not issue the declaration.
The House bill combines those two steps into one, so Mr. Bush must sign or veto the bill. That provision is expected to emerge from a House-Senate conference in the next few days.
Besides killing Mr. Dole's measure, the Senate rejected a measure sponsored by Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, that would have paid for the benefits with a cut in capital gains taxes and other tax changes.
The Democrats continued their attack on the Administration as more interested in aiding foreigners in difficulty than in helping Americans in need. Senator James Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee and chairman of the Budget Committee, said, "This administration can liquidate the debt of Malawi but can't help the unemployed factory worker in Maine."
The Republicans denounced the Democrats as heedless of the tax burden the growing national deficit and interest payments would impose on the next generation. Senator Dole said the message of the Bentsen bill was that "Congress does not care how big the Federal deficit grows."
Mr. Dole also insisted that while President Bush would sign his bill, and thus provide help to the unemployed, Mr. Bush would veto the Democratic measures and be sustained, causing needy unemployed workers to go without the extended benefits.
 
Which Way the Recession
 Richard G. Darman, Mr. Bush's budget director, has said that the Administration would support the Dole bill, although he believed that extended benefits were unnecessary because the recession was coming to an end.
That view got little support in the Senate today. Even Mr. Gramm said, "It may well be that the economy turned the corner last month, but it sure didn't leave any skid marks when it turned."
Democrats also argued that spending the money under a budget emergency declaration was proper because the recession was just the sort of problem that the emergency provisions of the budget act were aimed at. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said, "The budget agreement was intended to provide flexibility in dealing with economic problems, not as a device for the Administration to deny help to working families enduring hard times because the economy has gone bad."
Unemployment insurance covers about half of all workers and provides benefits of about half of the salary most recently earned up to ceilings that vary greatly from state to state.
 
Making It Easier to Qualify
 Current law provides extended benefits of up to 13 weeks, paid for equally from state and Federal funds. But even though the national unemployment rate was 6.8 percent for August, workers in only one state, Rhode Island, and in Puerto Rico were covered.
Democrats complained that the extended benefits fund had grown to nearly $8 billion but the program was too narrowly applied. Extended benefits are paid when joblessness among a state's workers who are covered by unemployment insurance reaches 6 percent, or when the rate reaches 5 percent if the level of insured joblessness exceeds by one-fifth the average level in that state over the last two years.
Under the Bentsen bill, the measuring standard would be total unemployment, not insured unemployment, on the ground that when there is widespread joblessness of any sort, it is harder to find a job. And all the benefits would be paid from Federal funds.
In states with 8 percent unemployment, averaged over the last six months, up to 20 weeks of additional benefits could be paid. Workers in Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi and West Virginia would become eligible, as Rhode Islanders and Puerto Ricans are now.
In states with 7 percent unemployment, 13 additional weeks of benefits could be paid. New York and California, the nation's two most populous states, are in that group. In all other states, 7 weeks of additional benefits could be paid.
The reach of the Bentsen bill would be temporary, extending only until next July, except for a provision affecting people who leave the armed services. A permanent change would make them eligible for 26 weeks of benefits, instead of the current 13 weeks. They would be able to start collecting after one week, instead of the current four. Both changes would put them under the same rules as people who leave civilian jobs.

HEADLINE: FAILING TO COMMUNICATE;
Dispute Over Settlements and Loan Deal Is Symptom of a Deeper U.S.-Israel Strain

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
The dispute between the Bush Administration and Israel over loan guarantees and restrictions on Israeli settlements underscores the stunning lack of communication between two Governments on some of the most sensitive issues between them.
"This whole crisis is symptomatic of our relationship," said an Administration Middle East expert. "We have this ritualized relationship, with all of the structures of closeness, but people don't really talk to each other or hear each other, because there is no real private honesty. Everyone is afraid to be honest, because they are aware that there are some real underlying differences over the question of the occupied territories." 
 Interviews in recent days with many American and Israeli officials and others involved in the dispute suggest that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir badly miscalculated when he brushed aside a Bush Administration request in early September to put off a request for $10 billion in loan guarantees or face a confrontation over Jewish settlements in the occupied territories.
 
Bush-Shamir Misunderstanding
 It is now evident that Israel's supporters in Congress have decided not to fight the Administration and will postpone dealing with the loan guarantee issue until after a Middle East peace conference begins.
The lack of communication between Mr. Shamir and President Bush goes back to the very first meeting between the two men in the Oval Office in April 1989, when Mr. Bush expressed his displeasure over Israeli settlement-building practices and Mr. Shamir responded, "It won't be a problem."
Mr. Shamir meant that if the Israelis really have an Arab partner for peace talks, settlements will not be an obstacle to peace. What Mr. Bush thought he heard, though, was a commitment from Mr. Shamir to slow down or stop settlement-building, and when just the opposite happened as soon as Mr. Shamir returned to Israel, the seeds of Mr. Bush's personal wrath with Mr. Shamir were firmly planted.
 
Loan Guarantees Delayed
 Mr. Bush's focus on Israeli settlements grows out of a longstanding American belief that an accord between Israel and the Arabs will only come about in a trade of land for peace, and if Israel builds housing all over the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, no trade will be possible.
The tension between Mr. Shamir and Mr. Bush dating back to that first meeting hung over their relationship. In early 1990, Israel appealed to the Bush Administration for $400 million in housing loan guarantees to help resettle Soviet immigrants who were flooding in.
The guarantees sailed through Congress, but they did not become available for almost nine months while Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d negotiated with the Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, an unusual letter in which Israel for the first time promised not to use the money to settle Soviet Jews "beyond the green line" dividing Israel proper from the territories occupied in the 1967 War. The expectation in Washington was that as a result of that letter there would be no increase in Israeli settlement activity of any kind, whereas the view in Jerusalem was that Israel had agreed not to spend the $400 million in the territories, but that it could spend its own money.
Mr. Levy also agreed to provide Mr. Baker with certain financial data to assure the Americans that their money was not going into the West Bank.
 
Baker and Levy Letter
 The Levy letter was signed on Oct. 2, 1990, and the $400 million in guarantees was granted. After the new year, though, it became apparent to the Israelis that the number of Soviet Jews that could descend on them could reach a million, far more than anticipated, and therefore their housing and absorption requirements would be much greater.
In between all of that the Persian Gulf War intruded and Israel sought a special aid infusion from the Bush Administration -- over and above the annual $3 billion it receives for economic and military assistance -- to compensate for losses it incurred from Iraqi Scud missile attacks and increased defense spending.
The Bush Administration, beholden to Israel for not retaliating against Iraq, agreed after a period of bargaining to a one-time grant of $650 million in cash -- on the condition that Israel not ask for any more extra aid of any kind until after Labor Day, when the Administration hoped it would be too late to get the request through Congress this fiscal year.
Between March and Labor Day, the President was privately seething over what he believed was Israeli non-compliance with the Levy letter of October and the fact that every time Mr. Baker came to Israel on his peace missions a new settlement was erected. Despite the Levy letter, Israeli settlements in the occupied territories were increasing instead of decreasing and the financial data Israel promised was not forthcoming. At a news conference on July 1, Mr. Bush said he did not think there "ought to be a quid pro quo" between a halt on settlements freeze and loan guarantees, but he implored the Israelis to live up to the Levy letter.
 
Lobbying Campaign in U.S.
 But Mr. Baker was obsessed with putting a peace conference together, and while he regularly spoke to the Israelis about problems he had with settlements, he acceded to their demand that a halt on settlement not be made a precondition for the peace conference, and sold that to the Arabs.
The Israeli Government began talking about the need for $10 billion in housing loan guarantees and the Israeli lobby, the American Israel-Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, and every other major American Jewish group began organizing a lobbying campaign that would culminate after Labor Day to insure that the Israelis got the money through Congress.
The Israeli Government was aware of how President Bush was feeling, because Israel's Ambassador to Washington, Zalman Shoval, was hearing it from his sources. But Mr. Shamir apparently did not take his warnings seriously. On June 22, Mr. Shoval, in an unsual move, went public. Asked in an interview with Israel Radio whether the $10 billion in loan guarantees was assured, he answered: "Very probably there will be a difficulty. The Government of Israel with all the data in its hands may have to decide whether the issue of settlement is a priority or that the issue of aid is a priority. Sometimes there are moments and there are issues where governments have to take decisions."
For his candor, Mr. Shoval was berated by his superiors. Mr. Shamir apparently thought the Administration was simply using the loan issue as leverage to get him to say yes to Mr. Baker's peace conference.
But he had received other warnings. On July 25, Vice President Dan Quayle personally warned the Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, when he visited Washington that linkage was a possibility if Israel did not curb settlements.
In early August, though, Mr. Shamir finally told Mr. Baker that Israel would come to his peace conference and Israeli officials said at the time that they assumed that the Shamir "yes" to the conference meant that the housing guarantees were assured.
While Baker aides say they never told the Israelis that, Mr. Baker, still focused on his peace conference, also did not explicitly tell Mr. Shamir that the Administration intended to hold up the guarantees until it got even more restrictions on Israeli settlements.
A few days later, after Mr. Baker returned from the Middle East, senior Administration Middle East experts began focusing on the gauarantees. It became clear to them then that President Bush had no intention of granting the guarantees without restrictions that would finally either freeze or severely curtail Israeli building. Mr. Bush is said to have literally laughed at the notion that the sort of understandings Mr. Levy agreed to for the $400 million guarantee would be satisfactory for the $10 billion.
 Meanwhile, Aipac and other Jewish organizations were putting the finishing touches on their lobbying campaigns for the guarantees.
Over the Labor Day weekend, Secretary Baker telephoned Mr. Shamir twice and asked him to delay the loan request for four months. But Mr. Shamir said he could not do that. He had just concluded an exhausting domestic budget battle in which he agreed to increase the defense budget by cutting the housing budget and the only way he could limit the damage to his housing budget was by assuming that the loan guarantees would come this fiscal year. It was already written into the Israeli budget.
The guarantees would enable Israel to borrow $10 billion from banks over the next five years at reduced interest rates, since the United States would be giving its assurance that it would meet any principal or interest payments that Israel could not make. Israeli officials, noting that Israel's credit rating is fairly good, say there would be no need for Washington to pay any money.
When Mr. Baker got no satisfaction from Mr. Shamir, the Administration turned to Congress to delay the issue for 120 days, which it now appears ready to do.
In four months, the Administration will again try to link Israeli housing guarantees with some sort of suspension of Israeli settlements. But the Administration apparently hopes that by then the Arab-Israeli peace conference will be well underway and they can use their leverage over Israel on that issue to help forge the first interim deal in that conference: Israel suspends settlements in return for the Arab countries' suspending their boycott of Israel and the Palestinians' suspending their uprising.

HEADLINE: Patrol Officers in New York To Test Semiautomatic Guns

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
The New York City Police Department, which has steadfastly resisted the trend toward arming police officers with quicker-loading, more powerful guns, has decided for the first time to let uniformed officers test semiautomatic pistols, a police official said yesterday.
Until now, the department has argued that the extra firepower made the weapons unsafe in densely populated urban areas. The police union favors 9-millimeter weapons, saying officers need them because of the proliferation of high-power semiautomatic and automatic guns in the hands of criminals. 
 First Deputy Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the department would issue 225 9-millimeter pistols to a handful of closely supervised uniformed officers. In addition, 94 more pistols will be used by special officers and detectives in the Housing Police, said Chief DeForrest W. Taylor, the chief of the Housing Police.
Mr. Kelly said the department still thinks the 9-millimeter guns are too dangerous for general use. But it is now willing to experiment with them, he said, "because of concern voiced by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and because the New York City Police Department wants to collect its own data in our own working environment."
The officials spoke at a hearing in Manhattan called by State Senator Emanuel R. Gold of Queens, who said he wanted to open a public debate on the choice of weapons.
About 500 nonuniformed officers -- detectives and narcotics police -- already have 9-millimeter pistols and the Transit Authority police began issuing them to subway patrol officers earlier this year. But until now, the department has been adamant in its refusal to give the guns to officers who patrol the streets. There are currently 27,250 members of the department.
Mr. Kelly emphasized that the weapons would be issued to only three officers in each precinct and only to those who accompany sergeants in patrol cars. That is to insure that those carrying the more powerful weapons will be closely supervised, Mr. Kelly said, emphasizing that the 6-shot, .38-caliber revolver will remain the official service firearm of the Police Department.
 
Reloaded in an Instant
 In general, 9-millimeter pistols fire bullets faster than .38-caliber revolvers and the bullets have more penetrating power. They can be reloaded in an instant by inserting a magazine, while a six-shooter requires slipping bullets one at a time into a barrel. The 9-millimeter pistols, to go to each of the 75 precincts within the next 30 days, fire up to 17 bullets without reloading.
Scores of police departments across the nation have been adopting 9-millimeter guns. "It's a modern trend," said Hubert Williams, the former police director of Newark who is president of the Police Foundation, a nonprofit police research organization. "Police departments are moving in that direction in larger numbers, places like Newark and Washington, D.C. The 9-millimeter is rapidly becoming the weapon of choice for police officers."
Mr. Williams, added, however, that because of the public safety issue, "New York is being very prudent, doing some tests, and that's a wise decision to make before they decide what direction to go in."
"Nine millimeter" and ".38 caliber" refer to the diameter of a gun barrel and are similar in size. A semiautomatic pistol, like a revolver, fires a round each time the trigger is squeezed.
Phil Caruso, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, told the State Senate Committee that introducing the 9-millimeter was overdue and called the .38-caliber an "anachronistic" weapon that is difficult to reload "under tense combat conditions."
Recalling the death of Scott Gadell, a 22-year-old rookie officer who was shot with a 9-millimeter semiautomatic while reloading his pistol during a gunfight in Far Rockaway, Queens, in 1986, he said the department had "a long history of resistance to technological change."
He attributed such resistance to "purely political and economic considerations," including a fear of more claims of police brutality if the gun is adopted and the cost of training.
Deputy Commissioner Kelly, however, said that the .38 was still the safest and most efficient weapon and that there were misconceptions about the 9-millimeter's effectiveness.
He said that the semiautomatic tends to jam, whereas the .38-caliber does not. He disagreed that police officers were "outgunned," noting that in 67 gunfights in 1990, 20 percent of bullets fired by police officers hit assailants, while only 6 percent of bullets fired at officers hit their mark.
But a real concern, he said, is accidental shootings, with nearly 14 accidental firings per 1,000 semiautomatics, compared with less than one accident for every 1,000 revolvers. He attributed the difference to a trigger pull that is too light in semiautomatics.
Chief Taylor said that the housing police would also test the guns, but he too supported the continued use of the .38-caliber in high-rise housing projects. Ninety-four 9-millimeter pistols will be issued, mostly to narcotics specialists and detectives, he said.
 
Senator Supports New Gun
 After hearing testimony, Senator Gold said he was convinced that the 9-millimeter was effective, reliable and safe and that police officials were overly concerned.
Of 4,200 transit police officers, 1,000 have been using the 9-millimeter pistols in the subways, said Assistant Transit Police Chief Walter D. Mickulas. The guns have been used in three subway incidents; there have been no accidental discharges, he said.
Most proponents said a major benefit of the 9-millimeter was what Chief Mickulas called "the psychological advantage" police officers felt they had in carrying the weapons.
"I think I'll feel safer that I'm not at a disadvantage from the start like now," said Officer Chris Minogue as he patrolled West 38th Street. "If a guy knows that I have the same firepower as he does, he might think twice before taking me on."
A half-dozen other officers in the Midtown South Precinct favored the 9-millimeter. But some wondered if they would ever get to use the gun. "To be honest," Officer Mark Mulitz said, "I'll only believe this when I have the gun in my holster."

HEADLINE: THE GATES HEARINGS;
Excerpts From C.I.A. Official's Testimony on Nomination of Gates as Director

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony by Charles E. Allen, a former national intelligence officer for counterterrorism for the Central Intelligence Agency, at the hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence on the nomination of Robert M. Gates as Director of Central Intelligence, with questioning by Senators Sam Nunn, David L. Boren and Frank H. Murkowski. The transcript was provided by the Federal News Service.
 
STATEMENT BY CHARLES E. ALLEN
 . . . I was involved in the White House Iranian initiative from September 1985 until it became publicly known in November 1986. . . . 
 During the first phase, I was asked by Lieutenant Colonel North to coordinate the collection of intelligence on the Iranian initiative and to protect closely this White House effort. During this period, I kept Mr. Casey and Mr. McMahon fully informed on the intelligence collected. Moreover, some of the intelligence was provided to Mr. Clair George, the Deputy Director of Operations. In keeping with Lieutenant Colonel North's instruction, I did not inform Mr. Gates, even though he technically was my immediate supervisor as Chairman of the National Intelligence Council.
During the period September 1985 until January 1986, I never once mentioned this activity or my role in it to Mr. Gates, although I learned after the initiative became public that he may have had some knowledge of it in December 1985.
My first direct contact with Mr. Gates on the Iranian initiative came after the Presidential finding was signed on 17 January 1986. . . .
Throughout the winter and spring of 1986, I occasionally briefed Mr. Gates on the status of the initiative and provided him with some, but not all, of the intelligence that was being collected. . . .
I saw Mr. Gates on 1 October 1986. I expressed concern to Mr. Gates over the problems with the White House-directed initiative and its eroding operational security. . . .
I told Mr. Gates that I was concerned about one other aspect of the Iranian initiative: the impasse over the price of arms being sold to the Iranians. I said that I could not prove it. But I thought that proceeds from the arms sales might have been diverted to support the contras in Central America.
 
Briefing Gates and Casey
 I recall in the context of that meeting describing the impasse over the pricing of the Hawk spare parts and the refusal of the Iranian Government officials involved to pay for the parts because the price was five to six times their actual cost, noting the desperate financial straits of Manucher Ghorbanifar [the Iranian arms dealer and middleman in the Reagan Administration arms sales to Iran] and his frantic call to me in August 1986 when he insisted his commission on the price of Hawk spare parts averaged only about 40 percent, mentioning Lieutenant Colonel North's reference to the reserve and his conversation with me on 9 September 1986, an indication that substantial profits were being accrued from the arms to Iran -- from the arms sales to Iran, pointing out that Mr. Hakim and Maj. Gen. Secord [Albert Hakim and Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, who replaced Mr. Ghorbanifar as "channels" to Iran] directly controlled the second channel to Iran and at the same time evidently also were principals involved in the private effort to aid the Contra struggle against the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua. I said I could not prove a diversion was occurring, but that my analysis indicated this could be the case.
Mr. Gates appeared startled and disturbed that the White House would involve itself in such a dubious activity, but then stated that this was potentially very serious and directed that I brief Director Casey immediately. I met with Mr. Casey on 7 October. Mr. Gates also attended. I briefed Mr. Casey on the pricing impasse, the discrepancy between what the Iranians and Mr. Ghorbanifar thought was a reasonable price and what U.S. intermediaries evidently were charging for the Hawk spare parts. I further explained the key roles being played by Mr. Hakim and Maj. Gen. Secord in managing the new channel to Iran and conducting activities in Central America in support of the contras. I stated that this was one of several factors that had left me to conclude that profits obtained from the arms sales were going to the contras, although I lacked direct proof.
At this meeting, Mr. Gates shared my concern about a possible diversion and indicated that the issue needed to be pursued. Mr. Casey seemed surprised by my statements and asked me to put my concerns in writing, which I agreed to do.

 	 	 		. . .	 	In hindsight, those of us who thought that a diversion had occurred should have raised the matter during the preparation of Mr. Casey's testimony. I considered raising the matter on the afternoon of 20 November when we met in the D.C.I. conference room with Mr. Casey to go over the draft testimony. I felt inhibited by the presence of a large number of officials, some of whom had just learned of this highly sensitive effort. I was also uncertain how to characterize the allegations of diversion, especially since the initiative was directed from the White House and since the evidence I had was still circumstantial. I believed I had already discharged my proper responsibility.
Even though the issue of the diversion of profits made from the arms sales to Iran was not included in Mr. Casey's testimony, I did not consider the issue closed, nor did I believe either Mr. Casey or Mr. Gates. Both had encouraged me to pursue the questions about improprieties relating to the initiative.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
QUESTIONS BY SENATOR NUNN
 Q. During this time, Mr. Allen, you had these suspicions and you conveyed those suspicions to various people in the C.I.A. And during that time you were meeting with Colonel North, I assume, frequently, were you not?
A. I met with Colonel North several times a week, and I talked to him on the secure phone several times a day.
Q. Why didn't you just ask him, or did you just ask him, "Colonel North, are funds being diverted?"
A. I did not put it to him that way. I put it in the form of: "Why are the prices so high? Why is there this funding impasse?" And each time I was given virtually a different story by Lieut. Col. North. Usually, you know, Ghorbanifar is the problem. Or, reopening production lines is a problem. Just go on and keep this story consistent with both Mr. Ghorbanifar and with Mr. Nir [Amiram Nir, a counterterrorism official for Israel]. And he was most emphatic.
It's a good question. Why didn't I? Because I thought it was getting fairly close to the bone at the White House to accuse them of what would appear to be a very imprudent thing to do, if they were taking profits, endangering the lives of hostages in Lebanon, and applying it to support another operation in Central America.
Q. But you indeed were accusing them of that with your superiors. Wouldn't it have been the logical thing to do to simply ask Col. North whether he was doing it before you basically aroused the suspicions or while you were arousing the suspicions and while you were working with him on a daily basis?
A. I could have gone that direction, but I decided to go up to the top through the C.I.A. and to the Director Casey so he could go as he thought proper to the White House. And I think he handled it quite well.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
QUESTIONS BY SENATOR BOREN
 Q. Well, Mr. Allen, it could be -- now, let me just say this, could it not have been that Mr. Casey did know about the diversion and that he wasn't so shocked and surprised about the diversion but he was shocked and surprised by the inept way in which it was being carried out, that the financing was going on and so on, and therefore he was shocked -- he might have well been shocked to learn all these problems with Mr. Furmark, but he might have known about the diversion and his shock might have been, "Oh, this has been so mismanaged now it's all going to blow sky-high." Is that another possible hypothesis?
A. That's strictly a hypothesis. I have no evidence that Mr. Casey was thinking along those lines.
Q. . . . You obviously think Mr. Gates was not knowledgeable about the diversion -- I assume you still think so -- at that time.
A. I firmly think that, yes.

 
Casey Walking Fine Line
 Q. Now, implied in your testimony is the feeling that, at least at that point in time, you also trusted Mr. Casey and did not believe that he knew about the diversion, at least in toto?
A. Contemporaneously, I had no reason to believe that he knew of the diversion.
Q. . . . Have you drawn any conclusions yourself or have you reached -- or have you speculated yourself, not in terms of what you believed at the time but what you believe now, in terms of whether Mr. Casey knew about the diversion when he was talking to you through this whole period?
A. Other than Lieut. Col. North's statement, which he gave under oath, I have no reason to believe he knew -- that D.C.I. Casey knew of the diversion. I have no personal evidence of that. I found that Mr. Casey sometimes walked a fine line, but he never crossed the line, based on what I've seen of the Director. And I have no reason to believe that he was deliberately deceiving me at that time.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
QUESTIONS BY SENATOR MURKOWSKI
 Q. I have questions on behalf of one of our colleagues, Senator Warner, with regard to the intelligence warning responsibility that you have. It's the understanding of the Senator from Virginia that you gave some warning on Iraq's intentions towards Kuwait in 1990. Is that correct?
A. That's correct.
Q. I also understand, on behalf of Senator Warner, that warning in itself can be rather controversial and not always popular. Based on your long relationship with Mr. Gates, I wonder if you could tell the committee how you view the mission of warning, its importance, what will Mr. Gates do, in your opinion, if he's confirmed, to improve the system by which we collect, analyze and disseminate warning.
A. Well, I believe that Mr. Gates's highest priority is to warn of threats to U.S. national security interests worldwide, and that his responsibility is to alert the President and policy officials as early as possible, based on reliable information that a threat to U.S. security is developing. In my view, in my conversation with Mr. Gates, he is an individual who really wants to strengthen the warning function. He recognizes that there will always be surprises to U.S. foreign policy, but I think he believes, with the proper techniques, the proper methodologies of warning, and also with regional specialists participating, that we can do a better job and we can avoid the surprise. . . .
He believes we need to do a better job in political intelligence. We can warn a lot about military mobilization, but there were political indicators relating to Mr. Saddam Hussein's intentions and plans to invade Kuwait. There were economic indicators that developed prior to the military mobilization. Once the military mobilization began around the 19th of July, 1990, we were able in warning to fairly well present a convincing case by the 25th of July that Saddam Hussein would invade Kuwait.
So I think -- I am very confident Mr. Gates will take a very strong hand in warning.
Q. Yes, and if I can go back, the general presumption was that we had little or no intelligence, or if we did we did not act on it. And I gather you're saying because of the political nuances, it was difficult to, I guess, come out publicly with any kind of a condemnation of Iraq early? In view of what they've done with the Kurds and their record, why would that be such a difficult thing to do? Clearly we were very dissatisfied with what was happening.

 	 	 		. . .	 	A. Well, I think, as Mr. Kerr [Richard Kerr, Acting Director of the C.I.A.] has testified, and I don't want to get into classified, but in closed session, and I support -- over in the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence -- I believe that the intelligence community performed rather well during that period.
I think to some degree sometimes we tell the policy level things that don't correspond with actual policy initiatives or thinking. But I think this is the strength of the intelligence community, is to be very independent and as objective as possible.
I think overall the Defense Intelligence Agency, C.I.A. and I, as head of the National Warning Community, did a very credible job in warning.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Senate Intelligence Committee conferring at confirmation hearings for Robert M. Gates yesterday were, from left, Senators Sam Nunn, Howard M. Metzenbaum and David L. Boren, the chairman. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mulroney Proposes New Canadian Framework to Stall Separatism

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, today proposed the most comprehensive constitutional overhaul since the nation's birth in 1867, recommending a new federal structure aimed at stalling the separatist movement in French-speaking Quebec.
The Government proposal, which was presented in a package called "Shaping Canada's Future Together," stressed the reaffirmation of a binding Canadian identity and called for the strengthening of economic integration by striking down trade barriers between the provinces. In his address to the House of Commons, the Canadian leader declared that "renewal is what Canadians everywhere seek for our country -- not confrontation, not division, not rupture." 
 Essentially, the plan is intended to fashion a new relationship by granting Quebec constitutional recognition as a "distinct" society because of its French language, culture and civil law. Its adoption, in amendments to the Constitution would require approval of Parliament and the endorsement of 7 out of 10 provinces with at least 50 percent of the population..
 
New Inducements Included
 An earlier long-pending unity plan, known as the Meech Lake Agreement, foundered last year over a similar proposal that aroused complaints in key parts of English-speaking Canada about granting the province a special legislative status and powers to override the 1982 Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Canada's bill of rights. Unlike the present proposal the Meech Lake arrangement needed the approval of all provinces.
In its efforts to ease passage this time, the Government is including as inducements some changes long sought by English-speaking Canada, including an elected Senate that could delay federal legislation for six months and, like the Senate of the United States, ratify federal appointments. Currently members of the Canadian Upper House are appointed by the Government to serve until they reach the age of 75. In recent years a rallying cry in western Canada has been for an "equal, effective and elected Senate." to replace what is essentially a body patterned after the British House of Lords with very limited powers and a tradition of docile support for the Government.
As a parliamentary democracy, Canada's Government business at the national level is done almost exclusively by the House of Commons. The leader of the majority party of the House of Commons, for the past seven years Mr. Mulroney of the Progressive Conservative Party, is prime minister.
 
Addresses Trade Barriers
 The country's economic ties also would be dramatically altered under the plan. Interprovincial trade barriers, which, for example, keep Moosehead beer bottled in New Brunswick, from selling in Ontario, or prevents Ontario-made bricks from being used in construction in Quebec, would be canceled and a new federal-provincial Council of the Federation would be created to solve economic disputes between the various provinces and the Federal Government.
The provinces would gain greater influence on national economic policy-making, including the running of the Bank of Canada, which controls interest rates.
 
'National Conscience'
 Other highlights of the plan that has been the subject of intense and at times divisive debate in the Mulroney Cabinet the past summer, include:
*A "Canada Clause" of the Constitution declaring what it means to be a Canadian. Among other points cited by the 59-page Government document outlining the proposals is "the importance of a national conscience that spurs us to make our contribution to global peace and development."
*Self-government within 10 years for the estimated 500,000 Indian and Eskimo peoples of Canada. The Government's document and briefers stressed that this would be achieved within the framework of both the Constitution and the charter of rights and that provincial laws of general application would continue to apply. The opposition of Indian groups to granting a special status to Quebec without obtaining similar rights for themselves had proven critical in capsizing the Meech Lake arrangement.
*New restrictions on the existing power of provincial governments to override the charter of rights.
 
New Mechanisms for Governing
 "What we're trying to do is set up new mechanisms to govern the country better," said Constitutional Affairs Minister Joe Clark, himself a former prime minister, whom Mr. Mulroney placed in direct charge of developing the proposals.
Early reaction was cautious and generally positive, except for the separatists of Quebec. Lucien Bouchard, leader of the separatist faction in the House of Commons known as the Bloc Quebecois, called the package "dangerous to Quebec."
Liberal Party leader Jean Chretien, criticized many aspects of the plan but added as a conciliatory note: "Let us demonstrate over the next few months thoughtfulness, reason, generosity, a willingness to accommodate and a skill to negotiate."
Preston Manning, leader of the Reform Party, a new protest party centered in Alberta which has arisen in opposition to what it regards as the constant series of deals to assuage Quebec, said that "On the surface there is some movement on Senate reform, but I think there's still a long way to go to accommodate alienation, not just in the west but all over the country."
 
Taking It on the Road
 The proposals now go to a 30-person Special Joint Committee of the Parliament, which has a mandate to travel widely and spur a national debate. On the basis of possible new input, it would then make suggestions for further refinements that would be brought back to the Government by the end of next February. The Government would then frame the legislation for the House of Commons and begin trying to sell the plan to the provinces.
Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa has enacted legislation mandating a referendum on sovereignty by the end of next year if the rest of Canada fails to come up with satisfactory proposals to keep Quebec within the federation.
Mr. Mulroney, who is hoping to use the national unity issue to reverse his record low popularity and win a third term in office -- he must call elections within two years -- dismissed the objections of the Quebec separatists.
"If we had put the Declaration of Independence and the Lord's Prayer on the table, the P.Q. and the B.Q. would have said it's insufficient," he said, referring to the Parti Quebecois and the Bloc Quebecois. "We are not going to be able to deal with the phonies who say they're interested in Canada but whose real objective is the destruction of the nation."

HEADLINE: THE GATES HEARINGS;
Early Indicators of Kuwait Invasion

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
In his Congressional testimony today, Charles E. Allen, the senior intelligence official, disclosed for the first time that as early as January 1990, he and other Central Intelligence Agency officials began to consider the possibility that Iraq might attack Kuwait.
Under questioning by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, at Robert M. Gates's confirmation hearing today, Mr. Allen, a senior analyst at the agency, said he had not received any special instructions in 1990 from the Deputies Committee, a panel of high-ranking Administration officials headed by Mr. Gates, to keep a closer watch on Iraq. 
 "I did not personally receive any such guidance," he said. Mr. Allen added, however, that he had the mandate to watch Iraq nonetheless.
"There were economic indicators that developed prior to the military mobilization," said Mr. Allen, a 32-year veteran of the agency. "Once the military mobilization began around the 19th of July, 1990, we were able in warning to fairly well present a convincing case by the 25th of July that Saddam Hussein would invade Kuwait."
On Aug. 2, he did.
Mr. Allen said that in conjunction with the Defense Intelligence Agency and the military's Central Command, his staff identified a possible threat to Kuwait from Iraq as early as January 1990. But that warning and more refined forecasts later went largely ignored in the Bush Administration.
Mr. Allen warned that the intelligence community needed to respond more actively to potential threats rather than wait until a crisis was imminent.
"We can always warn at the last minute when it's obvious that war is going to occur," he said. "But if you warn early enough, you can truly give the policymaker the tools to avert and defuse a crisis."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Ties Dinkins Aid to Payroll Cuts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Even as he proposed to recharge New York City's image and economy with a range of proposed building projects, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo warned the Dinkins administration yesterday not to expect too much quick help in balancing its budget unless it cuts the city payroll more.
The Governor's warning, delivered amid dollops of good news, put Mayor David N. Dinkins on notice that he expects the city to deliver on its pledges to reshape its spending, especially now that Mr. Cuomo has risked involving himself more deeply than ever in the city's fiscal problems by proposing to have the state assume the city's share of Medicaid costs over the next several years. 
 For his part, Mr. Dinkins said, "The spotlight has never left us." He and his aides said they would revise the city's four-year financial plan by mid-November to spell out more cost-saving moves, pressing anew for concessions from municipal unions that they have been seeking in vain for months.
Mayoral aides are drafting their own specifics for how many more city jobs should be cut through layoffs and attrition, how a state takeover of the city's $2-billion-a-year Medicaid costs would work, and whether it could happen faster than Mr. Cuomo has suggested.
They are also reviewing the possibility that hundreds of millions of dollars in aid from the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation could help finance tax cuts or stretch out the pace of further jobs reductions to ease the pain, and are studying the creation of new public authorities to maintain bridges or dispose of garbage financed by new tolls or fees.
 
'It's Not My Place'
 But Mr. Cuomo made it clear again yesterday that help will not come from the Municipal Assistance Corporation until the city has made its own cost-cutting plans clearer. His comments, in a speech to business and civic leaders in Manhattan, underscored the differences still to be worked out between City Hall and Albany, even as the Governor allied himself more firmly with the Dinkins administration in confronting the city's sprawling needs and burdens.
"I'm not going to presume to tell the city" what to do, Mr. Cuomo told the Association for a Better New York in a breakfast meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria in the second of a pair of public pronouncements since Monday. "It's not my place."
But the Governor cited his elimination of 15,000 jobs from the state work force since last fall and his refusal to grant raises to state employees' unions, in contrast to Mr. Dinkins's decision to grant raises. "You pay a price for it, certainly you do," Mr. Cuomo said, noting that angry workers had marched on the Governor's Mansion in protest. "But the reality is the unions will have to be at the table, M.A.C. will have to be at the table and I think they'll work it out."
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses, said: "I think the ball is in the city's court, and I think it's pretty clear what that expectation is, and it has to do with what the Mayor proposes to do with the size of the municipal work force."
 
'Has to Work With Labor'
 Municipal union leaders who heard the Governor's speech generally praised it, but they also repeated that they were not prepared to make concessions until they, too, see a long-term plan from the city.
"I want to work with the Governor, but the Governor's got to understand that he has to work with labor," said Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest city workers' union.
Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said of the Dinkins administration: "There is no fiscal plan for this city that goes beyond 1992. We are disbelieving."
Privately, some senior Dinkins aides described Mr. Cuomo's grab bag of development projects, many of them long discussed, as "old wine in new bottles" that might not be uncorked in time to benefit the political fortunes of either the Governor or the Mayor. They voiced some frustration that his proposal for assuming the city's Medicaid costs remained sketchy and appeared unlikely to generate large savings for several years, even if approved by the Legislature.
But they also acknowledged, with a mix of gratitude and envy, that by putting so many ideas together in a splashy slide show and stem-winding speech, and embracing the Mayor's call for a Medicaid takeover after first resisting it, Mr. Cuomo had managed to generate some optimism about the city's prospects, whatever the outcome of the proposals.
"There's no way the Governor can lose on this," one aide said.
Cuomo aides were equally quick to paint the Governor's announcements as a victory for the Mayor.
"He's a winner," Vincent Tese, the Governor's chief economic development adviser, said of Mr. Dinkins.
But there were stresses. Dinkins aides were encouraged by the Governor's proposals to take over Medicaid costs, ease state regulations that require the city to provide certain services in certain ways and to redistribute state education aid to give the city its proportional share.
They were quick to note, however, that Mr. Cuomo had not addressed other state-regulated programs which the State Financial Control Board recently cited as among the growing costs burdening the city's budget, from welfare payments to workers's compensation, health insurance and pension guidelines.
Mr. Cuomo took pains in his presentations to counter any notion that he was meddling in the city's affairs, or trying to dictate policy choices, or seeking greater powers over city spending by the control board, which he heads. The board was set up to oversee the city's finances in the fiscal crisis of the 70's and Mr. Dinkins has vowed to avoid a greater role for it at all costs.
"This is the Mayor's city," Mr. Cuomo said. "We are partners at his request and at his sufferance."
 
Cut Costs Permanently
 Still, Mr. Cuomo and Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, would both continue to hold considerable sway over the city's options under some of the Governor's proposals. Mr. Rohatyn has repeatedly insisted that he cannot provide the city with about $1 billion by refinancing some of the corporation's bonds without assurances that the city will cut costs permanently and reduce the size of the work force.
The corporation was set up during the crisis in the 70's to borrow money on the city's behalf when it was barred from the credit markets, with its bonds backed by first call on the city's sales tax revenues. Now Mr. Cuomo proposes giving Mr. Rohatyn new powers, by seeking legislation that would enable the M.A.C. to issue new bonds for the first time since the early 1980's to finance building projects on the city's behalf, since its superior credit rating allows it to do so at lower interest costs.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Kent L. Barwick; Sally Goodgold; Rev. Timothy S. Healy; Daivd R. Jones; Elizabeth Holtzman; Ruth W. Messinger
 
Chart: "Reactions to the Cuomo Plan"

HEADLINE: CUNY Student Leaders Run Up Big Tab

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Student leaders at the City University of New York were battling to keep tuition low. In doing so, they spent $49,000 on a three-day lobbying excursion to the Albany Hilton and $13,000 on a limousine service that chauffeured them around New York City.
The chairman of the University Student Senate, Jean LaMarre, also hired his twin sister and his best friend as his top assistants at annual salaries of $24,000 and $27,000 respectively -- roughly as much as starting instructors at the university make. 
 He and the other leaders spent all that money with the knowledge of the university's top officials, who approved each bill and gently admonished the students to be a little more frugal. They even approved air fare for three students to the Ivory Coast at a cost of $4,500 so they could attend an event called the African-American Summit.
Yesterday, the university's officials were shamefaced as they struggled to dampen a controversy over the expenditures after they were disclosed by a student news service and later reported in The Daily News.
 
Tacit Acquiescence
 But the officials seemed hard put to escape the implication that they had been giving their students some wrongheaded lessons in economics and management.
City University students may be poorer than those of years past, but their leaders have often adopted a more opulent style of command than student leaders of the past. And they have done so with the tacit acquiescence of administrators eager to maintain calm on their periodically unruly campuses. Many student leaders have fax machines and other high-technology equipment. One of the senate expenditures was $2,209 for electronic pager service.
Much of the senate's spending came as it was leading a protest against a proposed tuition increase that culminated in a student strike that shut down most of the university's campuses for up to three weeks. The senate's $345,000 budget this year is financed by an 85-cent activity fee each semester placed on each of the university's 200,000 students.
Top university officials, eager to avoid a repeat of a scandal five years ago over improper outlays by student leaders, warned the students last March that they were spending money like Wall Street executives, but went on to approve most of the expenditures and did nothing to stop the spending until yesterday.
Both the approvals and warnings were given by Tilden LeMelle, who resigned as vice chancellor for student affairs last spring to become president of the University of the District of Columbia. Mr. LeMelle did not return telephone calls to his office seeking comment.
Jay Hershenson, vice chancellor for university relations, said the university believed in letting students run their own affairs and has monitored but not interfered in the Student Senate's decisions. But after the public disclosures, the university's chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds, imposed the state's standards on travel expenses on the students, rather than the looser university standards.
In an interview, Mr. LaMarre, a 23-year-old senior at Brooklyn College, said the allegations about overspending were "a blatant attempt to try to undermine me and the organization" by another student officer, Rafael Alvarez, the vice chairman for fiscal affairs, who is considering a bid for Mr. LaMarre's job in elections next month.
"There is nothing that we spent, nothing that we purchased that was not legitimate and that was not approved by university officials," Mr. LaMarre said.
Ron Goulet, director of sales for the Albany Hilton, a hotel that state legislators and professional lobbyists often favor because of its proximity to the Legislature, said 200 students rented more than 100 rooms at the Hilton at $70 a room per night in February. The students had the hotel cater almost every meal over the three days and a reception at a cost of $26,000. Contracts for the visit were approved beforehand by university officials.
The more than $13,000 in limousine charges were billed to a single company, XYZ Car Service in Brooklyn, which is also used by members of the university's board of trustees. Assuming that an average trip cost $10, Mr. LaMarre and his associates would have had to make 1,300 trips since January to spend that amount. A university official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the bill was as high as it was because students demanded cars equipped with cellular telephones.
The expenditures were a sharp contrast to those of a decade or two ago, when student leaders scrounged accommodations with friends on trips to Albany and used the subway to get around New York. Mr. Hershenson was chairman of the Student Senate between 1974 and 1976 and recalled that on his Albany trips he stayed at a State University dormitory.
In 1989, roughly 30 students stayed at the Albany Hilton on a lobbying trip, the Hilton official, Mr. Goulet, said.
The Student Senate is made up of about 50 delegates from the university's 21 campuses. Theoretically, the senate is supposed to advise the university's board of trustees on issues affecting students, but in practice it spends much of the $345,000 it receives on advocacy and lobbying with City Hall and in Albany. The senate also puts out its own newspaper, though only one issue was published last year.
Mr. LaMarre, who has been chairman since January, is a speech major and the winner of a national debating contest. He receives a $650 monthly stipend for his senate work and lives with his mother in Flatbush, Brooklyn. He also was reimbursed by the senate for $8,197 in personal expenses.
"I'm one of the poorest students," he said. "I receive full financial aid."
In the interview, he said the senate felt it got a reasonable price from the Albany Hilton for a conference that trained students in the techniques of lobbying and gave them firsthand experience with legislators. He said that the cost came out to only $45 a student, but the arithmetic for having 200 students stay for three days at a cost of $49,000 works out to something closer to $81 a student per night.
The limousine service, he said, was necessary so that he and other student leaders could get around town late at night.
He said his sister and his best friend were hired with the senate's approval.
"I'd rather work with a friend than an enemy," he said.
