HEADLINE: Languages Becoming Hot Subject In Colleges

 BODY:
More college students in the United States are studying foreign languages than ever before, with Japanese, Russian and Spanish showing the greatest growth in enrollment, according to a new survey by the Modern Language Association of America.
The survey released last week found that nearly 1.2 million students were enrolled in language courses other than English last fall, an increase of 18 percent since 1986. 
 The survey, financed by the United States Department of Education, was based on written questionnaires to all 2,797 two-year and four-year colleges and universities; 98.2 percent respondved. The survey used enrollment figures from 1986 to 1990.
The study of foreign languages has been growing steadily since 1980, but for the first time since 1965 the percentage of students studying languages has increased markedly in relation to the percentage of students attending college, according to Phyllis Franklin, executive director of the Modern Language Association, made up of teachers and scholars in the language field. Since 1980, the number of college students studying languages has increased 30 percent, while the number of students attending college has increased 15 percent, she said.
The survey found that Spanish, French and German maintained their ranking as the three most popular foreign languages, in that order, but that the number of students studying French declined by 1 percent, from 275,328 in 1986 to 272,555 in 1990. Enrollments in Ancient Greek and Hebrew also declined.
The association's survey included culture and literature courses that were taught in a foreign language.
The enrollment in Japanese classes nearly doubled, the survey found. It said the number of students studying Japanese in the fall of 1990 was 45,717, compared with 23,454 in 1986. The survey said 44,384 students were studying Russian in 1990, an increase of more than 30 percent over 1986.
Together, Japanese and Russian accounted for about 8 percent of the 1990 enrollment in foreign language courses. Spanish had the highest number of students, 533,609, and the highest overall percentage, 45 percent. Its growth in enrollment from 1986 to 1990 was nearly 30 percent.
In the association's last survey, which studied enrollment figures from 1983 to 1986, Japanese showed the highest percentage increase, followed by Chinese, Portuguese and Russian, in that order.
 
Findings Provide Encouragement
 Helene Zimmer-Loew, president of the Joint National Committee for Languages, which represents 41 language associations, said: "We're thrilled to see this. It is very heartening to all of us in the field."
She said that the increase in students taking language courses probably reflects interest in countries that are economic powers or hotbeds of political activity.
"I don't think this reflects thousands and thousands of language majors or people who are going to be language teachers, although we always hope they will choose it," Ms. Zimmer-Loew said. "I think many are majoring in business and they see a second language as an absolute necessity because of a shrinking global economy."
 
Concerns Arise
 The study does not disclose what level of language the students are studying. Richard D. Lambert, director of the National Foreign Language Center, which also tracks foreign-language study, said that while the findings were encouraging, more information is needed on what types of students are studying languages and whether they continue with the languages to advanced levels.
"The question," he said, "is are we still working with a limited set of students from the arts and sciences? Are we lengthening as well as broadening? In terms of national policy, I think that's an important question."
The enrollment decline for French classes concerned Dr. Fred M. Jenkins, executive director of the American Association of Teachers of French, who said the popularity of Spanish was taking away students who might otherwise pursue French.
"We are not happy, and we are undertaking a drive of our own to make students, particularly on the secondary-school level, more aware of French and what it stands for," Dr. Jenkins said.
 
Spanish Is Spoken
 The popularity of Spanish is attributed partly to the influx of Hispanic people into the United States and partly to the fact that students find Spanish a useful language in this country.
"It is here; its time has come," said Dr. James R. Chatham, executive director of the American Association of Teachers of Spanish and Portuguese.
Meanwhile, the secondary-school level is also showing growth in foreignlanguage study, according to a study, not yet published, by the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages.
The council found that in the 1990-1991 academic year, about 30 percent of public school students in grades 7 to 12 were studying foreign languages, which is a 5 percent increase over 1985, the last time the council conducted a survey.
"The best news as far as we're concerned is this has been a period of some sustained growth," said C. Edward Scebold, president of the 6,000-member organization.

HEADLINE: Stall in Weicker's Union Negotiations

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Already bitter labor talks between Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and the unions representing state workers broke off today, with both sides saying they were nowhere near agreement on a package of wage and benefit concessions tied to the state's new income tax.
The breakdown raised the likelihood that residents could see further cuts in state services and more employee layoffs, some of which could coincide with the first impact next week of the new income tax that was intended to secure those state services. Among the cuts being considered is a partial closing of some state agencies, which might shut their doors for one or two days every month. 
 Mr. Weicker, a former Republican who was elected last year as a third party independent governor, has said that he needs more than $300 million in wage, benefit and pension concessions from the unions. He has accused the unions of reneging on an agreement signed this spring that guaranteed that amount, mostly in benefit deferrals that would have to be made up in later years. Union leaders say that earlier compact died on July 1, with the start of the new fiscal year, and that pay raises that took effect on that date will not be given back.
The talks broke up after an announcement today by administration negotiators that contrary to its early pledges, layoffs might be unavoidable in the 45,000-member work force even if the unions agree to the full concession package. The state sent layoff notices to about 2,500 workers last week -- the first wave in what they said could reach as many as 8,000 layoffs -- but the officials stressed that if the concession package could be signed, the layoffs would all be rescinded.
 
Could Not Be Guaranteed
 Labor leaders said the new wrinkle eliminated any motivation for them to voluntarily reopen their signed contracts and give back benefits, or even to continue the talks at all because the state was in effect saying job security could not be guaranteed regardless of what happened at the bargaining table.
"It's insane to think about giving something back and getting nothing in return," said Steven Perruccio, president of the Connecticut Employees Union Independent, which represents about 7,000 service and maintenance workers.
Mr. Weicker's press secretary, Avice A. Meehan, said that the legislature, in passing the $7.7 billion budget last month that created the income tax, also cut about $30 million in spending that has only come to light in recent days as the document has been analyzed. She said that agency heads were meeting today with administration budget officials to try and address the gap, and that some combination of layoffs and other service cuts might be necessary, with an outside limit of perhaps 1,000 layoffs a possibility.
The state employee unions were a major ally in Mr. Weicker's summerlong fight to impose a state income tax on Connecticut. Mr. Weicker said the new tax would allow other taxes to be cut, and so stimulate the faltering economy. The unions, in making the same case, also conceded that a large new revenue stream would make their members' jobs more secure.
The prospect that the unions could win on both fronts, keeping both their wage increases and the heightened job security from the revenues raised by the tax, has angered some lawmakers who voted for the wage tax. It has also bolstered the effort led by the Republican Party to repeal the income tax and substitute it with a traditional sales-tax based budget.
The repeal effort is expected to culminate next month with a proposed special session of the legislature. Lawmakers said that today's stumbling block in the labor talks made it even more likely that the concessions issue would hang over the repeal effort, though with uncertain impact.

HEADLINE: F.A.A. EASES PLAN FOR PHASING OUT NOISIEST JETLINERS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Responding to pressure from airlines and the White House, the Federal Aviation Administration today eased its plan to phase out the nation's noisier planes.
By allowing airlines to continue operating many of their older and noisier planes, the decision will delay for several years some of the benefits for people who live near airports. 
 Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said he had ordered that the timetable be made more flexible out of concern for the economic viability of the airlines. He acknowledged that the rules issued today would probably be challenged in court.
Mr. Skinner said the rules put the industry on a path that would eliminate most, if not all, of the louder planes by the year 2000, in keeping with a law Congress passed last year. He estimated that the number of people exposed to the worst noise would drop to 400,000 from about 2.7 million within the decade.
 
Debated for Months
 The agency's proposal had been debated for months, as a coalition of airlines and airplane leasing companies recommended the main change adopted today. The industry generally welcomed the final rule. But the stage appeared to be set for a confrontation with some local airports.
An initial proposal would have required airlines to quickly begin eliminating the noisier planes from their fleets, removing one-fourth of them by the end of 1994, and continuing the reductions until they were all gone by the end of the century. The new proposal allows airlines to add quieter planes first without necessarily removing the noisier ones.
The aviation agency, which is part of the Transportation Department, said it would carefully examine any efforts by local authorities to impose stricter noise-reduction plans than the one in the Federal rule. Mr. Skinner said the agency might go to court to overturn local rules that were too costly to the airlines or that hampered the efficient operation of the interstate aviation system.
"I and all of us in the Administration are very concerned with the financial health of the airline industry," he said, in explaining why the rules were modified.
The aviation agency has estimated that the rules will cost the industry up to $4.5 billion; the industry estimates the cost to be many times greater.
Those costs would have to be passed on to consumers or taken out of airline profits. The rules announced today allow airlines in financial distress to apply for permission to miss the rules' deadlines, but officials said they did not expect to see many waivers allowed.
 
Ultimate Goal Remains
 The ultimate goal of the rules has not changed: to attain a fleet of commercial jetliners that meet the quietest noise standards, known as Stage 3 aircraft, by the year 2000 or shortly afterward. There are now about 1,880 Stage 3 planes in the nation's fleet, accounting for about 45 percent of all jetliners; the 2,270 other planes are noisier Stage 2 planes.
The difference in noise between a Stage 2 plane, like a Boeing 727 or McDonnell Douglas DC-9, and a Stage 3 plane, like a Boeing 757, is easy to recognize from the ground. The noisier planes seem deeper in timbre, their vibrations are more penetrating and they can be heard from much farther away.
With the advent of the newer planes, which are also more efficient to operate, the number of people exposed to unbearably high noise around airports has been steadily declining for decades, a trend that would continue with or without the new rule.
The question is how fast the improvement must occur, and whether the Federal Government should dictate the pace or allow local politicians and airport operators to set up a regulatory patchwork across the nation.
The rules announced today, after months of public comment and behind-the-scenes lobbying over a draft proposal, would still force airlines either to buy new airplanes or to put quieter engines or "hush kits" on older planes.
But the rule issued today allows airlines, if they choose, to move toward compliance at first by increasing the numbers of quieter aircraft in their fleets, rather than by starting right away to eliminate the noisier ones.
Administration officials acknowledged that this means noise will not be reduced as much in the next three to five years as would have happened under the aviation agency's initial proposal early this year.
 
Airlines That Benefit
 The change will be of substantial help to some airlines, like Southwest Airlines or Northwest Airlines, which grew rapidly in the past decade and own a lot of noisier planes that have plenty of useful life in them.
The most prosperous airlines, including giants like United Airlines and American Airlines , are already well on the track toward complying with the new rules, and will not have to adjust their plans, officials said.
The new rules are of particular interest in New York and New Jersey, where amid a steady outcry by local residents, state lawmakers and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are considering requiring rapid reductions in noisy flights.
But the new rules are important from coast to coast. In Los Angeles, city and airport officials have been negotiating all summer with the Federal officials to draft a local noise rule that would control airline flights without overstepping the authority that the Federal Government is willing to cede to the city.
If even a few big cities adopt rules that are much stricter than the Federal rule, the airlines would have to pay more attention to local rules than to the Federal schedule because they cannot efficiently schedule their quietest planes to fly only to certain locations.
Because of these considerations, Federal officials acknowledged today that the rules are likely to be challenged by local officials, airlines or citizens groups -- possibly by all sides at once.
Patrick J. Russell, a lawyer from Far Hills, N.J., who is a member of the New Jersey Coalition Against Aircraft Noise and a leader of a national coalition of similarly minded groups, sharply criticized the Administration's announcement.
"Certainly we are not happy about it in the National Airport Watch Group," he said, "and we are certainly not happy about it in New Jersey." He said the group would continue to press for stricter local regulations.
The regulations were issued under a law passed by Congress almost a year ago. Initially scheduled to take effect on July 1, the rules were delayed by almost three months from the original deadline, as industry lobbyists pressed their case at White House offices, including the Office of Management and Budget, the Council on Competitiveness, and the Council of Economic Advisers.
In those meetings, the airlines urged that the F.A.A. adopt exactly the formula for phasing in the rule that was eventually chosen by the agency.
At first, the agency proposed a simple series of deadlines: one-fourth of an airline's noisier planes would have to be eliminated by the end of 1994, one-half by 1996, three-quarters by 1998, and all by the end of the year 1999, unless economic hardship prevented achieving the final deadline.
But a group of "have-not" airlines that would be hardest pressed to meet this schedule argued for another approach, one that would allow some of them much more leeway in the earlier years. They asked for the option of meeting the following deadlines: 55 percent of an airline's entire fleet must be the quieter models by 1994, 65 percent by 1996 and 75 percent by 1998.
Because many airlines already have substantial numbers of quieter planes in their fleets, these hurdles could be met in some cases while leaving most of the noisier planes in service.
In the end, either formula leads to a relatively quiet fleet by the year 2000. But at the beginning, to the dismay of people who complain about airport noise, fewer noisy planes will be retired, and there will be some net increase in noise as the airlines continue to increase their flights.
The issue of airport noise regulation boils down to this question: when should airlines have to modify or mothball their noisier planes? The law demanded that the switch take place by the year 2000, and left it up to the aviation agency to write rules phasing in the change.

HEADLINE: 40,000 Aliens to Win Legal Status in Lottery

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

 BODY:
At one minute past midnight on Columbus Day, would-be immigrants and their lawyers will dump tens of thousands of applications into bins at a Virginia post office as part of one of the stranger and more controversial innovations in a new immigration law.
Under the 1990 law, the first 40,000 applications received after 12:01 A.M. on Oct. 14 from people born in 34 nations will qualify for the green card that signifies legal permanent residency in the United States. 
 With some people planning to dump off or mail in hundreds of duplicates to increase their chances, the post office could receive as many as five million applications by the cutoff date five days later, according to some estimates.
While there have been similar lotteries in 1986 and 1989, they were smaller, with 10,000 and 20,000 winners, and were intended as one-time programs. The new lottery will become a permanent annual feature under the new immigration law.
 
Effort to Add 'Diversity'
 Among the applicants is Derek McMahon from Dublin, who has worked in the United States illegally for the past six years and said he would mail in 200 copies. "I've tried everything to get a green card and nothing has worked," he said. "This is my only chance."
The lottery was written into the law -- which allows for overall immigration of up to 700,000 people a year -- with the stated intent of bringing "diversity" by aiding countries whose immigration numbers dropped after the passage of a broad new statute in 1965.
The 1965 law lifted stringent quotas on immigration from Latin America and Asia and gave preference to immigrants closely related to citizens. Both changes reduced the influx from many European countries. Most of the 34 countries on the list for the new lottery are in Europe.
"This is kind of a white person's lottery," said Michael Maggio, a Washington-based immigration lawyer.
In particular, the new law, co-sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, favors the Irish, who are allotted at least 40 percent of the places. Some critics describe it as a disguised amnesty for the more than 100,000 undocumented immigrants from the Republic of Ireland who are living illegally in America; supporters say it is merely addressing years of discrimination against Irish immigrants.
Natives of Northern Ireland will be considered to be citizens of Britain, one of the 33 other countries included in the lottery.
 
Latin and Asian Influx
 With most immigrants now entering the country under the immigration law's provisions for family reunification, the flow of people from Latin America and Asia has continued, building on an initial influx from those nations after 1965.
Many European nations, and particularly the Irish, do not have that recent base of legal immigrants who can apply for entry for immediate family members.
"This is like a once-off effort to give these people an avenue into the family unification system," said Sean Benson, executive director of Emerald Isle Immigration Center, a nonprofit community organization in Queens that counsels illegal Irish immigrants.
Critics of what one lawyer called an "Irish sweepstakes" approach to immigration assert that it a mockery of the nation's immigration ideals, with possible racial undertones. They say it reinserts into immigration law the principle of national origin that was erased by the 1965 law. That law, among other things, ended a restriction on immigration from Asia.
Cecilia Munoz, an official of the Washington-based Hispanic rights lobbying group, National Council of La Raza, said, " 'Diversity' is clearly a euphemism. 'Diversity' under this law means larger numbers of white Europeans, and I think there is some irony in that."
 
Lotteries Aid the Irish
 She added: "Clearly, members of Congress are more comfortable with immigrants with last names similar to theirs. People who would fight us tooth and nail didn't bat an eyelash when the Irish got their amnesty. It says something about the politics of immigration. We are more comfortable with some people than with others."
Through vigorous organization, the Irish did well in the two previous immigration lotteries. Ms. Munoz also marveled as well at how effective the Irish had been in lobbying Congress, saying, "We talked to Congressional office after Congressional office that just was charmed by the Irish lobbyists."
Critis also say the lottery injects an element of randomness at a time when United States immigration law is attempting to attract what are considered to be desirable immigrants, with new provisions inviting people with particular job skills or large amounts of money to invest in businesses.
"It's not a true lottery, but more of a crap shoot," said Cornelius D. Scully, the State Department official who prepared the regulations under the guidelines of the new law.
After the first three years, during which at least 54,000 people are to be admitted from the Republic of Ireland, the Irish preference is to be dropped, Mr. Scully said. The total number of visas offered under the lottery each year will rise to 55,000.
An analysis of the legislation printed in the Federal Register this month noted there would be "the unseemly spectacle of thousands of applicants and their representatives going through bizarre gyrations in an effort to guarantee that their applications were processed early."
"This is a hell of a way to run a railroad," said Alan Nelson, a former Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service who is now a private consultant on immigration issues. "It sort of cheapens the immigration process."
Responding to the criticisms, Senator Kennedy said yesterday, "The provision is a long-overdue step to end this unfair discrimination against Irish immigrants, who for decades were limited to less than 1,000 visas a year."
He pointed out that the increase for the Irish was accomplished without restricting any other visa categories.
Supporters also argue that the Irish have historically been an important part of the nation's immigrant heritage that should not be lost. They say economic conditions in European nations, including Ireland, did not create the heavy immigrant flow from other parts of the world in recent decades.
 
Fine Points Decisisve
 Another widely raised objection is that some lawyers are charging fees that range into the hundreds and even thousands of dollars, essentially to stamp and mail envelopes containing very simple application letters.
The lawyers respond that as in any legal process, the fine points can be decisive. One group of 15 immigration lawyers from around the nation is holding regular telephone conference calls to discuss questions that include whether envelopes can be machine metered or must carry a postage stamp.
One member of the group has advertised a 95 percent success rate in the last lottery. Another said she had filed 150 applications and won all but six of them.
"We have spent hours and hours and hours going through the minute points," said one of the lawyers, Allen E. Kaye, who said he would be filing 100 applications for each of his 100 clients, for a total of 10,000 letters, and would probably rent a van to carry them.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Allen E. Kaye, an immigration lawyer, said he would be filing 100 applications for the green-card lottery for each of his 100 clients. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times) (pg. HEADLINE: DE GUSTIBUS;
Hello, Tomatoes! Goodbye, Columbus

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THINK of pasta without tomato sauce, polenta without cornmeal, pommes soufflees without potatoes, ratatouille without peppers and mousse without chocolate. What you'd have is European cooking without Columbus.
Some will argue that what the Old World brought to the New World -- apples, pears, peaches, milk and sugar cane, not to mention livestock -- was equally significant, but culinary scholars tend to think the Europeans got the better of the deal. Even if it took them a while before they realized what treasures they had. (For years, they were afraid to eat the tomato.) 
 On Sept. 6, the Smithsonian Institution began its commemoration of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage with a reception that featured dishes from the Old and the New Worlds before 1492. (These days, commemoration, not celebration, is the politically correct term.)
Unlike other aspects of the quincentenary, there isn't a lot of politics attached to chocolate and peppers.
"Food is one of the few safe grounds," said Katherine Kirlin, the special coordinator for the reception, "No scholars have called for revisions of food thoughts."
Indeed. Only a culinary churl would complain about the Italians getting the tomato.
Yet historians who study geopolitics do not award the tomato the importance it enjoys among culinary historians. For them the clout belongs to potatoes, corn and sugar.
"Potatoes and corn are more important to the diet because of nutrition and calories," said Carolyn Margolis, the assistant director of quincentenary programs at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History. She helped organize the museum's exhibition called "Seeds of Change," which opens on Oct. 26. "Sugar is important because it was the first major commodity that resulted in the plantation economy, slavery and the destruction of the rain forest," she said. "It continues to be political because of the migrant labor that is used to grow it.
"The true treasures of the New World were not gold, but botanicals."
Anyone who cooks would not argue with her assessment. But 500 years later it's hard to keep straight what came from where. The food now called Tex-Mex would not have existed without the arrival of cattle (and by extension, cow's milk) from Europe. And if you want to be absolutely accurate, you would say "as American as blueberry pie," because blueberries are indigenous, while the Europeans brought the apple.
The "Seeds of Change" exhibition was created to make its viewers aware of these contributions. "I don't think most people know how much has been contributed," Ms. Margolis said. "Food unites us and helps us appreciate other cultures."
As a companion to the exhibition, a handsome new book, "Seeds of Change" by Herman J. Viola and Ms. Margolis (Smithsonian Institution Press; cloth, $39.95; paper, $24.95), tells the same story with evocative photographs and inviting prose.
All of these threads were noted by Robert McC. Adams, the Secretary of the Smithsonian, in his remarks at the opening reception for the Columbus quincentenary. But unlike most Washington receptions, where the focus is the someone or something being honored and where the food is secondary, at the Smithsonian the meal was spotlighted.
Inside the Institution's forbidding red-brick Castle and its more welcoming gardens, the Old and New World each had its own buffet. Eric Michael, who owns Occasions Caterers with his brother, Mark, described what they served as three-quarters old recipes and one-quarter modern adaptations. Sopas and the guacamole that filled them belong in the latter camp, as did the melon and prosciutto; paella, capon pie and roasted quail legs in the former.
And some adjustments were necessary. Lard was replaced by oil, salt was toned down considerably, and dense, extremely sweet cakes were lightened up a bit.
Some of the seasoned Washington partygoers, used to roast beef, trees of shrimp and nothing more daring than a piece of rye bread, agreed. Even though such a lavish buffet would have cost a private individual $50 to $65 a person, the guests were nonplused by the likes of air-dried buffalo strips, cassava bread, cactus and jicama salad, roast wild boar and even tamales. Washington is not noted for its adventurous palates. Even Jean Lujan, the wife of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., was more interested in the popcorn than any of the exotics.
Did you like the wild boar, she was asked.
"No."
Did you like the squash?
"No."
Did you like the beans?
"They were O.K., but I'm a real simple kid," she said by way of explanation as she munched the popcorn.
But there was another point of view, one held by Dr. Adams, the Secretary of the Smithsonian. "I worked for a number of years in Mexico," he said, "so I should know Mesoamerican food very well. This is a good, bland introduction. It's a shame they didn't put out the chilies."
Who said food isn't controversial?

GRAPHIC: Photos: Food at the Smithsonian commemoration included everything from wild boar and wild turkey to six-bean salad. (Andrea Mohin for The New York Times) (pg. C6)

HEADLINE: Do Scarlett and Rhett Discover Love Anew? A Sequel Reveals All

BYLINE: By ELEANOR BLAU

 BODY:
"Tomorrow, I'll think of some way to get him back," says Scarlett O'Hara, the feisty, self-centered Southern belle in "Gone With the Wind." "After all, tomorrow is another day."
So ends Margaret Mitchell's 1936 soap opera of a novel, a Civil War epic that became one of the most popular books ever written. 
 And then what happens?
Well, for one thing, maybe Scarlett goes back to Tara, the beloved plantation in Georgia, moves on to Charleston, S.C., and later to -- Ireland? Not so far-fetched, considering that was her father's birthplace. It all happens in Alexandra Ripley's "Scarlett," the Warner Books sequel, which was authorized by the Mitchell estate, and is being published today in 40 countries and 18 languages.
More than a million copies of "Scarlett" were ordered by bookstores in advance of the publication, Ms. Ripley has been told, and no one doubts a movie can be far away. Still, what acclaim would "Scarlett" have to win to begin to match the popularity of its predecessor?
 
28 Million Copies Sold
 The Pulitzer Prize-winning "Gone With the Wind" has been translated into 27 languages and has sold some 28 million copies, more than any other book but the Bible. The 1939 movie of it -- one of the best-loved movies of all time -- won 10 Academy Awards and may forever have linked the protagonists with their portrayors: Clark Gable as the adventurer Rhett Butler and Vivien Leigh as Scarlett, whom he pursues through the nearly four-hour film and the more-than-1,000-page book, finally abandoning her with his classic adieu: "My dear, I don't give a damn."
Ms. Ripley, who was in New York this week, said she was well aware that some fans of "Gone With the Wind" would scorn the presumption of continuing what Mitchell said should have no sequel. She even heard about an "I Won't Read the Sequel Club" in Atlanta, which she herself asked to join after re-reading her own manuscript in its many rewritten, edited, galley and page-proof versions. (She received a membership plaque.)
For nonmembers of the club, it would be unkind to reveal the Ripley fate of Rhett and Scarlett, but the author did not mind noting that Scarlett "grows up" by admitting defeat and by experiencing love for Cat. Cat is a child. We won't say whose.
If Scarlett did not change, how could matters change between her and Rhett?
Ms. Ripley said she had decided early on that fans of the first novel would have her "pilloried" if, in more than 800 pages, the pair had still not gotten together. But that is not divulging the ending.
"Whoever writes the next book should send me flowers, because I've set it up for them," she observed.
The 57-year-old Ms. Ripley said she had spent five years on "Scarlett," the first year settling legal matters and the next year and a half in preparation, visiting libraries, archives and sites from Atlanta to Dublin and steeping herself in the Mitchell work.
After reading "Gone With the Wind" at least four times, and copying several hundred more of its pages in long hand (the only way she writes), Ms. Ripley said, she started underlining bits of it with colored pencils to try to fathom what she calls a most unusual style that broke rules of syntax and compressed a great deal.
"Margaret Mitchell was a better writer than critics have given her credit for," she said. Better than Ms. Ripley? A pause. "Yes," she said and smiled.
 
Other Historical Novels
 Ms. Ripley has written historical novels, including two set in her own and Rhett's home turf: "Charleston" and "On Leaving Charleston," as well as "New Orleans Legacy," all Warner paperback best sellers.
The author, who lives in Virginia with her husband, a professor in the rhetoric department of the University of Virginia, and who has two daughters by an earlier marriage, tried to imitate Mitchell's style for only a few hundred of the book's 823 pages, she said, to gain the trust of readers. Then, she said "Gradually, I could slide into my own voice."
Even while imitating, she said, she avoided the black dialect of "Gone With the Wind," which she considered not only demeaning but also hard to read.
"Gone With the Wind" ends in 1873, and that's when "Scarlett" starts, a few days later, at the burial of Melanie Wilkes. Melanie is, of course, the wife of Ashley, whom, all these years, until recently, Scarlett had thought she loved. (You don't want to be told Ashley's lot, do you?)
Plotting the novel and trying to match it to the times was difficult. "I read seven books on Wall Street and the economy," Ms. Ripley said. "This was the big thing happening. Not only was I reading things I did not understand, it bored me senseless. There were things going on in the Balkans, but can you see Scarlett saying, 'I think I'll grow cotton in the Balkans?' "
But when Ms. Ripley read about this being tumultuous times in Ireland, "with early skirmishing and political parties and rhetoric" -- much like the pre-Civil War times in which "Gone With the Wind" opens -- "I said, 'Oh, thank you, God!' " she said.
 
No Graphic Sex
 The Mitchell estate put only two restrictions on her efforts, said Ms. Ripley: don't include miscegenation or graphic sex. The sequel is more open about sex than its predecessor, but she said, "I'm a three-dot writer" who thinks suggestion is more of a turn-on than explicitness.
Her biggest problem early on was that she considered Scarlett "a thoroughly loathsome character." The one thing she admired, she recalled, was that Scarlett always kept her promises. "But her ruthlessness I found appalling." A friend advised her that she didn't have to like Scarlett, merely love her.
Rhett, on the other hand, was no trouble at all. "An adventurer who is au fond a good guy, nice to children and to his mother. And he's an educated man. He was a joy to write."
According to biographies, she said, Mitchell experienced more pain than pleasure from her huge success. Ms. Ripley, though, said she felt like "the luckiest person in the world."
She has received a $160,000 advance for "Scarlett," which is less than half the advance she was to have received for a book for Warner that was postponed for the sequel. But she has that book and another one under contract for Warner now and stands to earn more for "Scarlett."
"It's not just avarice," she said. "It's vanity" -- she shrugged -- "hubris? I would like to have people go into bookstores and say, 'Is the new Ripley out yet?' "

HEADLINE: New Life for a Neglected Jewel in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Architects have sometimes wondered if George Herbert Wyman designed the Bradbury Building as a kind of architectural surprise. From the street, it looks like a nondescript 19th-century building with a plain Romanesque facade of brick and sandstone.
But after passing through a narrow arched entry, the visitor suddenly arrives in a grand atrium. The eye is almost overwhelmed, carried up five stories on ornate black wrought-iron railings and staircases and carved red oak wainscoting and fascias to the clerestory windows and skylight that bathe the entire space in a warm ocher. Two open-caged hydraulic elevators glide up and down on either side. 
 It is, in the architect Charles Moore's words, "one of the most thrilling spaces on the North American continent," a building that might seem more at home in Milan, lower Manhattan or San Francisco if it had to be in California.
The 1893 Bradbury was rededicated on Sept. 24 after two years of painstaking restoration. Its red-oak paneling has been sanded and refinished to a bright rose luster. The floors of Mexican tile have been patched up, the glazed yellow brick walls have been restored, the red Italian marble wall bases cleaned and shined and 98 years of grime scraped off the skylight panes.
 
Hopes for a Renaissance
 The building's current owners, a partnership led by Ira E. Yelin of the Yelin Company, hope it will form the nucleus of a renaissance of the once grand center of downtown Los Angeles, now dilapidated. The first tenants will soon begin to occupy some of the 61,000 square feet of office space, with ceilings that range from 12 to 14 feet.
The restoration is almost certain to win applause from architects and architectural historians, among whom the Bradbury has aroused almost cultlike adoration. It is widely considered one of the finest historic buildings in Los Angeles, a city with only four official National Historic Landmarks.
Mr. Yelin, who spent $5.6 million to buy the Bradbury (the renovation cost another $6 million, plus $2.4 million for seismic strengthening) is banking on a revival of the Broadway area, which is strategically positioned at the core of the city. Just to the west is Bunker Hill, on which the newest office towers have been built; to the east is the new Ronald Reagan State Office Building and booming Little Tokyo; to the north is the Civic Center and the Los Angeles Times building. He foresees a corridor of development, with the Bradbury in the center, connecting these focal points of Los Angeles's civic life.
The Bradbury was originally commissioned by Lewis Bradbury, a mining magnate. He gave the task to Wyman, a young draftsman who worked for a local architect. Wyman was a kind of architectural supernova; the Bradbury was his one flare of glory, but a magnificent one.
By the time Mr. Yelin bought the building in 1989, the oak paneling and railings were so dark with dirt that his architect, Brenda A. Levin of Levin and Associates in Los Angeles, thought they were made of mahogany. Ms. Levin migrated here from New Jersey 15 years ago and has since become one of Los Angeles's leading restoration architects, having also restored the Oviatt and Fine Arts buildings.
She said she was daunted by the Bradbury task. "This is the most significant piece of architecture in the city of Los Angeles," she said. "I had a fair amount of apprehension dealing with someone else's vision."
She tried to preserve every possible original detail, while updating to modern office standards and safety codes. There were numerous difficult decisions. For example, more than 50 panes of untempered glass in the dome were broken. The question was whether to replace the entire skylight with tempered glass or keep the existing glass with wire mesh below. She decided to keep the original glass for fear of changing the color of the light in the atrium.
The restoration encountered not a few political problems. For example, the Fire Marshal at first wanted to have the wrought-iron staircases enclosed, which would have been something like placing a plaster robe over Michelangelo's statue of David. The compromise was to install sprinklers all around the interior galleries of the atrium.
But the greatest challenge may not be so much esthetic as economic. The surroundings remain intimidating. Derelicts and drug addicts haunt the doorways and alleys in the neighborhood. Across Third Street, just north of the Bradbury, the city has permitted another developer to put up El Metro Plaza, a garish structure for Mexican restaurants with brass-colored piping and with two odd cupolas that would seem offensive even in Tijuana.
Moreover, the building reopens at a particularly inopportune time, with downtown vacancy rates in Los Angeles running at about 20 percent and with another 3.8 million square feet of Class A office space under construction. So far one tenant has signed up for the Bradbury, Kathleen Sullivan, the Treasurer of California, who has taken 4,477 square feet in the southwest corner of the fifth floor for her Los Angeles office.
Whatever its economic prospects, architectural historians welcome a salvaged Bradbury Building that Thomas S. Hines, an architectural historian at the University of California, Los Angeles, calls the earliest example of Los Angeles's "tradition of futurism."
"It is really a machine-age building," he said, "It is an early monument in a city that has come to be recognized as one of great 20th-century architecture. When we find a 19th-century building that provides a prelude for the 20th century, then you have reason to celebrate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The grand atrium of the restored Bradbury Building in Los Angeles. (Julius Shulman for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 620 words

HEADLINE: Aquino May Agree to a U.S. Pullout Over 3 Years

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Sept. 24

 BODY:
Faced with widespread opposition to her proposal for a national referendum to approve a new 10-year American lease on the Subic Bay Naval Station, President Corazon C. Aquino may accept a compromise allowing for a three-year American withdrawal from the huge military base, Philippine officials and Western diplomats said today.
Despite what appears to be a political defeat for Mrs. Aquino, diplomats in Manila said that there was still no evidence to suggest that the United States would be evicted from the base anytime soon, and possibly not for several years. 
 "There's a general election next year to pick Mrs. Aquino's successor and a new Senate," an American official noted. "If the compromise is a three-year withdrawal, that would leave three years to work out a new arrangement for Subic. The new Senate may be much more amenable to an agreement."
On Sept. 15, Mrs. Aquino went on national television to call for a "people's initiative" to overturn a looming vote in the Philippine Senate to reject the new American lease for the base, the largest American military base in Asia.
 
Public Support for Bases
 The landmark 12-to-11 vote rejecting the lease came the next day, with the majority describing their action as a long-delayed demonstration of sovereignty and national pride in the Philippines, which was an American colony from 1898 to 1946.
Polls indicate that the public strongly supports the American bases, which employ thousands of Filipinos and pump hundreds of millions of dollars into the country's struggling economy. But Mrs. Aquino's plan for a national referendum to overturn the Senate vote has met with little public enthusiasm in the last week, and it has inspired an angry debate within the Philippine Government over the legality of the referendum plan and over Mrs. Aquino's allegiance to the Constitution that she helped craft after her election in 1986.
Under the Constitution, the new American lease for the naval base would have required two-thirds approval in the 23-member Senate. It also says that American troops should have left the Philippines by Sept. 16 if a new lease had not been approved by the Senate.
 
Statement by Aquino
 On Monday, Mrs. Aquino said in a statement sent to news organizations that "our main thrust continues to be the call for a referendum." But she added that "we are always willing to talk to anyone, especially the senators who may have compromise positions" and she said that one senator's proposal for a seven-year American withdrawal from Subic was "interesting and should be considered."
Lawmakers and diplomats took the statement as evidence that Mrs. Aquino was prepared to back down from her call for a national referendum and leave a final decision about Subic's future in the hands of her successor and the new Senate. Mrs. Aquino has insisted she will not seek a second term.
Senators on both sides of the issue have moved this week to reach an agreement that, depending on the proposal, would allow the United States to withdraw from Subic over two to seven years -- an agreement, in effect, to leave a final decision on the base's future until after next year's general election.
In a speech today to a Manila business group, the president of the Philippine Senate and one of the base's fiercest opponents, Jovito Salonga, outlined a proposal for a two-year American withdrawal from Subic.
Mrs. Aquino is calling for ratification of a new lease for Subic on economic grounds, saying that in addition to the economic benefits to the Subic Bay area the impoverished Philippine Government needs the more than $2 billion that the United States has offered in rent payments over the next decade.

HEADLINE: The Governor's Gift: Energy

 BODY:
Gov. Mario Cuomo's ambitious plan to revitalize New York City is more than welcome. It is essential. Mr. Cuomo, while remaining helpful, had kept aloof from the city's deepening fiscal crisis. But now he has acknowledged his leadership role as Governor and come up with an imaginative roster of programs that, though short on detail, is long on promise.
Not all his ideas are new. Many are familiar old ones cleverly repackaged, and many rely on money and an economy he does not control. Indeed, several of his proposals are expensive prescriptions for his successor. But even so, he offers New York City a gift: the energy of leadership. 
 What New Yorkers need now is chapter and verse. But if the city can realize even half of his wish list, he will have created a solid legacy. And in the meantime his initiative puts constructive pressure on the other players in this great municipal drama -- City Hall, the labor unions, the business community and the State Legislature.
The most significant fiscal part of Governor Cuomo's new program is his overdue declaration of a campaign for a gradual state takeover of Medicaid, as Mayor David Dinkins has long urged. New York is one of only five states that require localities to pay part of those soaring expenses. Mr. Cuomo proposes that they surrender some of their tax revenues -- though he has yet to say how much. The state would also run Medicaid, finally assuring that the same government that provides the money is responsible for spending it.
The Governor also offers to support a list of public works proposals that would create thousands of jobs. Few are new and many have long been stalled. Even so, by adopting them as his own priorities he might move them along. Among the proposals are these:
Transit to and Between Airports. Mr. Cuomo proposes using a $3-a-passenger tax to build a light rail system of "people movers" connecting city airports, subways and commuter rail lines. The idea requires Port Authority approval of the tax and its use.
Rail Freight Connection. He recognizes the importance of finishing the Oak Point rail freight link in the South Bronx, to relieve the city of much truck traffic. This long-stalled project needs an additional $93 million, from the state and the Port Authority.
Hunters Point. This huge residential and commercial project along the East River in Queens would be nearly the size of Battery Park City. The Governor's commitment to create a subsidiary of the Urban Development Corporation to coordinate the project could, if the economy cooperates, give it a jump-start.
Riverside South. Mr. Cuomo wants to push along this immense West Side development by financing environmental and planning studies for a new road to replace the Miller Highway. The source of funding remains unclear, however, and there's no certainty he can win approval to demolish the Miller Highway, now being rebuilt with Federal funds.
Science Library. The Governor's plan encompasses the creation of the world's largest science, industry and business library. The state and city have agreed to provide about a quarter of the needed $75 million to $80 million. The rest will come from the New York Public Library, donations and state bonds.
There are other proposals in Governor Cuomo's program, like the long-deferred Second Avenue subway and a fanciful suggestion for high-speed ferries. But the test of his initiative does not lie in the specifics of individual proposals, no matter how wishful their concept or uncertain their fate. What the Governor has now given New York City is leadership, and hope.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Blockade Is Cuba's Economic Problem

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The United States-Cuba policy formula in "Fortress Cuba, Lonely Cuba" (editorial, Sept. 8) seems to be reducible to the proposition, let Cuba rot. I am prepared to accept that your conclusion may be the result of faulty data, and point out mistakes that deserve correction: 
Cuba has a constitution adopted by 97.7 percent of voters in a 1976 referendum by secret ballot. Elections, also by secret ballot, are regularly held among candidates for local bodies, who elect members of provincial and national bodies. The system is similar to those of many Western European democracies where the government is elected by the members of Parliament.
Candidates in Cuba do not need to be millionaires; they are freely nominated to run from the ranks of their own constituencies and periodically must account to their voters. Even though voting in Cuba is not compulsory, and elections are held more often than in the United States, participation in all our elections runs higher than 90 percent.
You overlook the illegal, implacable economic, commercial and financial blockade imposed on Cuba by the United States for more than 30 years. That blockade prevents Cuba from even purchasing foodstuffs and medicines from the United States. That is the major cause of the material difficulties Cuba faces and a continuing source of hardship for its people.
It was the United States Government in 1959 and 1960, in violation of bilateral agreements, that reduced and then canceled Cuba's sugar quota in the United States market. Washington began this and other economic aggression before Cuba proclaimed socialism as a goal. As Dwight D. Eisenhower and Richard M. Nixon recognized in their memoirs, from the first weeks of 1959 the United States began drawing plans against Cuba, and on March 17, 1960, the President approved and ordered execution of the plan that would culminate in the Bay of Pigs failure.
You fault Cuba for lack of economic diversification. Cuba now successfully uses every industrial possibility of sugar cane -- production of energy, paper, cattle feed, particle board and many other byproducts. Biotechnology, the pharmaceutical industry and manufacture of medical equipment and electronics play an increasingly important role in our economy. Many United States citizens suffer the consequences of not being able to buy type B antimeningococcal vaccine, which the United States does not produce, but whose importation the United States prohibits.
It is true that, as a result of the United States blockade, Cubans face difficulties and limitations. But in Cuba, no one knows hunger or malnutrition. Despite enormous external obstacles, our socialist society guarantees a dignified and decent existence to all, including free education, and medical and hospital assistance.
No one in Cuba suffers the sad and miserable life of countless millions in other parts of the world, including the United States, who lack employment, schools and medical attention, and who wander the streets without housing, without care and without hope.
 
RICARDO ALARCON DE QUESADA
Representative of Cuba at the U.N.
New York, Sept. 10, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Bush Forecasts G.O.P. Victory In Trenton Fight

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 24

 BODY:
President Bush came to New Jersey tonight and raised $800,000 for Republican legislative candidates, who he predicted would take control of the State Legislature in November.
"After talking to Republican leaders and reading about what is happening in the state," the President said to about 1,000 Republicans at a fund-raising dinner at the Ramada Renaissance Hotel here, "I believe the Republicans will take both the Assembly and the Senate in the fall." 
 Although it was a political speech, the President never mentioned state tax increases engineered by the Democrats and the Governor, nor did he mention Gov. Jim Florio by name.
The only reference in his address was oblique, when Mr. Bush said, "Frankly, I wish Tom Kean was still governor of this state."
 
Florio Goes Unmentioned
 Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who sat at the head table and introduced the President, thanked Mr. Bush for campaigning on his behalf in 1980, but he also did not mention Governor Florio.
The President's speech came against a favorable political background, in which Mr. Bush has few problems save a stuttering economy and rising unemployment.
Mr. Bush alluded to the jobless when he said that Democrats wanted to extend unemployment benefits. But he said that doing so would increase the national debt.
The President is reluctant to tap into the $8 billion Unemployment Trust Fund, although many Republicans in Congress favor using the fund for a 10-week extension of benefits for those whose payments are running out. Democrats want 10 or more weeks.
Mr. Bush said the best way to attack unemployment was to "pass the capital gains differential," an income-tax revision that would allow greater tax deductions for investment income. That, he said, would spur industrial and research growth that would ultimately lead to job creation.
He also chided Democrats for attacking his domestic program.
"I'm a little tired of hearing from Democrats that we have no domestic agenda," Mr. Bush said, adding that "our national drug policy is working," and "our crime package is the most comprehensive in American history."
He suggested several times that voting for Republicans would "bring common sense back to government" in New Jersey and the nation, a hint that "common sense" could be a Republican theme in elections this fall.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 26, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article and picture caption in some copies yesterday about President Bush's appearance at a New Jersey fund-raiser misidentified the locality where the event took place. It was East Brunswick, not New Brunswick.

HEADLINE: Brazil Seeks Credit Deal

BYLINE: By AP

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Brazil said today that it would present a new plan to foreign creditors next week to reschedule the $52 billion it owes to private banks.
The Brazilian central bank said its top debt negotiator, Pedro Malan, would travel to New York to meet with the banks' steering committee on Monday. 
 Officials hope the United States Government will put pressure on the banks to reach a deal with Brazil, which owes a total of $123 billion to foreign lenders.
In August, Brazil offered to convert its private foreign debt into five new types of medium- and long-term bonds. But creditors demanded a shorter repayment period, higher interest rates and payment guarantees.
No details of Brazil's new proposal were given. But the Government is expected to ask for new loans in exchange for concessions on the bond issue. The money would reportedly be used to buy United States Treasury bonds. Their earnings would guarantee the payment of principal on the new bonds that Brazil issues.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper at Five-Month High On News of Zaire Violence

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures prices jumped to a five-month high yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid reports that violence in Zaire had spread to the copper-rich southern tip of the central African nation.
Copper for delivery in September climbed 2.85 cents, to $1.1025 a pound, the highest settlement of a near-term copper contract since April 18. Other copper contracts finished 1.75 cents to 2.65 cents higher. 
 The chief market influence was the increasing unrest in Zaire, the world's fourth-largest copper exporter, where 30 people were reported to have been killed this week in rioting and looting by mutinous Zairean soldiers. The rioters aim to unseat Zaire's ruler of 26 years, Mobuto Sese Seko.
European officials of the state-owned mining company, Gecamines, were unable to confirm reports that the company's offices in the southern city of Kolwezi had been bombed.
The reports fueled speculation that Zaire's 1991 copper production will fall far below the company's recent forecast of 250,000 tons, compared with last year's 400,000 tons. Many analysts expect Zairean production of 180,000 tons this year.
Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc., said Zaire's copper output could fall as low as 125,000 tons.
The copper mines are Zaire's economic lifeline, said James Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York. "That's all they have," he said. "If they seize the mines, this President will fall."
Mr. Steel said copper's other supply-and-demand fundamentals were negative but that prices would surely rise if shipments from Zaire were interrupted.
Crude oil ended nearly unchanged on the New York Mercantile Exchange after recovering from a decline started by a tentative agreement among OPEC ministers to increase their oil production ceiling by a million barrels a day. The move is likely to hold cash crude prices steady in coming months, OPEC officials said.
Crude for delivery in November rose 2 cents, to $22.21 a barrel; October heating oil fell 0.09 cent, to 63.60 cents a gallon; October unleaded gasoline rose 0.70 cent, to 61.78 cents a gallon; November natural gas rose 1 cent, to $1.899 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Grain and soybean futures ended mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade as selling linked to the advancing Midwest harvest offset buying prompted by easier credit terms for the Soviet Union.
Wheat for delivery in December settled 3/4 cent higher at $3.27 1/4 a bushel; December corn finished 1 1/4 cents lower at $2.47 1/4 a bushel; December oats fell 1 1/2 cents, to $1.29 a bushel; November soybeans ended 1 3/4 cents lower at $5.90 1/4 a bushel.
Cattle futures advanced on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with higher cash cattle prices and signs of stronger wholesale beef demand. Pork futures retreated as hog traders began evening up their positions ahead of tomorrow's quarterly hog inventory report, which is expected to show an expanding hog supply.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in U.S. Trading; Iraq Move Eases War Fears

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell in quiet domestic trading yesterday after posting gains overseas. Gold prices were mixed.
Analysts attributed some dollar selling to an Iraqi promise to allow unimpeded helicopter flights by United Nations nuclear inspection teams. The move by Baghdad helped ease some concerns of traders about a possible renewal of conflict in the Middle East. 
 The dollar, which is seen as a safe currency in times of international turmoil, had gained over the last week from Iraq's refusal to allow inspections of its suspected nuclear sites and President Bush's threat to escort the United Nations flights with American warplanes.
Mr. Bush put that threat on hold yesterday.
Analysts said the dollar was not affected by the Commerce Department's report that durable goods orders fell 3.8 percent in August.
"The durable goods was somewhat anticipated," said Walter Simon, a vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Company. "People are taking a break after 10 straight days of fairly big moves." The report concerns orders for goods that are expected to last three years or more.
The British pound rose to $1.7355 in New York, from $1.7290 late on Tuesday. But in earlier trading in London, sterling fell to $1.7330, from $1.7430 on Tuesday.
The dollar fell to 133.22 Japanese yen in New York, from 133.45 on Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to 133.22 yen from 132.97 yen, and in London, it fell to 133.20 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 1.6805 German marks, down from 1.6865; 1.4635 Swiss francs, down from 1.4690; 5.7260 French francs, down from 5.7455; 1,256.75 Italian lire, down from 1,261.00, and 1.13455 Canadian dollars, up from 1.13375.

HEADLINE: India Approves Ventures With Americans

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
India's Commerce Minister announced today that his Government had approved two joint ventures between American multinationals and local companies, and preliminary plans for two others.
The minister, Palaniappan Chidambaram, said India had given final approval for a joint venture by I.B.M. and the Indian conglomerate Tata Industries to produce I.B.M. Personal System 2 computers and computer programs, and by the Indian auto maker Maruti Ltd. and the Ford Motor Company to produce aluminum radiators for cars. 
 The International Business Machines Corporation is returning to the Indian market after the company left in 1977 in response to a law limiting foreign ownership to 40 percent. The bitter dispute was a landmark in efforts by third world countries to limit the influence of multinational corporations.
 
Change in the Law
 A new law that took effect on July 24 provides for the automatic approval of foreign stakes up to 51 percent, and an accelerated approval process for foreign companies seeking higher stakes, Mr. Chidambaram said. The Indian Government has eased restrictions on foreign investment as part of a broader strategy of reducing the Government's role in the economy and reducing India's reliance on bank loans to finance economic growth, the minister said.
India is struggling with a large trade deficit, continuing trade disputes with the United States and a $69 billion foreign debt. On Friday a group of international lenders led by the World Bank endorsed the Government's economic stabilization plan, which calls for a 23 percent devaluation of the rupee and smaller budget deficits, and increased assistance to India.
But Ajay S. Kapur, an economist at the WEFA Group, an economic consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said that India still faced formidable problems in attracting foreign investment. India's reputation for low manufacturing wages is an illusion because of low productivity, steadily rising government salaries and powerful unions with close ties to political parties, he said.
"One shouldn't think of India as a land of multitudinous landless laborers waiting to be hired to make transistors," he said, while adding that engineers, software programmers and other professionals were often paid far less in India than in the West.
 
Few Investments Come In
 India attracted only $70 million worth of foreign investment last year, compared with $480 million even in the Philippines, Mr. Kapur said.
Mr. Chidambaram is on a five-day visit to the United States to woo American businesses and discuss trade issues with the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills. But the Indian Commerce Minister said he had not discussed the United States' investigation of charges that India allows the piracy of American patents, copyrights and trademarks. The four-month-old investigation could lead to trade sanctions on Nov. 26.
The Indian Government has also approved preliminary plans by the General Motors Corporation and Hindustan Motors Ltd. to build cars and automobile parts, and for the Kellogg Company to set up a breakfast cereal factory and sell stock to local investors, the minister said.
Richard E. Lovell, a spokesman for Kellogg, which is based in Battle Creek, Mich., said India's growing middle class and strong domestic transportation and distribution network had attracted the company. "We see India as a good-potential, long-term-growth market," he said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Taxable Money Funds Off; Tax-Frees Up

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields of tax-free and taxable money market funds moved in different directions for the week ended yesterday, with tax-free yields moving up and the yields on taxable funds going down.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report, which monitors the funds, pointed out that "tax-frees are affected more by supply and demand, while the taxables are influenced primarily by monetary policy." 
 Mr. Frank explained that recently a larger supply of tax-free securities had been available. He said that the increase in the supply of municipal debt came after a period of low-supply had driven up prices.
 
Response to Fed
 "Now the prices of tax-exempts are coming down, and yields going up," he said, adding that the yields on taxables have been moving down because of the Federal Reserve's recent easing of rates.
The average 7-day compounded average yield for the tax-exempts rose to 4.43 percent from 4.30 percent a week ago, while the simple yield rose to 4.33 percent from 4.21 percent. The average 30-day compounded yield rose to 4.28 percent, from 4.20 the previous week, and the 30-day simple yield rose to 4.19, compared with 4.12 percent the previous week.
The assets of tax-exempt funds dropped by $308 million, to $87.1 billion, and portfolio holdings averaged 60 days to maturity, compared with 61 days a week ago.
The highest yield among funds with assets of more than $100 million was the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a 7-day compounded yield of 5.32 percent.
Among funds investing in individual state securities, in New York, the Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market continued to provide the highest 7-day compounded yield at 4.98 percent, up from 4.83 percent.
In Connecticut, the Prudential Connecticut Municipal Money Market Series again led with a 4.76 percent 7-day compounded yield, up from 4.58, while in New Jersey, Calvert N.J. Tax Free Reserves reported a 7-day yield of 5 percent, up from 4.92 percent.
On taxables, Mr. Frank said that the average 7-day compounded yield was 5.31 percent, down from 5.35 percent, and the simple yield was 5.18 percent, down from 5.21 percent. The 30-day average compounded yield dropped to 5.38 percent, down from 5.41 percent, and the 30-day simple yield was down to 5.24 percent from 5.27 percent.
 
Taxable Assets Decline
 Assets of the taxable funds declined by $900 million, to $456.1 billion, Institutional ownership, however, was up by $670 million, which means that the public was doing the selling and probably moving into short-term bond funds or other fixed-income assets for better yields. Mr. Frank said the average maturities of the taxable funds remained at 60 days.
For the third straight week, the taxable fund with the best return was Riverside Capital Money Market Fund of Columbus, Ohio, with a 7-day compounded yield of 6.44 percent.
By comparison, the average rate of return on bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, dropped to 5.06 percent from 5.10 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: Durables and Resales Of Homes Off in August

BYLINE: By AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Factory orders for durable goods and sales of existing homes fell last month, according to reports released today, prompting concern about the sectors that were expected to lead the economy out of recession.
"The reluctant recovery does not look too durable at the moment," said John M. Albertine, the head of an economic forecasting firm here. 
 Daryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., concurred, saying, "There's reason to fear the recovery has stalled."
 
'A Solid Gain'
 But Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said the economy was growing in the July-to-September quarter and played down the August decline in durable goods orders, those for items expected to last three or more years.
Noting that orders posted a record gain in July, Mr. Boskin said the two months taken together reflect "a solid gain." But he acknowledged a need "to see an improvement in the consumer sector."
The Commerce Department said today that durable goods orders fell by 3.8 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $125.9 billion, from $130.8 billion in July. A sharp drop in transportation orders led the declines in most large categories.
"We have severe doubts about whether the surge in manufacturing can be sustained, given the drop in consumer confidence and the weakness in domestic automobile sales," Mr. Albertine said.
 
Realtors' Report
 In another report, the National Association of Realtors said today that sales of existing single-family homes fell by 2.1 percent in August, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.2 million, down from 3.3 million a month earlier.
The report also showed a revised drop in sales in July -- 7.5 percent, steeper than the 6.7 percent decline initially reported. Sales of new homes also fell in July, according to Government figures.
Until July, sales of new and existing homes had risen every month since the housing recession bottomed out last January.
The July rise in durable-goods orders was revised to 11.7 percent, the biggest gain since the Commerce Department began tracking them in 1958. Orders were first estimated to have advanced 11.2 percent.
Still, it was just the third advance since the beginning of the year, and the August relapse meant orders for the first eight months were down by four-tenths of a percent from those of the 1990 period.
Durable goods are considered a barometer of manufacturers' production plans. A decrease could result in less production and a loss of jobs.
A Production Slowdown
Mr. Delano said most of the good economic news recently had concerned production, including manufacturing and housing. But, he added, this activity is slowing because of a lack of demand from consumers, who represent two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
"People are still concerned about jobs and income," he said.
The durables report showed that transportation orders fell by 9.2 percent in August, the first decline since April. A large decrease in aircraft orders offset gains in other equipment including automobiles.
Transportation orders had risen by 27.1 percent in July, three-fourths of which was from the aircraft industry.
But even without the decline in the transportation category, overall orders were still down by 1.6 percent.
 
Nonmilitary Orders Down
 Nonmilitary orders for capital goods, excluding aircraft, also fell, by 2.7 percent, to $24.8 billion, after advancing 5 percent a month earlier. This category is often a measure of business confidence and plans to expand and modernize.
But unfilled orders rose three-tenths of a percent, to $502.1 billion, the second straight advance after four consecutive drops. A rise in unfilled orders often portends increased output to keep up with demand.
The often-volatile military category posted a 14 percent gain, to $10.7 billion, after a 13.2 percent advance in July. These orders had plunged by 13.1 percent in June. Excluding the military category, orders were off by 5.2 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A Campaign 'Of a Lifetime' By Mercedes

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE most extensive advertising campaign ever for the most expensive line of Mercedes-Benz automobiles ever -- with an expected sticker price as high as $125,000 -- will introduce the redesigned S-Class as "the car of a lifetime."
Beginning on Monday, elegantly understated advertisements by McCaffrey & McCall Inc., will herald the first complete overhaul of the top-of-the-line S-Class in 11 years. Besides two lushly celebratory television commercials and Mercedes-Benz's largest distribution of magazine inserts, the company will send out brochures and videotapes to pique the interest of affluent car buyers, who are being pursued as never before. 
 "We've been more aggressive than most people would have anticipated from Mercedes-Benz," said John Doig, deputy chairman and chief creative officer for McCaffrey, the agency for Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc. since 1979. Still, the campaign speaks in the characteristic voice of the German car maker, a mix of the "poetic" and "motor oil," he said in an interview yesterday in his midtown Manhattan office.
"You have to feel moved to get into this car," added Albert Weiss, general manager of marketing communications for Mercedes-Benz, during a call to Mr. Doig's office from a dealers' meeting in San Francisco. "Part of it is the emotion, or, you might say, the passion, of Mercedes."
Stirring that passion is the mission of the commercials, which will start their run during "Monday Night Football" on ABC. "You have built a rewarding life on understanding the difference between excellence and next-best," a soothing-voiced announcer says in one spot, as a car emerges from misty mountains. "Now, Mercedes-Benz has built the car for you."
The spots call the S-Class "the car of a lifetime, for the people who have created it and the people who will drive it."
The multi-fold-out insert echoes that hushed tone. "Nothing feels like a Mercedes," it says. "The sense of security as deep as the pilings under a bridge. The sheer unflappable poise. The strength. The substance." More than 20 million inserts will appear through January in 21 magazines from Architectural Digest to Travel & Leisure.
The 28-page brochure, as well as the 10-minute videotape, will offer more detail about the S-Class's five models, including their self-closing doors, double-paned glass and Bose sound system. The campaign continues using the long-time corporate theme, "Engineered like no other car in the world."
The recession is complicating the S-Class introduction. It is "probably one of the first where affluent people haven't spent freely through it," said Will Metzger, McCaffrey's executive vice president and management supervisor, who accompanied Mr. Weiss to San Francisco. The agency is undaunted, he added, because the company's "values of safety, durability and reliability" should mesh with car buyers' new, less flashy attitudes.
"You can sell them," he continued, "but it takes a much more concentrated effort."
The S-Class models cost more than most other imported cars. While Mr. Weiss would not discuss prices, which are to be announced on Tuesday, they are expected to range from around $65,000 for the 300SE and 300SD (diesel) sedans to around $125,000 for the 600SEL sedan with a V-12 engine. Current S-Class prices range from about $53,000 to $90,000.
Mr. Weiss also declined to discuss the S-Class ad budget, other than to say it would be "the largest effort we've ever put together for a new product." From 80 percent to 90 percent of all Mercedes-Benz's national advertising for the rest of the year will be devoted to the line, he added.
National ad spending for all Mercedes-Benz cars totaled $88.3 million last year, according to Leading National Advertisers, and $42.6 million for the first six months of this year.
Through August, Mercedes-Benz's United States car sales were down 21.2 percent from the first eight months of 1990. That compares with declines of 17.9 percent for BMW, 21.1 percent for Volvo and 48.2 percent for Jaguar.
