HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Regular Bidding Pattern Returns

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Customers returned to their regular bidding patterns at yesterday's auction of $9.25 billion worth of new five-year Treasury notes.
The notes were sold at an average yield of 7.05 percent, down from the average yield of 7.37 percent at the last five-year note sale on Aug. 28. 
 Of the bids that were accepted by the Treasury, more than 93 percent were submitted by New York-based primary dealers.
That was a sharp turnaround from Tuesday's two-year note auction, when New York dealers ended up buying only 78 percent of the $13 billion worth of notes that were sold. Typically, about 90 percent of all winning bids are placed through New York dealers.
The big drop in New York's share on Tuesday led to speculation among some market participants that the Salomon Brothers scandal might have persuaded banks, pension funds and other big institutions that in the past have placed bids through New York's 35 primary dealers to bypass the dealers and submit bids directly with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
 
No Ready Explanations
 Traders and analysts were at a loss to explain the swing back in the number of dealers placing bids. But because of its longer maturity, the five-year securities are more speculative instruments than two-year notes. As such, dealers are generally more comfortable buying the riskier securities than other investors might be.
"In terms of distribution, this was a much more normal auction," one government bond trader said. "But it is also the first auction since the Salomon scandal broke that the price of the issue has fallen after the results were announced. Now we will have to see how the market reacts to paper that for the first time in six weeks or so is trading at a loss."
Late yesterday the five-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.06 percent.
The five-year auction took place during a session when prices in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds fell slightly in light trading.
Reports that new orders for durable goods and sales of existing homes both fell during August were largely shrugged off by traders.
 
Drop in Durable Goods
 The 3.8 percent drop in durable goods orders was somewhat smaller than most analysts had expected, and only partly erased the huge 11.7 percent increase reported for July.
To some analysts, a second consecutive increase in order backlogs was more important than the drop in new orders.
"The fact that unfilled orders rose for the second straight month suggests a continued moderate increase in production," said Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. "What remains unclear is whether there will be enough of a pickup in final demand to support further growth."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 102 19/32, down 5/ 32, to yield 7.89 percent, compared with 7.88 percent late Tuesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 1/8 in late trading, down 2/ 32, to yield 7.56 percent. And the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes auctioned on Tuesday were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 6.10 percent.
 
Bill Rates Off Slightly
 Rates on short-term Treasury bills fell marginally.
By late in the session three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.15 percent, down 2 basis points, or two-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 1 basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.19 percent.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, investors snapped up a $524 million offering of serial bonds from the State of California.
The securities, which were sold at competitive bid, were won by a group led by BankAmerica.
The securities were reoffered to investors at yields from 4.30 percent on bonds maturing in 1992 to a maximum yield of 6.35 percent on securities maturing in 2010 and 2011.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Investment bankers involved in the transaction said late yesterday that all but $46 million of the bonds had been sold.
 
Corporate Issues
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager on an offering of $150 million worth of three-year notes for Wells Fargo & Company.
The 7 5/8 percent notes, which mature Oct. 1, 1994, were priced at $99.724 to yield 7.73 percent, 1.35 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by about 1/8 point.
Corporate bond traders said price of most issues in the secondary market for investment-grade issues were little changed. Activity remains very light, they said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
French Retailer Seeks Piece Of the Fifth Avenue Trade

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
As Galeries Lafayette prepares to open its first American store in Trump Tower on Saturday, two questions seem to be on everyone's lips: Who will Donald Trump escort to the black-tie gala this evening? And can the fashionable French store survive some of the stiffest competition in American retailing?
The question about Mr. Trump's sidekick will be answered tonight, but questions about Galeries Lafayette's success will take longer to answer. After all, other French, Japanese and Italian retailers have faltered badly in the United States. After the curiosity seekers have browsed through the store, retailing experts say, they wonder whether Galeries Lafayette can attract the jaded and cautious shoppers who have severely cut back their spending at its Fifth Avenue neighbors. 
 "It must be different," said Kurt Barnard, a widely followed retailing consultant and publisher of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report. "If it can't distinguish itself from other specialty stores, people will come on opening day to see what it's like and then go right back to shopping at Bloomingdale's and Saks."
Georges Meyer, the Paris-based chain's vibrant chairman and chief executive, simultaneously acknowledges his competition and dismisses it. "I would be a fool not to be concerned, but I can only say that it's always the same thing," he said. "In the desert island, you have no competition, but you also have no customers. In New York, you have many, many customers and also much competition."
Among Galeries Lafayette's nearest neighbors are Bergdorf Goodman and Henri Bendel, while Bloomingdale's and Saks Fifth Avenue anchor the outposts of one of the world's premier shopping districts.
The mere mention of such names has chilled the ambitions of many potential competitors. But Mr. Meyer and Eugenia Ulasewicz, the former Bloomindale's executive he chose to head up Galeries Lafayette U.S.A., are forging ahead with an almost exclusive mix of European labels, carrying price tags of $300 to $700 for women's suits and dresses. The Manhattan store will carry only women's clothing, accessories and cosmetics.
From the cafe au lait and croissants on opening day to the cash registers with bilingual displays, Galeries Lafayette, at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, is making a point of being Gallic. "We don't have to be French; we are a French store," said Ms. Ulasewicz, who is an American. "As a French store, we are going to be different from the merchandise we sell to the currency exchange service we have."
The French sights, sounds and smells all add up to a loud vive la difference, which retail experts say is almost the only way Galeries Lafayette can survive. Other foreign retailers have faltered in the United States because they emulated their successful American counterparts too closely, said Jack Hyde, a professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology.
He cited Seibu, the flashy Japanese department store chain that opened a branch in Los Angeles in the early 1960's. It closed when customers learned they could get the same merchandise across the street at the May Company.
 
Others' Attempts
 After its initial success, Benetton, the Italian sportswear company, has had difficulty in the United States market. And Takashimaya, the Japanese department store chain that is building an office tower on Fifth Avenue, has planned a retail store on the lower floors but is proceeding cautiously after a previous specialty store venture in New York failed to meet the company's expectations.
"Differences in culture, differences in society, make it difficult for outsiders to operate a department store here," said Jiro Shinohara, executive vice president of Takashimaya U.S.A.
Mr. Meyer contended that there were very specific reasons why other foreign retailers failed to win over the price-sensitive American consumer.
In the case of a well-established competitor, Au Printemps, a French department store that opened an American branch in 1987 and closed it in 1989, its location in a mall outside Denver had more to do with its demise than its choice of merchandise or its selling strategies, he said.
At Galeries Lafayette, only one American garment maker, Nicole Miller, is represented among the predominantly French designs hung on the sculptured steel racks specially designed for the store by the Walker Group, a New York-based architectural firm.
Kookai, Claudie Pierlot, Jean-Charles de Castelbajac, Lolita Bis, Plein Sud and P. J. Hoenscheid are among the many European labels that make up the $10 million worth of merchandise in the store for the opening. Some of these labels are carried by other New York specialty and department stores, but Galeries Lafayette will carry them in greater depth.
Other experts say Galeries Lafayette may even turn the tables on its American competitors. Many American chains are saddled with huge debts, are in bankruptcy or are simply suffering through the recession, which gives foreign retailers an advantage.
 
Good Timing for a Move?
 "Yes, it's a zero-sum game, but the toll of that game has left the U.S. retailing industry in a very precarious position," said Randall E. Gebhardt, senior partner with Retail Planning Associates Inc., a retail consulting firm based in Columbus, Ohio.
"Take Bloomingdale's and Macy's," Mr. Gebhardt said. "Both of those operators because of their financial structures are unable to implement the aggressive marketing and merchandising strategies that would enable them to fend off an aggressor like Galeries Lafayette."
That advantage, coupled with the strong relationships Galeries Lafayette has built with designers over its 99-year history, will give the store an advantage.
Galeries Lafayette can coax its designers into producing exclusive merchandise or allowing Galeries Lafayette to introduce their lines in the United States. Lolita Lempica, for example, is starting her more moderately priced or "bridge" line.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 8.05 as Nasdaq Index Sets Record

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell slightly in rudderless trading yesterday, while smaller issues reached record levels for the second time in four sessions.
The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 8.05 points, to 3,021.02. But the Nasdaq composite index, which tracks the performance of smaller stocks traded over the counter, rose 1.34, to 527.81, shattering the record set on Friday. In that session, the index surged 4.52, to 527.19. 
 "People are looking to the over-the-counter market for smaller stocks that haven't participated in this overall rally," said Norman J. Shapiro, the senior vice president and manager of equities at Vantage Securities in Edison, N.J. "People are looking for value."
 
Trading at 153.9 Million
 Volume on the Big Board was light, with 153.9 million shares traded; a moderate 171.5 million shares changed hands on Tuesday. Declining issues outpaced advancing ones yesterday, 838 to 732.
Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.83, to 386.88, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index lost 0.37, to 212.53. But the American Stock Exchange market-value index crept up 0.75, to 372.91.
As in Friday's session, the interest in smaller stocks was fueled yesterday by gains in computer and biotechnology issues, analysts said.
Oracle Systems, up 2 1/8, to 13 5/8, was the most actively traded over-the-counter issue, with 10.2 million shares changing hands. The software company said on Tuesday that net income for its first fiscal quarter, which ended on Aug. 31, was $2.4 million, or 2 cents a share, compared with a loss of $29 million, or 22 cents a share, in the 1990 period. The report was better than expected, and several analysts raised their earnings estimates for the company.
Other over-the-counter winners were the 3Com Corporation, a computer company, which climbed 1 1/2, to 9 3/4; Immunex, a biotechnology company, which soared 4 3/4, to 51, and Chiron, another biotechnology company, which inched up 1 5/8, to 70 1/4.
But blue-chip issues did not fare as well, bobbing up and down within a narrow trading range for most of the day before slipping a bit in the last two hours of trading.
 
Some Staying Out
 Many investors, eager for fresh economic news and uneasy about third-quarter earnings, continued to sit on the sidelines. But trading was active in some selective stocks.
Upjohn, up 3 1/4, to 47 1/2, rose sharply on what traders said were recurring rumors that the pharmaceutical company might soon face a hostile takeover attempt. Upjohn would not to comment on the rumors.
General Dynamics, up 3 7/8, to 49 1/2, was the biggest winner on the Big Board, following positive remarks by its chairman and chief executive, William A. Anders. He said the company's third-quarter earnings would probably exceed $1.50 a share, the median of estimates by analysts. Mr. Anders also said the company was considering the possibility of a stock buyback or special dividend.
For the second straight day, Salomon Brothers gained on the Big Board, closing up 5/8, to 23 1/8. Though it dipped on Tuesday morning to its low for the year, the stock rebounded that afternoon and closed up 3/4, to 22 1/2. Trading in the stock continued to be heavy yesterday.
In a letter made public on Tuesday, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, indicated that Salomon's house-cleaning in response to the Treasuries market scandal last month might preserve its status as a primary dealer.
Another brokerage, Morgan Stanley & Company, leaped 3 5/8, to 52 5/8. Some analysts said yesterday that they had increased their projected 1991 earnings estimates for Morgan. It was the second strong performance for the stock in as many days; Morgan closed up 1 1/4, to 49, on Tuesday.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Home Desk

LENGTH: 2054 words

HEADLINE: Inventors in Search Of New Must-Haves

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
MEMORABLE dates in the annals of home improvement. 1860: Li- noleum. 1938: Teflon. 1945: Tup- perware. 2001: Floating furni- ture.
History marches on. 
 Humankind has a seemingly inexhaustible lust for invention. Ten years ago, it was almost impossible to predict that by 1991, fax machines and portable telephones would be the stuff of everyday life. By 2001, according to a new book, they may be joined by voice-activated microwave ovens, floating furniture, robot bartenders and remote-controlled vacuum cleaners.
Dr. Myun W. Lee, a human factors engineer and director of the Research Institute of Engineering Science at Seoul National University in South Korea, is convinced that the world will be a better place because of his mushroom-shaped, remote-control vacuum cleaner, now in production. It works like a toy robot and has a snap-off control box attached to its handle.
"If you are in the mood for exercise, go to the aerobics club," he said in a telephone interview. "Don't vacuum."
"More Future Stuff: Over 250 Inventions That Will Change Your Life by 2001," by Malcolm Abrams and Harriet Bernstein, to be published by Penguin Books next month, explores the outer limits of human ingenuity. From Jetsonian high-tech engineers to resolute backyard putterers, the book chronicles designs that are actually on the drawing board or in production.
Many of the ideas spring from personal experience. "We all have an element of creativity," said Gerald Udell, a professor of marketing at Southwest Missouri State University who evaluates inventions for individuals and companies. "The question is, do we take that creativity and do something with it?"
Ingenuity needs to be matched by gumption. Had a Swiss machine shop operator not been obsessed with burrs, there would have been no Velcro. Had an Oregon track coach not stuffed a piece of rubber into his wife's waffle iron, the world would be without the Nike waffle sole.
According to Harold Livesay, a professor of business and economic history at Texas A & M University in College Station, Tex., there is now a tendency to view inventors as kooks despite a flourishing culture of entrepreneurship. In contrast to Thomas Edison's era, he said, "we've become awfully homogeneous."
"Inventors are risk-takers," he added. "Somewhere early in the 20th century, we shifted from being a risk-taking to a risk-minimizing society."
So behold the risk-takers, the absent-minded professors, the ordinary people equipped with extraordinary ideas. Time will tell which of their concepts will be the microwave ovens of the future, and which are destined for the manual garbage compactor (a new invention).
"A robot bartender might not change the world," said Mr. Abrams. "But if we ever stop believing, we're at a standstill."
Here are some of the new inventions.
 
Vacuum Cleaner
 Dr. Myun W. Lee's motto is, "Let your fingers do the cleaning."
His remote-control vacuum cleaner, called the Power Brush, is one in a line of "High-Touch" products being manufactured by Daewoo Electronics of Seoul, South Korea. In developing the design, which is currently in production but being revised, Dr. Lee had "people with disabilities, the elderly and yuppies" in mind (estimated cost, $500).
To operate the Power Brush, attach the control box to the base and take a seat. To empty, lift the flip-top lid.
Most high-tech products force consumers to "tip-toe through too many functions," he said, adding, "Ordinary people have to learn too many transient things."
Among Dr. Lee's inventions are a voice-activated microwave oven and a personalized television. Upon hearing a verbal command, the oven opens and delivers its tray. Its data base, containing more than 200 recipes, can tell a cook when to "prepare onions"; the rather presumptuous contraption will also have a personalized salt and sugar detector.
Dr. Lee's television adjusts the color according to the program. "If you're watching sports, you might want to emphasize red, blue and yellow," he explained. "Indicate 'Drama' and the colors will go pastel."
 
Infant Exerciser
 On a single day, Drs. Daniel and Lois Fermaglich, husband-and-wife pediatricians in Denville, N.J., treated three infants who had severely injured themselves in walkers.
"Children move five feet per second in a walker," Lois Fermaglich said. "If we don't come up with an alternative, people are going to keep using them."
The Fermaglichs took the challenge. Their stationary infant exerciser, which has yet to find a manufacturer, uses a treadmill that allows a baby to exercise his or her legs without getting into mischief.
The baby sits on a rotating seat in the middle of a circular tray. The device "lets a baby use the upper arm muscles, which develop first, as well as sit, stand, turn, look around the room and play," Dr. Fermaglich said.
A perennial parenting problem is where to seat the baby. Dr. Fermaglich said infants love the stationary walker. Until their idea reaches fruition (estimated cost, $80 to $100), she advises parents to take the wheels off walkers.
"Frustration is a parental concept," she said.
 
Holographic Windows
 Watching the winter sunlight stream through her apartment overlooking the Charles River in Boston, Elisabeth King, an architectural designer, began to dream about new ways to get sunlight into buildings.
She and three colleagues, Hendrik J. Gerritsen, Donald Thorton and David Pitcher, are now developing holographic windows. Their "holographic diffractive structure," a ridgy plastic film, would be incorporated into windows and bend sunlight in a new way.
"Instead of hitting the floor, it would hit the ceiling," Ms. King said. "Rooms would be suffused with a broad gentle glow, like a very big skylight without the hole."
The partners in the Advanced Environmental Research Group Inc. of Providence, R.I., have yet to invent a mass-production process, but are confident of its viability and its ramifications for home design.
"Getting beautiful sunlight into buildings usually requires large amounts of glass," she said. "This would bring nicer light into small areas. You could even project sun to where the plants are."
 
Floating Furniture
 Dr. William Calderwood, a family practitioner in Peoria, Ariz., has a rather Disneyesque idea.
"Space is at such a premium," he said. "I thought, wouldn't it be wonderful if the bed could rise up majestically off the floor?"
The doctor is quite serious about his patented invention, which was inspired by his 6-year-old son, Adam, , who has spinal muscular atrophy. With the Silver Rainbow Company of Hayward, Calif., Dr. Calderwood developed a prototype helium-filled floating bed, which "prevents pressure sores," he said. And unlike a water bed, it is lighter than air.
 
Robot Bartender
 Stephen Grevan, the president of Honeybee Robotics of Manhattan, calls his Robotender "the first step to a more completely automated home."
Mr. Grevan's company designs robots for NASA; this one, however, has commercial potential. With a reach of 4 1/2 feet, the steel-armed bartender (estimated cost, $175,000) is programmed to mix more than 100 drinks, ordered via a personal computer. It can also make coffee and tea.
"Robots like highly organized environments," he said, adding that this one can "measure the perfect dryness in a martini and keep it uniform. That's not something people can do."
 
Portable Vacation Homes
 Hypertat is an acronym for High Performance Habitat, a modular building developed by Mike Jantzen and Ted Bakewell 3d of St. Louis. Like gigantic Lego blocks, the modules, made primarily of plastic, are designed to create small, well-insulated buildings as well as complexes of several thousand square feet, said Mr. Bakewell, a builder.
Unlike a tent, Hypertat is a permanent, rigid-walled structure that sits on telescoping legs above the ground.
There are three test units in the field: an atmospheric research lab 12,000 feet up in the Rockies, a NASA lab in Mississippi and one in the Biosphere 2 in Arizona.
"We want to bring sustainable, energy-efficient creature comforts to remote areas," he said.
The cost for the "ecologically sensitive" habitat would range from $50 to $150 a square foot. The idea, he said, is to "combine the convenience and freedom of an RV with the size and comfort of traditional buildings."
 
Bike Wheels
 Futuristic bicycle wheels, which take their design cues from NASA airfoils, are already on the market. They were designed by Mark W. Hopkins, an avid cyclist and a senior research engineer with Du Pont's Advanced Composites Division, and his colleague Frank Principe.
Instead of bladed spokes, the wheels have three thick high-performance spokes configured like a large peace symbol. The airfoil shapes allow air to pass with minimum resistance, resulting in lower drag.
The wheels, consisting of an aluminum rim and spokes made of carbon, epoxy resin, glass and Kevlar fibers, enable a serious biker to travel a full mile an hour faster.
At $750 a wheel, that's who they are intended for -- though "some people are buying them because they look neat," Mr. Hopkins said.
 
Roll-Up Grill
 LeRoy Shinler, a sprinkler fitter in Rush City, Minn., loved family snowmobile outings but hated cleaning up after the hotdog roasts.
"After cooking, you have a greasy mess," he said, "and what do you do with it?"
For years he tried to figure out a way to make a roll-up grill that could be tucked under the snowmobile hood. He finally succeeded in developing a prototype; it has four bendable legs and rolls one way into a cylindrical container -- an ingenious procrastination device that staves off cleaning until you get home (estimated cost, $40).
 
Manual Compactor
 Henry Massonnet, a French inventor, has made a product for the 90's that is already in the marketplace: a manual garbage compactor. Now being distributed by Compac Manufacturing of Virginia Beach, Va., the compactor, which retails for $39.95, is the size of a large-size kitchen garbage can.
"There are more and more packages, and we are creative," Mr. Massonnet said. "This compacts them, you know?"
A standard garbage bag fits inside; when a lever on the lid is pulled, the refuse is crushed.
 
Gutter Cleaner
 William Putnam, a machine operator for Boeing who lives in Portland, Ore., dreads cleaning gutters.
"It's one of the most neglected chores," he said. "It's painstaking. It's dangerous."
So he went to the hardware store, convinced, he said, "that there's got to be some tool for the homeowner that does the same thing as a ladder and water hose."
There wasn't. So he invented one.
He bought some plastic plumbing and a pop-up sprinkler and took a sliding handle off a car-wash brush. The result is his patented Gutter-Cleaning Machine, yet to be manufactured (estimated cost, under $20.) As he explained, it allows the homeowner to "spray along the gutter channel and do the job while they're just walking along."
 
NewHardy Grass
 From the National Turfgrass Evaluation program in Beltsville Md., a self-supporting program partly financed by the Federal Department of Agriculture, comes a new product and uplifting news: a fast-seeding grass that requires 30 to 50 percent less water. The lawn is a mixture of zoysia, known for its ability to withstand heat, drought and poor soil, and tall fescue, a type of cool-season grass. Previously, zoysia had to be planted plug-by-plug like a hair transplant, a time-consuming and expensive business. It also turned brown in winter.
Kevin N. Morris, an agronomist who is the program's director, said the new mixture, which will probably be available in two to three years, is "just about year-round green."
Seed for a 5,000-square-foot lawn would probably cost about $50. A test patch of four acres planted on the Washington Mall withstood the Operation Desert Storm celebrations and recovered in six weeks.
The lawn is potentially exciting because, as Mr. Morris said, "it can forgive the homeowner." The grass, which in tests established itself in 12 to 14 weeks, stayed greener with less water and fertilizer than conventional grass and -- mowers, take heart! -- if not mowed for several weeks, "the neighbors won't call the police on you."

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD

BYLINE: By Lawrence Kutner

 BODY:
CHILDREN who are old enough to know what they want, but not yet aware of how much things cost, sometimes become angry and confused when their parents cannot afford to buy things their friends have. Their innocence allows them to ask questions and make statements that can upset parents or make them feel guilty.
Sandra Bou-Assi remembers the confused look on her 8-year-old son Bashir's face this summer. They had invited another boy to their home in Arlington, Mass., to play. The boy refused because they did not own a Nintendo game. 
 "I told Bashir that his friend is the one who's missing out because we do a lot of fun things here," said Ms. Bou-Assi, a single unemployed mother of two sons whose budget is stretched to the limit. Her sons have been asking for separate bedrooms; they do not understand that she cannot afford higher rent. They also refuse to eat the free breakfast and lunch the school provides because doing so will encourage their classmates to tease them.
"It's difficult for them because children can be vicious," Ms. Bou-Assi said. "When their friends go to Disneyland, they want to go, too. I tell them that they'll get there eventually, but they'll have to wait."
To understand why children are so envious and demanding at certain ages, parents must consider a child's stage of development, the values of their household and the symbolism involved.
Preschoolers' demands are likely to be transient. A 4-year-old who sees a particular doll or toy for the first time may insist, with great melodrama, that she has wanted it "all her life!"
"Often the best thing you can do is to avoid impulse buying," said Dr. Martin E. Ford, a developmental psychologist and an associate professor of education at Stanford University. "If you wait a few days, the child's desire will often go away by itself."
In elementary school, children are much more interested in comparing themselves to their peers, and have a much greater desire to fit in. As with adults, money takes on a more symbolic value.
"Adults use money to buy security, affection, power and recognition," said Dr. Kenneth O. Doyle, a psychologist at the University of Minnesota specializing in the psychology of money, who added that children learn the value of money from their parents. He has found that what bothers many children is not being poorer, but standing out from the crowd.
"When children interact, poorer children can feel ashamed, unloved, isolated or weak because they don't have or do the things other children can," Dr. Doyle said. "But richer children can feel tainted by money because it might cause them to be rejected by their classmates. Deep down, they're convinced that their family must have done something bad to have gotten it."
Psychologists stress the importance of looking beneath the surface to learn why a child wants something expensive.
Children can be helped to understand those reasons and explore alternatives. For example, a child who insists on buying expensive athletic shoes may just want to belong to a particular social group at school. He views the shoes as a ticket to acceptance, but may not see other ways to fit in with the same crowd.
Similarly, a girl who covets a particular piece of jewelry may be looking for a sign that her parents recognize her growing maturity. An increase in her privileges might give her the same satisfaction.
"You can use these situations to begin teaching your children what you value," Dr. Ford said.
By exploring beneath the surface, parents can also gain control of their own emotions, which are often triggered by a child's questions.
"The big error is for the parents to feel humiliated and shamed for not providing everything the children want," said Dr. Rita P. Underberg, a clinical professor of psychiatry at the University of Rochester Medical Center. "The attitude of the parents will affect how the children feel about themselves."
 
Discover What the Real Need Is
 HAVING your child ask for something you cannot afford or prefer not to buy can be very distressing. Here are some ways to find out what the child's real need is:
Take your child's emotions seriously.
"Don't minimize your child's disappointment,," said Dr. Rita P. Underberg, a clinical professor of psychiatry at the University of Rochester Medical Center. A request for something extravagant or unusual is often a sign the child is feeling rejected by other children. If you ignore those feelings and desires, the child will feel even more rejected and may conclude that you are not a safe person to talk to since you are rejecting him as well.
Try to keep your own emotions out of it.
Remember that money is often a symbol for something else, although it may symbolize different things to you and to your child.
"Be matter-of-fact in stating that you cannot afford something, rather than weighing your child down with your own anxieties over finances," advised Dr. Kenneth O. Doyle, a psychologist at the University of Minnesota specializing in the psychology of money. "Talk about ways you might be able to save enough to do it in the future."
Remember that preschoolers often interpret a rejection of their ideas as a rejection of themselves. "Try not to convey the attitude that they're bad if they ask," Dr. Doyle said.
Talk to your children about the values of the television programs and commercials they watch.
Many programs offer an unrealistically high standard of living. Commercials tout the social and practical benefits of products without mentioning the costs. Children do not have much perspective on either.
"It makes many children feel that Mom and Dad aren't successful because they don't live like most of the families on TV," Dr. Doyle said. "That breeds shame and resentment."
Consider offering your child a "matching grant" for an item she wants.
If your child wants a thing that is only a bit out of your normal price range, think about whether she might combine money she saves with money from you. This has two advantages: It delays the purchase, so the child may decide it is unnecessary. And children tend to be much more critical shoppers when their own money is involved.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Borden Official Moves Up To Post of Chief Executive

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Anthony S. D'Amato was elected chief executive of Borden Inc., the company announced yesterday. He has been president and chief operating officer of the food and industrial products company since July 1990.
Mr. D'Amato, who succeeds R. J. Ventres on Nov. 1, said in a telephone interview yesterday that his priority for the company was completing a two-year-old restructuring plan intended to streamline its business and shed unprofitable operations, particularly in the dairy industry. 
 The company has said it expects an earnings decline in the third and fourth quarters, and lower per-share earnings for the year if the pressures of the recession and stiff competition in the snack food industry continue.
"This is the world we live in," Mr. D'Amato said. "The economy has not been great. We are into one heck of a contest in the snack food area."
But Mr. D'Amato said he expected the company, which had flat growth last year with $7.6 billion in sales, would begin to realize the benefits of its $700 million program of modernization, construction, and consolidation in the coming year.
"In 1992," he said, "I expect earnings will start to be generated."
Wall Street analysts were cautious, however, about Borden's immediate prospects. William F. Mcguire, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, said that Mr. D'Amato's background in chemical and other non-food divisions of the company, put him in a disadvantage in handling food operations, which are responsible for roughly 75 percent of the company's sales.
"It means that in the next four or five years he has to learn about food on the job," Mr. Mcguire said. "The fact of the matter is that we on Wall Street don't have great confidence that he knows a lot about marketing and that is the name of the game in the 1990's."
Mr. D'Amato attended the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn as an undergraduate and spent two years at Northwestern University as a graduate student. After working for the General Electric Company for seven years, Mr. D'Amato joined Borden in 1959 as an engineering manager for film operations. He was later named general manger of the Resinite department and was later made vice president and president of the Chemical division, succeeding Mr. Ventres.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Asked to Expand Undercover Bias Testing

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -

 BODY:
Scholars and civil rights supporters are calling on the Federal Government to expand the use of undercover investigations to root out discrimination in employment, housing and business.
Arguing that much bias against black and Hispanic people goes undetected, the scholars say such operations would go a long way in documenting the problem and could be an effective tool in enforcing antidiscrimination laws. 
 "It's cheap, it's doable and it provides conclusive evidence of discrimination," said Michael Fix, a senior researcher at the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research institute based here that is holding a conference Thursday on the use of undercover investigations in antidiscrimination policy.
 
Checking for Race Bias
 The technique generally involves sending people who are alike in virtually every way except race or ethnicity to apply for jobs, housing or mortgages. The results are then analyzed for how differently whites are treated diferently from black or Hispanic people .
State and local fair-housing groups often use testers to ferret out bias in the sale and rental of housing.
The group of scholars and civil rights backers plans to publish its findings and make them available to Congress and other policymaking bodies. In addition to researchers at the institute, the group includes professors from several universities and lawyers from the Washington Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law.
At present, only the Department of Housing and Urban Development, among Federal agencies, provides money for undercover operations to enforce antidiscrimination statutes or to study the extent of discrimination.
 
Ethical Concerns
 Citing ethical concerns, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve today rejected a proposal to use undercover investigators to expose mortgage lenders who discriminate against minority borrowers. "I have very serious questions about whether the central bank should be sponsoring and supporting deception," Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Fed, said at the meeting.
Figures that will be reported at the Urban Institute's conference indicate that New York City had one of the country's worst records when it comes to housing discrimination.
A study conducted by the Federal housing department found that in 61 percent of the cases in which white and Hispanic people attempted to purchase a house in New York, the whites received more favorable treatment. The study found that in 44 percent of the cases the whites were treated better than blacks when trying to buy a house.
The study considered unfavorable treatment to have occurred when a minority person was told that an advertised house or apartment was no longer available when in fact it was, or when a white was shown more houses or apartments than a black or Hispanic person, or when minorities were quoted different financial terms, from the amount of rent and security deposit to or whether utilities were included.
 
New Issue in the Debate
 Mr. Fix is among those who say using undercover investigators in employment discrimination could put to rest a thesis, which has gained currency recently, that the main type of bias today is favoring minorities over whites, or "reverse discrimination."
Many civil rights groups and Government agencies rely on statistics to provide evidence of lingering discrimination. These groups reason that the lack of minorities in a company or getting mortgage loans indicate the presence of bias.
Conservatives have argued that statistics are not proof of discrimination, since they cannot show whether the disparity was the result of bias or of other factors.
In a paper that he will present at the conference, Mr. Fix and his colleague Raymond Struyk compare the debate over the 1988 amendments to the Federal Fair Housing Act to the current Congressional battle over the civil rights bill. The two authors assert that because studies using undercover testers have been so common in the housing area, few people question the fact that discrimination is widespread there.
This authors argue that as a result, there was little difficulty in gaining passage of amendments to the Fair Housing Act that would allow for fines of up to $100,000 for anyone convicted of discriminating in housing. The measure was strongly supported by George Bush, who was then Vice President.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Painted by Numbers, 1980's Are Rosy To G.O.P., While Democrats See Red

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
There's a story line for sale in Washington these days, and it goes something like this:
In 1981, a Republican President came to town, deeply concerned about social justice. Over the next decade, he and his successor raised the tax burdens of the rich, expanded social spending for the poor and eased the financial woes of the middle class. By every important measure, 10 years of Republican rule have made America a fairer place. 
 Whatever one thinks of the story, it does not sound familiar. And its Republican authors say that is precisely the point.
Stung by the repeated Democratic assertion that the Reagan-Bush years enriched the wealthy at the expense of everyone else, they have been arming themselves with fresh studies and a newly insistent tone for what is being called the "fairness debate."
 
Swapping of Statistics
 "The rich got richer and the poor got richer, and that's a good thing," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who helped write a study defending the 1980's as a jeweled crown of growth and prosperity for all. "I don't think there was any unfairness in it."
Such suggestions make the eyes of Democratic leaders widen and their veins bulge. They counter with a barrage of numbers that purport to show a tattered safety net, widening income gaps and tax breaks for the rich.
At stake in this swapping of often-esoteric statistics are decisions on taxes and spending that involve hundreds of billions of dollars, as well as an edge in the 1992 Presidential race. Both sides play with sharp elbows, few statistical referees and the frequent imputation that their adversaries have all the intellectual credibility of unreconstructed Soviet historians.
"This is in the spirit of 'Joseph Stalin was a sweet man,' " Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, said in an interview this week of what he called the Republican rehabilitation of the 1980's.
 
New Poverty Figures
 The partisan jousting over social equity is likely to take on new life on Thursday, when the Census Bureau makes public its annual measure of poverty in America, a count colored by recession and expected to show significant increases in the number of poor people.
So divided are the two sides that they cannot even agree when the 1980's began. Republicans tend to date their analyses forward from the growth that began in 1983, while Democrats sometimes talk of the Reagan-Bush era while pointing to trends in inequality that began in the 1970's.
 
Republicans Play Catch-uUp
 During last year's budget debate, the Democrats used their arguments about fairness to great effect, turning back Administration proposals that they said would have required a larger sacrifice from the poor than from the wealthy.
Since then the Republicans have been involved in a game of catchup. The latest salvo has come from Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the ranking minority member of the House Ways and Means Committee. Writing in the summer issue of Policy Review, published by the Heritage Foundation, he trieds to rally the conservative faithful, saying, "The facts are on our side."
 
The Boom Years
 When Republicans talk about income growth, they tend to emphasize the period from 1983 to 1989, when it could fairly be said that the rich got richer and the poor did too.
In that period, the nation enjoyed its longest peacetime expansion, the poverty rate steadily declined and median family income reached its an all-time high of $34,200, using 1989 figures adjusted for inflation. Meanwhile, they say, both inflation and unemployment dissipated.
Most of what makes this statistical picture hold, however, is the declaration that the 1980's began with the roaring year of 1983 and the ommission of the current recession. Defending this choice, many Republicans say it took two years for the Reagan policies to take effect.
 
Still Below High of '79
 But others cry dirty pool.
"If you compare things at the bottom of a recession to a recovery year, of course things are going to look good," said Robert Greenstein of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research organization attacked by Republicans for its statistics on income inequality.
Democrats say the poor were devastated by the recession in the early 1980's -- which many in the party say was induced largely by Republican choice -- and that they have still not recovered. In 1989, the mean family income for the poorest fifth of Americans was $9,400, or $400 less, in dollars adjusted for inflation, than its all-time high 10 years earlier.
Democrats also argue that while incomes grew for everyone they grew much faster for the wealthiest. Figures of the Congressional Budget Office figures show that from 1977 to 1988, the inflation-adjusted incomes of the bottom 90 percent grew by only a 10th of a percent. Those of the richest 1 percent exploded with a 96 percent gain.
 
Patterns of Stagnation Seen
 Democrats use figures like those to argue that the middle class is under stress, and that Republican boasts of record median incomes mask darker trends. The median family income of $34,200, while a record, represents only a 2.4 percent increase over 10 years, a rate they call meager.
They argue that the only reason middle-class families have seemed to keep pace is that they are working harder, adopting a treadmill life style that more and more relies on a second wage earner.
Many point to the research of Frank Levy, an economist at the University of Maryland, who traces wage stagnation back to the rise in energy prices in 1973. From 1958 to 1973, he said, the median income of a 50-year-old man, working full time, grew by more than half, from $20,400 to $31,900 in numbers adjusted to 1989. Since then, it has virtually languished, coming in at $32,700 in 1988, dealing a blow to the American expectation of generational progress.
 
'Rich Man's Burden'
 On taxes, those emphasizing the fairness of the 1980's essentially repeat the arguments with which the decade was launched: When rates are cut, the economy booms and the rich end up paying more in absolute dollars than they would have.
Representative Archer points to what he calls the "rich man's burden." In 1981, he says, the wealthiest 5 percent of Americans accounted for 35 percent of total tax receipts; by 1988, that figure had risen to 46 percent. Over the same period, the share contributed by the entire bottom half of American earners dropped from 8 percent to 6 percent.
And while income taxes fell for everyone, he says, they fell most of all for the poor. Citing budget office data, he noted that income tax rates fell by 9 percent for the wealthiest fifth, but 20 percent for the middle three-fifths and 275 percent for the bottom fifth.
In 1980, the poorest fifth of Americans received refundable tax credits worth 0.4 percent of their income. By 1990, that figure had risen to 1.5 percent. While the budget office warns that expressing that change as a 275 percent gain is statistically "meaningless," Mr. Archer disagrees.
The Republicans also point proudly to the 1986 tax act that removed about six million poor families from the income tax rolls.
Not so fast, says the other camp: If the richest are contributing a greater portion of total tax dollars, that is only because they are receiving an even larger portion of total income.
And Democrats say whatever mercies were extended to the working poor by lowered income tax rates were more than offset by rises in Social Security taxes. When all Federal taxes are included, the richest fifth of Americans saw their tax rate drop from 27.3 percent in 1980 to 25.8 percent in 1990, a decline of 5 percent. At the same time, the poorest fifth saw their rate rise, from 8.4 percent to 9.7 percent, a 15 percent increase.
Perhaps nowhere do sharper differences emerge than when the two sides look at spending trends. Representative Archer argues that the Reagan years actually expanded the social safety net.
He has compiled a table of 38 Government programs for children and families and calculated an 18 percent, inflation-adjusted increase in social spending from 1981 to 1989. The calculations exclude huge programs like Social Security and Medicare, which primarily help the elderly.
An expanding social safety net? "Preposterous nonsense," snorted Representative Downey, just this side of apoplectic, before pinning responsibility for homelessness on what he called cuts in housing assistance.
It depends on what you count. Half of the increase in social spending figured by Mr. Archer came from a rise in health insurance costs for Federal and military workers. Colin Powell's health plan is scarcely what the Democrats consider a social program.
 
Program Cuts Listed
 Mr. Archer argues that housing assistance has grown by 65 percent. Mr. Greenstein argues that its rate of growth fell by 75 percent, and that the slowdown occurred just as the private market for low-income renters fell apart, causing the need for inexpensive housing to soar.
Outside the fray, observers often argue that the efforts at political scorekeeping detract from thinking about solving endemic economic problems, ranging from Government deficits to health care costs to failures in education and training.
"It begs the essential question: Have we laid the groundwork for a healthy future?" said John Karl Scholz, an economics professor at the University of Wisconsin and a former aide at the Council of Economic Advisers. "I think there's much reason for concern."

HEADLINE: News Media's Libel Costs Rising, Study Says

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
News organizations are increasingly likely to lose libel suits that go to a jury, and if they lose they are increasingly likely to face multimillion-dollar damage judgments, according to a new study by a New York-based organization that tracks libel law.
The organization, the Libel Defense Resource Center, said in a report to be released today that news organizations lost two-thirds of the libel trials in which they were involved in 1989 and 1990, and that the average award was just under $4.5 million. That was a tenfold increase from the average award of $432,000 in 1987-88, when defendants won half of such trials. 
 The report also estimated that about 90 percent of libel actions against the news media are dropped, settled or dismissed before going to trial.
 
Record Judgments Cited
 More and more juries are awarding huge sums in libel cases. For instance, a record libel judgment of $34 million set in 1990 against The Philadelphia Inquirer was broken earlier this year with a $58 million judgment against the Dallas-based Belo Broadcasting and its affiliate, WFAA-TV.
Such judgments have proved so potentially devastating to even the largest news organizations that some of them are settling with plaintiffs rather than risking a loss on appeal.
While The Inquirer, which is owned by Knight-Ridder Inc., is contesting its judgment, Belo Broadcasting, which is owned by the A. H. Belo Corporation, said in June that it had settled the case for an undisclosed sum.
In a letter to employees, Robert W. Decherd, Belo's chairman, said that because of the "sheer size" of the judgment the company's libel insurers had pressed for settlement, in part to avoid paying interest on the judgment during the appeals process, which could have taken three years.
Similarly, Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. of San Antonio has announced the settlement of a $29 million judgment for an undisclosed amount.
 
Raising the Ante
 "Huge awards are the most reversible, yet the economic ante has been raised to the point that the actuality of having the award collected is too Draconian," said Henry R. Kaufman, general counsel for the center. He added that such settlements can only encourage other libel plaintiffs.
The largest libel award ever affirmed by a Federal appeals court was in 1987 against WBBM-TV, a CBS-owned station in Chicago, for $1 million in compensatory damages and $2.05 million in punitive damages. In a commentary, a news anchor had suggested that Viceroy cigarettes had developed advertisements intended to attract minors to smoking, and the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation sued.
For a decade, the center has been analyzing trends in libel law, and the most recent two-year period reflects a renewed hostility to news organizations not seen since President Ronald Reagan's first term.
From 1981 to 1984, the average damage award was more than $2 million. In the 1985-86 period, the average declined to $1.2 million, and in 1987-88, the average dropped further, to $431,000.
The giant leap in the average damage award in the past two years to $4.5 million suggests that juries are once again inclined to punish news organizations.
"If there was a honeymoon it was a brief one," Mr. Kaufman said.
But there may have been some encouraging news in the center's report in that an average of 15 libel actions went to trial each year in 1989 and 1990, compared with an average of about 30 each year in the earlier 1980's.
News organizations may view that decline to an increased willingness by judges to dismiss libel suits before they get to trial. But the decline may also reflect a greater willingness for news organizations to settle libel suits outside court. Moreover, it may reflect a chilling effect on aggressive coverage by news organizations that might risk a libel action.

HEADLINE: Salvadoran Rebels Adjust to Fall in Political Power

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
Not so long ago in the arid hills that straddle El Salvador's northern border, it seemed that the Marxist guerrillas who died fighting the Salvadoran Government would simply be replaced by their sons and daughters.
So profound was the feeling of injustice in the region, rebel leaders insisted, that the civil war could go on forever unless the Government made profound political concessions. In the pockets of Salvadoran territory that the guerrillas controlled, boys carrying semi-automatic rifles echoed those assertions. 
 But with the signing yesterday at the United Nations of the first seemingly conclusive accords in seven years of peace talks, the guerrilla front appeared to have recognized that El Salvador has changed and that a generation of Salvadorans was slipping from its influence.
 
Trying Times
 Despite the global shift that helped to unseat their Sandinista patrons in Nicaragua and isolate Fidel Castro in Cuba, the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, known by its Spanish initials as the F.M.L.N., remains probably the most militarily potent insurgency that Latin America has ever seen.
What the rebels are no longer, according to opinion polls and independent analysts, is a strong and growing political force.
"The F.M.L.N. is worried because its political image has deteriorated significantly," said Ruben Zamora, a Salvadoran legislator who having long been allied with the guerrillas was the most prominent leftist politician to return from a life of exile to institutional politics.
"They recognize now that we were right," Mr. Zamora said in a telephone interview yesterday from San Salvador. "They want to achieve peace to participate in the elections of 1994."
The return to a legal political role has been a stated goal of the rebels since 1984, when the late Jose Napoleon Duarte, then the newly elected Christian Democratic President, called them to talks in the mountain town of La Palma.
 
Low-Intensity War
 But throughout the tortuous series of encounters that continued into 1988, neither the warriors who held sway in the rebel alliance nor the ascendant generation of commanders in the armed forces showed much willingness to compromise.
As the Salvadoran Army swept through rural areas with civic-action campaigns intended to gain the trust of peasants, the rebels countered with a two-track policy. In essence, the front tried to build its support among unionized workers and other Government opponents in the cities while pressing a low-intensity war of ambushes, land mines and sabotage in the countryside.
Late in 1985, the five factional armies of the rebel front renewed their efforts to unite under a single Marxist-Leninist political party. The attempt, which failed, suggested that the front had deferred its hopes of generating the kind of international support that buoyed the Sandinista insurrection in 1979 and instead saw the need to build internal unity and discipline as a greater priority.
Despite about $4 billion in economic and military aid from the United States to the Salvadoran Government, the war remained deadlocked after 1984. But that did not budge army and rebel leaders from their respective convictions that they could win military victory.
Salvador Sanchez Ceren, the 47-year-old former teacher who heads the oldest rebel army, the Popular Liberation Forces, underscored the paradox during an interview in a remote Salvadoran village late in 1985. For the war to end, he said, the Government "has to be convinced that the F.M.L.N. will never give up its guns."
But in trying to make that argument persuasively, the rebels found their military success increasingly in conflict with their political aims. Peasants and workers who had provided their traditional political base grew deeply tired of the fighting.
The guerrillas' goal of Marxist revolution also began to clash with the ideological direction of the governments and parties from which they had drawn support abroad. In 1982, France and Mexico pronounced the rebels a representative political force.But late in 1988, when they sent a diplomatic mission to European and Latin American countries, the rebels found themselves startlingly unwelcome.
In September 1989, Joaquin Villalobos, a former student activist who heads the People's Revolutionary Army faction and is recognized as the pre-eminent rebel leader, said for the first time that only with peace could the F.M.L.N. achieve its revolutionary goals. Yet many analysts believe that it took the outcome of the countrywide offensive that the rebels launched two months later to convince Mr. Villalobos and his comrades of his thesis.
The large-scale operation showed surprising rebel power and left little thought that they could be defeated on the battlefield. The simultaneous killings of six Jesuit priests, apparently by army soldiers, also dramatically undermined United States assertions to have reformed the Government armed forces.
But the insurgents also ran into devastating evidence that their hopes of setting off a popular insurrection had been far-fetched. In some poor neighborhoods, as guerrilla fighters approached, their would-be supporters ran away.
In a country where sympathy with the guerrillas has often been considered a crime, the reliability of polls of their popular support is difficult to judge. But apparently independent surveys showed support for the rebels at well under 10 percent while the the backing for Mr. Zamora and other leftist politicians who risked their lives to return home rose significantly. In 1989 elections, their Democratic Convergence polled less than 4 percent; last year, the Convergence gathered more than 12 percent.
The difficult chemistry between the Government and rebel officials was apparently overcome when Mr. Sanchez and Mr. Villalobos joined the three other senior rebel commanders -- the Communist Party leader, Shafik Handal; Eduardo Sancho, a former high school teacher who leads the National Resistance faction, and Francisco Jovel, another former student leader who leads the smallest F.M.L.N. faction -- at the United Nations.
Still, it was impossible last night not to wonder how easily men like Mr. Villalobos, a guerrilla for half his life, would be able to reintegrate themselves into Salvadoran society.
"If all of these changes are made, it would be worth it to lose some elections," the boyish-looking commander, often called one of the most ruthless of rebel leaders, said in an interview after the accords were signed. "Without them, it would not be worth anything to win them."
Throughout most of a news conference, rebel leaders appeared almost sobered by the prospect of the negotiations ahead. But at one moment, Mr. Villalobos marveled at the thought that the security forces that have been blamed for thousands of killings would be disbanded.
"Can you imagine what this implies?" he asked, smiling. "This, obviously, is a real revolution."

HEADLINE: SALVADORAN CHIEF AND REBELS REACH BROAD AGREEMENT

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The Salvadoran President, Alfredo Cristiani, and five guerrilla commanders reached a broad agreement today on the country's political and economic future that was seen as a major breakthrough in the search for peace in El Salvador.
Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who convened negotiations between the two sides in New York 10 days ago, said it was his "firm expectation" that what is called the New York Agreement would break the deadlock in the negotiations. He said negotiations would resume Oct. 12 for a cease-fire. 
 President Cristiani, in an interview shortly before departing for San Salvador, predicted an end to the country's 11-year-old civil war by the end of the year.
 
'Victory of Democracy'
 Schafick Handal, leader of the Salvadoran Communist Party and spokesman for the five insurgent groups, said the agreement was of "great transcendence" and constituted "a new victory of democracy in El Salvador." He said it represented social and political advances made possible by the 11 years of civil war.
The agreement, which climaxes a negotiating process begun 18 months ago under the auspices of the United Nations, covers a broad range of security and economic issues having to do with the reintegration of the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front into civilian life.
Under the agreement, the rebels will be able to seek appointment to a new civilian-controlled police force without discrimination and the Government will protect the right of guerrilla families to hold on to the land they have occupied. A peace commission will also be set up to oversee the carrying out of the accords.
Truce in Weeks Predicted
 Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey and chairman of the Western Hemisphere Subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, telephoned from Washington to say that the "pace of the breakthrough caught everyone by surprise." He predicted that it would lead to a cease-fire within weeks.
Bernard W. Aronson, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affiars, called this "sort of the definitive moment." He added, "If the guerillas mean what they say in these documents then the war is over."
Mr. Cristiani said that only a handful of issues, mainly having to do with the reform and reduction of the armed forces, remain undecided before a cease-fire. He said there was already consensus on some of them.
"As I said in my speech Monday, 1991 will be the year of peace," he said, referring to his address to the General Assembly.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar announced the accord after a brief signing ceremony in his offices.
The five guerrilla commanders and a government delegation led by Mr. Cristiani's chief of staff, Oscar Santamaria, and the Deputy Minister of Defense, Col. Mauricio E. Vargas, signed the agreement.
The guerrilla leaders are Mr. Handal, Joaquin Villalobos, Salvador Sanchez Ceren, Eduardo Sancho Castaneda and Francisco Jovel. Mr. Sanchez is also known as Leonel Gonzalez, his nom de guerre, Mr. Sancho as Ferman Cienfuegos, and Mr. Jovel as Roberto Roca.
Critics have maintained that Mr. Cristiani, who has been under great pressure from the Salvadoran armed forces and his own political party not to give away too much, will have difficulty keeping his commitments in terms of the behavior and reform of the armed forces, but the United Nations mediator, Alvaro de Soto, discounted that.
Mr. de Soto, the Secretary General's representative in conducting the negotiations, said he had "no reason to doubt that the armed forces will accept it."
He noted that Colonel Vargas was here for the negotiations and had signed the accord and that the Defense Minister, Gen. Rene Emilio Ponce, had been regularly consulted.
The accord, which complements earlier accords on human rights protection and political reform, has these main points:
* A National Commission for the Consolidation of Peace will be set up to oversee the carrying out of the accords. It will consist two members each from the Government and guerrilla front, plus representatives of the political parties, the church and the United Nations,
*The armed forces will be "purified" on the basis of the evaluation of its members by an ad hoc commission. In settlement of a long-contended point, the guerrillas agreed to a Government request for two army officers to take part in the deliberations, without a vote.
*In principle, it was agreed to reduce the size of the army, although the numbers and details are still to be negotiated.
*Former guerrilla combatants will not be discriminated against in consideration for membership in the new national police to be created under civilian leadership.
*The Government agreed to a guerrilla request to protect the right of guerrilla families and sympathizers to hold onto lands they have occupied in guerrilla-dominated areas since early in the war.
 
Guerrilla Demand Abandoned
 The guerrilla front apparently abandoned a long-standing demand for incorporation of some of its members into the army at all levels, including command posts. Mr. Cristiani simply noted that the topic did not figure on the agenda that had been agreed upon for the remaining negotiations, and he said there was agreement not to add any more issues before a cease-fire.
El Salvador's civil war grew out of the rise in the 1970's of public frustration with one of the most entrenched military governments in Latin America and the fascination of reformers and university students with the seeming potential of Marxism-Leninism to end social and economic inequities.
Opposition political parties, particularly the Christian Democrats, had grown throughout the decade but saw their quest for power blocked by fraudulent elections in which the military front party always managed to get its presidential candidate elected.
In the mid- and late-1970's, three newly formed clandestine organizations -- the People's Revolutionary Army, the Popular Liberation Forces and the National Resistance -- began to kidnap for ransom, commit political assassinations, and take over farms and businesses with the help of the vast network of so-called mass organizations that they created.
 
The Most Violent Year
 The armed forces and rightist paramilitary groups reacted with a rising tide of repression and death squad killings, but the Government of Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero weakened rapidly and seemed unable to deal with the growing chaos.
The downfall of the Somoza Government in nearby Nicaragua in July 1979 after a brief insurrection and the rise to power there of the leftist Sandinista Front, which was believed to feel a commitment to reciprocate for help it had received from the Salvadoran guerrillas, seemed to set the stage for a quick rebel victory in El Salvador.
But a military coup in October 1979, led by midlevel officers and encouraged by the United States, brought to power a military-civilian junta that promised reforms and eventual free elections to try to head off the insurgency. At the same time, the Carter Administration, increasingly concerned about the path the Sandinistas were taking in Nicaragua, began to advise the new Government actively and to consider military aid.
The land redistribution enacted by the new Government early in 1980 set off a binge of political killings and massacres that made that year more violent than any in the war that was to follow. As many as 10,000 people died in political killings that year, including Archbishop Oscar Romero, three American nuns and a religious laywoman, and the head of the land redistribution program and two Americans assisting him.
With this backdrop and the junta seeming to totter on the brink of disintegration, the guerrillas began their first big offensive of the war on Jan. 10, 1981. Expecting it to be the only one they would need, they called it the "final offensive." Instead, it was the first of many big battles in the long war.
The Salvadoran Army pulled itself together enough to repel the guerrillas in that first offensive, and the Carter Administration in its final days approved military aid. The incoming Reagan Administration committed itself to propping up the Salvadoran junta, which by then included Jose Napoleon Duarte and his Christian Democratic Party.
In an appearance before Congress early in 1981, Secretary of State Alexander M . Haig promised that the United States was prepared "to go to the source" -- meaning Cuba -- to block the supply of weapons to the Salvadoran rebels.
The United States immediately began to send military trainers and advisers in small numbers to equip and train the Salvadoran armed forces. Over the coming decade, military and economic aid to the country of some five million people came to an estimated $4 billion.
In the process, aid to El Salvador and continuing support for the Government there became one of the most sensitive issues in American foreign policy. Critics maintained that the successive Salvadoran governments did not deserve aid because of their failure to reform the armed forces and halt political killings and other human rights abuses.
 
Elections Are Held
 Under United States pressure, the junta held elections in 1982 for a constitutional assembly, which wrote a new constitution and in 1984 called presidential elections, won by Mr. Duarte.
But as the war raged, the other political phenomenon that developed alongside the Christian Democrats was the Nationalist Republican Alliance, or Arena, founded in 1981 by Roberto d'Aubuisson, a cashiered army officer who had been accused by Mr. Duarte and others of being behind many of the death squad killings of 1980.
Mr. d'Aubuisson, a charismatic man who virulently attacked both the Christian Democrats and the guerrillas, found strong voter support from a curious mixture of peasants, small farmers and shop people and the most powerful landowners and businessmen in the country.
In the 1989 elections, with Mr. d'Aubuisson's past always a shadow over the party, Mr. Cristiani, a smooth-talking businessman and coffee grower from the mainstream of the party, was picked to run for President.
With Mr. Duarte dying of cancer and the Christian Democrats under heavy criticism for corruption, Mr. Cristiani won easily.
One of Mr. Cristiani's promises was to bring peace to El Salvador, and while critics at first doubted his intentions, he quickly set out on the path of negotiations that culminated in the accords announced at the United Nations today.

5 Killed Scattered Violence
 SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Scattered fighting between leftist rebels and troops took at least four lives on Tuesday, reports from the Government and the guerrillas indicated today. A construction union leader was also slain in the capital in what appeared to be the work of a rightist death squad.
 Radio Farabundo Marti, the rebels' clandestine station, said that guerrilla forces ambushed a paratroop battalion on Tuesday in Cabanas province, about 50 miles northeast of the capital. It said two Government soldiers were killed in the fighting, but gave no other details.
 A Government communique said that two guerrillas were killed and a third was wounded in a clash near the town of San Jose las Flores, 55 miles northeast of the capital, and two more guerrillas were wounded in fighting outside the city of Chinameca, 75 miles east of San Salvador.
 The police said Miguel Angel Martinez, a 26-year-old union leader, was shot to death on Tuesday evening and his body dumped by a passing car onto a street in San Salvador's business district. The authorities said they had no leads on who was responsible for the slaying. Members of a United Nations human rights mission went to the scene to examine Mr. Martinez's body.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, at head of table, presiding as Salvadoran guerrilla leaders, at left, and Government negotiators signed a broad agreement yesterday that was seen as a major breakthrough in the search for an end to El Salvador's 11-year-old civil war. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "From Coup to Agreement"
 
Oct. 15, 1979: A coup led by two moderate colonels, Jaime Abdul Gutierrez and Adolfo Arnoldo Majano, deposes Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero's rightist military government. The colonels name a 12-member Cabinet a week later.
 
January 1980: Two junta members and most of the Cabinet resign, arguing that the Government is moving too slowly on social reforms. Three civilians are named to the junta, which eventually announces banking and land reforms.
 
PUB-DATE: March 9, 1980:
 
PUB-DATE: March 24, 1980:
 
Dec. 2, 1980: Three American nuns and a lay churchworker are abducted as they leave the international airport. They are found buried in a shallow grave two days later and the United Sates temporarily suspends economic and military aid. Six National Guard troops are arrested later in the case.
 
Dec. 13, 1980: Mr. Duarte is named El Salvador's first civilian President in 49 years, leading a four-member civilian-military junta that also serves as the legislatture.
 
Jan. 11, 1981: Guerrillas announce their first concerted push for a military victory. It flops when massive support of the people does not materialize.
 
PUB-DATE: May 6, 1984:
 
Oct. 15, 1984: Mr. Duarte and other government leaders meet with guerrillas in the northern town of La Palma in their first attempt to negotiate a peace. By this time the war has claimed more then 50,000 lives. No firm agreements are reached.
 
Sept. 10, 1985: President Duarte's daughter, Ines Guadalupe, is kidnapped and held for 44 days before being freedin exchange for more than 100 political prisoners.
 
1985-1991: Numerous rounds of inconclusive peace talks are held between the Government and the rebels in Mexico, Venezuela and Costa Rica.
 
Nov. 16, 1989: Army troops enter the campus of the University of Central American in San Salvador and kill six Jesuit professors, their housekeeper and her daughter. Nine military men, including four officers, are charged later in the case.
 
PUB-DATE: June 1, 1990:
 
Sept. 24, 1991: The Government and five guerrilla commanders reach a broad agreement that President Cristiani predicts will end the civil war. The pact provides for reintegrating the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front into civilian life.
