HEADLINE: The Bush-Hussein Duel;
U.S. Aides Admit Iraq Is No Armed Threat But Say That Control Must Be Established

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The showdown in a Baghdad parking lot between United Nations inspectors and Iraqi officials was less a struggle over a batch of documents than over who is calling the shots in the Persian Gulf's unstable peace -- George Bush or Saddam Hussein.
With Baghdad's new overture tonight to the United Nations, President Bush may have won the central gamble behind his strategy in the gulf. Administration officials have said they were betting that Mr. Hussein would back down and that Mr. Bush would never actually have to carry out his strongly implied threat of using military force.
 
Again Using U.N. Aegis
 Clearly, Mr. Bush is driving the Western approach to the Iraqi President in the latest struggle, although he is careful to do so in the name of the United Nations, as he has been throughout the last year. 
 The United States provided the intelligence that is leading the inspectors to increasingly sensitive Iraqi military installations in ways that Pentagon planners are fully aware will irk the Iraqis. Washington is supplying the technology for the inspectors to communicate with the outside world and thus turn their dispute into a public spectacle.
Like the recent tension over Iraq's refusal to permit the unfettered use of helicopters by the United Nations inspectors, the dispute over whether they may take documents out of Iraqi Government buildings narrowly sprang from efforts to carry out the Security Council resolutions that established a cease-fire in Iraq last spring.
 
It's More Complicated
 But the motivations for the latest standoff between Mr. Bush and Mr. Hussein go well beyond the legalities of enforcing the resolutions or even removing Mr. Hussein's ability to develop nuclear weapons. American officials, including Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, acknowledged today that is not any real threat -- in the short term or even medium term.
Rather, the new tensions, and Mr. Bush's warnings of the possible use of force, demonstrate vividly that what exists in Iraq is not a permanent peace, but a continuation of the tenuous truce established after the allied ground offensive drove Iraqi forces from Kuwait last winter.
That was only one of three major objectives set by the anti-Iraq coalition for the war. Mr. Bush and his allies are still fighting -- with little evident headway -- to secure the two others: demolishing Iraq's ability to field a modern army that could threaten another neighbor and, perhaps more important to the President, eliminating Mr. Hussein as a political and military force in the Middle East.
The President would very much like to see Mr. Hussein ousted. He has said so at every opportunity, reaffirming in recent days that he will oppose the lifting of economic sanctions as long as Mr. Hussein is in power.
The President and his advisers continue to insist that they are not undertaking any open or covert effort to overthrow Mr. Hussein, although they would certainly deny any secret operations even if one were under way. Washington has often turned to the Central Intelligence Agency and covert operations against a foreign government in circumstances similar to the current situation in the gulf, where other means, including open warfare, did not fully achieve American objectives.
"We're still not foolish enough to fall for the trap of changing the U.N. agenda to target any one individual," an Administration official said today.
 
Warning From the White House
 What then does Mr. Bush hope to accomplish by keeping open the threat of possible new military action against Iraq? Clearly that is what the President was doing today by proceeding with deployment of Patriot missiles to Saudi Arabia, huddling in the Oval Office with General Powell and other advisers, and then putting out the word that his patience was wearing thin and that "all options are open."
Administration officials freely acknowledged that Mr. Hussein and his political power are a central target of current American policies in Iraq, which they hope will prevent him from dragging a political victory out of his military defeat and making, as one official put it, "a mockery" of the President's painstakingly wrought coalition.
"If you're going to build any kind of credibilty for a new world order," another official said, "you've got to make people accountable to legal procedures, and Saddam's flaunted every one."
Was the United States deliberately trying to increase tensions with Mr. Hussein as a way of provoking a military confrontation and giving it an excuse to resume the war, this time with more ambitious objectives?
Administration officials say no, and it is evident that the Pentagon is reluctant to take on another fight. General Powell has firmly established himself as a war planner who demands clear-cut military and political objectives and then does not move until he has more than enough reserve power to handle any contingency.
Some influential lawmakers, including Representative Les Aspin, Denmocrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, believe that Mr. Bush has backed down from the brink of military confrontation several times in recent weeks. "It looks like he's bending over backward to avoid it," Mr. Aspin said.
 
Various U.S. Objectives
 Asked why Mr. Bush had been engaged in another test of wills with Mr. Hussein, Administration officials begin with the argument that they are simply trying to carry out the United Nations mandate to plumb the depths of Iraqi efforts to build a nuclear weapon, develop germ-warfare devices and stockpile poison gas for use in war -- and then obliterate those programs.
Beyond that, officials said Mr. Bush is driven by complex political pressures, including his desire to hold together the anti-Iraq coalition, to maintain the United States' role as the enforcer of the peace in the Mideast as he seeks to drag the region's fractious people into a peace conference, and to maintain a strong American military presence as the agreement to keep a rapid-deployment force in southern Turkey nears its Sept. 30 expiration date.
"The long-term threat is that the coalition could fragment and the sanctions against Iraq would simply fall by the wayside," an official said.
 
'Worst-Case Scenarios'
 Another said: "Saddam's power is growing every day and the President cannot tolerate that. If he keeps solidifying this political power, and the coalition breaks up, then you're back to square one before the war. True, he won't be a real military threat to anyone for years. But you have to think in the long term and base your policy on worst-case scenarios, even if you don't believe they're going to happen."
Mr. Aspin argued that there are legitimate roles the United States military can play under these circumstances, saying: "First of all, sending the military in to escort inspectors could avoid the kind of standoff in the parking lot that you've got right now because you would have guys carrying guns to make sure they could leave with the documents. Of course, you'd have to have the backup there in case it turns into a firefight."
Mr. Bush, Mr. Aspin continued, "may have some further military role in mind "to leverage further cooperation by Saddam."
"Is there a military-target list or something else the military might do in order to put political pressure on the Iraqi Government?" he asked. "I wouldn't be surprised if they were looking at a list of targets. But the military would still want to know specifically what they were being assigned to do and what the measure of success would be, instead of just being drawn into some vague mission."

HEADLINE: '48 Hours' Quietly Succeeds at CBS

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
Quietly, "48 Hours," the other CBS news-magazine program, has become a vital part of that network's prime-time schedule.
Two weeks into the new television season, "48 Hours" is now firmly established as CBS's anchor at 10 P.M. Wednesday night. Its success is a big surprise, not least to CBS: the program, which examines one topic intensively over a two-day period, was only an official announcement away from being canceled last spring. 
 For most of its early existence -- almost two full years on the air -- "48 Hours" functioned more as economic necessity than as programming choice. It stayed on because CBS had few programs that were successful, and "48 Hours," beyond its journalistic value, had one virtue many of the network's other struggling programs did not: it was cheap. Its weekly budget often was less than half the $1 million spent for an hourlong entertainment show. Still, when CBS's prime-time standing started to improve, the anemic ratings of "48 Hours" made it a target.
"I know there were serious discussions about knocking us off," said Andrew Heyward, the program's executive producer.
 
A Last Chance
 After watching his program languish most of last year at 8 o'clock on Wednesday night, Mr. Heyward went last March to Jeff Sagansky, CBS's Entertainment division president, and asked for one last opportunity for the program to prove itself, in a spot where it stood at least a fair chance of reaching an audience. He asked for Wednesday night at 10.
None of the three networks had been able to find a hit to place in the 10 o'clock spot on Wednesday, with the result that many Wednesday viewers had simply deserted network television.
In its first try, on April 10, "48 Hours" won that time period with a highly promotable look at the phenomenon of college spring break in Florida. But as the spring and summer went on, using topics as diverse as battered wives and New York City traffic, "48 Hours" continued to win.
In fact, over the last dozen weeks, "48 Hours" has been the No. 1 program in the time spot 10 times. Its average rating grew to an 11.2 at 10 P.M., after averaging only an 8.9 when it played at 8 P.M.
Much of that success was achieved against summer repeats on the other networks. But last week, in its first try against new programs, "48 Hours" still finished a strong second, after NBC's "Quantum Leap."
David F. Poltrack, the senior vice president of research for CBS, said that the network had no lingering doubts about the program's progress. "We certainly don't expect it to finish third in the time period, and we think it can win."
Mr. Heyward went further: "My goal is to make us like a '20/20' franchise by the end of this season." ABC's news magazine, "20/20," is one of the strongest hourlong programs in television.
Beyond the more viable time period, several factors have contributed to the climb of "48 Hours," Mr. Heyward said, starting with a growing understanding of which topics work best in the program's format.
"I don't know infallibly what will work," Mr. Heyward said, "but our stock in trade is the gritty exploration of a social issue as seen through the lives of people who experience them." In many instances that has translated to crime: street crime, organized crime, crime detection. Last night's program focused on scientific crime solving, including such techniques as "blood spatter" detection.
On occasion the program has been criticized for leaning too heavily on crime topics because those seem to draw the best ratings. But Mr. Heyward said that some distinctly non-criminal subjects, including life in the Appalachian mountains, have also worked well. "Our great vulnerability," he said, "has always been that we're about a single topic." That means some topics simply can't be examined because the producers know the audience will not be interested. Foreign stories, for example: You won't see many of them on "48 Hours."
"On a conventional magazine show," Mr. Heyward said, "You can always reward the viewers for watching a story on South Africa with a great celebrity interview."
 
Growing Acceptance
 Mr. Heyward said a factor in the program's favor was the growing acceptance of news programs as network entries at 10 P.M. In addition to "20/20" on Fridays, where it has often finished among the top-rated programs on television, ABC's Thursday-at-10 news program, "Prime Time Live," is slowly building strength.
Still another advantage of the 10 P.M. time period for a news program, Mr. Heyward said, is the support it draws from CBS stations around the country because it delivers a news-watching audience for their local late newscasts.
Indeed, local stations often find a local angle for the stories covered on "48 Hours," and then promote their own newscasts during commercial breaks in the network program. Since "48 Hours" was moved to Wednesdays at 10, local CBS station managers have been among the program's most vocal supporters.

HEADLINE: 18th-Century Furniture And Art to Be Auctioned

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
The collection of 18th-century French furniture and European paintings put together by Elizabeth and Howard B. Keck of Los Angeles is to be auctioned in December at Sotheby's in New York, the auction house announced yesterday.
The Keck collection -- 300 pieces of furniture, decorations and paintings -- was assembled over the last 15 years by Mr. Keck, the 78-year-old son of the founder and the former chairman of the Superior Oil Company, and his wife. The couple were divorced this year. Sotheby's identifies Mr. Keck as the seller of the collection it estimates will total more than $20 million. 
 Although the auction house describes the Keck holdings as "the finest collection of French 18th-century furniture to be auctioned in the United States in about 20 years," the presale estimates on the most important pieces are equal to or below prices paid at auction in the 1980's for French furniture of comparable or lesser importance.
Asked if the recession had influenced the auction house's valuations on the Keck art and antiques, Diana D. Brooks, the president of Sotheby's in New York, said: "No. As far as we are concerned, there has been no recession in the French furniture field. The best way to present property today is to place estimates that are perceived to be extremely reasonable and, as much as possible, based on historical precedents."
The prize items in the sale are a Louis XVI chest and a fall-front secretary, awash with gilded bronzes and Japanese lacquer panels, by Adam Weisweiler. The Weisweiler chest and desk belonged in the 19th century to the Duke of Hamilton, and are to be sold as one lot, with an estimate of about $2 million. That price would equal the current record for one piece of French furniture sold at auction in the United States -- a Louis XVI secretary covered with Sevres plaques, that brought $2.09 million in 1986 at Sotheby's in New York.
Another piece of Keck furniture is a Louis XV flat-topped desk by Joseph Baumhauer, formerly in the collection of Nathaniel Rothschild of Vienna. Sotheby's expects it will sell for more than $1 million.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Looking Racism in the Face in St. Louis

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Tonight "Prime Time Live" uses hidden cameras to catch some common affronts by white Americans that keep reminding black Americans that the colorblind millennium has yet to be achieved. Diane Sawyer goes to St. Louis, Mo., with two 28-year-old men, Glenn Brewer, who is black, and John Kuhnen, who is white, and assigns them to shop in the same stores, try to rent the same apartment and apply for the same job. The results, visible at 10 on Channel 7, will shock only the most naive viewers but should distress everybody.
At several stores, Mr. Kuhnen gets instant service; Mr. Brewer is ignored except at a record store, where a salesman keeps a close eye on him without offering any assistance. When they go for a walk, separately on the same street, a police car passes Mr. Kuhnen but slows down to give Mr. Brewer a once-over. At a car dealership, Mr. Kuhnen is offered a lower price and better financing terms than Mr. Brewer. Inquiring about a job at a dry cleaner that has advertised for help, Mr. Kuhnen is told jobs are still available; Mr. Brewer is told, "The positions are taken." Following up a for-rent sign, Mr. Kuhnen is promptly offered an apartment, which he does not take; 10 minutes later, Mr. Brewer is told it has been rented for hours. It adds up to a quick course for whites in the run-of-the-mill indignities that many blacks endure day after day. 
 If the two men were treated the same anywhere, that is not shown; you just have to trust Ms. Sawyer's reporting. Two observers, Julianne Malveaux, a University of California economist, and Clifford L. Alexander, former Secretary of the Army, are brought in as a kind of chorus. Unfortunately, their comments sound like routine newspaper editorials. Hard-headed analysis of why the attitudes and practices found here survive and perhaps prevail in St. Louis and elsewhere would have been welcome, but this is not that sort of program.
The juiciest scenes are the ones in which Ms. Sawyer and her camera crew do some confronting. "What's the difference," she keeps asking the automobile salesman who quoted different figures on the same red convertible, and gets no coherent answer. At the apartment that was, then was not for rent, she asks the same question. The manager tells her: "Oh, ma'am, I am not prejudiced. I got Mexican. I got Jewish." But he concedes there are no black tenants. The "Prime Time" staff members are then thrown out by the building's owner, who insists, "We have never discriminated, as long as they don't have four or five kids."
Maybe these people are worried about the law. Maybe they are just embarrassed. Either way, their distress is the only cause for optimism in tonight's painfully pertinent report.

HEADLINE: 35 Law Firms in New York Pledge More Minority Hiring

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
Seeking to combat the persistent underrepresentation of minorities in their offices, 35 major law firms in New York City pledged yesterday to hire more black, Hispanic, Asian-American and American Indian lawyers and to treat them equally in assignments and promotion once they arrive.
The law firms set a goal of hiring one minority lawyer for every 10 new lawyers they recruit over the next five years -- almost double the current rate. 
 They also pledged to address systemic problems that have seen minorities fare much worse, and stay more briefly, than their white counterparts at New York's most prestigious law firms. The moves are part of a City Bar Association initiative to enhance opportunities for minorities.
"There are problems at every level -- at recruitment, at retention and promotion, and the only way to make sure that changes occur is to address them all at the same time," said the president of the City Bar Association, Conrad K. Harper. He said he hoped that other firms and corporate legal departments would join the initiative, which he called "a major step toward the complete integration of the legal profession in New York City."
"These firms are more committed than I've ever seen them to doing something significant, and doing it now," said Mr. Harper, a partner at Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, who is the bar group's first black president. "Bleak as the situation is, it has gotten better in the last few years and with this kind of commitment I expect it to get better still."
Mr. Harper maintained that the sour state of the legal marketplace, which has seen many of the 35 firms curb hiring and lay off record numbers of lawyers, would in no way blunt the initiative.
"The firms," he said, "clearly recognize that we're looking toward the long term, and the economy of the moment will not be the economy over the next five years."
The participating firms include some of the city's largest and most renowned, like Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, Debevoise & Plimpton and Cravath Swaine & Moore.
Minorities now make up 15 percent of the enrollment in the major law schools from which New York's largest firms recruit. But the number of minorities joining large law firms has consistently lagged far behind, largely because they have viewed such firms as inhospitable.
And the percentages remaining there to become partners are starker still. Mr. Harper said minorities accounted for only 28 of the more than 1,000 partners in the 35 firms. taking part in the bar association effort. "At that level, the number drops almost to invisibility," he said.
The New York numbers are not atypical. According to a 1989 survey by The National Law Journal, 4.1 percent of the lawyers at the nation's 250 largest law firms are black, Hispanic, Asian-American or American Indian. In the partnership ranks, minorities accounted for only 1.9 percent.
"There's been some marginal success, but trying to move legal institutions is like trying to turn a battleship on a dime," said Robert J. Grey, a Virginia lawyer and chairman of the American Bar Association's commission on opportunities for minorities.
The Law Journal's next survey, to be published later this fall, is expected to show little improvement in the situation, nationally or in New York. A few large firms, like Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton and Debevoise & Plimpton, are at or near the 10 percent figure. But of the 1,100 lawyers at three other New York firms -- Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson; Stroock & Strook & Lavan, and Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood -- only 22 are minorities, and but one of them is a partner.
Other local bar groups have adopted similar, or even more ambitious, measures. Two years ago, for instance, 90 law firms and corporate legal departments in San Francisco pledged that by 1995, 15 percent of all their associates and 5 percent of their partners would be members of minority groups. By the year 2000, the numbers would be 25 percent and 10 percent.
Minority lawyers have long complained that once they join large law firms, they are placed on a separate, slower track. Beyond more aggressive recruiting of minority lawyers, the firms have pledged to insure that they consistently receive comparable assignments, serve the same important clients and generally "receive equal training, mentoring, guidance, feedback and opportunities to grow and succeed."
 
Social Activities
 The program also calls for minority lawyers to be included in "work-related social activities" -- the outings, dinners and other occasions where valuable contacts are made. Signatories also pledged to hold no functions at private clubs that discriminate on the basis of race, creed, religion or sex.
The city bar committee was established last year, in large part after the black partners at major firms complained about the slow increase in their ranks since 1969, when Amalya L. Kearse became the first minority partner at a major New York firm. "At the rate we were going, there were going to be only 30 of us by the year 2,000," one proponent of the program, who asked not to be identified, recalled. The panel was headed by Cyrus R. Vance, the former Secretary of State and a partner at Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett.

HEADLINE: Inmate Count In Some Jails Drops Sharply

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Two months after New York City officials warned that they were running out of jail space, the city's prison population has decreased so sharply that as many as 1,100 cells were vacant this month. It is the first time in two years that any significant number have been empty.
City officials and criminal-justice experts point to a variety of reasons for the decrease: faster transferring of convicted inmates to state prisons, and rearranging of court vacation schedules to avoid the traditional summer slump in resolving criminal cases. Also, fewer felonies are being reported and fewer felony arrests are being made. In addition, more of those arrested for misdemeanors are being given desk-appearance tickets instead of jail time. 
 The decrease has opened a debate among city officials over whether the Dinkins administration should push ahead with a $291-million prison-expansion program, which would create about 3,000 new beds in cells and dormitories on Rikers Island over the next two years.
 
Room for New Prisoners
 The city's increased efficiency in passing inmates to state prisons has led to an increase in crowding there: the number of state inmates rose this month to 57,000, from 54,000 in February. James B. Flateau, a spokesman for the State Division of Correctional Services, said room for new state prisoners was being created through more double bunking and supervised work-release programs for inmates who are close to parole eligibility.
The city's inmate population decreased from a peak of 22,273 inmates in July to about 20,800 last week, according to the city Correction Department, the agency that runs the jails. In the last month, the census has hovered between 95 percent and 96 percent of capacity compared with overflows of 102 percent in the spring and summer.
Correction Department records indicate that between 800 and 1,156 cells and dormitory beds have been available in recent weeks, the first time since December 1988 that so much space has opened in a jail system that usually has no vacancies.
Though some city officials and prison experts are questioning the expansion program, citing the jail-census decline, the city's Correction Commissioner, Allyn R. Sielaff, cautions that the downward trend could quickly reverse, with a return to bulging, explosive prison conditions.
Critics, however, say the construction plan should be halted, pointing out that 1,600 more jail beds are scheduled to be available through completion of a new rigid-frame plastic building next month and the expected arrival of a prison barge in February.
Mr. Sielaff, who supports the building program, said in an interview that the jails could be filled again if the state ran out of room for prisoners or arrests in the city soared. "It is far too early to say the population is down signficantly," he insisted. "We need a bit of cushion so that we are not always at the edge of an overcrowding precipice."
Mr. Sielaff emphasized that many of the city's jails were in disrepair and would have to be replaced or renovated.
But the city's Deputy Mayor for Public Safety, Milton Mollen, said some projects may be delayed or scrapped.
"We have to take into consideration that the jail occupancy is less than we feared it might be this summer," Mr. Mollen noted in an interview.
The City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, who temporarily blocked emergency contracts for several of the proposed jails in July, said in an interview that the overall building plan was "wasteful and inexcusable" in light of the city's financial difficulties. The Comptroller can record a formal objection to contracts awarded by city agencies but the Mayor has the final authority to approve or rescind the contracts.
Richard T. Wolf, the executive director of the city Board of Correction, an independent oversight agency, said that if a downward trend was underway, the city should reconsider building plans and "redouble efforts for prudent alternatives to incarceration."
Mr. Sielaff described the jail decrease as "unprecedented for this time of the year." In a report sent on Sept. 6 to Judge Morris Lasker of Federal District Court in Manhattan, who has oversight jurisdiction for conditions in city jails, Mr. Sielaff attributed the decline to the larger exodus to state prisons and to faster court dispositions of cases.
The state has responsibility for imprisoning criminals sentenced to more than one year; the city is responsible for holding defendants awaiting trial, prisoners sentenced to terms of less than one year and people accused of violating parole. The length of time detainees stay in city jails depends on how long it takes to try them, and how long it takes to process them for transfers to upstate prisons.
In past summers, the courts often slowed down because of vacations by court personnel and lawyers. Mary deBourbon, a spokeswoman for court administrators, said that vacation schedules this summer were juggled and that more judges and clerks were assigned to the State Supreme Court, where felony matters are heard. As a result, the number of felony cases completed in the city courts during the summer term -- June 17 to Sept. 9 -- rose to 15,278 compared with 14,011 for the same period last year.
 
Desk Appearance Tickets
 In addition, fewer people were being locked up in the first place. The felony crime rate and the number of felony arrests both declined for the first half of this year compared with the same period last year. Through June, 265,001 felonies were reported, down 4.8 percent and 75,126 felony arrests were made, down 6.4 percent.
And Mr. Mollen and several criminal-justice experts said that a torrent of police desk-appearance tickets for misdemeanors this year may have contributed to the decline in jail population. Through July 31, the police issued 37,995 desk tickets compared with 23,527 for the same period last year.
A defendant who gets a ticket is given a court date but is released. Those who are arrested for the same offense could be briefly jailed if bail is set and they are unable to raise it.
But Jeremy Travis, the Police Department's Deputy Commissioner for Legal Matters, said the desk tickets probably had little effect on the jails because most are given for minor, nonviolent offenses that rarely result in a defendant being held for bail.
 
Sanctions on Overcrowding
 In July, Mr. Sielaff said that he might be forced to release prisoners awaiting trial because of court sanctions on overcrowding. He projected that the jail population could swell to 26,000 in the autumn unless the state prison authorities expedited the transfers of those classified as state-ready.
The city says the improvement is a result of the state's willingness to accept larger weekly transfers. State officials, however, asserted that previous backlogs had been created mainly by the failure of the city jail authorities to prepare medical and administrative records required for transfers.
The low point in transfers of state-ready prisoners occurred in the week ending July 12, when only 201 were removed, according to the Correction Department. Since then the weekly flow has ranged between 417 and 614. The backlog decreased to 1,113 last week compared with a peak of 2,513 on July 15.
This month the weekly transfers have fallen below 500. Mr. Flateau of the State Correctional Division, attributed the dropoff partly to high unemployment in the city: the number of inmates in the city who can find jobs and thereby be freed through new state work-release programs has fallen. With more inmates remaining in upstate prisons, there is a shortage of beds for newcomers from the city.
Mr. Flateau added that the weekly transfers would soon rise with more space in state prisons provided through double bunking.

HEADLINE: Cuomo's Blueprint: Building a Legacy

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 25

 BODY:
While intended to breathe life into New York City's moribund economy, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's blueprint for fiscal recovery could also establish a lasting legacy for the third-term Governor.
Like the economy itself, Mr. Cuomo's record of governmental activism has withered somewhat during the recession. But the ingeniously packaged plan he presented this week provides an opportunity to resuscitate an image that has been deflated by an ambivalent electorate, devastating budget cuts and conflict with the Legislature. 
 Following the examples of two of his predecessors -- one remembered for rescuing New York City, the other for building massive public works -- Mr. Cuomo proposed a plan aimed at nursing an ailing city to health with a broth of bricks and mortar.
As was apparent to those who listened to Mr. Cuomo's speeches on Monday and Tuesday, the strategy of linking his political recovery to that of the city's economy is fraught with peril. Even as business and civic leaders have applauded the Governor's courage, they have raised questions about both the feasibility and the true impact of his proposals.
Today, for instance, the co-chairman of Mayor David N. Dinkins's management advisory task force, Donald D. Kummerfeld, argued that the Cuomo plan will do little to help the city in its time of real need, the next four years.
 
Help, in Awhile
 The Governor's proposal for the state to assume the local share of Medicaid costs eventually could save the city $1 billion a year, but not until the end of the century. It might take almost that long to create many of the jobs promised by his public works initiatives, if they are built at all.
"Until there's some specific hard dollars coming from a source other than the taxpayers of the City of New York, I don't know that you can allege that there is any help," Mr. Kummerfeld said.
What makes the Governor's plan risky is that the successes and failures of his plan for "a new New York" can be easily measured. If subway trains never speed below Second Avenue or water ferries never skim across New York Harbor, Mr. Cuomo will be held accountable.
But Mr. Cuomo calculated that the gamble had to be taken to raise the city's confidence. Someone, he determined, had to provide momentum simply by talking about the future rather than dwelling on the disheartening present.
"We need to stop moaning and start moving," the Governor told a meeting of business and political leaders on Tuesday morning.
It was not the Governor's first instinct to ride to the rescue. In July, he played down the potential for restructuring the Medicaid program, citing the difficulty of winning approval in the Republican-led State Senate. That fed criticism that Mr. Cuomo is often unwilling to expend his political capital, particularly in his dealings with the Legislature.
But what became clear to the Cuomo administration as the summer progressed -- particularly as public confidence in the city's economy and its leadership waned -- was that the Governor would be held accountable along with the Mayor for the city's problems. The public mood threatened to poison his reputation, both in New York and across the country.
"The Governor realized that he and the Mayor were both in a box created by the city's fiscal problems," a Dinkins aide said, "and that he had to find a way for them to get out arm in arm."
Mr. Cuomo, with a keen ear for public opinion, has spent the last year listening to the wails of a disgruntled public. He heard the voices of the voters who reprimanded him with a 52 percent showing at the polls last November and the profane shouts of the state workers who marched on the Executive Mansion last winter.
He took particular offense at a Time magazine cover story that asked whether the Big Apple was rotting. His blood boiled when politicians, both Democrats and Republicans, suggested that the Democratic Party would be embarrassed by holding its 1992 convention in New York City.
"Why did I do what I did when I did it?" Mr. Cuomo asked today, while addressing a reporters' luncheon in Washington. "It pains everybody who's from New York City. You have the recession, you have the drugs, you have the AIDS, you have less and less money from Washington, you have the whole world beating you up. People get depressed. They get angry. Things get worse and you say, 'Let me see if I can do something.' "
 
From Schools to Prisons
 Mr. Cuomo also was pained that the state's severe fiscal problems had forced him to pare the social programs at the heart of his own agenda. After overseeing huge increases in education funding, he cut aid to schools. After trumpeting his Decade of the Child agenda, he killed the college scholarship program that was to be its centerpiece.
What often seemed to be left of Mr. Cuomo's legacy was the construction of a record number of prison cells, a dubious accomplishment by even the Governor's reckoning.
"Rockefeller left the road system, the mall in Albany, all the universities," said Assembly Speaker Mel Miller. "Hugh Carey's monument is that he saved the city from bankruptcy. Maybe it sunk in that what you're remembered for as a Governor are the institutions you create and the temples you leave."
Mr. Cuomo's closest advisers uniformly dismissed the notion that the Governor was motivated by building a concrete legacy. But several said he did want to shuck the criticism that he is more interested in the politics of the nation than the problems of the state.
"I think he really wants to appear gubernatorial," said Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine. "At the same time he is speaking out on national issues, traveling internationally, he wants people to understand he is engaged in the most pressing problems of the state. And right now, those are centered in New York City."

HEADLINE: UKRAINIAN LEADER AND BUSH CONFER

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The Ukrainian leader, Leonid M. Kravchuk, met with President Bush today to discuss his breakaway republic's economic needs and nuclear weapons policy. It was the first visit to Washington by a leading Soviet republic official since the failed coup last month.
A State Department official who specializes in Soviet affairs said the 45-minute discussion in the Oval Office did not signify recognition of Ukrainian independence, but was "part of the process of U.S. contacts with people in the Soviet Union at all levels -- in Moscow and at the republic level." 
 Mr. Kravchuk, 57 years old, who is chairman of the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet and the leading candidate in coming presidential elections, said he told Mr. Bush that the Ukraine needed help from the United States to employ new technology to augment the production and export of grain. The republic of 52 million people is the Soviet Union's chief grain-producing area.
The Ukrainian leader also reiterated that his republic had no intention of keeping the nuclear weapons based on its territory, promising to transfer them to he control of the central authorities.
 
A Peace Corps Program?
 Mr. Bush outlined possible economic aid to the Ukraine, including consideration of a Peace Corps program and technical assistance, a White House statement said. The two leaders came to no agreements, but arranged for continued meetings between specialists to develop assistance programs and future contacts.
The statement quoted Mr. Bush as saying that the Ukraine "has a special place in the hearts of Americans."
The President has been walking a fine line between endorsing democracy in the republics and supporting efforts by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to keep the Soviet Union unified in some form. He backed independence for the three Baltic states, but has stopped short of recognizing the independence of several other republics.
In a speech to the Ukrainian Parliament on Aug. 1, he warned against the dangers of "suicidal nationalism."
This morning, Mr. Bush called Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, to wish him good health -- Mr. Yeltsin was out of work part of last week with what aides described as a minor heart problem -- and to discuss what progress has been made between Moscow and 12 republics in negotiating a treaty that will dictate their future relationship.

HEADLINE: Family Leave: Fine, in Modest Doses

 BODY:
The idea of guaranteeing unpaid leave to workers who must cope with family emergencies has great appeal. It also carries hidden economic costs. Now, two Senators have created a sensible plan that respects both humanitarian needs and business realities.
Sponsored by Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Christopher Bond, Republican of Missouri, the bill would guarantee many workers 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for babies or seriously ill family members. But by scaling back the number of eligible employees and toughening the definition of "seriously ill," the Senators hope to avoid the fate of last year's bill: a Bush veto. 
 Whatever Mr. Bush decides to do this time around, he won't be able to ridicule overly harsh mandates. The Dodd-Bond bill would exempt small business, high-paid "key" employees and many part-timers; indeed, it exempts more than half the work force. And it provides for light penalties and strong employer protections, like the right to require a second medical opinion.
Nevertheless, the bill is setting off alarm bells in executive suites. The reason has less to do with what's in this bill than with what employers fear will be in the next one. To them, unpaid leave is a short skip away from mandated paid leave and a growing array of enumerated emergencies. These fears are not ill-founded; some family-leave advocates have said that the Dodd-Bond compromise is as important for the precedent it would set as for the benefits it would confer.
But if mandates mushroom, what began as a wholesome expression of concern for families will become an economic affliction. Employers are likely to compensate for costly mandates by cutting jobs or lowering wage offers and fringe benefits, like health insurance. This could hurt poor workers most; they're less likely to take the unpaid leave but will still suffer lost benefits.
Employers are increasingly offering on-site day care, guaranteed leave and other benefits that make caring for children easier. This response is no act of charity but rather a strategy for attracting applicants from a labor pool that increasingly comprises two-earner families and for cutting down on worker turnover.
If Washington tramps too heavily, it risks stifling this encouraging trend, wiping away options in favor of a one-size-fits-all benefits package. Mandated benefits thus warrant caution.
The Dodd-Bond bill is cautious; its cost will likely be measured in hundreds of millions, a minor threat to a $6.5 trillion economy. Meanwhile, the bill sends an important signal about how society values families and children. These gains are worth grabbing -- even as Congress needs to be reminded that more of the same is not necessarily better.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Defeating Hussein, Once and for All

BYLINE: By Al Gore; Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, is a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee. This article is adapted from a Sept. 19 Senate speech.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I support the President's moves to force Saddam Hussein to comply with the terms of the gulf cease-fire. But I disagree with the President's policy at a more fundamental level -- namely, his persistent view of Saddam Hussein as an acceptable part of the landscape, if and when we finally get him cut down to size.
The only way we can hope for long-term relief from Saddam Hussein is if Saddam Hussein ceases to hold power, and if his Baathist regime is dismantled as well. Realizing that the burden of proof rests with those who say that Mr. Hussein can be toppled, I think it possible to describe how that might be done. 
 In general, the formula for deposing him involves these elements: blocking his access to international support, building up his opponents and cutting off resources for rebuilding his military machine.
Under the first heading -- blocking Saddam Hussein's access to outside support -- I have to ask again why we didn't long ago begin documenting Iraqi war crimes against Kuwait. Even though we may never get him or his lieutenants into the dock to face war-crimes charges, the historical record should be filled in rather than allowed to fade. The truth should be spread in Iraq and the Arab world, using overt and covert methods to make sure that the message gets through.
We also need to isolate Saddam Hussein by improving our relations with Iran as rapidly as conditions permit. Meanwhile, the central U.S. role in Mideast peace talks, from which Iraq is completely excluded, has the benefit of destroying his usefulness to the Palestinians.
As for building the stock of Saddam Hussein's opponents, we should be using every resource to weaken his image and destroy the illusions his propaganda machine labors to create. Surely that is something our intelligence services know how to do! At the same time, we should be helping opposition forces -- most of them in exile -- to unify and improve their organization.
Under the third heading -- stopping Iraq from rebuilding its military -- we have to make sure that the economic tourniquet stays on tight, but take steps to assist the Iraqi people. The U.N. has it about right: sales of oil for humanitarian purchases, with neither the money nor the goods passing through the hands of the Iraq Government. The message to the Iraqi people has to be that Saddam Hussein is not only powerless to end their misery but is its cause.
There are other steps we should take, aimed at blocking Iraqi access to knowledge and technology. That means doing everything to halt Iraqi work in space science and nuclear physics to the extent they depend on equipment, services or training -- including university training -- from countries with advanced capabilities.
We also need to encourage a flow of intelligence from Iraq by offering protection and rewards to anyone who comes forward with useful, verifiable information. The standoff between Saddam Hussein and the courageous team of U.N. inspectors has been a perfect summary of what we face. Nothing could more clearly demonstrate that U.S. policy must address the underlying problem: Saddam Hussein's rule and system of Government are incompatible with the peace and security of our own country.
Finally, we have to get much tougher about exposing the foreign suppliers that Iraq used to acquire nuclear, chemical and biological facilities in the first place. If this means deeply embarrassing certain friendly governments, so be it. Otherwise, nothing will change.
There are other examples, but I would like to draw attention to the Swiss, who have benefited enormously from the security we have provided in Europe for the last 50 years. Switzerland has become a well-known haven for arms dealers and proliferators. Its Government values the security and tranquillity of its own people, but in this area its contribution to the security of other people in the world is substantially negative. It is time for the Swiss to live up to their image of clean rectitude. Other countries may feel pinched by that same shoe. So be it.
We can no more look forward to a constructive long-term relationship with Saddam Hussein than we could hope to housebreak a cobra. But it is not just enough to say that there will not be normal U.S. relations with Iraq while he is in power.
It is time to get down to cases. Sooner or later, he will go. Sooner is better. And with him, the entire Baathist rule by terror has to go as well, or we may simply exchange one brutal character for the next.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Two States Price Tax-Exempt Debt

 BODY:
Connecticut and Massachusetts priced tax-exempt debt securities yesterday, taking advantage of the current low interest rates.
Connecticut's $266 million special tax obligations were tentatively priced through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette for a top yield of 6.684 percent for an issue due in 2009, the longest maturity, The lowest yield was 5 percent for the 1993 maturity. Moody's gave the issues an A1 rating, and Standard & Poor's an AA minus rating. 
 The $150 million of hospital revenue bonds issued by the Massachusetts Health and Education Facilities Authority were tentatively priced to yield 7 percent for the long-term maturity of 2024. Kidder, Peabody headed the underwriting group.
Yields for other maturities in the issue ranged from 5 1/2 percent for the 1995 maturity to 6 3/4 percent for the year 2012. Ratings were AA by Moody's and A plus by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances in the U.S. After a Mixed Day Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced yesterday in hectic domestic trading after finishing mixed overseas.
The dollar settled mixed overseas and headed lower when trading shifted to domestic markets. Traders sold the dollar after the release of worse-than-expected economic data that indicated the recovery might be waning. 
 The Government reported that the economy declined at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the spring. A separate report showed an 8.9 percent increase in the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits.
"That made a lot of people feel that the dollar would soften, that the Federal Reserve may take action to keep interest rates soft," said Andrew Busch, a trader with Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Lower interest rates tend to erode the value of dollar-denominated securities, lessening demand for the United States currency.
 
Many Traders Caught Short
 But many traders were caught short once the dollar had fallen and were forced to buy it back in busy, technically driven trading.
The dollar also drew support from hints that the United States could become involved in military actions against Iraq.
"The market does not want to be short dollars in a big way with all the uncertainty in the gulf, the Soviet Union, in Yugoslavia," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
The dollar typically is viewed as a safe haven in times of world turmoil.
Mr. Donney described the day's trading as "very choppy and indecisive."
In Tokyo, the dollar finished trading at 133.43 yen, up 0.21 yen from Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 133.60 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 133.95 yen, up from 133.22 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7325, compared with $1.7330 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.7285 to buy 1, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7355.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6875 German marks, up from 1.6805; 1.4675 Swiss francs, up from 1.4635; 5.7490 French francs, up from 5.7260; 1,263.85 Italian lire, up from 1,256.75, and 1.1360 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1346.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices for Silver Contracts Retreat Again in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver futures prices fell sharply yesterday as weak economic data and a relaxation of tensions in the Middle East knocked out the market's main supports.
Gold futures also retreated, grains and soybeans fell, livestock and meat futures were mostly higher and energy futures were mixed. 
 Silver for delivery in September tumbled 10.9 cents, to $4.108 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The more heavily traded December contract dropped 11 cents, to $4.155. October gold fell $2.20, to $350.80 an ounce.
 
Reversal of Factors
 The losses by silver extended a decline that began on Wednesday after it had climbed a total of about 18 cents in three sessions to its highest price in more than two months.
The rally was partly based on economic data that suggested industrial demand for silver would soon strengthen and on the Bush Administration's threat to force Iraq to cooperate with United Nations weapons inspectors.
Both factors were reversed yesterday.
The Government reported the American economy declined at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the spring, a revision of more robust estimates issued in earlier reports, and there was a big jump in the number of people seeking jobless benefits early this month.
The United Nations Security Council, meanwhile, accepted an Iraqi proposal aimed at ending the three-day detainment of its inspection team in Baghdad.
Crude oil prices finished largely unchanged on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as traders digested news from an OPEC meeting and watched developments in Iraq.
Light sweet crude oil for delivery in November settled unchanged at $22.21 a barrel; October home heating oil fell 0.5 cent, to 63.10 cents a gallon; October unleaded gasoline rose 0.24 cent, to 62.02 cents a gallon; November natural gas rose 1.9 cents, to $1.918 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Grain and soybean futures prices settled mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as harvest pressure replaced increased Soviet grain purchases as the big market influence.
Wheat for delivery in December settled 1 1/2 cents lower at $3.25 3/4 a bushel; December corn fell 1 3/4 cents, to $2.45 1/2 a bushel; December oats dropped 2 1/4 cents, to $1.26 3/4 a bushel; November soybeans fell 2 1/4 cents, to $5.88 a bushel.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Municipal Debt Ratings Fell In 3d Quarter, S.& P. Says

 BODY:
The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that the quality of municipal debt declined sharply in the third quarter.
The rating service said $17.4 billion in municipal debt received lower credit ratings in the quarter, while only $1.9 billion in debt received higher ratings. A hundred issues were downgraded, while 30 were upgraded. Most of the municipal issues were general-obligation and housing debt. 
 In contrast, $5.2 billion of municipal debt was downgraded during the second quarter, S.& P. said, while $1.4 billion received higher ratings. In that quarter, 74 issues received lower ratings, while 38 were upgraded.
States whose debt received lower ratings in the third quarter included New Jersey and Connecticut, as well as Illinois, which was under review for several months.
S.& P. attributed the decline in credit ratings mainly to the recession, which has sharply the tax revenues of a number of states, making it more difficult for them to balance their budgets.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ameritech Is Offering Its Own Mastercard

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Following the success of A.T.&T. and its Universal card, Ameritech yesterday became the first "Baby Bell" to offer a credit card that can be used for consumer purchases and to pay for telephone calls.
The new card, to be called The Ameritech Complete Mastercard, will be offered to most of the phone company's 10 million residential customers in the Midwest, depending on credit history. 
 The card will not carry the typical bank annual fee of $15 to $20, but will have an interest rate of 16.8 percent to 19.8 percent, depending on the balance owed; the more owed, the lower the rate. The card will also carry a 10 percent rebate offer on local and long-distance calls.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, already the fifth-largest issuer of Visa and Mastercards, has been so successful with its Universal card that by the end of the year it will become the second-largest issuer in the $269 billion market, according to the Nilson Report, a newsletter in Santa Monica, Calif. By then, A.T.& T. card holders are projected to have charged nearly $13 billion for retail goods and telephone calls.
Stephen G. Ford, an Ameritech spokesman, said his company's credit card had been under study for several years. "We've been contemplating this long before A.T.& T.'s Universal card," he said.
Ameritech has joined with a unit of Household International of Prospect Heights, Ill., the largest non-bank issuer of credit cards. Household, with nearly $4 billion in credit-card receivables, will own and finance the Ameritech receivables. Ameritech, based in Chicago, said it would pay for marketing costs.
Because of the arrangement, it is unclear whether Ameritech will ever make much profit from the service, but analysts say the new card could encourage use of local pay phones and aid brand loyalty for Ameritech.
"This is more of a marketing tool than a profit center," said David Robertson, president of the Nilson Report.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up After Jobless Report

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
An unexpectedly large rise in weekly unemployment claims in the week ended Sept. 14 helped to push up prices of Treasury notes and bonds and caused interest rates to fall yesterday.
The release of the Labor Department figures is timely because President Bush is scheduled to meet today with key economic advisers, including the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan. 
 That meeting comes only days before the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee is scheduled to gather in Washington. The timing of the two sessions, coupled with continued weak economic data, suggested to market participants that the chances have increased that the Fed may be on the verge of cutting short-term interest rates again.
 
'Political Pressure on the Fed'
 "The market is sensing that the political pressure on the Fed is intensifying," said James A. Fralick a principal and senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
The initial claims report was "another piece of data that raise the question of whether we are in a recovery," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International. "Looking ahead, we will see more layoffs and more problems in the labor market."
Even if the Fed does decide to ease policy again, Mr. Brusca said, there is little reason to suggest that another cut in the overnight Federal funds rate would do much to spur the economy. The funds rate, which analysts say the Fed is currently trying to keep at 5 1/4 percent, is the rate the Fed charges banks that need overnight loans.
With the exception of the last two quarter-point cuts in the funds rate, the bulk of the rate relief supplied by the central bank came late last year and early in 1991.
With the lagging effect of changes in monetary policy, "we should be seeing the benefits of most of the Fed's easing moves right now, but we aren't," Mr. Brusca said.
 
Bullish Notions'
 After the claims numbers were announced "everybody started to refurbish their bullish notions," one government securities trader said. "What they are looking at is that the major impetus behind the lift we have seen over the last quarter -- the manufacturing sector -- may well stall out in the next month or two."
Market participants said trading activity was brisk throughout the session, especially in maturities from three months out to three years.
While short-term securities were the most popular, longer-term notes and bonds also posted gains.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 102 26/32, up 7/32, to yield 7.87 percent, compared with 7.89 percent late Wednesday.
Analysts said that further declines in the yield on the benchmark issue seemed likely.
"I think bond yields are headed toward 7.50 percent, and it is likely that will not be the low," said Roger Froelich, president of Technical Dimensions, a Mount Kisco, N.Y., firm that provides analysis on the credit markets. "Technically, the market is still very strong. And economic fundamentals are showing a recovery that is weak at best."
In the Treasury note market, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 102 11/32, up a quarter of a point, to yield 7.53 percent.
Prices of the two issues auctioned by the Treasury earlier in the week also advanced.
By late in the day, the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes sold on Tuesday were offered at a price to yield 6.04 percent. And the 7.00 percent five-year notes sold on Wednesday were offered at a price to yield 7.00 percent.
Anticipation of another easing move by the Federal Reserve pushed down short-term Treasury bill rates.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 5.12 percent, down 3 basis points, or hundreths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.15 percent.
 
Money Supply Figures
 The Fed's weekly money supply report did little to discourage thoughts that the central bank might ease policy further, even though the figures announced yesterday were slightly larger than the market had expected.
The Fed said that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Sept. 16.
M-2, the monetary aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, rose by a healthy $5.2 billion. But the increase left M-2 growth for the year at just above 2.5 percent, which is the lower end of the Fed's target range.
The rise in Treasury prices and the drop in yields was sufficient to encourage six more companies to price more than $1.5 billion in new securities in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
Among the issuers was a financing subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, which offered $500 million worth of five-year notes backed by Sears credit-card receivables.
The 7 3/4 percent notes, which have an expected final maturity of Sept. 15, 1996, were priced at $99.468 to yield 7.88 percent, 85 basis points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's new 7 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
Dean Witter Reynolds acted as lead underwriter for the offering. The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
G.M. Acceptance Offering
 The General Motors Acceptance Corporation offered $300 million of five-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 8 percent notes, which mature Oct. 1, 1996, were priced at $100, or par, 95 basis points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.& P.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, participants said prices of most issues were unchanged in sluggish trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt securities, municipal bond traders said prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about an eighth of a point.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 3.80 as Small Investors Stay Out

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were slightly lower yesterday in moderate trading, as investors with little interest in buying trudged to the sidelines. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 3.80 points to close at 3,017.22.
Big Board volume was 160.3 million shares, compared with 153.9 million on Wednesday. Advancing issues outpaced declining ones, 877 to 709. 
 While the market closed slightly down from the previous session, Hugh A. Johnson, the chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation, noted that there were actually some good up and down swings, and at one point late in the afternoon the Dow was up at least 15 points before fading.
Professionals in Control
He described yesterday's activity similar to what had been going on in the market all week, with swings driven solely by professional trading in the absence of smaller investors who have stayed out.
"The market has remained within this 2,900 to 3,050 range because there is a debate going on," he said. "The debate is whether we are getting a recovery or not. There is deep concern that we may not get strong enough earnings to validate or support stocks at current levels."
The downward revision of the second-quarter gross national product, a measurement of the value of the nation's output of goods and services, and greater-than-expected number of new jobless claims reported yesterday cast further concern among investors about the state of the economy and approaching tide of new corporate earnings.
Large blue-chip issues gained strength in afternoon trading, with some cyclical stocks like Ford Motor, which rose 7/8, to 30 1/4, and General Motors, which also gained 7/8, to 37 7/8, adding support to the market. Bonds also added strength to the market.
 
Other Indexes Lower
 The New York Stock Exchange's composite index slipped 0.09, to 212.44, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down by 0.39, to 386.49.
Over-the-counter trading was brisk, as the composite index dropped 0.88, to 526.94. Part of that market's decline could be attributed to Scimed Life Systems, which fell 29 3/4, or 34.2 percent, to 57 1/4. The medical-supply company said late on Wednesday that it "was evaluating the future commecial status" of its Express catheter line in the United States.
Scimed also said it expected Eli Lilly's Advanced Cardiovascular Systems unit to receive another patent on a rapid-exchange catheter in the near future. On Aug. 21, the Lilly unit filed a complaint chargingg patent infringement. In addition, Scimed has reported weaker-than-expected earnings for the second quarter.
The drug group is characteristic of just how sensitive the market is to earnings news, Mr. Johnson said.
Trading on the American Stock Exchange fared a little better, with the composite index up 0.71, to 373.62.
Three groups, airlines, automobiles and technology, displayed some strength yesterday. "These groups are particularly sensitive to the economy," Mr. Johnson said. "It shows at least that some investors are looking beyond the soft economic numbers. They believe the outlook is brighter than the overall market suggest."
Some of the special situations in yesterday's market included Transco Energy, which rose 1 1/4, to 18 1/4. Lawrence A. Crowley, an analyst for Rauscher Pierce Refnes, upgraded the stock to "buy" from "neutral." He said he thought the recent selloff in the stock was "completely overdone," and from a price point of view, attractive.
He and other analysts think a ruling from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission on Wednesday over past pricing policy was not as negative as some investors had expected. On Wednesday, the stock dropped 2 1/8.
Salomon continued to rebound yesterday, as the stock closed higher for the third consecutive trading session. It rose 1 1/4, to 24 3/8, while other securities firms were mixed -- Morgan Stanley fell by 7/8, to 51 3/4; Paine Webber slipped 1/8, to 26 1/4, and Bear, Stearns was unchanged at 15.
Pyramid Technology's stock fell 1 7/8, to 16 1/4, on news that a Treasury Department contract for which it was the main subcontractor was being reviewed. The contract was given to American Telephone and Telegraph, but the General Services Administration has asked the Internal Revenue Service, which awarded the contract, to seek further information on its choice of A.T.& T.
The motion came after I.B.M. filed a protest against the selection of A.T.& T.

HEADLINE: U.S. Inquiry Into Salomon Is Expanded

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Salomon Brothers' efforts to corner the government securities market were also an attempt to manipulate foreign exchange rates, Richard C. Breeden, the commission's chairman said today.
"It is possible to manipulate interest rates and seek to profit from that manipulation in the foreign exchange market," Mr. Breeden told the oversight subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee. "We're looking at it," he added, "because it would be possible to use one market to attempt to influence the other." 
 Paul W. Mozer, who was dismissed by Salomon last month, was head of both Salomon's government securities desk and its foreign exchange desk. He is under investigation by both the S.E.C. and the Justice Department.
Robert E. Denham, Salomon's general counsel, whose testimony to the subcommittee today preceded Mr. Breeden's, told the panel "it would be very hard to manipulate the price of a two- or five-year security as a way of making money on the foreign exchange market."
Mr. Breeden also told the subcommittee that "it appeared that there may have been some concerted activity" involving Salomon and other firms or people at the May Treasury auction in which Salomon has already admitted violating trading rules. He said the issue required "a careful assessment of the activity" when the bonds were resold.
Mr. Breeden said further that "it appears that a large number of dealers may have reported deliberately inflated estimates of customer interest" when purchasing the debentures of Government-sponsored enterprises like the Federal National Mortgage Corporation and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Mr. Breeden and other regulators who testified today, however, warned Congress against taking precipitious action.
"Overreaction or adoption of ill-considered changes could result in significant costs to the Government and ultimately the taxpayers," Mr. Breeden said. "In addition, no system of regulation, however thorough or costly, can totally prevent the determined efforts of persons willing to lie, alter or falsify documents or otherwise conceal abusive activity."
 
Senate Adopts Violation Measure
 Meanwhile, by a voice vote Wednesday, the Senate adopted a measure supported by Mr. Breeden that would make it an explicit violation of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 for any broker, dealer or bidder in government securities to knowingly make false or misleading statements. A similar measure is pending in the House. Under current law a violation of the Securities Exchange Act is subject to civil fines and may be referred to the Justice Department for criminal prosecution.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut and co-sponsor of the Senate measure, said that it was needed to insure that regulatory agencies had "the broadest possible authority to prevent, detect and prosecute those who make false or misleading statements" in connection with purchases of government securities.
Deryck C. Maughan, Salomon's newly appointed chief operating officer, told the subcommittee that Salomon had made "millions" from the May auction, and that these profits were translated into bonuses for Salomon's managers and employes.
The subcommittee's chairman, Representative J. J. Pickle, Democrat of Texas, said he suspected that Salomon was not alone in violating the securities laws. "If you were taking advantage of the system, it seems to me that others were doing the same thing," he said.
 
Allusions to Other Violators
 Indeed, Victoria Whitenton, director of money markets for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, told the subcommittee that "Salomon has not been alone in its manipulation" of the debenture market. She said that 18 of 27 members of Freddie Mac's debenture dealer group "indicated that they had supplied false information" about their purchase of debt instruments. None, including Salomon, has been barred from future purchases.
Similarly, Linda K. Knight, vice president of the Federal National Mortgage Association, said that "several dealers may have engaged in misstatements in the past." None has been barred from future purchases.
"We do not condone it," Ms. Knight said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Hill & Knowlton Chief Makes an Abrupt Exit

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Robert L. Dilenschneider, the ambitious architect of Hill & Knowlton Inc.'s drive to become one of the world's largest public relations agencies, abruptly turned his job over yesterday to Thomas E. Eidson, the chief operating officer.
Hill & Knowlton, a subsidiary of Britain's WPP Group P.L.C., said Mr. Dilenschneider had resigned, which he denied. "All I am free to say is that I left and that I will finalize my new plans shortly," Mr. Dilenschneider said. 
 Sources familiar with Hill & Knowlton described a confrontation between the 47-year-old executive and Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of WPP. Mr. Dilenschneider had been unhappy with the pressure to focus on improving margins rather than pursuing growth opportunities, they said. Hill & Knowlton had lost a number of key clients in recent years and had been singed by internal dissent over its willingness to take on controversial assignments like the anti-abortion campaign of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. In addition, the recession demoralized the company, putting pressure on it to lay off employees and cut expenses.
"I don't know anyone working there who isn't dreaming of getting out," said one former senior executive who had clashed with Mr. Dilenschneider and other managers over the decision to represent the bishops. "They treat everybody as an expendable commodity."
 
Reputation of New Chief
 Mr. Eidson (pronounced ED-son), also 47, is assuming the titles of both president and chief executive. He has a reputation for being more concerned with details and predictable in his goals. He is inheriting a firm with 66 offices and 1,800 employees in 25 countries. The company had revenues of nearly $197 million last year. Its earnings are not publicly reported, but both profits and revenues are said to be down this year.
Timothy Metz, a senior vice president of Hill & Knowlton, described Mr. Dilenschneider as "a Vesuvian personality," adding, "I think he believes you die if you can't grow."
Mr. Dilenschneider declined to comment yesterday on widespread reports that he left Hill & Knowlton without having to promise not to compete, a common restriction in executive resignations and dismissals.
Mr. Dilenschneider joined the company in 1967 after graduating from Ohio State University's School of Journalism. He rose through the Chicago office to become chief executive in 1986. He began acquiring smaller public relations firms almost immediately. The expansion continued after Hill & Knowlton's parent company, the JWT Group (formerly J. Walter Thompson), was acquired by WPP in 1987.
Hill & Knowlton was founded in 1927 by John Hill, a conservative Midwestern Republican, and nurtured by its relationships with blue-chip companies like Mobil Oil, Pepsico, Procter & Gamble and Johnson & Johnson. Under Mr. Dilenschneider, it became equally well known for crisis management and its participation as an adviser in bruising hostile takeovers. Mr. Dilenschneider further raised both the company's profile and his own with a book about public relations, "Power and Influence."
There was not much surprise at his departure, Mr. Metz said, but plenty of mixed feelings. Mr. Eidson, who has been with the company for 19 years, began his career as an account executive in Los Angeles. Mr. Metz said that many executives felt Mr. Eidson was better suited to lead the company in the 1990's.
In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Eidson declined to criticize Mr. Dilenschneider but sketched a sharply different focus for the firm.
"There was too much concentration in our industry on rate of growth in the 1980's," he said. "The business needs to be focused on serving the existing client, our most precious resource."
 
Relationship With Mazda
 He cited his slow cultivation of Mazda Motor, the Japanese car maker that has become the company's biggest client. "If that's a slow build, so be it," he continued. "It's a stable build. Just as in advertising, it's become very costly to go after new business. It's not unusual to spend $50,000 to try to land a new business."
In recent years, Mr. Eidson has been involved in reorganizing Hill & Knowlton operations overseas and in the United States. "I feel fairly comfortable with our structure at the moment," he said. "A shake-up now would be undoing everything I just did."
Mr. Eidson became general manager of the company's operations in the Western United States in 1981. He became president and chief operating officer of the company's domestic business in 1986, and last year was named president and chief executive of Hill & Knowlton International, the overseas division.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Robert L. Dilenschneider, left, the president and chief executive of Hill & Knowlton, yesterday parted ways with the firm he joined some 24 years ago, leaving it under the control of Thomas E. Eidson, its chief operating officer. (Photographs from Hill & Knowlton)

HEADLINE: Japanese Finance Minister Reportedly Sets Resignation

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto has told elders of the ruling party that he will resign to take responsibility for Japan's ongoing financial scandals, but not until after an important meeting of world financial leaders in Bangkok, Thailand, next month, according to reports here today.
Just about every major newspaper and television news broadcast carried the reports. Mr. Hashimoto's office refused to comment, but a member of Parliament from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and some senior Finance Ministry officials said they understood the reports to be correct. 
 The resignation would be a symbolic assumption of responsibility for the scandals. Since the resignation is likely to come after the passage of tougher securities laws and after Mr. Hashimoto has fulfilled his international obligations, political analsyts said the timing might help save his political career.
 
Important Global Issues
 If, as reported, he does stay on through the Bangkok meeting, Mr. Hashimoto is likely to give Japan a stronger, more experienced voice at the crucial series of talks, where large-scale financial aid to the Soviet Union and Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund are expected to be discussed.
His presence could also benefit the United States at the meeting, since Mr. Hashimoto has often aligned himself with American positions. He was instrumental in Japan's decision to provide billions of dollars to the United States during the Persian Gulf war, a stand that won him public praise recently from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
There has been speculation for several months that Mr. Hashimoto would resign because of the scandals, which have implicated just about every major securities house and bank in Japan in unethical practices. The scandals have also tarred the ministry by suggesting that its oversight of the financial industries was lax and that in some instances regulators winked at such unethical practices as improper payments to cover stock market losses of some brokerage house clients.
Mr. Hashimoto was personally embarrassed when one of his political secretaries admitted helping arrange illegal loans from a major bank for three friends of Mr. Hashimoto.
Mr. Hashimoto has hinted several times that he is prepared to resign. He is, however, widely reported to harbor ambitions of being prime minister someday, and he apparently is letting politics influence his timing. He has said he does not want to step down until he has taken measures to prevent similar financial scandals from occurring in the future. A bill to toughen the securities laws is expected to pass Parliament in the next few weeks.
 
Key Role in Talks
 Today's reports were a relief to ministry officials, who were concerned that Japan would be entering the Bangkok meetings with a newcomer or interim official as Finance Minister. Besides attending the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund there, Mr. Hashimoto is expected to be the chairman of a meeting of the finance ministers of the seven leading industrial nations, known as the Group of Seven.
He is expected to deliver an important speech underscoring Japan's growing commitment to Asia as a focus for aid, investment and trade, a trend that has gathered momentum in recent years. The speech is also expected to hold up the economic success of Asia as a model for the rest of the world.
The meetings in Bangkok end Oct. 17, just before the ruling Liberal Democratic Party holds elections for a party president, who always becomes prime minister. Mr. Hashimoto's resignation at that time would be considered a token gesture, a party official said today, because there would be a Cabinet reshuffle after the election anyway. But the official added, it would allow Mr. Hashimoto to say he had lived up to his responsibilities, and thus it would perhaps salvage his political career.
