HEADLINE: Chief Is Toppled at British Aerospace

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Sir Roland Smith, the chairman of British Aerospace P.L.C., is resigning after a reported rebellion by large shareholders and the board of the company, which is Britain's largest military contractor and exporter of manufactured goods.
By several accounts, Sir Roland's downfall is a result of a clumsily handled share offering now under way, a sharp drop in the company's profits, an autocratic management style and differences over the company's efforts to diversify from the military and aerospace businesses. 
 "Some institutional investors have been very upset," said an investment manager at a large British insurance company, who insisted that he not be named.
British analysts and newspapers said board members and senior executives, including Richard H. Evans, British Aerospace's chief executive, were irritated by Sir Roland's strong will and his tendency to act on his own.
"The professor's style was a little bit more abrasive than other directors liked," said Keith I. Hodgkinson, an analyst at Lehman Brothers International Ltd., referring to Sir Roland, a longtime marketing professor. "He would tend to dictate."
Some analysts wondered today whether Sir Roland's ouster would cause British corporations to question whether someone could really serve effectively as the chairman of several companies at the same time, a common practice here. Sir Roland was chairman of seven or so companies and a director of several others.
Unlike chairmen in the United States, chairmen of British companies often are not also chief executives and may not be deeply involved in the hands-on management of the company.
British Aerospace's board said Sir Roland would be replaced temporarily by Sir Graham Day, the 58-year-old chairman of Rover, the car company that British Aerospace bought from the British Government in 1988. Sir Graham is also chairman of Cadbury Schweppes, the food and drink company, and Powergen, a new investor-owned power-generating company. He is a director of several other companies, including the Laird Group P.L.C. and Thorn EMI P.L.C.
Sir Graham said he would relinquish his duties temporarily at Rover and the other companies to devote time to British Aerospace.
Efforts to reach Sir Roland, Sir Graham and Mr. Evans today were unsuccessful.
This is hardly the first board room coup at a blue-chip British corporation. The chairman of Midland Bank, one of the nation's largest financial institutions, was toppled last March after the board decided he was not moving fast enough to revive the troubled bank.
Still, the abruptness of the British Aerospace announcement, coming late Wednesday night after a reportedly stormy board meeting, shocked many in the country. "The British way is to retire the person gracefully," said Nigel Nicholson, director of the Center for Organizational Research at the London Business School.
In a front-page article today, The Independent, a British newspaper not given to sensationalism, called the resignation "one of the most spectacular and brutal board room coups witnessed in many years." Several newspapers said Mr. Evans was a leader of the group of outside directors and senior executives who demanded Sir Roland's resignation, which becomes effective Oct. 7.
Sir Roland, 62 years old, has been chairman of British Aerospace since 1987. He oversaw its diversification into areas like cars, real estate and construction. He has also been pushing the company to form partnerships in the aerospace business to reduce the high costs and risks involved in developing and building new products.
Like contractors everywhere, the company has been struggling to adjust to an era of much lower military spending by Britain and other countries.
Even the addition of different products has not helped much in these tough times. The British and American recessions and the economic slowdown in other European countries have depressed Britain's real-estate and car businesses. Orders for civilian aircraft fell because airlines were hit hard by the recessions and a drop in passengers during the war against Iraq.
On Sept. 11, British Aerospace announced that its pretax profits in the first half of this year had plunged by 49.4 percent, to 86 million ($139.4 million). It also disclosed that it expected a program to overhaul its businesses, which includes cutting about 10,000 jobs, to cost 520 million ($900.9 million) by the end of 1993. As a result, the company said it would take a charge against earnings this year of about 250 million ($433.1 million).
That means the company will suffer a pretax loss of about 100 million ($173.3 million) for the year, Mr. Hodgkinson, the Lehman Brothers analyst, predicted.
Sir Roland's problems culminated this month when plans for a 432 million ($748.4 million) share offering by British Aerospace leaked out, depressing the company's stock price.
In trading on the London International Stock Exchange, British Aerospace's shares closed today at 4.28 ($7.42), up 3 pence (5 cents). Earlier this month, the stock had plunged to a low of 3.95 from 5.55 on Sept. 8. Its 1991 high is 6.64.
In a statement issued late Wednesday night, Sir Roland said: "In order to end damaging speculation about the future of the company, I have decided that it would be in the best interests of British Aerospace if I resigned now so that the management of the company can implement its strategy without any of the uncertainties which have surfaced since the announcement" of the share offering.

HEADLINE: Nintendo and Minnesota Set A Living-Room Lottery Test

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
In Minnesota, all you will need is a dollar, a dream and a Nintendo set.
The state plans to test a system that will allow people to use Nintendo equipment to play the state lottery in the comfort of their living rooms. 
 With the growth of lotteries tapering off, industry executives and officials in other states are eager to see whether this approach can draw more people to the games by letting them play without standing in line to buy tickets.
 
Combating a Slowdown
 "The lottery industry is looking for ways to expand its horizons," said Connie Scovin, an executive with the Control Data Corporation, the Minneapolis-based company that developed the idea and is designing the test system.
Nearly a third of the nation's homes have Nintendo sets, and if the Minnesota test is successful, Control Data plans to make the system available to other states.
The test will involve 10,000 homes next year. For the test, the state will provide the video game sets and the modem devices that allow them to communicate with a central computer. Participants, who will pay a service charge of $10 a month, will get software that lets them play all of Minnesota's games, including the biggest jackpots.
After players set up accounts with the lottery, they will be able to select their lottery numbers on their television sets at home. The numbers will be stored electronically in the central lottery computer and in a file in the player's Nintendo set.
Small prizes will be credited to the player's account. To collect a large jackpot, winners will have to go to a state lottery office and identify themselves as the holder of the winning account.
It is illegal in Minnesota for minors to play lottery games, and the Nintendo plan has been criticized by the State Attorney General and others who say it will make it easy for children to gamble. The system will have passwords and other safeguards intended to thwart unauthorized playing.
"Kids are gambling now; this will allow them to gamble more," said Tony Bouza, the former Gaming Commissioner in Minnesota. Young people today are well acquainted with technology, and they will inevitably devise ways to bypass the security measures, he predicted. He also said that gambling at home by adults sets a bad example for children. "You can't create safe sins," he said.
But others say the new system could serve a broader purpose, providing the catalyst that will encourage more people to use computers and phone lines to tap into a growing pool of information and services.
Nintendo's use as a gambling device may help put spark into the market for such on-line services, said Gary Arlen of Arlen Communications Inc., a research firm in Bethesda, Md. "I've been looking for the killer service," he said. "This is the kind of thing that makes sense."
For more than a decade, large corporations like Sears, Roebuck and I.B.M. have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in networks that allow people to shop, read the news, and make travel reservations using home computers linked to telephone lines. Such systems, including a Sears-I.B.M. joint venture, Prodigy Services Company, have been somewhat cumbersome to use and have been viewed more as a novelty than a necessary adjunct to daily life. Only about 3 percent of the households in the United States use an on-line service like Prodigy, Mr. Arlen said.
But as giant corporations have stumbled, Nintendo has been lurking in the background, the envy of the industry, with 30 million units already in use. Nintendo has had its eye on far more than the video-game market since it sold its first machine in the United States in 1986.
In Japan, Nintendo customers use their machines for banking and for buying and selling stocks. In a prescient bit of engineering, Nintendo included a plug to snap in a modem on the bottom of every machine sold in the United States.
With the lottery game, Nintendo will introduce its modem to the United States. As a contractor to Control Data, Nintendo will supply the modem and a specially designed software cartridge that provides lottery graphics. Control Data officials said Nintendo was providing the 10,000 machines and the other equipment for the test at no cost. The machines retail for about $80.
People who already have Nintendo machines would have to retrofit them with a modem to take advantage of on-line services. Computer modems are currently available for less than $100, and Mr. Arlen said Nintendo engineers could probably come up with a modem that would cost $50 to $75. Still, he questioned how many consumers would be willing to nearly double their investment in the machines.
Nintendo has also explored setting up a game network in which players could challenge other players, and has considered a stock trading service with Fidelity Services of Boston. Both projects are on hold. Nintendo said in a statement, "We are constantly approached by third parties who have ideas that are outside the traditional video-game arena."
Some in the industry say Nintendo may harm its image by its association with a lottery. They note that the company is already under fire from some parents and educators who say its games lack educational content.
"It's Jimmy the Greek comes home to your kid's bedroom," said Bob Heitman, general manager of the Sierra Network, a computerized game network that charges players to use its service. The network is a unit of Sierra On-Line Inc., a maker of computer games.
"I have a bad feeling for lotteries," he said. "As a family game company, I would not do it or advocate that our company do it."
 
New Uses for Older Machines
 For Nintendo, the lottery business could help prolong the life of its older model, which has been outmoded by a more powerful Nintendo machine introduced in the United States last month. Also, the introduction of gambling could help combat the general decline in interest in video games.
In a statement, Nintendo said, "This test could provide us with some insights into the potential for further network applications; however, our main focus is to find the kind of entertainment software that will truly take advantage of that potential."
Nintendo says that its machines are more than just toys and that 35 percent of Nintendo players are over the age of 18. Minnesota lottery officials and Control Data executives say their system's safeguards should be adequate to keep children from playing the lottery at home. Otho Brown, a vice president of Control Data, likened the situation to banking through automatic teller machines -- parents who keep the password a secret should have no concern about a child's misusing a cash card.
The lottery system has a number of built-in safeguards, including a feature that disables the unit if an incorrect password is entered. Becoming eligible to play the lottery at home is an involved process that requires mailing in a copy of a driver's license or other photo identification. And, all play is prepaid through deposits the account holders make with the lottery, so no one can run up a big unpaid bill. A $50 daily limit will be put on each player.
 
Control Data's Hopes
 If the home system is successful, it could provide an important business advantage for Control Data. The Minnesota-based company lags behind the Gtech Corporation of West Greenwich, R.I., the leader in supplying computer equipment and services to lotteries.
"We entered the test with the idea that lotteries would use it nationwide," said Mr. Brown of Control Data. He said lottery growth has slowed because the games have already attracted all the people interested in playing.
Nationwide, more than $20 billion was spent on lottery tickets last year, an increase of 2.8 percent from a year earlier, according to the North American Association of State and Provincial Lotteries in Washington. There are lotteries in 33 states and the District of Columbia.
As a result of the slowdown in the rate of growth, Mr. Brown said the lottery industry has been exploring ways to increase the appeal of the games and attract new types of customers. A group of state lotteries is considering sponsoring a nationally televised lottery show.
Mr. Brown said Nintendo owners are better educated and more affluent than the typical lottery players. He said that if home lottery play caught on, it could increase volume by 10 percent to 15 percent a year.

HEADLINE: West Reluctant to Quell Zaire Unrest

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Western Governments, including those that have sent troops to help evacuate foreigners from riot-ravaged Zaire, expressed reluctance today to help quell disorder that is endangering the rule of their longtime ally, President Mobutu Sese Seko, as civil unrest reportedly spread across the country.
American and French officials said Kinshasa, the capital of Zaire, appeared calm today after unpaid troops sacked the city on Monday and Tuesday. 
 As United States military transport planes continued to move hundreds of French and Belgian troops to bases near Zaire today, Western officials said their efforts would be limited to evacuating foreigners.
"We are not there to help Mobutu, that's absolutely clear," said Laurent Aublin, a spokesman for the French Embassy in Washington.
In 1978, when French, Belgian and Moroccan troops intervened with United States support in southeastern Zaire, they not only rescued foreigners but also helped suppress an incursion from Angola of dissident troops opposed to General Mobutu. The officials today said that they would not intervene against domestic opponents of General Mobutu, who did not seem able to form a cohesive military force.
"The French intervention then was also aimed at turning back the aggression," Mr. Aublin said. "This time that is not the case. France has not taken responsibility for restoring order in Kinshasa."
American and Belgian officials made similar remarks, with one Belgian saying that there had been no opposition to his country's efforts to take control of airports in southeastern Zaire for the evacuation. "There was no typical military fighting at the landing locations, so I wouldn't characterize it as a military confrontation," he said.
The local police have taken control of Kinshasa and its airport, which French troops had occupied this week to evacuate their citizens. A spokesman for the State Department, Richard Boucher, told reporters today that while Kinshasa and another city, Lubumbashi, appeared calm, civil unrest had been reported "in several provincial areas."
Reuters reported that General Mobutu was on a yacht about 30 miles from Kinshasa.
 
Security Forces Kill 50
 His unpopularity in the West has grown because complaints of human rights abuses and corruption in his country, while hardly a recent development, have been intensifying, and because of the decline of Soviet power and the departure of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola. These developments have also reduced his value as an anti-Communist bulwark.
As many as 50 unarmed people have been killed by Zaire's security forces at opposition demonstrations since April, said Curt R. Goering, the deputy executive director of Amnesty International USA, a New York-based human rights group. Last year at least a dozen students were slain at a demonstration in Lubumbashi, and there were unconfirmed reports of as many as 100 to 150 dead, he said.
When Belgium demanded a full investigation last year into the Lubumbashi killings, General Mobutu responded by closing three provincial Belgian consulates, expelling 800 Belgian development workers, restricting Belgian flights and halting interest payments on Zaire's $500 million debt to Belgium, the Belgian official said.
[The European relief organization Doctors Without Borders estimated that about 100 people had died and 1,250 to 1,750 people had been injured in the riots since Monday, The Associated Press reported from Kinshasa.]
The troops who terrorized Kinshasa this week, after learning that they would not to be paid, usually receive as little as $10 a month. In contrast, estimates of the President's personal wealth run as high as $5 billion to $6 billion, said Phillip G. LeBel, the director of the Center for Economic Research on Africa at Montclair State College in Upper Montclair, N.J.
"He has created such an intricate web of corrupt business and political arrangements that he has stifled all economic activity," Mr. LeBel said.

HEADLINE: The Salvador Accord: Conflict Is Far From Over

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The two sides in the Salvadoran civil war have agreed, in the accord signed Wednesday evening, that their country should become a fairer place in which to live. But the transformation of this hope into reality will essentially rely on the good faith of two foes who have given each other no quarter until now.
Pressures born of a shift in the global political balance brought the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani to this breakthrough, but the rank and file on each side is deeply distrustful of the other. 
 In the towns, hamlets and byways of the tiny Central American country, where soldiers and guerrillas still confront each other daily in a war in which no prisoners are taken, neither side feels it has lost. Therefore, neither side feels it should concede or give up anything.
 
The Challenge Ahead
 That is the challenge awaiting those who negotiated the agreement in New York in 10 days of sometimes round-the-clock sessions under the direction of the United Nations' Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar. Indeed, observers of the process said the two sides often spent more time negotiating with their own people than with the enemy.
The accord, which Mr. Perez de Cuellar said has untied the Gordian knot that had deadlocked the negotiations earlier this year, consists of broad agreements on the organization of a new national police force under civilian control, "purification" and reduction of the armed forces, an assurance that families and sympathizers of the guerrillas will not have to vacate lands they occupied a decade ago in guerrilla-dominated areas of the country, and creation of a commission to carry out the agreement.
The New York accords complement agreements reached earlier on respect for human rights and political changes intended to give the former guerrillas a better chance of winning elections. Negotiators said the next round of talks, to begin Oct. 12 in Mexico, will deal with a few remaining points on the armed forces and then the form of a cease-fire.
 
The Distrust Is Evident
 Although there is a general sense among all concerned that the guns should be silenced by the end of the year, the extent of the distrust remaining between the two sides was obvious in comments made almost as soon as the document was signed.
"Something the army hasn't seemed to understand is that the bell has tolled to end the war," proclaimed Joaquin Villalobos, considered the most skilled and ruthless of the five guerrilla leaders.
"They don't want to hear it," he asserted, "because they've converted the war into their business, into their reason for being."
And just days before signing the accord, another guerrilla leader, Salvador Sanchez Ceren, declared in an interview, "Even if the army is reduced and reformed, and even if a United Nations verification mechanism is established, neither we nor Salvadoran society can have enough confidence in the army."
 
'A Defensive Strategy'
 President Cristiani, for his part, said that if the guerrillas were to launch a significant military operation before the Mexico round of talks "it would not look good for the peace process." But he said the army would not give up its currently aggressive patrols in guerrilla areas, which he described as falling "within a defensive strategy."
Mr. Cristiani, who represents the more conciliatory wing of his rightist party, the Nationalist Republican Alliance, has often come under criticism from his own supporters and from within the army for his willingness to negotiate. While he was in New York, a Salvadoran newspaper closely identified with the powerful landholding class from which the President comes sharply criticized him in an editorial.
He dismissed such critics by saying there was "basically no alternative" to negotiating.
Mr. Cristiani not only faces the challenge of keeping the army and extreme right on board but also will be tested in his ability to respond to social and economic demands made by the guerrillas and by soldiers who will lose their jobs in the army reduction.
The once-fraudulent electoral process has been cleaned up significantly in recent years, and the political parts of the peace accords further improve the left's chances of fair treatment, but the guerrillas will eventually be tested on whether they are truly able to put faith in elections as the way to solve political differences.
Mr. Villalobos is the guerrilla chief whom the Government thinks will have the most difficulty keeping the promise of the rebels to confine their future struggles to peaceful political activity. Mr. Sanchez, by contrast, talked of a new phase "in which the forces in search of democracy and liberty are going to express themselves more in the political fight."
The ultimate tests will be how the former guerrillas react if the voters find little appeal in their electoral messages, and how the right and the army respond if the voters do like the message of the former rebels.

HEADLINE: U.S. Policy on Yugoslavia Shifts to Curbing Serbs

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 26

 BODY:
In vehemently denouncing Serbia before the Security Council on Wednesday and accusing it of special responsibility in Yugoslavia's intensifying civil war, the Bush Administration has abandoned its earlier policy of finding blame on all sides and has decided to try to use its influence to limit further expansion by the Serbs.
The United States and its allies apparently chose to raise the intensity of their warnings to Serbia at this time, after the current Serbian offensive againt Croatiabogged down, hoping that the Serbs can be disuaded from making any new drives on areas beyond Serbia where there are significant Serbian populations. 
 "The government of Serbia and the Yugoslav federal military bear a special and indeed growing responsiblity for the grim future which awaits the peoples of Yugoslavia if they do not stop the bloodshed," Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said during a special session of the Security Council held Wednesday to impose a total arms embargo on Yugoslavia and to endorse European Community mediation efforts.
"Clearly, the Yugoslav Federal military is not serving as an impartial guarantor of a cease-fire in Croatia," he continued. "On the contrary, it has actively supported local Serbian forces in violating the cease-fire, causing deaths to the citizens it is constitutionally supposed to protect. The military has initiated what can only be described as outright military intervention against Croatia, while repudiating the authority of Yugoslav Government institutions which have sought to control it."
 
Stopping the Serbs and the Army
 For now at least, it appears that the Bush Administration has abandoned any hope it had for rebuilding a federal Yugoslavia and has decided instead to concentrate on preventing Serbia and the Yugoslav army that it dominates from dismembering other independence-minded republics and establishing its own "small Yugoslavia," or "Greater Serbia," as Mr. Baker put it.
"Secretary Baker has inserted the United States into a conflict, which up to now he has allowed to be primarily handled by the Europeans, in a way that appears to place America on the side of the Croats, even though he calls on all sides to end the violence," said Steven Burg, an expert on Yugoslav politics at Brandeis University. "While he appears to have been motivated by the opportunity to achieve a cease-fire in place, at a moment of relative balance, the irony is that his statement may weaken the American claim to be an honest broker capable of neutral mediation in the future."
Although in May and July the State Department reprimanded the Serbs for trying to impose their will on other Yugoslav republics, it always accompanied those warnings by cautioning the other republics against unilaterally pulling away from the Serbian-dominated central Government. Washington warned all of them not to expect American diplomatic recognition.
 
German Threat of Sanctions
 In fact, Mr. Baker was accused by some conservative commentators of having implicitly encouraged the Serbs to try to forcibly hold Yugoslavia together by the vigorous manner in which he seemed to oppose the uniltaeral, and inevitable, declarations of independnce by Slovenia and Croatia.
That posture contrasted sharply with that of the Germans, who for much of the summer pressed the European Community to chastise Serbia, even raising the prospect of economic sanction against Belgrade.
Mr. Baker, speaking at Wednesday's special meeting of the Security Council, certainly went out of his way to erase any lingering impression that the United States was ready to countenance Serbian efforts to hold Yugoslavia together by force, making it clear that the United States has joined an increasingly large international chorus in singling out the Serbs for particular responsibility.
"It is clear that the Serbian leadership is actively supporting and encouraging the use of force in Croatia by Serbian militants and the Yugoslav military," he said. "The apparent objective of the Serbian leadership and the Yugoslav military working in tandem is to create a 'small Yugoslavia' or 'Greater Serbia,' which would exclude Slovenia and a rump Croatia."
"This new entity would be based on the kind of repression which Serbian authorities have exercised in Kosovo for several years," the Secretary of State said referring to a region where ethnic Albanians are in the majority. "This entity would also be based on the use of force -- well underway in Croatia, and beginning to take shape in Bosnia and Herzegovina -- to establish control over territories outside Serbia."
Mr. Baker, in remarks addressed to various Yugoslav-American groups, said the United States appreciated the concerns of all the peoples of Yugoslavia everywhere about their future in the event that Yugoslavia disintegrates.
"But the United States cannot and will not accept repression and the use of force in the name of those concerns," he said.

HEADLINE: Senate-House Conference Agrees To Extend Unemployment Relief

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
Senate and House conferees reached quick agreement today on a $6.4 billion measure to provide extended unemployment benefits for people who have been out of work at least half a year.
The measure, which would provide up to 20 weeks of additional benefits in the states hit hardest by the recession, faces an almost certain veto by President Bush, but Democrats hope to override a veto by him for the first time. 
 The compromise agreement, adopted by exchanging documents without a face-to-face meeting, includes a House provision that would pay for the measure by declaring an emergency under last year's budget act, either upon Mr. Bush's signing the bill or a successful effort to override his veto.
 
Bill Returns to Each House
 In its version of the bill, the Senate had included a two-step provision, like the one Mr. Bush used to kill a similar measure in August when he signed the bill but blocked the benefits from flowing by refusing to issue a separate declaration of emergency. This two-step provision was abandoned by the Senate in the conference with the House, so Mr. Bush will have to veto the bill to stop it.
Now the measure returns to each house for a final vote, and the removal of the two-step provision may cost the bill Republican votes in the Senate. Thirteen of the Senate's 43 Republicans voted for the bill on Tuesday when it passed, 69 to 30. The House, which pressed for emergency designation, will not vote before Tuesday when it returns from a four-day weekend recess, but the Senate may vote as early as Friday.
If as many as four Republican Senators change their votes and oppose the bill, they would deny the bill the two-thirds majority needed to override a veto. The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, has been saying, publicly and privately, that he has enough Republicans ready to switch to sustain a veto.
The House passed the bill 283 to 125 and is expected to be able to muster more than a two-thirds majority when it votes on the compromise.
The bill would replace, temporarily, an existing extended benefits program that is drawn so narrowly that benefits are now paid only in Rhode Island and Puerto Rico. The new program would be paid for entirely out of Federal funds, drawn from a $7.7 billion trust fund created to pay for extended benefits.
The existing progarm is paid half from that trust fund and half from state funds, and provides up to 13 weeks of benefits after someone covered by unemployment insurance exhausts his or her benefits. In most states, benefits are limited to 26 weeks and have averaged $167 over the last 12 months.
Under the bill, up to 20 additional weeks of benefits would be paid in states where total unemployment averaged 8 percent over the previous six months. Currently that would include Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi and West Virginia as well as Puerto Rico and Rhode Isand.
Workers in states where unemployement has averaged 7 percent or more would be eligible for up to 13 additional weeks. Thirteen states, including New York and California, and the District of Columbia, are on that list. Workers in all other states would be eligible for 7 additional weeks of benefits.

HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PEOPLE IN POVERTY SHOWS SHARP RISE IN U.S.

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26

 BODY:
The poverty rate rose sharply last year and the incomes of Americans declined, according to a Census Bureau report that provides the first detailed look at suffering in the current recession. The report immediately touched off a debate about how much pain the recession would ultimately inflict, on whom, and for how long.
But by the bureau's estimate, 2.1 million more Americans were living in poverty in 1990 than in the previous year. 
 The trends of rising poverty and declining income, while broad, were not universal. For instance, the main increases in poverty occurred among white and Hispanic people, not blacks, and took place in the Northeast. The poverty rate rose for both children and the elderly. It rose inside metropolitan areas, but not beyond them.
The main drop in income was among white men, rather than among women or blacks. Income declined in the Northeast and the West, but not in the South or Midwest. It dropped for households at all earnings levels, but not for those 65 years old or more.
 
Role of Geography
 Census officials speculated that the racial differences were primarily being driven by geography, since 71 percent of blacks live outside the Northeast and the West, where the recession is taking its greatest toll. They also said a larger percentage of poor black families were headed by an unmarried woman, than poor white or Hispanic families. Such households are more likely to rely on welfare and less likely to have their incomes cut by recessionary layoffs. They added that as the recession went on, they did not expect blacks to be spared.
The poverty rate is a controversial measure intended to reflect the percentage of Americans living below a threshold of minimal need, estimated at $13,359 for a family of four in 1990. It is not adjusted for regional variations in the cost of living. Many conservatives have said the measurement, which excludes noncash benefits like food stamps and health insurance, exaggerates the extent of poverty.
The poverty rate is mainly of interest because of the measure it provides of social well-being rather than for allowing individuals to qualify for government assistance.
In 1990, the bureau estimated, 33.6 million Americans were living in poverty, pushing the poverty rate up to 13.5 percent from 12.8 percent a year earlier. Median household income fell 1.7 percent, to $29,943.
Many analysts, including some inside the Census Bureau, expressed surprise at the magnitude of the changes, since the recession did not officially begin until halfway through 1990. They said its full effect might not be known until next year's survey, which will cover 1991.
Democratic leaders, who have been emphasizing what they call the unfair economic effects of the 1980's, quickly seized on the report to argue that it portends high poverty rates and a suffering middle class well into the future.
"This is really distressing," said Senator Paul Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who is chairman of the Joint Economic Committee and who renewed his call for extended unemployment benefits.
 
Contrast in Views
 "The siren song that the Administration has been singing that this is a short and shallow recession is being belittled by all the evidence," he said.
But those with a more sanguine view of the future were interpreting the numbers as predictable and passing.
"It's about what you'd expect," said Ben J. Wattenberg, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, who has written a book predicting robust economic growth for the next decade. "Without being facetious -- surprise, surprise -- in a recession some people lose their jobs and poverty goes up a bit."
Mr. Wattenberg said this was the ninth recession since World War II, adding that in each case median incomes subsequently surged to record highs.
Some of those who expressed surprise at the magnitude of the rise in the poverty rate turned to unemployment statistics by way of comparison. The unemployment rate only rose to 5.5 percent in 1990 from 5.3 percent in 1989. If a small change in unemployment could send an additional 2.1 million Americans into poverty, they say, the effects will be much worse for 1991, when unemployment is expected to average about 6.7 percent.
Citing such numbers, Isaac Shapiro, an analyst at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research center, argues the poverty statistics "are surprisingly bad given how early we are into the recession."
A different gauge of their effect comes more informally, from a Census Bureau office pool by those involved in the measurement. The median guess was that the poverty rate would reach 13.1 percent, said one analyst, who said the professionals were surprised when the number surged to 13.5 percent.
If there was good news in the report, it was that differences narrowed in the earnings between blacks and whites and between men and women. In 1990, black married couple families had 84 percent of the income of married whites, an all-time high. Women's earnings rose to 71 percent of those of men, also an all-time high.
But that silver lining came with its own cloud: the gain was a result of declines in the earnings of white men, rather than in gains by other groups. Men's earnings fell 3.6 percent, to an average of $27,866 in the third consecutive year of decline. Women's earnings remained unchanged at $19,816.
"Women as a whole haven't been as badly hit by the recession because they're not in the factory-line manufacturing jobs," said Patricia Ruggles, an economist at the Urban Institute. "They tend to be in the service sector, with jobs like waitresses, maids, clerks."
Median household income fell by 5 percent in the Northeast, to $32,676. In the West, it fell by 3.1 percent, to $31,761. Both areas still had significantly higher household incomes than the Midwest or South, which registered $29,897 and $26,942, respectively.
On a per-capita basis, real income for all Americans declined for the first time in eight years, by 2.9 percent to $14,387.
Despite the rising poverty rate, today's number of 13.5 percent remains below the recent high in 1983 of 15 percent. Nonetheless, it is higher than at any time in the 1970's.
Ms. Ruggles and others expressed particular concern about the long-term effect on the poorest fifth of Americans, who were battered by the 1981-82 recession and whose average incomes are still less than they were in 1979, when adjusted for inflation. She said she feared the poor might be caught in a one-step forward, two-step backward pattern of battering recessions and slow recoveries. The poverty rate for whites rose to 10.7 percent, from 10 percent in 1990. For Hispanic people, the figures rose to 28.1 percent from 26.2 percent.
The rate for blacks, though not registering a statistically significant gain, remained the highest of the three groups, at 31.9 percent. By Census figures, Hispanic people may be either black or white.
The Northeast was the only region to experience a growth in poverty, to 11.4 percent from 10 percent in 1989, although its rate remained the country's lowest. In 1990, the rate was 12.4 percent for the Midwest; 15.8 percent for the South, and 13 percent for the West.
The poverty rate inside metropolitan areas rose to 12.7 percent from 12 percent in 1990.
 
Rise in Elderly Poor
 The poverty rate for the elderly rose to 12.2 percent from 11.4 percent, even though the overall earnings of the elderly did not decline. Analysts say that is because a large proportion of the elderly are concentrated just above the poverty line, so a small changes can push them across the official barrier.
While the elderly rate rose, it is still sharply diminished from its levels a generation ago. In 1967, the poverty rate for the elderly was 29.5.
The poverty rate for children also rose, to 20.6 percent in 1990 from 19.6 percent the previous year.
Analysts have said the high percentage of children in poverty is being driven by the increasing numbers of female-headed households. Married couples continued to have the nation's lowest poverty rate: 5.7 percent.
The Census Bureau produces the annual report by interviewing 60,000 households each March, in a data base separate from the decennial census.
In calculating its official rates, the bureau counts only cash income and not benefits like subsidized housing, Medicaid or food stamps. It then computes the percentage of people who fall below an income threshold, which is adjusted each year for inflation.
A number of conservatives have said that by failing to count food stamps and other Government benefits, the bureau vastly overstates the amount of American poverty.
Others, including Ms. Ruggles of the Urban Institute, have argued that the bureau underestimates poverty.
Census officials have argued that any measure of poverty is subjective and the rates are chiefly of interest in tracking trends, which remain about the same no matter which definition is used.
Some programs do use the poverty line in determining eligibility, but usually not on a one-to-one basis. The food stamp program, for instance, typically provides assistance to families with incomes of about 120 percent of the poverty threshold.
Democratic leaders lost no time in calling for stepped-up measures of Government intervention. "The country cannot continue to tolerate this," said Representative Thomas Downey, a Long Island Democrat. "You're not going to be able to put enough locks on the door to protect yourself from people being dislocated."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Arkansas Traveler

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
Can the Governor of one of the smallest, poorest states in the South win the Democratic nomination for President? Can he if he is an intellectual, a one-time Rhodes Scholar, a Yale Law graduate? If he has a certain detachment, a sense of humor about his ambition?
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas is about to find out. He has scheduled a press conference for next Thursday to announce his plans, and nobody doubts that he is going to run. 
 After a speech to the National Newspaper Association here in Little Rock, he was surrounded by local reporters. "Can you beat George Bush?" one asked.
"Not tomorrow," he said. "That's what we have elections for."
Mr. Clinton talked about issues. Then Bill Simmons, chief of the Associated Press bureau here, said: "That sounds awfully high-minded for a competition that can be settled on Willie Horton." The Governor replied that the Willie Horton tactic in the 1988 Bush campaign could have been handled -- by answering it directly and addressing the real issue of crime and people's fear of it.
Later, in a conversation on board a plane, Governor Clinton talked about the irrelevance and ugliness of recent campaigns. "Maybe you have to be crazy to run for President these days -- anybody who files should be disqualified," he said with a smile.
"But I don't see this as a Don Quixote venture," he went on. He told a story about a police officer who drove with him on a recent visit to Houston: a man 27 years on the force, who called himself a conservative.
"I saw you on C-Span," the officer said. "You going to run for President?"
"Do you think I have a chance to win?" Mr. Clinton replied.
"Hell no! With that war and all . . ."
As they drove along, the Governor asked what issues the officer would use if he were running. The officer talked about economic stress, stagnant wages, the ever-rising cost of health care . . . . And those are some of the very issues that Mr. Clinton thinks can win the 1992 election for a Democrat if he manages to focus the campaign on them.
"People now believe the Presidency is about foreign policy," the Governor said. "But that's not what they really care about in their own lives.
"I basically agree with E. J. Dionne's argument [in his book "Why Americans Hate Politics"] that the recent elections have given Americans false choices. The Republicans won by dividing us -- by saying, 'If you're for civil rights, you're pro-quota,' 'If you want government to help solve problems, you're for more taxing and spending.'
"So the Democrats lost the elections, but the people lost the aftermath. In 1988 Americans knew the cold war was over. They wanted to move on from Reagan. Bush knew that -- it's why he talked about being the Education President, the Environment President. But he won on 'Read my lips' and plastic surgery on Dukakis.
"Bush was hurt by the way he won that election. He was below 50 percent in the polls in 1990, but he was saved by Saddam Hussein."
The next campaign, Mr. Clinton said, should be about how to rebuild this country's internal strength so it can live up to its vision of itself and carry out its responsibilities in the world.
"We have no strategy for our economic future," he said. "We have the biggest underclass of any major country. The middle class is under stress. The Reagan-Bush policy is just Keep inflation down, reduce government. I don't think that will cut it."
Education should be a major national emphasis, Mr. Clinton said -- as it has been in Arkansas during his years as Governor. Sending a child to college today takes three times the percentage of family income that it did a few years ago. He spoke of a new national program of college loans to be repaid out of graduates' income or by doing national service. The Reagan-Bush effort to reduce Federal support for college students was "nutty," he said.
"The Democratic primaries could define the issues for the general election," he said -- "present the real choices this country faces. Bush may win in the end because people see him as having the experience in foreign policy, but the worst that could happen is to make him a better President in a second term."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Japanese Shift Away From U.S.

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
TO diversify the risks to its economy, Japan is shifting the focus of its global strategy away from the United States and toward Southeast Asia and Europe.
The shift results in part from a decision to resist what the Japanese Government and many business executives regard as a rising threat of American protectionism. This week, Japanese companies said they would retaliate against a 63 percent United States tariff on advanced screens for computers. Citing the tariff, the Toshiba Corporation said it was moving its manufacturing operations out of the United States. 
 But the Japanese decision to diversify also stems from a conviction that economic growth in the United States will continue to lag behind that in some other regions. A white paper presented to the Japanese Cabinet last May noted that despite some improvements in American manufacturing productivity, "these indicators of improvement should not lead us to be too optimistic, for a number of problems still remain, such as the economy's deep-rooted reliance on imports, the sluggish growth in R.&D. investment and capital stock, and the slowdown in investment for strengthening productive capacity."
In a study for the Conference Board, two economists, Gail D. Fosler and Kenneth Goldstein, wrote that the motivation behind the shift in Japan's strategy "is no mystery." They attributed it chiefly to the long-run rise in the yen's value. They wrote that "the cost of Japan-based production, which is already relatively high, will be increasingly disadvantaged."
Production abroad has other advantages. A Toshiba spokesman said his company would prefer to continue production in America because "our policy is manufacturing as close to our customers as possible."
But that also goes for customers other than Americans. Japan is trying to establish a much stronger presence in Europe before economic unification gets into full swing there at the end of 1992.
There is another reason Japanese industries are diversifying their direct investment globally: the rising cost of capital in Japan, with Japanese costs approaching the levels in other countries.
Capital costs are likely to continue to rise, especially after the beginning of the new century, for demographic reasons: Japan has the fastest-aging population mix of any industrial country. At a recent conference of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Kumiharu Shigehara, director of the Bank of Japan's Institute for Monetary and Economic Studies, said the demographic changes "will reduce Japan's savings substantially from around the start of the next century."
One policy implication of this trend, he said, is that Japan should aim at a high savings rate mainly through an increase in consumption taxes, and should devote most of the extra savings to domestic investment in infrastructure and housing. "But a portion of such savings," he added, "might better be channeled to developing countries in the forms of direct investment and lending to them directly or through multilateral institutions."
Japan's diversification strategy has been in motion since the mid-1980's. The Conference Board study shows that in the first half of the 1980's Japan's exports to the United States rose from 24 percent of its total exports to almost 40 percent, while the share going to Southeast Asia and Europe declined. But in the second half of the 1980's, while the share of Japan's exports to the United States dropped to 31 percent, it rose to 22 percent from 14 percent for Western Europe and to 29 percent fom 19 percent for Southeast Asia. The growth rates are even more pronounced: From 1985 to 1990, as Japanese exports to the United States rose just 39 percent, the country's exports to Southeast Asia and Europe shot up by 150 percent.
Japanese direct investment shows similar global shifts, especially in Southeast Asia. Twenty years ago, of all foreign direct investment in that region, 12 percent came from Japan, 20 percent from Europe and a little more than half from the United States. By 1990, the United States' share had fallen to 20 percent, Europe's share to less than 5 percent, while Japanese direct investment in Southeast Asia surged to nearly 40 percent of the total.
These trends are likely to result in important shifts in regional economic relations and in the United States-Japan relationship. After World War II, Japan depended heavily on the United States both as a provider of security, sponsor of its acceptance in the international community and its most important economic partner by far. Today Japan is increasingly chafing under its bilateral dependency on the United States and is moving to a more diversified global strategy.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 28, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
The Economic Scene column yesterday referred incompletely to action by the Toshiba Corporation in response to a United States tariff on imports of advanced computer display screens. Toshiba plans to move production of only one Toshiba computer model out of the United States; it is not moving all of its manufacturing operations.

HEADLINE: Incomes Rise 0.4%, but Spending Is Weak

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Incomes grew four-tenths of 1 percent in August, but consumers increased their spending by only one-tenth of 1 percent, the Government said today in a report showing that consumers are not providing their usual lift to the economic recovery.
During past downturns, consumers used their economic muscle to bring the economy out of recession. Their spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. 
 "Obviously, consumers are not leading the way out of the recession," said Lawrence A. Hunter, an economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis, said: "It's going to be a while before we see consumer spending perk up. The fundamentals are not there: jobs, income growth and rising confidence."
The Commerce Department reported that incomes totaled $4.82 trillion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate in August, up from $4.80 trillion a month earlier. It was the sixth straight advance; an initial decline of one-tenth of 1 percent reported for July was revised in today's report to a gain of two-tenths.
Disposable income -- income after taxes -- rose five-tenths of 1 percent in July, after remaining unchanged a month earlier.
Personal consumption, on the other hand, was at a $3.840 trillion annual rate, up from $3.837 trillion in July, but the smallest increase since spending fell five-tenths of 1 percent in April.
The spending and income figures were not adjusted for inflation, leading Mr. Hunter to suggest the increase in consumer spending in August was "an illusion."
"When adjusted for inflation," he said, "spending actually was down two-tenths of a percent." He added that "there is reason to believe that consumer spending may not grow at all in the next several months."
Disposable incomes, when adjusted for inflation, were up two-tenths of 1 percent, but Gordon Richards, an economist at the National Association of Manufacturers, said that even if that gain was sustained for the next 12 months, it would translate into only a 2.4 percent increase.
That, he said, is "scarcely enough to accelerate the economy."
A key component of the income category -- wages and salaries -- rose $13.7 billion, wiping out an $8.8 billion loss the previous month. The improvement had been anticipated after earlier reports of increases in both wages and the length of the workweek.
But Mr. Sohn said: "I don't think that's going to be repeated in the near future. Employment is really going nowhere. The number of hours worked is going to slow down. Wages are not going up that rapidly."
The difference between incomes and spending meant Americans' savings rate -- savings as a percentage of disposable incomes -- edged up to 3.9 percent, from 3.6 percent in July.

HEADLINE: Weak Economy Takes Toll on Its Experts

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25

 BODY:
The recession, which they failed to predict and now declare over, is weighing heavily on the nation's economists.
The weak economy, combined with a wave of mergers in the banking industry and a mixed forecasting record, has dimmed employment prospects for the people who earn their living analyzing it. And, except for the academic branch, economists are sharing the worries of other Americans, from the assembly line to the executive suite, about whether they will be victims of downsizing. They recall the corporate casualties of the mid-1980's, when in some cases entire departments were eliminated. 
 "Business economists are plagued with a new round of anxiety about the standing of our profession and, to be frank about it, new concerns about job security," Richard D. Rippe, president of the National Association of Business Economists and a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, told the annual meeting here.
Unlike many conventions, the association's gathering saw only a minor amount of overt job-searching among the 400 members who attended, 100 fewer than at last year's meeting in always-popular Washington.
Here, they padded about the lush Biltmore Hotel on Pershing Square, birthplace of the Oscar and site of numerous movies and television series, but the talk in the corridors was of casualties at such employers as the First National Bank of Chicago, General Motors and First Interstate Bancorp. The economists also did a lot of talking about how to make themselves more clearly relevant to their employers' bottom lines.
"It's a bad time to look," lamented Richard Nelson, a former professor who is about to leave his post as chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco. "There are clearly fewer jobs for economists than there used to be."
One member sent a $475 company check in July to register for the convention, but he had to change his plans when his department was wiped out in a cutback.
Only 22 job openingsappear in the association's latest quarterly posting, fewer than half the number at the 1989 peak. About half of the recent listings had an international element. Only a few mentioned compensation; except for one six-figure salary, the average was below $50,000.
Of those seeking jobs, David Williams Jr., an association staff aide, said, "I'd say 75 percent are on the street; the other 25 percent know they're going to be on the street sooner or later."
Bank economists, in particular, are honing their skills to address specific practical topics, like a particular industry or geographic area. In many cases they have become tactical advisers to their organization's securities traders. The idea is to demonstrate to management that they can contribute directly to profits.
 
Offering Advice
 James Annable, a senior vice president of the First National Bank of Chicago, said that during the 1980's his department was among the first to argue that Rust Belt industry would revive, not disappear, and that the bank should dispose of bad loans made to less developed countries.
"We're the people who recommended dumping our L.D.C. debt early, saving us hundreds of millions of dollars," Mr. Annable said. Even so, he lost two of his staff last week, part of a bank-wide reduction of 1,000 positions resulting from market pressure to become more efficient.
Jerry L. Jordan, senior vice president and chief economist at First Interstate, which has had heavy losses in real estate, said he now gives most of his attention to certain industries and to international issues, spending only 10 percent of his time on the traditional macroeconomic, or big-picture, analysis.
"What we had to learn to do is spend more time framing the questions people ask us and stop dreaming up our own questions," Mr. Jordan said, adding that he now advised young economists to learn finance, accounting and computers.
 
Revising Their View

Others see themselves as internal consultants with a single client, top management. They seek to "add value," as economists put it, by helping strategic planners or by analyzing the effect of possible economic shocks.
To be sure, some of the problems of the fraternity, including what Mr. Rippe called doubts about the economists' standing in the eyes of superiors and a loss of self-esteem, arose from flawed analyses that were offered. In some cases, particularly those involving elaborate computer simulations of the economy, members promised far too much.
Mr. Rippe found that while the association's panel of forecasters had done an adequate job during the 1980's predicting gross national product and inflation, the record was poor regarding interest rates, on which far more money rides.
He cited one study of 19 periods in which the economists got the direction of Treasury bond rates wrong 14 times and the direction of bill rates wrong 11 times. Predictions of corporate earnings were similarly deficient.
 
Picking Convention Sites
 A certain degree of humility about the limits of forecasting has also crept into the association's planning for future conventions. This gathering, which involved a long trip for most members at a time of financial pinch, was planned 10 years ago. Now the sites are picked only three years ahead, with Dallas and Chicago scheduled to be followed by Philadelphia, in 1994.
But painful as the squeeze has been for many, economists do not seem inclined to view their situation as terminal. This reflects not only a conviction that they still have a role to play -- in many cases as part of a line operation -- but also a respect for the laws of economics and the intricate way the market system, in which they are all believers, allocates society's resources.
"There's no sympathy," commented Stuart G. Hoffman, the chief economist for the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh. "It's the market working -- for you or agin you."

HEADLINE: Bond Rates Drop as Fed Move Is Seen

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates fell to their lowest level since March 1987 yesterday on speculation that the Federal Reserve Board and the Bush Administration were formulating a plan to jump-start a very sluggish economy.
Based on the day's developments, credit market analysts and traders seem to see a plan that includes lower interest rates, a cut in military spending and a cut in taxes. 
 The speculation, which began on Thursday, was prompted by a meeting Mr. Bush held at the White House yesterday with key economic advisers. The meeting came only days before the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet and at a time when the recovery that has been widely heralded by Administration officials appears to be losing steam.
Prices of Treasury securities were moving higher before the meeting was convened yesterday, and the rally gathered strength as the session progressed.
Early news reports on the meeting suggested strongly to traders that the Bush Administration expects the Fed to provide more stimulus to the economy through an easier monetary policy.
"Bush clearly expects the Fed to do more to help the economy," said James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management, a money management firm in New York. "With the Fed's Open Market Committee meeting on Tuesday, the market is of a mind to think that the Fed is going to ease."
Those thoughts were given additional credence after a Market News Service report on the meeting moved across trading screens. Mr. Bush, the story said, made it clear to Mr. Greenspan that he expected greater efforts to stimulate growth.
A sense in the market that some sort of fiscal stimulus might accompany an easier monetary policy appeared after it was announced that Mr. Bush would be making a televised address on military policy at 8 o'clock last night.
"If the rally we saw were solely on the thought that the Fed is going to ease, bonds wouldn't have moved so much," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and fixed income markets.
"Thoughts of cuts in defense spending could well have been another reason why bond yields fell. The Fed should be delighted that this is not just a rally in short-term rates."
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 103 17/32, up 23/32, to yield 7.81 percent, compared with 7.87 percent late Thursday.
According to analysts at Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc., it is the lowest rate on the benchmark issue since March 31, 1987, when yields on the bond also stood at 7.81 percent. Four years ago, however, bond yields were in the process of moving higher.
In the secondary Treasury note market, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 23/32 late yesterday, up 13/32, to yield 7.47 percent.
And prices of the new two-year and five-year notes auctioned earlier this week also improved.
The 7 percent five-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 6.94 percent. And the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.00 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to down slightly.
Late in the day three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.12 percent, unchanged from late Thursday. But six-month bill rates fell by three basis points, or three one-hundreths of a percentage point, to a late offered rate of 5.14 percent.
Issuance of new investment-grade corporate debt continued yesterday, although at a less hectic pace than earlier in the week.
Among the new issues priced yesterday was a $200 million offering of three-year notes by the Commercial Credit Corporation.
The 6.95 percent notes, which mature Oct. 1, 1994, were priced at $99.932, to yield 6.975 percent, 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Revamping At Control Data

 BODY:
The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it would create "separate legal entities" for its three primary businesses: information services, government systems and computer products.
The announcement lifted Control Data stock, which closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $9.875, up $1.25. About 1.6 million shares were traded. 
 No timetable was given for the restructuring. Lawrence Perlman, president of the Minneapolis-based company, which had 1991 revenue of $2.9 billion, said Control Data had been put on a sound financial footing in the last two years. He added. "The company must be reshaped to enable each business to gain access to capital and to increase its flexibility in forging strategic relationships that can broaden customer and technology bases."
Control Data earned $3 million, on revenue of $1.69 billion, in 1990. Revenue in the second quarter of this year fell 8.5 percent, to $371.3 million, and earnings fell 47 percent, to $5.9 million. The company said the decline stemmed from the weak economy and lower demand for computer products.
Rick J. Martin, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Research, said the announcement was probably intended to send a message to Wall Street that Control Data was more than a mainframe computer maker.
Its computer operation generates 40 to 45 percent of revenue, Mr. Martin said, but only 25 percent of its profits. Military systems generate roughly 20 percent of revenue, but only 5 percent of profits. Information services account for 35 to 40 percent of revenue but 65 to 70 percent of profits.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
A Longer Life, And Saving for It

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
Americans are on a collision course with economic reality, living longer, retiring earlier and saving less than they did a generation ago. At the same time corporations are shifting their focus away from traditional employer-paid plans that provide defined benefits to defined contribution plans, like 401(k) plans, that require employees to defer a portion of their compensation for retirement and often to decide how to invest that money.
"The days of paternalism are over," said Joel S. Isaacson, director of financial planning at Clarfeld & Company in New York. "The burden of meeting any retirement objective falls on the employee." 
 But the great majority of Americans have failed to realize this. Merrill Lynch & Company, in a recent survey of people aged 45 to 64, found that 80 percent felt they would be well prepared for retirement, and that 59 percent expected to rely primarily on Social Security or employer-provided pension benefits.
According to the Treasury Department, however, among people older than 65 with annual incomes greater than $20,000, Social Security now provides only 20 percent of their income and pensions only 15 percent, while personal savings and investment provide 39 percent. Some continue working because they cannot afford to retire.
Commenting on the gap between expectations and reality, John L. Steffans, executive vice president, Merrill Lynch private client group, said, "Beginning early in the next century, America may face widespread indigence, or poverty, among the elderly, on a scale previously unseen in the United States," unless personal savings are dramatically increased from the present annual rate of 3.7 percent.
Avery E. Neumark, partner in charge of pension and benefits planning for Weber, Lipshie & Company in New York, said he advised clients to put away 10 percent for retirement savings on a personal basis, regardless of any employer-provided benefits, beginning with a tax-deferred 401(k) plan if one is available.
"Expect the unexpected -- sickness, disability, problems with a pension plan," he said. "The employee has to do it himself, and it requires a lot of self-discipline."
Merrill Lynch calculated different annual savings needs for different age groups to provide a retirement income of 60 percent of present level income. Based on average household income of $40,000 in 1990, 7 percent interest on savings, 4 percent annual salary growth and life expectancy of 78 years, the firm said the following amounts would be needed: age 35, $1,542; age 40, $2,089; age 45, $2,942; age 50, $4,108, and age 55, $6,387.
But those figures may be conservative. Inflation could exceed 4 percent, needs could be greater than 60 percent, and many people live beyond 78. Indeed, Mr. Steffans noted that "women who reach age 65 this year will live to an average age of 89, men to age 83." In the 1950's, people typically lived only a few years beyond their retirement age of 65. "The more you build up, the better you sleep at night," Mr. Isaacson said, adding: "You have to give very strong thoughts to investing the money. You shouldn't be passive and leave it in money-market or fixed-income funds." He recommended stock funds for long-term growth.
David M. Blitzer, chief economist for the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which is publishing a new newsletter called Your Financial Future for companies to send to employees with their quarterly 401(k) statements, said many people "are conservative to a fault." Because their "dominant concern is safety," they have placed the bulk of their 401(k) money in guaranteed investment contracts. But some people are growing concerned about the safety of some of these investments, which are guaranteed by insurance companies. In any event, Mr. Blitzer noted, historic studies have shown that over time equities have provided a far greater return.
"For the generation now retiring, housing provided a huge portion of retirement savings," he said. People who bought a house in the 1950's could sell it, buy a smaller house or apartment and have a tidy nest egg to live on. But real estate is no longer appreciating as it did, he noted.
Richard Pallan, senior managing director and chief of defined contribution plan services for the Putnam Companies in Boston, suggested money in 401(k), I.R.A. and other retirement accounts be divided into three groups: growth, or small-capitalization stocks; conservative growth, typified by the S.& P. 500 stock index, and conservative income, as characterized by bond funds.
He would allocate these amounts: for people in their mid-20's to mid-30's -- 60 percent growth, 30 percent conservative growth and 10 percent conservative income; in their late 30's to late 40's -- 50 percent, 40 percent and 10 percent; early 50's to early 60's -- 30 percent, 30 percent and 40 percent, and retired -- 15 percent, 25 percent and 60 percent.
The goal, he said, is to "maximize the end value of your investments so you have maximum flexibility" in retirement.

HEADLINE: BUSH WANTS A RISE IN BANKS' LENDING

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
At his second meeting in three days with his economic advisers, President Bush today asked banking regulators to review their procedures to make sure they were not inhibiting banks from making loans, White House officials said.
The President and his advisers are clearly concerned about the slow pace of the economy almost a year before the Presidential election. But because of the large budget deficit, expected to be well over $300 billion in the next fiscal year, they do not have the leeway to cut taxes or increase spending, the usual steps for an Administration facing a sour economy in an election year.
 
Pressing a Point
 That is one reason they are focusing on bank regulations, and today they called two of the nation's top bank regulators to an otherwise routine meeting of the President's Economic Policy Council. The regulators were Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and William Taylor, who has been nominated to be chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. 
 On Wall Street, long-term interest rates fell today to their lowest level in four and a half years because of speculation that the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve were working on a plan to stimulate the economy.
But officials who attended today's White House meeting said no bold new initiatives were under discussion. They also said that this was not an occasion to press Mr. Greenspan to lower interest rates further. The Federal Reserve has been lowering interest rates steadily since the middle of 1989.
Officials said Mr. Bush wanted to hear from the regulators and to encourage them to weed out unnecessarily stringent practices that might be preventing banks from lending to qualified borrowers. Fewer bank loans mean slower growth in the money supply and thus a weaker economy.
"People are still having trouble getting money, especially small businesses," Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, told reporters. "We want to make sure that examiners are aware of this problem and that steps are being taken by the banking industry to see that indeed they are not being overly restrictive on their loans."
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said in an interview after the meeting that he had argued forcefully that the economy was being dragged down by what he called a "credit crunch."
"We want to make sure we're doing everything we can to be helpful," Mr. Mosbacher said. "It's not a minor problem. It's very serious. Small businesses can't get loans.
 
Offering an Example
 Mr. Mosbacher told the group of a Rhode Island consulting firm, Aquidneck Management Associates Ltd., that was being forced out of business by credit restrictions set by the F.D.I.C.
Mr. Greenspan and other economists in and out of the Government say that unreasonably strict behavior by bank examiners may be one reason that lending is so restrained, but that it is not the main reason.
More important factors, they say, are that the demand for loans is still down because businesses are not expanding, that banks with many bad loans on their books are gun-shy about new lending and that many banks are working to improve their ratio of capital to liabilities.
Late last month, the Fed reported that its quarterly survey of financial officers at large banks showed that they expected their lending to rise only modestly if at all for the rest of the year.
In the spring, when the Administration was jawboning about tight credit, officials urged bank regulators to use new accounting procedures that would let banks write off portions of bad loans and not the entire loan. But opposition from the General Accounting Office and the Securities and Exchange Commission kept the new procedures from being put in place.
 
A Nominee to the Fed
 The President also today formally nominated Susan M. Phillips, a former chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and now an administrator at the University of Iowa, to a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board.
The President's intention to pick Ms. Phillips was an open secret and was widely reported last spring. She would replace Martha R. Seger, who resigned in March. Ms. Phillips's views on monetary policy are not pulbicly known.
Another Bush nominee for the board, Lawrence B. Lindsey, a White House economist and former professor at Harvard, is encountering difficulty in winning Senate confirmation.
Senator Terry Sanford, a North Carolina Democrat, is leading the opposition. The Senator contends in public that Mr. Lindsey is not really from the Richmond district that he was nominated to represent, but the more likely reason for the opposition is Mr. Lindsey's conservative views.
 
Optimism From Greenspan
 The consensus of the officials at the Economic Policy Council meetings Wednesday and today is that the economy bottomed out in the late spring or early summer and will grow at an annual rate of 2.5 percent to 3 percent in the last half of the year.
Mr. Greenspan is said to have told the group that he was encouraged about economic prospects for the rest of the year because inventories were low and consumption was now greater than production. That means production should increase in the months ahead and give stimulus to the economy.
"But everyone is concerned about the strength and durability of the recovery, and everybody thinks it should be doing better," one senior official said.
The Economic Policy Council is headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Other members include Commerce Secretary Mosbacher; Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

The Economy
President Bush asked banking regulators to make sure they were not inhibiting banks from lending. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and William Taylor, who has been nominated to head the F.D.I.C., met with the President and his economic advisers, who are clearly concerned about the economy's slow pace barely a year before the Presidential election. [Page 1.] 
 Incomes grew four-tenths of 1 percent in August, but consumers increased their spending by only one-tenth of 1 percent. [36.]
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady proposed giving the Administration greater control over the quasi-independent agency that manages the rescue of the savings and loan bailout. He conceded that fundamental changes are needed before Congress will vote more money to pay for the highly unpopular effort. [35.]
The nation's economists are deeply troubled by the recession, which they failed to predict and now declare is over. The weak economy, combined with a wave of mergers in the banking industry and a mixed forecasting record, has dimmed employment prospects for people who earn their living analyzing it. [35.]
Companies eager to keep organized labor out of their work sites are increasingly cutting short organizing drives by dismissing campaign leaders, and even entire staffs, labor experts say. [21.]
 
 Markets
Long-term interest rates fell to their lowest level since March 1987 on speculation that the Fed and the Bush Administration were planning to jump-start a very sluggish economy by lowering interest rates and cutting military spending and taxes. [35.]
Stocks slipped for the day and for the week, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 11.18 points, to close at 3,006.04, in a day with eight program trades. For the week it was down 13.19. [38.]
The dollar fell, reflecting continued pessimism about falling interest rates following the meeting between President Bush and Mr. Greenspan. Gold prices also closed lower. [43.] Coffee prices plunged on forecasts for more rain in the previously dry growing regions of Brazil and on growers' failure to reduce the glut. [43.]
 
 Companies
First American Bank officers and directors told hostile lawmakers that they were unaware until earlier this year that B.C.C.I. owned the institution. [35.]
Citicorp Mortgage is being reorganized to cut costs and tie its operations more closely to the branch networks of Citibank. It is one of the nation's largest home-mortgage lenders. [37.]
Community Psychiatric Centers saw its earnings shrink to 1 cent a share, surprising analysts, who had expected 40 cents. The company's stock plunged 27 percent to $17.25, making it the largest percentage loser on the New York Stock Exchange. [37.]
G.M. killed 20,000 animals in automobile safety tests in the last decade, The Detroit News reported. A group called People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals urged a boycott of G.M. [26.]
A shopping mall anchored by Macy's and Nordstrom's was opened in Menlo Park, N.J. The 1.3-million-square-foot mall was the third mega-mall within a few square miles. [21.]
A jury awarded a Texaco employee $6 million in damages. She said she was rejected for management jobs because of sex discrimination. The award is subject to judicial review. [25.]
