Americans are living longer, retiring earlier and saving less than they did a generation ago, and employers are providing less in the way of traditional pensions. Financial experts warn that indigence lies ahead unless people save more. Your Money. [36.]
The elements for a robotic ant were patented by a professor of electrical engineering at Boston University. The six-legged machine is small enough to handle individual cells under a microscope or, possibly, to serve as a miniature spy. Patents. [36.]

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARMS PLAN;
Arms Plan Hailed in Congress But Some Call for More Cuts

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Senators and arms control experts mostly praised President Bush's proposals this evening for eliminating short-range nuclear weapons, calling bombers off alert and asking for new talks with the Soviet Union on long-range weapons.
But leading Democrats faulted the President for not placing enough emphasis on the nation's economic troubles, while disarmament advocates said the plan did not go far enough. 
 Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is the Minority Leader, said that the plan seized the initiative and showed that the United States was providing "strong, sensible leadership for the world."
 
'The Nuclear Abyss'
 Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, the Majority Leader, welcomed the move as a way to reduce stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction, shrink the risk of conflict and move the nation, "away from the nuclear abyss."
But in an official Democratic response, following the President's nationally televised address, Mr. Mitchell also struck a partisan note. "We're pleased that the President has accepted the view we've been urging for years," he said, reiterating the Democratic call for more attention to economic growth in the United States.
"To maintain our status as the world's superpower, to retain our military strength, to compete in the international economy, to provide a better life for all Americans, those now living and those yet to come -- if we're to do all these things, we must have a strong and growing economy," he said.
Senator Joseph R. Biden, the Delaware Democrat, welcomed the President's initiative to remove tactical nuclear weapons from Europe and from ships at sea but asserted that it does not go nearly far enough.
 
The Obvious and the Dubious
 "What disappoints me is that he continues to support strategic weapons like the B-2 and Star Wars for which there is no compelling case," Mr. Biden said, refering to a new strategic bomber and defenses against ballistic missile attacks on the United States.
"Nor did he propose a plan for the radical cuts in strategic arms that are now warranted and for which Gorbachev and Yeltsin have called," Mr. Biden said. "In short, he conceded the obvious but defended the dubious."
Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, said, "The President has responded to the need for real innovations in the new international landscape forever altered and changing still because of the coup in the former Soviet Union."
Jack Mendelsohn, the deputy director of the Arms Control Association, a Washington-based research group, said that the proposal to eliminate multiple warheads only for land-based missiles is heavily weighted in favor of the United States. The United States has a much higher proportion of its multiple-warhead missiles aboard submarines than the Soviet Union.
Mr. Mendelsohn predicted that this offer would be quickly dismissed by the Soviet authorities.

PUB-DATE: September 28, 1991

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2744 words

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARMS PLAN;
Remarks by President Bush on Reducing U.S. and Soviet Nuclear Weapons

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Following is the text of remarks by the President in an address to the nation tonight, as recorded by The New York Times:
Good evening. Tonight I'd like to speak with you about our future, and the future of the generations to come. 
 The world has changed at a fantastic pace with each day writing a fresh page of history before yesterday's ink has even dried. And most recently, we've seen the peoples of the Soviet Union turn to democracy and freedom, and discard a system of government based on oppression and fear.
Like the East Europeans before them, they face the daunting challenge of building fresh political structures, based on human rights, democratic principles, and market economies. Their task is far from easy, and far from over. They will need our help. And they will get it.
But these dramatic changes challenge our Nation as well. Our country has always stood for freedom and democracy. And when the newly elected leaders of Eastern Europe grappled with forming their new governments, they looked to the United States. They looked to American democratic principles in building their own free societies. Even the leaders of the U.S.S.R. republics are reading The Federalist Papers, written by America's founders, to find new ideas and inspiration.
Today, America must lead again -- as it always has, as only it can. And we will. We must also provide the inspiration for lasting peace. And we will do that, too. We can now take steps in response to these dramatic developments -- steps that can help the Soviet peoples in their quest for peace and prosperity. More importantly, we can now take steps to make the world a less dangerous place than ever before in the nuclear age.
A year ago, I described a new strategy for American defenses, reflecting the world's changing security environment. That strategy shifted our focus away from the fear that preoccupied us for 40 years -- the prospect of a global confrontation. Instead, it concentrated more on regional conflicts, such as the one we just faced in the Persian Gulf.
 
A Smaller Military
 I spelled out a strategic concept, guided by the need to maintain the forces required to exercise forward presence in key areas, to respond effectively in crises, to maintain a credible nuclear deterrent, and to retain the national capacity to rebuild our forces, should that be needed.
We are now moving to reshape the U.S. military to reflect that concept. The new Base Force will be smaller by half a million than today's military -- with fewer Army divisions, Air Force wings, Navy ships, and strategic nuclear forces. This new force will be versatile, able to respond around the world to challenges -- old and new.
As I just mentioned, the changes that allowed us to adjust our security strategy a year ago have greatly accelerated. The prospect of a Soviet invasion into Western Europe, launched with little or no warning, is no longer a realistic threat. The Warsaw Pact has crumbled. In the Soviet Union, the advocates of democracy triumphed over a coup that would have restored the old system of repression. The reformers are now starting to fashion their own futures, moving even faster toward democracy's horizon.
New leaders in the Kremlin and the republics are now questioning the need for their huge nuclear arsenal. The Soviet nuclear stockpile now seems less an instrument of national security, and more of a burden. As a result, we now have an unparalleled opportunity to change the nuclear posture of both the United States and the Soviet Union.
If we and the Soviet leaders take the right steps -- some on our own, some on their own, some together -- we can dramatically shrink the arsenal of the world's nuclear weapons. We can more effectively discourage the spread of nuclear weapons. We can rely more on defensive measures in our strategic relationship. We can enhance stability, and actually reduce the risk of nuclear war. Now is the time to seize this opportunity.
After careful study and consultations with my senior advisors, and after considering valuable counsel from Prime Minister Major, President Mitterrand, Chancellor Kohl and other allied leaders, I am announcing today a series of sweeping initiatives affecting every aspect of our nuclear forces -- on land, on ships, and on aircraft. I met again today with our Joint Chiefs of Staff, and I can tell you they wholeheartedly endorse each of these steps.
I'll begin with the category in which we will make the most fundamental change in nuclear forces in over 40 years -- non-strategic or theater weapons.
Last year, I canceled U.S. plans to modernize our ground-launched theater nuclear weapons. Later, our NATO allies joined us in announcing that the alliance would propose the mutual elimination of all nuclear artillery shells from Europe, as soon as short-range nuclear force negotiations began with the Soviets. But starting these talks now would only perpetuate these systems, while we engage in lengthy negotiations. Last month's events not only permit, but indeed demand swifter, bolder action.
I'm therefore directing that the United States eliminate its entire worldwide inventory of ground-launched short-range, that is, theater nuclear weapons. We will bring home and destroy all of our nuclear artillery shells and short-range ballistic missile warheads. We will, of course, insure that we preserve an effective air-delivered nuclear capability in Europe. That's essential to NATO's security.
In turn, I have asked the Soviets to go down this road with us -- to destroy their entire inventory of ground-launched theater nuclear weapons: not only their nuclear artillery, and nuclear warheads for short-range ballistic missiles, but also the theater systems the U.S. no longer has -- systems like nuclear warheads for air-defense missiles, and nuclear land mines.
 
Recall for Tactical Nuclear Arms
 Recognizing further the major changes in the international military landscape, the United States will withdraw all tactical nuclear weapons from its surface ships and attack submarines, as well as those nuclear weapons associated with our land-based naval aircraft. This means removing all nuclear Tomahawk cruise missiles from U.S. ships and submarines, as well as nuclear bombs aboard aircraft carriers. The bottom line is that under normal circumstances, our ships will not carry tactical nuclear weapons.
Many of these land and sea-based warheads will be dismantled and destroyed. Those remaining will be secured in central areas where they would be available if necessary in a future crisis.
Again, there is every reason for the Soviet Union to match our actions -- by removing all tactical nuclear weapons from its ships and attack submarines; by withdrawing nuclear weapons for land-based naval aircraft, and by destroying many of them and consolidating what remains at central locations. I urge them to do so.
 
Treaty as a Springboard
 No category of nuclear weapons has received more attention than those in our strategic arsenals. The Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (Start), which President Gorbachev and I signed last July, was the culmination of almost a decade's work. It calls for substantial stabilizing reductions and effective verification. Prompt ratification by both parties is essential.
But I also believe the time is right to use Start as a springboard to achieve additional stabilizing changes.
First, to further reduce tensions, I am directing that all United States strategic bombers immediately stand down from their alert posture. As a comparable gesture, I call upon the Soviet Union to confine its mobile missiles to their garrisons, where they will be safer and more secure.
Second, the U.S. will immediately stand down from alert all intercontinental ballistic missiles scheduled for deactivation under START. Rather than waiting for the treaty's reduction plan to run its full seven year course, we will accelerate elimination of these systems, once START is ratified. And I call upon the Soviet Union to do the same.
Third, I am terminating the development of the mobile Peacekeeper I.C.B.M. as well as the mobile portions of the small I.C.B.M. program. The small single-warhead I.C.B.M. will be our only remaining I.C.B.M. modernization program. And I call upon the Soviets to terminate any and all programs for future I.C.B.M.s with more than one warhead, and to limit I.C.B.M. modernization to one type of single warhead missile, just as we have done.
And fourth, I am canceling the current program to build a replacement for the nuclear short-range attack missile for our strategic bombers.
And fifth, as a result of the strategic nuclear weapons adjustments that I've just outlined, the United States will streamline its command and control procedures, allowing us to more effectively manage our strategic nuclear forces.
 
More Direct Command Structure
 As the system works now, the Navy commands the submarine part of our strategic deterrent, while the Air Force commands the bomber and land-based elements. But as we reduce our strategic forces, the operational command structure must be as direct as possible. And I have therefore approved the recommendation of Secretary Cheney and the Joint Chiefs to consolidate operational command of these forces into a U.S. Strategic Command, under one commander, with participation from both services.
Since the 1970's, the most vulnerable and unstable part of the U.S. and Soviet nuclear forces has been intercontinental missiles with more than one warhead. Both sides have these I.C.B.M.s in fixed silos in the ground where they are more vulnerable than missiles on submarines.
I propose that the U.S. and the Soviet Union seek early agreement to eliminate from their inventories all I.C.B.M.'s with multiple warheads. After developing a timetable acceptable to both sides, we could rapidly move to modify or eliminate these systems under procedures already established in the Start agreement. In short, such an action would take away the single most unstable part of our nuclear arsenals.
But there is more to do. The United States and the Soviet Union are not the only nations with ballistic missiles. Some 15 nations have them now, and in less than a decade, that number could grow to 20. The recent conflict in the Persian Gulf demonstrates in no uncertain terms that the time has come for strong action on this growing threat to world peace.
Accordingly, I am calling on the Soviet leadership to join us in taking immediate concrete steps to permit the limited deployment of non-nuclear defenses to protect against limited ballistic missile strikes -- whatever their source -- without undermining the credibility of existing deterrent forces. And we will intensify our effort to curb nuclear and missile proliferation. These two efforts will be mutually reinforcing. To foster cooperation, the United States soon will propose additional initiatives in the area of ballistic missile early warning.
 
Talks With Russians Sought
 And finally, let me discuss yet another opportunity for cooperation that can make our world safer.
During last month's attempted coup in Moscow, many Americans asked me if I thought Soviet nuclear weapons were under adequate control. I do not believe that America was at increased risk of nuclear attack during those tense days. But I do believe more can be done to insure the safe handling and dismantling of Soviet nuclear weapons. And therefore, I propose that we begin discussions with the Soviet Union to explore cooperation in three areas.
First, we should explore joint technical cooperation on the safe and environmentally responsible storage, transportation, dismantling, and destruction of nuclear warheads. Second, we should discuss existing arrangements for the physical security and safety of nuclear weapons and how these might be enhanced. And third, we should discuss nuclear command and control arrangements, and how these might be improved to provide more protection against the unauthorized or accidental use of nuclear weapons.
My friend, French President Mitterrand, offered a similar idea a short while ago. After further consultations with the alliance, and when the leadership in the U.S.S.R. is ready, we will begin this effort.
The initiatives that I'm announcing build on the new defense strategy that I set out a year ago -- one that shifted our focus away from the prospect of global confrontation. We're consulting with our allies on the implementation of many of these steps which fit well with the new post cold war strategy and force posture that we've developed in NATO.
As we implement these initiatives we will closely watch how the new Soviet leadership responds. We expect our bold initiatives to meet with equally bold steps on the Soviet side. If this happens, further cooperation is inevitable. If it does not, then an historic opportunity will have been lost. Regardless, let no one doubt we will still retain the necessary strength to protect our security and that of our allies, and to respond as necessary.
 
Honoring Commitments
 In addition, regional instabilities, the spread of weapons of mass destruction, and as we saw during the conflict in the Gulf, territorial ambitions of power-hungry tyrants, still require us to maintain a strong military to protect our national interests, and to honor commitments to our allies.
And therefore, we must implement a coherent plan for a significantly smaller but fully capable military, one that enhances stability but is still sufficient to convince any potential adversary that the cost of aggression would exceed any possible gain.
We can safely afford to take the steps I've announced today, steps that are designed to reduce the dangers of miscalculation in a crisis. But to do so, we must also pursue vigorously those elements of our strategic modernization program that serve the same purpose. We must fully fund the B-2 and S.D.I. program. We can make radical changes in the nuclear postures of both sides to make them smaller, safer and more stable. But the United States must maintain modern nuclear forces including the strategic triad and thus insure the credibility of our deterrent.
Some will say that these initiatives call for a budget windfall for domestic programs. But the peace dividend I seek is not measured in dollars but in greater security. In the near term, some of these steps may even cost money. Given the ambitious plan I have already proposed to reduce U.S. defense spending by 25 percent, we cannot afford to make any unwise or unwarranted cuts in the defense budget that I have submitted to Congress. I'm counting on congressional support to ensure we have the funds necessary to restructure our forces prudently and implement the decisions that I've outlined tonight.
Twenty years ago when -- when I had the opportunity to serve this country as Ambassador to the United Nations, I once talked about the vision that was in the minds of the U.N.'s founders -- how they dreamed of a new age when the great powers of the world would cooperate in peace as they had as allies in war.
 
Positive Soviet Response Seen
 Today I consulted with President Gorbachev. And while he hasn't had time to absorb the details, I believe the Soviet response will clearly be positive. I also spoke with President Yeltsin and he had a similar reaction -- positive -- hopeful.
And now, the Soviet people and their leaders can shed the heavy burden of a dangerous and costly nuclear arsenal which has threatened world peace for the past five decades. They can join us in these dramatic moves toward a new world of peace and security.
Tonight, as I see the drama of democracy unfolding around the globe, perhaps -- perhaps we are closer to that new world than ever before. The future is ours to influence, to shape, to mold. And while we must not gamble that future, neither can we forfeit the historic opportunity now before us.
It has been said, "Destiny is -- is not a matter of chance, it is a matter of choice; it is not a thing to be waited for, it's a thing to be achieved." The United States has always stood where duty required us to stand. And now let them say, that we led where destiny required us to lead -- to a more peaceful, hopeful future. We cannot give a more precious gift to the children of the world.
Thank you, good night, and God bless the United States of America.

HEADLINE: Soviets Voice Doubt Mideast Talks Will Get Under Way on Schedule

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 27

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that there were "some doubts" that a proposed peace conference between Israel and its Arab neighbors would be convened before the end of October, the goal set by American and Soviet officials when they announced plans for the talks in July.
Mr. Gorbachev, who spoke at a news conference following talks here today with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, did not say what had raised the doubts. But he said he remained hopeful that the peace talks would start next month as planned. 
 "We and the U.S. as co-chairmen are acting on the basis of the time-frame agreed," he said. "I think this process is so essential, and we have come so close to it, that all sides understand their responsiblity and are taking steps."
 
Palestinians Meeting in Algiers
 Egypt, Syria, Jordan and Lebanon have all agreed to come to the proposed peace conference. Israel has conditioned its attendance on a demand that the proposed Jordanian-Palestinian delegation not include Palestinians from East Jerusalem, stateless Palestinians or members of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
For their part, the top Palestinian leadership is now gathered in Algiers to decide whether or under what circumstances to send a delegation to the talks.
During his one-day visit to Moscow, Mr. Mubarak met for 90 minutes inside the Kremlin with Mr. Gorbachev and had a 15-minute telephone conversation with Boris N. Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic. Mr. Yeltsin is on vacation at a Black Sea resort.
President Mubarak told Mr. Gorbachev that he was counting on Moscow to play a strong role at the proposed peace conference, Egyptian officials said later.
Mr. Mubarak also expressed support for Mr. Gorbachev and his policy of democratic and economic change.
 
Egypt Backing Gorbachev
 Egypt, the Arab world's most populous nation and a close ally of the United States, has become one of Mr. Gorbachev's firmest supporters in the Middle East. Mr. Mubarak has asked the wealthy Persian Gulf Arab states to consider economic and political support for the Soviet Government.
Egyptian officials say the Soviet Union provides an important symbolic and practical balance to Washington, which is closely tied to Israeli policy. Among other things, Moscow has consistently spoken out on behalf of the Palestinians.
Moscow has sharply cut back its support of Arab governments, including Syria and Libya, which for years depended on them for arms and aid. At the same time, Moscow has moved closer to Israel, agreeing to establish full diplomatic relations.

HEADLINE: Here in the Suburbs, Malls (Like Hope) Spring Eternal

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MENLO PARK, N.J., Sept. 27

 BODY:
Here in suburbia, where malls are Broadway, Main Street and the town common all rolled into one, the opening of a 1.3-million-square-foot shop-'till-you-drop paradise today was a major municipal event.
Never mind that the Menlo Park Mall is the third mega-mall within a few square miles or that there is a recession going on. The 30-minute ceremony this morning had all the pomp and circumstance once reserved for mayoral portrait unveilings and city hall cornerstone layings and other community events that people tell their grandchildren about. There were perky singers up on a stage, front row seats filled with V.I.P.'s in pin-stripe suits and speeches by elected officials, including Gov. Jim Florio. 
 He said he liked the mall because it was bringing 170 stores and 4,000 jobs into an area that already had two malls within half an hour's drive of each other. About 85 percent of the space has been rented -- a cause for a good deal of executive back-patting in a recession that has left other New Jersey shopping complexes struggling.
"Sure, the fact that we're in a recession is a concern," said Jeremiah W. O'Connor Sr., the chairman of the O'Connor Group, which runs the mall, "but we're not looking at whether it will turn in '91 or '92 because we'll be here in 2001 and 2002. Recessions come and go. These things you build for 20 to 30 years."
What put Menlo Park on the map the first time was the electric light bulb. Thomas A. Edison invented it in a laboratory here. What put Menlo Park and all of Edison Township on the map in the 1980's was a real-estate boom that turned communities like these from remote suburbs into a new kind of American downtown.
Some real-estate people talk about location, location, location. To mall owners like Mr. O'Connor, the make-or-break factor is anchors, anchors, anchors: the big stores that retailers count on to serve as magnets for customers. "We've got Macy's and Nordstrom's," Mr. O'Connor said. "We're down the road from Penney's, Steinbeck's, Fortunoff, Sterns, A.&S. They just don't have the same power in anchors."
Mr. O'Connor said that when he bought the mall in 1988: "We saw a property that had a 3.5 percent share of the market. We said it ought to be four times that. We we said to Nordstrom's, 'What do you think?' and here we are."
Whether its anchors can carry the mall in a depressed, saturated market is an open question. "The issues in a state that has no growth are, will Nordstrom's have pulling power, and whose teeth are they going to pull?" said George Sternlieb, a professor emeritus of urban studies at Rutgers University. "This is a zero-sum game."
And it is an increasingly competitive game. The International Council of Shopping Centers reported earlier in the year that 68 shopping centers with 5.2 million square feet of space were started in New Jersey in 1987 and 55 with 3.2 million square feet in 1990.
 
Greeters Like Beauty Queens
 Even so, a mall ribbon-cutting was a not-to-be-missed experience for the crowd that arrived an hour before the stores opened for the first time.
Alan Borack of Fords, N.J., took the day off to attend, "and I don't particularly like malls." Kathy Scutro of Garwood, N.J., said she was going in late.
There were even official greeters. They were the ones with the Menlo Park banners slung over their shoulders like beauty queens. Their job was to walk up to shopper after shopper and say, "Welcome. Have a good day today."
 
12 Movie Screens
 The opening day shoppers looked in on Wings 'n' Things and Linens 'n' Things. (One sells fast food, the other home furnishings.) They walked down columned corridors with The Gap, a Baby Gap and a Gap Kids. And 130,000 square feet was leased to stores run by The Limited: Lane Bryant, Lerner New York, Structure and Victoria's Secret, along with The Limited and The Limited Express.
The mall's owners destroyed the mall to save it. They tore down all the stores in a 30-year-old shopping complex except Macy's. The two-story structure they built has sculpture -- two totem-pole-like creations, an abstract work called "The Happy Shopper" and a bronze creation called "Puddle Jumpers." It has what John F. Phelan, an executive vice president in Mr. O'Connor's company, called the "water feature," a machine that makes water bubble like a brook right there in the middle of the mall.
Then there is the "entertainment component" the 1,000-seat food court and the 63,000 square foot movie-theater complex -- with 12 screens, the largest in New Jersey, Mr. O'Connor said.
The whole mall, Mr. O'Connor said, sets a new standard for architecture, increasingly important in luring customers from nearby malls like Bridgewater Commons and the Woodbridge Mall. "This is terrazzo here," he said, pointing to the floor in the food court, "but it's beautifully done. And in the main mall, it's beautiful marble. It's real where you expect it to be faux."
If that does not appeal to shoppers, the mall's owners are hoping that the theme they have chosen will. The theme is N.J. Style.
"We were throwing around ideas," said Tammy Crimando, the marketing director, who grew up in Newton, N.J., went to Rutgers University, now lives in Ledgewood, N.J., and claims to have heard all the jokes about New Jersey that have ever been told. "We kept coming up with stylish, stylish, stylish. My boss said, 'How do you say New Jersey and stylish together? It's an oxymoron.' Our idea was not necessarily high style."

HEADLINE: About New York

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
Her head bent over a ledger, Olga Loeb was in control. She gripped a wad of cash in one hand, a pen in the other.
"Just let me get this out of the way," she said, barely looking up. "I don't like to carry it over the weekend." 
 Certainly, ma'am. This, after all, is the gift shop of the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center -- the special realm of the plain-spoken monarch known simply as Mother Loeb to her many friends on the tattered Grand Concourse. More than a quarter century ago, this diminutive woman created the gift shop from nothing.
It is a place of flowers and magazines and candy bars and teddy bears and cigars for proud fathers. It has raised more than a million dollars for the hospital that her late husband, a surgeon, helped found and to which she has dedicated much of her life.
She opens the shop herself every weekday morning and locks the door every night. On Oct. 21, she will be 95 years old.
Mrs. Loeb characterizes her motivation as purely selfish. "It gives me a lift," she said. "Can you imagine if I sat home everyday and looked at the wall?"
This "selfishness" relates to her philosophy of life. "You get what you give, and if you don't give, you can't expect to get."
A delivery man comes in with a box full of scarfs and hats, items Mrs. Loeb had picked out herself in a showroom. As she counts them, she advises a nervous new father on receiving blankets. She tells someone else where M & M's are stored. She quotes the price of a box of tissues from memory.
Mrs. Loeb was born in Vienna. Her father made fringe for fancy chairs. The family came to America to seek a newer world. They landed at Ellis Island, settled in Philadelphia and moved to the Bronx in 1911.
It was a beautiful place, more country than city. The subway had just come, and the flowers on a breezy spring day recalled a Monet landscape. It was a time strangers tipped their hats and smiled.
It was also a time of common hardship. Many people worked in garment industry sweatshops and were unemployed for months during slack periods. There were no unions, no unemployment insurance, no welfare. "Families took care of each other," Mrs. Loeb said.
As a girl, she carried a can from house to house to collect pennies for a new dispensary that became the forerunner of what is now Bronx-Lebanon, at East 174th Street and the Grand Concourse in the Tremont section.
The mail carrier arrives. "You look beautiful as always," he chirps. "Like a rose, baby." The phone rings and Mrs. Loeb is asked how she is. "You know how old people feel," she answers. "Sometimes they're very good, sometimes they're pretty good."
Mrs. Loeb built a successful career at a time when most women didn't work, buying fine merchandise for fine stores. She worked in Manhattan, then Syracuse, Little Rock and Ithaca. At age 40, she returned to the Bronx to marry the distinguished Dr. Martin J. Loeb, who was 17 years older and quite a catch.
"I guess at that time I was a very attractive young woman," she allowed.
Doctors' wives then didn't work, so she threw herself into volunteerism. She became active in the hospital's ladies auxiliary, spearheading such efforts as selling new mothers certificates with doctors' signatures and photos of the new arrivals. She talked a reluctant board into converting a waiting room into a shop to be run by volunteers.
When her husband died in 1961, she pushed ahead. "I didn't sit and bemoan my fate," she said.
As the day scurries on, Mrs. Loeb calls the bank to see if a check has cleared, lends an orderly $20, chats with the head of the nursing staff, arranges papers for an upcoming meeting of the hospital's board, of which she is a member.
It occurred to her interviewer that she must have a lot of funny stories of hospital life. "Stories are usually sad," she answered.
Bronx-Lebanon serves the nation's poorest Congressional district and faces a never-ending flood of all the health problems afflicting the urban disadvantaged: hypertension, hepatitis, high infant mortality, etc. This is a hospital that gives away millions of pounds of food to the needy.
And as AIDS has ravaged those with too many problems already, Bronx-Lebanon has marshaled more and more resources to fight the disease. One resource is Mrs. Loeb, who makes a habit of visiting AIDS patients to talk, bring a candy bar, hold a hand.
"You can go up and see a patient today and tomorrow he's gone," she said. "It's very sad."
There are days when it is hard to get out of bed, but Mrs. Loeb manages. "When problems come up from doctors to porters, they look for me," she explained. "Can I fix it?"
Yes.

HEADLINE: Cuomo, Heading to Tokyo, Says It's Strictly Business

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 27

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who often boasts that if New York State were a country it would have the world's ninth-largest economy, leaves for Tokyo on Saturday on a trade mission that comes against the backdrop of a precipitous decline in new Japanese investment in New York in recent years.
While much of the decline is tied to internal economic problems in Japan and is common to other states, several American and Japanese executives said the slowing of investments was magnified in the New York City area, with many Japanese investors increasingly nervous about the city's prospects in the wake of its fiscal turmoil and tremendous social problems. 
 In that sense the Governor's visit, aimed largely at attracting Japanese capital to New York, may be a tough sell, even with his dramatic proposal this week of a state-backed $7 billion package of public-works measures that he said would help rejuvenate New York City.
On the brighter side, New York State's exports to Japan, which is now its second-largest foreign trading partner after Canada, have more than doubled in the last three years, to $3.9 billion. That gain far outpaces the United States average for exports to Japan, and stems from a growing trade in everything from antiques and jewelry to chemicals and heavy machinery.
The Governor will meet with a variety of top political and business leaders, including a tentatively scheduled visit with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, although Cuomo administration aides have insisted this week that the trip is solely intended to promote New York's economy and not the Governor's profile as a foreign-policy expert.
And despite the embarrassing release recently of a memorandum from one adviser to the Governor suggesting that he berate the Japanese on free-trade issues in order to demonstrate his toughness on foreign affairs, the aides said Mr. Cuomo is going to Japan to reap goodwill, not a diplomatic confrontation.
"The message is going to be 'We like you here in New York; we want you to come in a big way,' " said Vincent Tese, the state's director of economic development and one of Mr. Cuomo's closest aides. "There will be no element of Japan-bashing in our presence or our statements."
At an Albany news conference today, Mr. Cuomo himself declined to discuss what he plans to talk about, telling reporters it would be "disrespectful" to do so before they had been delivered to his Japanese hosts.
But he said of the visit, the only one he has made as Governor overseas outside of a 1987 trip to the Soviet Union: "I made a mistake in not going earlier. The visit is extremely important to Japanese business people." Referring to Japanese investments in New York, he added: "I should have gone a long time ago and paid my respects and said, 'Thank you. This is good.' Those Japanese signatures are on our paychecks."
In New York and elsewhere in the country, the recent falloff in Japanese investment appears to have received a mixed reaction. Japanese observers frequently point to Americans' clamoring for their capital at the same time that Japanese involvement in the purchase of some American landmarks like Rockefeller Center has prompted much hand-wringing about a possible Japanese financial takeover.
"We do send very conflicting signals," said John K. Wheeler, the vice president of the Japan Society, a nonprofit educational organization in Manhattan. "The Japanese are at the least confused, and sometimes very irritated."
In any event, investment is no longer growing appreciably.
For most of the last decade, the total Japanese investment in nonbanking companies in New York soared, to $6.5 billion in 1988 from $368 million in 1981, and the number of New Yorkers employed by these companies nearly tripled in that time, to about 40,000, according to figures compiled by the United States Commerce Department and the State Department of Economic Development.
Although specific figures are not available for 1989 and 1990, there is wide agreement that they have almost leveled off for the time being.
"I simply don't see any major investment taking place in any major industries in New York State right now" among Japanese companies, said Eiso Kawamoto, the president of the IRM Company, a Japanese-owned research and marketing firm with offices in Manhattan. Mr. Kawamoto added that while the trends in New York were not highly unusual, there had been at least modest growth in some states in the South and Middle West.
While Mr. Cuomo can obviously do little to influence Japan's economic conditions, several business executives said he would have an unusual opportunity to have his pitch for New York heard, because many Japanese continue to view him as a possible future President despite his professed lack of interest in the White House.
"They'll come and listen to him because of the Presidential possibilities, but then he's got an audience to work his message with," said Maynard Toll, an American who is the Tokyo-based president of CS First Boston (Japan) Ltd., an investment bank.
Cuomo administration aides said the Governor was expected to sign a handful of agreements in Tokyo involving export of New York State companies' products to Japan. But the primary purpose of the trip appears to be one of acting as chief chearleader for the state.
While there is nothing that the Governor can offer specifically to the Japanese, the aides added, he will discuss his development plans for the city as well as the standard array of incentives available to companies that consider locating in New York, including the investment tax credit for locating in one of 19 special "economic development zones" around the state.
Although they may not make or break bottom-line investment decisions, the Japanese place considerable symbolic importance on visits by dignitaries like Mr. Cuomo. Conversely, the trips can generate minor diplomatic strains within Japan, as when Mayor David N. Dinkins canceled a scheduled trip there last winter because of the Persian Gulf conflict. Even Mr. Cuomo's visit, while much heralded, caused some disappointment in Osaka when aides canceled a planned one-day stop there because of scheduling difficulties.
Still, the larger question raised by the recent falloff is whether Japanese companies' perceptions of New York City will make them reluctant investors even when their own economic conditions change and they have the capital to consider large-scale investments.

HEADLINE: More Employers Seen Using Dismissals to Fight Unions

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Companies eager to keep organized labor out of their work sites are increasingly cutting short organizing drives by the blunt and often effective tactic of dismissing leaders of the campaigns, many labor experts say.
It is strategy that, in recent years, has been invoked even in a relative bastion of labor like the New York region. Sometimes, the leaders are discharged as part of a mass dismissal, like the one at The Sae Gae Times, a Korean-language daily newspaper on West 27th Street in Manhattan, where three-quarters of the editorial staff was dismissed in May, just days after the start of a union organizing campaign. 
 More frequently, labor experts say, companies discharge just a few key leaders. An effort to organize workers at two hospitals in Burlington County, N.J., foundered last year after management dismissed a hospital housekeeper, who union organizers said had been a principal force behind the drive. And in Brooklyn, after a union began a recruitment campaign at a used-clothing salvager, three of the six employees on the organizing committee were discharged.
"It happens in most organizing campaigns," said Jack Sheinkman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union. "It strikes fear in the workers. What it does is deter union organizing."
Officials of the National Labor Relations Board said that there are no statistics that would show how frequently workers are dismissed for union activity.
 
Dismissals Are Denied

But Thomas A. Kochan, a professor of management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said his own analysis of the board's data showed clearly that the number of dismissals has been increasing. "There is no question that the number of people fired for organizing activity went up in the 1970's and continued to go up in the 1980's," Professor Kochan said.
On average, one worker active in recruitment campaigns was discharged for every 20 workers who voted on whether they wanted union representation, Professor Kochan determined in research he completed in 1987.
Management representatives agree that companies have become much more aggressive in fighting union-recruitment campaigns, but they deny that companies dismiss workers for union activity.
"I've participated personally in 700 elections and I've been involved in thousands of other campaigns that did not result in elections, and I can't think of a single instance where a company fired an employee engaged in union activity to discourage union activity," said Robert Lewis, a lawyer who has represented employers for 40 years and has written a book explaining how companies can win union elections.
Many labor leaders say that public opinion has made fierce tactics acceptable. As the public has turned more hostile to organized labor over the last two decades, they say, many companies have grown more willing to use hardball strategies, and even illegal ones like dismissals, to beat back recruitment drives.
 
Worker Intimidation
 Labor leaders say the Reagan Administration's defeat of the air-traffic controllers' union in 1981 with other successful uses of replacement workers in high-profile labor disputes, have also contributed to a climate that has emboldened employers. In the heyday of organized labor during the 1930's, 40's and 50's, companies were often reluctant to employ harsh or illegal tactics for fear of being tainted as union-busters. But the accusation no longer carries the same social stigma, or runs the same business risks, labor leaders say.
Union leaders and some labor experts contend that dismissals during recruitment drives can be critical to defeating a union. They can dispirit and intimidate workers, labor leaders say, and appealing such acts can take years at the National Labor Relations Board and in the Federal courts.
An employer can defeat a union campaign and save money, even if the Federal regulators ultimately rule that the employer improperly discharged workers for union activity and order payment of fines and back pay.
 
Workers' Leader Dismissed
 "It's profit-maximizing behavior," said Wayne Vroman, an economist at The Urban Institute in Washington.
Two years ago, the Communications Workers of America tried to organize workers at the Zurbrugg Hospitals, two medical centers in Burlington County, N.J., outside Philadelphia.
Larry Cohen, the union's organizing director, said that during the campaign the workers' leader, Betty Watson, a housekeeper in one of the hospitals, was dismissed.
A year later, in a hearing before the labor relations board, the hospitals' lawyer admitted that Ms. Watson was dismissed for her union activity, Mr. Cohen said. The hospital agreed to give Ms. Watson her job back, along with back pay.
 
A Personal Dispute
 But the loss for a year of Ms. Watson's leadership, along with the fear instilled by her dismissal, broke the back of the recruitment campaign, Mr. Cohen said. A vote of the hospitals' 600 employees on whether to affiliate with the union ended in a tie. A second vote ended in defeat for the union, he said.
Union leaders contend that an organizing campaign led to mass dismissals at The Sae Gae Times, the Korean-language newspaper. But it is too soon to know whether the discharges will undercut the recruitment effort.
The dispute began with a minor personal spat in early May. Cho Yun Suk, a low-level editor at the newspaper who was returning to work after lunch, had a chance encounter with Lee Yoon Sook, who supervises the typesetters. Ms. Cho said Ms. Lee made a disparaging remark about Ms. Cho's being unmarried.
One word led to another, Ms. Cho said through a translator, and eventually she called Ms. Lee a "Yankee bride," an insult that refers to Korean women who marry American soldiers stationed in South Korea. Ms. Lee is a member of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, Ms. Cho said, and like many church members, is married to an American.
 
Disparate Suspensions
 The words set off sparks at the paper, where there had long been tension between supervisors, many of whom belong to the Unification Church, and reporters and low-level editors, most of whom do not and feel discriminated against.
Ms. Cho, who does not belong to the church, was eventually suspended without pay for 30 days. Ms. Lee, a church member, got a three-day unpaid suspension.
The disparity infuriated many reporters and editors who signed petitions, confronted management and then, nervous about their job security, went to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union for help. (The union represents workers at another Korean-language daily in Manhattan, The Chosun Daily News, where half the staff was dismissed last year during a union organizing campaign.)
"When we presented the protest petition, we were kind of scared," said Kim Bong Ho, who was a reporter at The Sae Gae Times. "We needed job security."
By late May, after 14 of the paper's 21 reporters and editors had signed cards saying they wanted to be represented by the union, two union officials went to the paper to demand recognition. They were turned away, said Ann F. Hoffman, the head of the division for professional and clerical workers of the I.L.G.W.U.
Two days later, on May 31, the newspaper's president, Kim Byung Ho, announced that 17 people were being dismissed, according to four employees who were discharged. Fifteen of the dismissed worked were reporters and editors, 10 of whom had signed union cards.
Employees said they were told by the president that the paper was losing money and needed fewer people because it was computerizing many operations. Mr. Kim also said that the layoffs had been under consideration for a while, but that the events of the previous two days had forced him to proceed immediately, the discharged workers said.
"It was saying that the real reason for what they were doing was union activity," Ms. Hoffman said.
Mr. Kim declined a request for an interview. An aide referred questions to the newspaper's lawyer, Mark Goldstein, who said he could not comment on the case because it is before the National Labor Relations Board.
The garment workers' union went immediately after the dismissals to the labor relations board, charging the newspaper with violating the law by discharging people for union activity.
It could be a long time before the matter is resolved. An administrative law judge will conduct a hearing, scheduled for December. His ruling can be appealed to the five-member National Labor Relations Board in Washington. The board's decision then can be appealed in the Federal courts.
The union fears that time will be on the employer's side. If the case takes two to five years, the union might win the battle but lose the war. Will the dismissed workers still be around to return to their jobs? Will the remaining workers still want to join the union?
Officials of the National Labor Relations Board said that, while some cases do drag interminably through the regulatory process and the courts, most get a quick response.
To cut through red tape when an employer is accused of extreme violations, Federal regulators can seek a court injunction ordering a company to rehire discharged workers while the labor relations board tries to resolve the overall dispute. But it is rarely invoked.
A request from the garment workers' union for such an injunction aganst The Sae Gae Times is being considered by the labor board.
A similar injunction was issued last month against a Brooklyn company, which was ordered to rehire 208 workers who had been on strike since January 1990. The dispute at the company, Domsey Trading, a salvager of used clothing, also had its origins in a union organizing campaign.
Employees had approached the garment workers' union two years ago, saying they were poorly paid and complained that they were forced to wear large numbers on their chests.
Minutes after a union organizer went to the plant in December 1989 to request formal recognition, the owners dismissed one of the six workers on the organizing committee, said Joe Blount, a union organizer.
Within a month, half of the six committee members had been dismissed, Mr. Blount said. Two-thirds of the workers then went on strike to protest the dismissals. An official of the company, who declined to identify himself, asserted in a telephone interview that no one had been dismissed for union activity.
The injunction ordered Domsey to take back the employees while the labor relations board considers the case. Union officials said they hoped that a similar court order would be obtained for those dismissed by The Sae Gae Times.
"We think the facts are pretty compelling," Ms. Hoffman said.

HEADLINE: Guidepost;
Lower Mortgage Rates

BYLINE: by ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
To stimulate the real estate market, mortgage lenders have been lowering rates to levels not seen since 1978. For homeowners with mortgages negotiated in recent years, this offers an opportunity to refinance. Getting the most out of refinancing depends not only on the lower rate but also on how long an owner plans to stay in a house. For those planning on staying three years or less, the rule of thumb is that a new mortgage rate should be at least 2 percentage points below the old rate in order to realize a benefit from the new closing costs. Homeowners expecting to stay at least six years need a rate at least one percentage point lower than their current rate to recover closing costs. Here are the national average rates this week for the most popular mortgages compared to rates a year ago. The rate given for a one-year adjustable rate mortgage, known as ARM, is the average introductory rate for an ARM with a 30-year term.

HEADLINE: Rash Remedy on Illegal Aliens

 BODY:
The landmark 1986 immigration law set out to discourage illegal aliens by turning off the economic magnet and penalizing employers who hire them. Now opponents of employer sanctions argue that the law has provoked insupportable discrimination against legal residents who look foreign. They are pressing for a bill to repeal sanctions sponsored by Senators Orrin Hatch, Utah Republican, and Edward Kennedy, Massachusetts Democrat.
That represents a rash remedy for an uncertain ailment. The evidence is mixed and, in any case, proponents of repeal have yet to show why less drastic alternatives won't work. 
 The 1986 law was a compromise. It conferred amnesty on hundreds of thousands of illegal aliens already in the U.S. At the same time, it required employers to verify the status of new hires, to discourage more illegal immigrants from coming. Once employers are satisfied that any of about 20 documents that establish work eligibility, like a Social Security card, are not fraudulent, they notify the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Department of Labor.
It's a simple procedure that 80 percent of employers seem to be following. But last year the General Accounting Office, Congress's investigating agency, found that about 20 percent of employers avoided hiring people who looked or sounded foreign rather than risk being penalized.
Opponents of sanctions have seized on the G.A.O.'s finding of a "widespread pattern of discrimination" to urge repeal. They also cite a 1990 study by the Urban Institute and the Rand Corporation, two think tanks, concluding that the flow of illegals has not decreased significantly. If sanctions are causing discrimination and not discouraging illegals, critics argue, why continue them?
That's the theme of the Hatch-Kennedy proposal. It would repeal sanctions and increase the number of Border Patrol agents from 3,800 to 6,600. Better control of the borders is certainly desirable. But it ought not preclude other measures, short of repealing sanctions, that could lessen the law's discriminatory effect.
The G.A.O., which did not urge repeal, recommended at least two that haven't been adequately tested. One is better education of employers, which the Immigration Service has now begun. Another is reducing the number of acceptable work authorization documents to lessen the likelihood of fraud. Counterfeit-resistant Social Security cards are gradually being phased in, and states are experimenting with more secure licenses for drivers. But the immigration agency has not promoted greater reliance on fewer documents, and its own records are not always up to date.
Opponents of sanctions -- and all concerned with preserving civil rights -- are right to be concerned when a Federal law is shown to increase discrimination. But that's far from clear and, at least until lesser remedies are pursued, repealing sanctions remains premature.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Peru's President: A Good Bet

 BODY:
Despite concerns about human rights, Congressional committees are about to release economic and military aid to help Peru's President Alberto Fujimori fight the cocaine trade. The concerns are valid, but Mr. Fujimori still deserves the show of confidence.
The Bush Administration's plans for $34.9 million in military aid, including 50 military advisers, stirred fears of United States involvement in a Vietnam-like quagmire. The Peruvian military's human rights record, as sorry as any in the Americas, makes the idea seem even more dismaying. 
 Yet a realistic attack on the drug problem requires some participation of the Peruvian military, since the Shining Path rebels exert strong influence over much of the highland areas where coca is grown. The rebels, who seek power through terrorism and intimidation, extort money from drug traffickers and protect coca farmers from Government attack.
Mr. Fujimori also insists that drug policy depends on much more than the military. Coca growers, he argues, don't deserve to be lumped together with criminal drug traffickers. Most are poor people for whom Peru's collapsed economy offers few options; many who had hoped to get rich growing coca are now disappointed: the growers' income averages only $400 per year.
Mr. Fujimori's response calls for military pressure on the Shining Path accompanied by ambitious economic restructuring, for which Washington would contribute an additional $60 million.
In exchange for their agreement to substitute other crops for coca, Mr. Fujimori would grant campesinos title to their lands, a step that would give them a personal stake and allow them to organize for sale of legitimate crops to big purchasers. He would also develop roads to ease transportation of substitute crops. And he would promote other development strategies in hopes of creating low-end jobs.
The total $94.9 million aid package is far less than what Peru might eventually require to regain control of the highlands and restructure its economy. But the money will make clear that Washington believes Mr. Fujimori deserves support. Such an endorsement would reinforce his influence over the military, with the promise of better performance on human rights.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off as Traders Focus On Bush-Greenspan Talks

BYLINE: By By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday, as traders showed continued pessimism about the direction of interest rates.
Gold prices also closed lower. 
 Analysts said the foreign exchange markets were focused on a meeting yesterday between President Bush and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, told reporters that Mr. Greenspan had told Mr. Bush he believed the fundamentals of the economy were strong and the recovery from the recession was continuing.
But Mr. Bush expressed concern that restrictive lending policies by banks could have a chilling effect on the economy, Mr. Fitzwater said.
Traders took a bleak view of the meeting and the economy, fearing that the Fed would continue to lower interest rates to stimulate activity, and many sold dollars.
The dollar, like other currencies, draws support from higher interest rates.
"There's not been any good news whatsoever in the last few weeks," said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with the Bank of New York Company. "All the fundamentals point to a weaker dollar, and that's what we have."
There was more evidence of a struggling economy yesterday as the Commerce Department reported that despite a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in personal income in August, consumer spending was up a barely perceptible one-tenth of 1 percent.
However, the figures, which were in line with market expectations, had little effect on the dollar.
The British pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.7435 in New York, from $1.7285 late Thursday. In earlier London trading, the pound rose to $1.7370 from $1.7325.
The dollar also lost ground against the Japanese yen, falling to 133.15 yen in New York, from 133.95 yen on Thursday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 133.82 yen, up 0.39 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 133.40 yen.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.6705 German marks, down from 1.6875; 1.4535 Swiss francs, down from 1.4675; 5.6905 French francs, down from 5.7490; 1,249.00 Italian lire, down from 1,263.85, and 1.13355 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1360.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.6755 German marks, down from 1.6820; 1.4590 Swiss francs, down from 1.4640; 5.7055 French francs, down from 5.7300; 1.8890 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8960; 1,253.00 Italian lire, down from 1,255.85, and 1.1338 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1348.
Gold fell on the Commodity Exchange in New York, slipping $1.70, to $349.10 a troy ounce.
