HEADLINE: ART;
Brazilian Sculptor, Celebrated at Home, Gets a Belated U.S. Debut

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

 BODY:
A BRAZILIAN sculptor, Jose Resende, is renowned in his own country, having had a dozen solo exhibitions there in the last 20 years and having participated in twice as many group shows, including three Sao Paulo Bienals. Abroad, he has been in the Venice Biennale (1989), a survey of Brazilian art in Paris (1987) and, come 1992, will be in Documenta Kassel, in Germany.
But only now is the artist making his debut in the United States -- at the Joseloff Gallery at the University of Hartford. This delay, though deplorable, is not surprising, for the balance of power on the international art scene usually reflects that in global economics. But that natural law has not deterred Latin American artists from commenting defensively and with some justification on the patronizing attitude taken by the United States to art from countries south of the Rio Grande. As the Uruguayan Conceptualist Luis Camnitzer once remarked, New York City is "the center of the empire," and "the measuring stick for success" is set "by the empire and not in the colonies." 
 All the same, many attempts have been made to set the record straight in North America, notably the recent "Latin American Spirit," a survey staged by the Bronx Museum of the Arts. This made it embarrassingly clear that there is more to Latin American art than the work of Diego Rivera, Rufino Tamayo, Matta, Fernando Botero and the others who have made it within the empire.
The show also demonstrated that artists in the other America have long since taken matters into their own hands by eschewing the folk art approach beloved by sophisticates in the more prosperous countries and taking the international route. The two Brazilian pioneers of this in the 1960's were Helio Oiticica and Lygia Clark, and Mr. Resende has followed in their footsteps.
At first glance, there is nothing exotic about his work: it could have been produced anywhere in the Western world. In one way, place has nothing to do with it, for the 11 pieces were done from scratch on the Joseloff premises. They are, however, re-creations of works done in Brazil, which may explain some of their disconcerting effect.
As John Singer Sargent defined a portrait by its effect on a picky patron -- a likeness with something not quite right about the nose -- Mr. Resende can be described as a process artist who comes across as an Eva Hesse or a Robert Morris manque. That impression digested, the viewer focuses on the manque part only to find that the differences are far greater than the similarities.
For one thing, Mr. Resende is profligate with materials. Even as artists in the north are beginning to react against the waste of natural resources, this one from the south uses leather and copper as if they were plastic and newspaper.
The largest of these untitled works consists of three hides on which are poured two horizontal pools of paraffin wax. Congealed within the pools is a jumble of leather thongs and the entire relief is suspended by more thongs. The leather, which would provide shoes for the proverbial Ethiopian (or Brazilian) village, is a pristine pink-yellow, except where the wax has spilled and darkened it. As for the wax, it suggests windows of frosted glass, while the thongs could be vines closing from the outside.
In a floor piece, the leather plays the part of three giant lily pads and the wax the milky liquid retained by their curly edges. An argument could be made for a connection between these two works and the wonderful excesses of equatorial vegetation. Nature may also have been the unconscious inspiration for the seven-foot-tall cylinder of wax that is corked by a bundle of fresh leather and in which thongs turned black are imprisoned like insects in amber.
Though Mr. Resende studied at the College of Architecture and Urbanism at one university and taught for 10 years in a college of the same name at another, his sensibility seems anything but urban. He includes a snake sliding down the wall to the floor that is a stream of polished lead in which wire brushes are imbedded at regular intervals. His response to Giacometti is a figure made of blackened steel bars connected by eye hooks that is clambering onto a 30-foot-long wall made with bales of hay.
Then there is the ball of lead and copper wire that reposes in a small lake of motor oil. Twisted cables connect the receptacle to a slanted copper tube overhead that in turn is suspended from the wall by a single cable. It could be the playful invention of a farm worker with time on his hands. The difference between this and the "Venus" that greets the visitor at the entrance to the gallery is staggering. A 20-foot-tall torso with legs doing a split, the figure is cut from black steel and has a spiral of lead wrapped around the waist and each thigh. This is a monument that would look equally formidable in a jungle clearing or on a city plaza, and though not African in style, it bespeaks the African spirit that is said to infuse Brazilian life and customs.
Visitors who think "American art" upon entering the gallery will leave it not exactly enlightened about Brazilian internationalism, but they will be fully aware of its existence. As Elaine Barella says in her brochure introduction, Mr. Resende's vision is "universal in scope and specific in inquiry."
The works of Jose Resende remain through Oct. 9 at the Joseloff Galley at the University of Hartford in West Hartford.

HEADLINE: HOBOKEN JOURNAL;
In Mile-Square City, Buses Are Waging War for Commuters

BYLINE: By EDWARD SHANAHAN

DATELINE: HOBOKEN

 BODY:
EVERY weekday morning, as the sun rises over the Hudson River, a war is waged on the traffic-clogged streets of this mile-square city. It's not a drug war or a gang war. It's a bus war.
"I hate to use that term," said Lieut. John Aiello, commander of the Police Department's traffic division. "But that's pretty much what it seems like it's come to."
Hoboken residents who work in Manhattan don't have to race to catch their buses; one stops at each corner along Washington Street nearly every minute during the morning rush. 
 This glut of buses is a blessing to the city's large population of young professionals, many of whom moved to Hoboken because it allowed them to get out of New York City, but not too far out.
The quality of the ride varies from bus to bus, as does the price. Some buses offer air-conditioning in the summer, while others have only open windows. Fares range from $1.25 to $1.90. Paying top dollar does not always guarantee the most comfortable ride. For $1.25, a rider can sometimes get a plush, high-back seat on a retired touring coach.
 
'It's Great for Me'
 "It's great for me because I work at Rockefeller Center," said Mark Habersaat, a paralegal, as he waited for a bus at Washington and 12th Streets on a recent morning. "I usually don't have to wait more than two minutes for a bus. Today, I'm out here more than three minutes. That's unusual."
Competition for commuters has grown so fierce in recent years, however, that the city's Police Department is calling on state and Federal authorities to try to correct what it says is a dangerous situation.
"No question there's a demand for bus service," Lieutenant Aiello said. "But the way things have gotten, it's out of control. You have so many buses on Washington Street. They're all going after every passenger. We're having trouble maintaining safety."
 
State Agency Investigating
 Sonny Messina, head of the State Transportation Department's regulatory office, confirmed that the agency was investigating bus activity in Hoboken. "We're looking at the situation," Mr. Messina said. "That's all I'm going to say right now."
With three companies battling for as many as 10,000 riders every day, problems are bound to crop up on Washington Street, Lieutenant Aiello said. It certainly doesn't help that two of the companies fighting for passengers are owned by families that nurse a decades-old hatred for each other.
The kind of problems facing Lieutenant Aiello can be seen any morning between 6:30 and 9:30. During that peak period, 67 buses traverse the two-lane Washington Street every hour. Buses traveling south carry riders to the city's PATH train terminal. Northbound buses take commuters through the Lincoln Tunnel and into the Port Authority terminal on Eighth Avenue.
Because many people hop on whichever bus reaches them first, drivers have become adept at maneuvering the crowded main street in order to pick up as many passengers as possible. Drivers rarely pull up to the curb to load riders, often glide through red lights if they spy a sizable crowd of passengers ahead and invariably leapfrog one another in the frantic race to reach the next stop first, crossing Washington Street's center line to pass stopped competitors.
Sometimes, drivers from the same company team up to prevent a competing bus from moving forward. On a recent ride south on Washington Street, one passenger noticed that the bus he was riding had suddenly stopped at an intersection. The driver had stopped not to pick up passengers, but to block a competing driver in the oncoming lane from passing the bus in front of him.
"They violate the law every day," said a 76-year-old man who gave his name only as Charles. He spends many mornings sitting on benches at Washington Street bus stops, watching the cat-and-mouse maneuvers of the 50-seat buses up and down the crowded street. "The cops should be out here enforcing the laws," he said.
Though Lieutenant Aiello agreed that his officers could issue a slew of traffic summonses to bus drivers on a daily basis, he said he simply did not have enough manpower to fight the war. "I don't have enough men to control the buses," he said. "It would take half a dozen handing out tickets all morning long."
 
Beyond Traffic Violations
 While drivers for all three companies serving the New York route -- N. J. Transit, Red Apple Transit and Holiday Coach Touring -- violate the city's traffic laws to some degree, Holiday and Red Apple are by far the worst offenders, Lieutenant Aiello said.
Police records show that workers for the two companies have pushed the competition beyond mere traffic violations, vandalizing buses and assaulting one another. In some cases, drivers from one company have stopped their buses in the middle of Washington Street, sneaked up behind their competitors and disabled the vehicles.
"You need a shotgun to keep those guys apart," Lieutenant Aiello said, referring to the owners of Red Apple and Holiday. "It's always been like a Hatfield and McCoy situation."
Actually, it's a Sacco and Agresta situation. Joseph Sacco owns Holiday Touring and its local affiliate, Maria Transportation. Joseph Agresta and his cousin, William Errico, run Red Apple and Hoboken Transportation. The origin of their dispute is murky, but their hatred for each other is crystal clear.
"Agresta and Errico don't want us to make a living," said Keith Sacco, who helps his father run the family's bus business. "It's too late for us to reconcile."
Mr. Agresta maintains that the Sacco family isn't interested in providing service, only in hurting the competition for "personal reasons." Of his feud with the Saccos, Mr. Agresta said: "It's bad blood; that's all I can tell you. He's only in it for spite's sake."
The battle between the two families originally involved control of local bus routes, but escalated when the Federal Government deregulated interstate bus traffic in 1982.
"At that point, any small carrier could gain entry to any route," said Dennis Watson, a spokesman for the Federal Interstate Commerce Commission. "It meant anybody with vehicles and the proper insurance could go up against the big companies."
In Hoboken, deregulation meant that the simmering feud between the Agrestas and the Saccos was going to get hotter.
Until the laws governing interstate bus commerce were relaxed, N. J. Transit held a stranglehold on the New York route. In 1984 Mr. Agresta began running Red Apple buses into Manhattan. Mr. Sacco has tried several times to start New York service, most recently in January. N. J. Transit charges $1.90 each way for the 20-minute ride; Red Apple and Holiday each charge $1.25.
The added competition has had a big impact on N. J. Transit's ridership. The state-subsidized transportation giant currently carries about 59,000 riders a month on its 126 lines between Hoboken and the Port Authority Terminal. As recently as 1989, the 126 handled 109,000 passengers a month.
Neither Mr. Sacco nor Mr. Agresta could provide ridership figures, but each scoffed at the other's claim of carrying roughly 3,500 passengers a day.
 
Effects of Competition Felt
 "The regional economic downturn is responsible for some of our falloff," said Jeff Lamm, a spokesman for N. J. Transit. "But a lot of it is competition."
While the authorities keep watching them, Mr. Sacco and Mr. Agresta are watching each other. The companies are headed to court to try to settle their differences legally. Meanwhile, Keith Sacco has compiled a videotape of offenses he says were committed by Red Apple drivers against his buses, and Mr. Agresta and Mr. Errico spend their mornings driving Washington Street, monitoring the buses' maneuvers.
And how do riders feel about the bus wars?
"I don't notice how they drive," Eddie Curtis said. "I'm more concerned with getting to work."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Free Trade for Mutual Funds?

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
The winds of globalization have swept away many of the barriers that corporations and brokerage houses once faced when they tried to trade securities or raise capital beyond their home market.
From London to Tokyo, from Toronto to Thailand, markets have opened their doors -- grudgingly, perhaps, but steadily -- to foreign money and foreign muscle. Foreign companies sell bonds and stock in the United States, and American firms compete for underwriting business abroad. Foreign currency trading follows the sun, influenced more by time zones than by national borders. Americans open bank accounts denominated in German marks; Asians invest in United States Treasury bills. 
 What's missing from this picture? Mutual funds, the favored vehicle for middle-class investors. Despite a decade of worldwide financial deregulation, trade barriers remain a stubborn fact of life for those who sell mutual funds and other "pooled investments." And unless regulators adopt a new approach to such funds, a leading industry official has warned, those barriers are likely to remain high for years to come.
David Silver, a former Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer who has been president of the Investment Company Institute in Washington since 1977, delivered his cautionary advice last week at the annual meeting of the International Organization of Securities Commissions, made up of market regulators from around the world.
A special panel on mutual funds was one of just eight "showcase" sessions scheduled by the regulators' group during the four-day conference -- a sign, Mr. Silver observed, of how important this type of investing has become on the world scene.
"Twenty years ago, it would have been extraordinary for this subject to have been included," he said. "Today, with worldwide mutual fund assets in excess of $2.5 trillion, it would be extraordinary for mutual funds not to be high on your agenda."
But despite the explosive growth, Mr. Silver said, "progress in cross-border sales of mutual fund shares has lagged far behind efforts toward easier cross-border transactions in other financial areas."
Mr. Silver placed at least half the blame for those difficulties on world securities regulators -- reserving the other half for the United States tax code, whose treatment of portfolio profits has made American mutual funds less attractive to foreign investors. But while Congress is weighing a change in the tax code, Mr. Silver predicted that little progress would be made on the regulatory front unless the watchdogs stop fretting about how a fund is organized and look instead at how well it protects investors.
Some countries -- including the United States -- require that mutual funds be organized as separate corporations, with boards of directors. Other nations permit "unit trust" organization, in which funds are simply products of the sponsoring management company. In that form, an independent trustee oversees the manager's actions on behalf of investors; in the corporate form, a board of directors has that oversight duty.
In Mr. Silver's view, the form a mutual fund takes is largely "an accident of history or cultural norms." Yet, typically, each nation will require that foreign mutual funds be organized the same way domestic funds are -- and will reject for domestic sale any fund that is organized differently.
Since that approach makes it unlikely that any fund could satisfy every nation, Mr. Silver suggested that regulators forget style and look at whether the fund provides investors with certain basic safeguards. Are there prohibitions on self-dealing by fund managers or their affiliates, limits on management fees and clearly disclosed investment policies and goals? Are fund assets safe from theft? Can shares be reliably priced and redeemed by investors? Is the capital structure simple and strong? Is accurate information supplied to new investors on a continuing basis?
Looking at countries around the world, Mr. Silver found considerable agreement on the need for these protections -- even where there were vociferous disagreements about which structure best provided them. For that reason, he said, "I am optimistic that by ignoring organizational structure and focusing on core investor protection concerns we can achieve greater success in breaking down existing barriers to cross-border mutual fund sales -- to the benefit of the world economy and to the world's investors."
And, of course, to the world's mutual fund industry. But at least one leading member of that industry is skeptical that cross-border sales are anything but a long-term prospect. Edward C. Johnson 3d, the chairman of Fidelity Investments' holding company and a participant in the regulatory panel, said he would be willing to tailor his funds to whatever rules the local authorities might cook up -- if they'd just let him compete on an equal footing with domestic fund companies.
What he frequently finds instead, he told the regulators, are vague administrative requirements that make it a practical impossibility to set up a profitable business even in markets that are ostensibly open. Fidelity has found most Asian markets, aside from Hong Kong, to be extremely inhospitable, he said, and has met with "only limited success" in Europe. "All I ask is to be treated like a local resident -- without advantage or disadvantage," he said.
"So while I support the idea of being able to sell a pooled investment in every single market," Mr. Johnson said, "in the practical world, it's going to be very hard to do -- unless we started saying to some of these countries that we would treat their exports to America the same way that we are treated there." After the panel concluded, Mr. Johnson expanded a bit on what he had in mind: "It just seems to me that, if Hyundai can sell cars here in America, I ought to be able to sell mutual funds in Korea. That's pretty simple, isn't it?"

HEADLINE: Forcing Salomon Into Buffett's Conservative Mold

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Warren E. Buffett, the vaunted Omaha investor, did not get what he bargained for when his Berkshire Hathaway company bought a $700 million stake in Salomon Brothers four years ago. Now, as Mr. Buffett scrambles to save the company, it is becoming clear that Salomon did not get what it expected either.
The new Salomon that Mr. Buffett is creating is likely to be a very different one from the old one -- smaller, less haughty and less inclined to take risks. That aversion to risk reflects Mr. Buffett's style, and may also reflect the nature of his investment, which will remain a safe one unless things get far worse than they are now. 
 But before he can forge the new Salomon, Mr. Buffett, now chairman, must assure its survival by finding ways around the four areas that are producing nightmares for some Salomon employees. They are:
* Government action. Foremost would be that the Government takes severe action against the firm. It is already a given that Salomon will pay huge civil penalties for violating the rules governing auctions of Treasury securities. But it hopes to retain its status as a primary dealer in Treasuries and to avoid criminal charges against the firm. Either action could severely weaken it, even lead to its failure.
* Massive staff defections. Important Salomon staff members who stick around through Dec. 31 will receive a share of a $100 million bonus pool put in place before the Treasuries scandal arose, as well as normal annual bonuses. But once January arrives and these financial handcuffs are off, there remains the possibility that large numbers of employees will walk. To counter this, Salomon plans to pay large bonuses to important staff members, despite the Congressional hostility and unfavorable publicity that is likely to result. And it will probably come up with an incentive plan putting more stock into the hands of some workers.
* Fleeing banks. Salomon does not now need new bank loans, in part because it has cut assets by $40 billion, back to the levels of last December. But it needs to preserve existing lines of credit, and to arrange additional financing backed by securities. If major banks agree to provide financing at reasonable terms, that would provide an important psychological lift. But if there are doubts about Salomon's long-term credit, some important areas of business could be closed off. This might not lead to the firm's failure, but it would certainly constrain it and leave it at a competitive disadvantage.
* Massive customer defections. When the Salomon scandal first arose, fear that customer defections could sink the firm were rampant. At this point, only a relative handful of customers have walked away, mostly government-related entities. But others have cut back their business, and Salomon knows that it will lose much of the business it has if people believe its customer relationships have withered to the point it will be difficult for it to distribute securities.
So far, none of these dire events have occurred. And if Mr. Buffett, armed with his reputation for integrity and a new management team, can hold them at bay, Salomon is likely to survive and could prosper.
Though Mr. Buffett and Deryck C. Maughan, the new chief operating officer, have been preoccupied with Salomon's problems and have had little opportunity to look forward, interviews with Salomon executives last week painted a portrait of a vastly different Solly.
 
Time for 'Tough Questions'
 "We will be more focused," said Mr. Maughan. "That means competing where we are strong." Marginal businesses, he said, will be cut off. He said he had not yet made much progress in identifying such businesses, but would do so before the end of the year. "Because we have had a large capital base," he added, "in the past we have not had to ask the tough questions."
Creating such a firm has the potential for considerable internal conflict, which could also affect business and hasten defections. Mr. Buffett has no experience as a Wall Street manager, and his conservative financial style clashes with that of Salomon.
Berkshire Hathaway, the company Mr. Buffett has built, owns $700 million in preferred stock, which could be converted into a 14 percent stake in Salomon at $38 per share. At the moment, with Salomon shares trading near $25, conversion is a long way off.
It is conceivable that the nature of this stake will reinforce Mr. Buffett's conservatism. In an annual report to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders, he noted that the company would have done better if he had been willing to borrow more money. But he posed the hypothetical question of what he would do if he thought there was a 99 percent chance of raising profits by taking on more debt, and a 1 percent chance of results "falling somewhere between temporary anguish and default."
He answered this way: "We wouldn't have liked those 99:1 odds -- and never will. A small chance of distress or disgrace cannot, in our view, be offset by a large chance of extra returns."
It is fair to say that virtually any trader at Salomon would relish such odds.
Nonetheless, it is clear that Warren Buffett's Salomon will cut back on its debt level. Just before the crisis, every dollar of shareholder equity was supporting $37 of assets, with the rest of the money borrowed in one form or another. That ratio is down to around $27 now, and is likely to head lower.
To a large extent, the clock ticking the loudest for Solly is the staff bonus and defection question.
Mr. Buffett and Mr. Maughan have only three months to persuade the staff that there is a high likelihood of success in their efforts. If there are enough defections after Dec. 31, it is possible that none of the other questions will matter.
 
Can Managers Adapt?
 "There are a number of people who have lost faith, or who never had it, or who simply don't want to tough it out," Mr. Maughan said. "They will leave at the end of the year. But I am confident that the vast majority are willing to adapt to our new circumstances."
Other senior managers are not quite so confident. "It's tough to come in in the morning and open the paper. You just wonder when it is going to stop," said one executive. Another said he would stay, but added, "For the bulk of the employees, the critical question will be how much of the uncertainty has been taken out of the air."
The answer may be that not enough uncertainty has been removed, although Mr. Maughan vows that important decisions on the firm's priorities will be made by then. It is now virtually certain that the various Government probes will not be completed by the end of the year.
Salomon's fear of a criminal charge against the firm is based on the repercussions, not on the fine it would pay. States would line up to impose their own penalties and customers shy away from doing business with a convicted felon.
"I think we could survive a criminal charge, but it would be damaging," said Mr. Maughan. Salomon executives are quite aware that neither E.F. Hutton nor Drexel Burnham Lambert, the two firms that pleaded guilty to crimes in highly publicized scandals of recent years, is still in business.
Both of those firms fought the charges before eventually pleading guilty, and prosecutors came to feel that executives at the firms had tried to cover up the facts. Mr. Buffett's strategy has been to be open, hoping to win points by cooperation and by emphasizing that all those responsible for the violations are gone. The downside to that strategy is that there will be little hope for a defense if the Government decides to file charges.
The firm also hopes to regain its status as a primary dealer in Treasury securities. That is important not just because it is a profit center, but for the signal it would send from the Federal Reserve about the Government's official attitude to the new Salomon. "Our continued access to the secured borrowing markets could be impaired if our primary dealer status was removed," said John G. Macfarlane 3d, Salomon's treasurer.
So far, Salomon's strategy seems to have worked better with regulators than legislators. Both Richard Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, have praised the cooperation, encouraging hope at Salomon. But many key Congressmen have called for severe punishment of Salomon, and regulators know that if they seem to give the firm a break, there will be harsh criticism on Capitol Hill. On the other hand, if they are so tough that Salomon winds up severely damaged, it is hard to imagine any other firm choosing to cooperate in the future when it discovers violations.
Salomon is likely to further rile Congress when it awards bonuses this year. "It will not be radically different," said Mr. Maughan of the bonus plan, despite Congressional outrage at the huge pay some traders got last year. "We will pay for performance, as all Wall Street does." But there is talk that there will be a larger spread of bonuses, with top performers doing better than they might have expected, and lesser lights doing worse.
There is a school of thought in the firm that its compensation system, which paid one trader, Lawrence Hilibrand, $23 million last year, played a big role in the bond disaster. Mr. Hilibrand traded in the bond arbitrage department, using huge amounts of capital to seize trading advantages identified by computer programs. He did so under a deal the department had negotiated with the former top management, guaranteeing employees a share of the profits they generated.
The result, said a high Salomon official, was "a series of boutiques under one roof, as opposed to one firm." That reduced cooperation and customer service, he added.
For Salomon it is especially unfortunate that the illegal activities came in the heart of the firm. "The whole fixed income area is built on our strength in government bonds," said Eric R. Rosenfeld, a Salomon managing director who became head of the Government bond operation after the scandal broke.
One telling example: Competitors say Salomon used its strength in Treasuries to get World Bank business, then used that business to become a major underwriter of foreign government bonds. The World Bank has suspended Salomon until the end of October.
It is hard to overstate Salomon's position in the Government bond market. "They have an incredible franchise," said Raymond Mason, the chairman of Legg Mason, the regional brokerage firm based in Baltimore. "They were considered the premier bond firm in the country, certainly one of the best in the world, if not the best."
That position meant that institutions felt a Salomon relationship was a must. "They had a great set of customer relationships," said a top executive of a rival firm. "Every customer felt they had to do business with Salomon, or they would somehow miss out on important market information."
Salomon cultivated an image as a firm that would provide liquidity to the market when needed. If an institution wanted to get out of a big position in stocks or bonds, Salomon was almost certain to be on the list of firms that were called. It was the most likely one to make a bid, albeit one that could be well below the last trade in the security.
"Salomon is one of the few who will step up and take significant positions for their own accounts," said James A. Harmon, the chairman of Wertheim Schroder & Company, a competitor. "They take risks."
 
Signs of a New Caution
 Today, Salomon officials insist they stand ready to make markets, just like always. But speaking not for attribution, they concede they may be a little more cautious. If the perception spreads that Salomon is no longer willing to take risks, that could do more damage to the firm's franchise than the scandal has done. One of Mr. Buffett's challenges is to balance his own dislike of risk with Salomon's historic role.
Salomon's weakened financial position may have reduced the size of positions that can be taken, but so far it has not affected the willingness of others to trade stocks and bonds with it. But the same cannot be said of the markets in such highly complex areas as interest-rate and currency swaps. Taking a position in many of these markets involves a promise to make certain payments for up to seven years, and only those with the best credit ratings can play. Mr. Maughan says Salomon is determined to remain a player, but concedes it is now hampered.
Underwriting securities is one of the most vulnerable areas to scandal. Salomon officials say they had been scheduled as lead manager of one bank offering that will be announced soon, but were demoted to co-manager. There are at least two other underwriting assignments that the officials think they would have won but for the scandal.
The risk for Salomon is that as the uncertainty continues, its earnings capacity will wither while its fixed costs do not. If that happened, it might have to radically shrink to stay in business. But Salomon officials contend that will not be necessary.
"We will be a little leaner, but the basic business of being a full-scale financial intermediary will be there," said William A. McIntosh, a managing director in charge of sales management. "We intend to be a major participant in the stock and bond markets worldwide."
If it is to succeed at that, Salomon must first get by the Government hurdles, and then get its customers back. "Their brand name in the marketplace has been severely damaged," said Gordon S. Macklin, chairman of Hambrecht & Quist, and a former head of Nasdaq. "But if there is one individual who could restore credibility to a brand name, it is Warren Buffett. That could well limit the economic damage."
 
 
 
THE SALOMON SWAGGER
 There was a Salomon style in trading, and everyone knew it. It was big, bold and very confident.
"Part of Salomon's mystique was its macho kind of swagger," said a senior executive at a competitor. "They took multiples of risks on their desks," compared with other firms.
Managing traders taking such risks is a challenge, one that was largely met by executives who have now departed. Of the current leadership, said one competitor who refused to be named, only Stanley Shopkorn, the vice chairman in charge of equities, has proven he can do so.
Sometimes Salomon's style won praise, as when Salomon and Goldman Sachs agreed to buy stocks to counteract a wave of sell orders on Oct. 20, 1987, helping to halt the crash. But it was just as likely to stir outrage.
A classic example came in December 1986 when stock index futures were expiring. Conventional wisdom held that the expiration would cause a wave of selling, driving down prices.
In those days, firms were allowed, but not required, to disclose what trades they would execute at the close of trading to offset their positions in expiring futures. Salomon chose not to do so that month. As a result, other traders did not realize a lot of shares were waiting to be bought at expiration.
Prices rose at the close instead of falling and there were demands for an investigation. A lot of firms lost money, Salomon cleaned up and the rules were changed to keep such a thing from happening again.
It was that sort of action that created resentment of Salomon on the Street. "To the extent our hubris is the victim of the current events, so much the better," Deryck C. Maughan, Salomon's new chief operating officer, said in an interview last week.
Then, speaking of his success in building Salomon to the status of the most successful foreign firm in Japan, he said, "There was a less supreme attitude overseas."
 
 
 
HOW BERKSHIRE PLAYS IT SAFE

For Warren E. Buffett, Salomon Inc. was a new kind of investment. And despite all that has happened, it is unlikely to be a loser for Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the company he runs.
Mr. Buffett made his reputation investing in companies with secure market positions in solid businesses, and he tried to buy stocks when they were unpopular and cheap. Berkshire's 1.7 million shares in the Washington Post Company, to cite one example, were bought in 1973 at an average cost of $5.63. Now they trade for more than $200 each.
But by 1987, the stock market was booming and it was getting very difficult to find stocks that met Mr. Buffett's criteria. He had gone a couple years without a major common stock purchase.
So Berkshire tried a new strategy. It helped to fend off Ronald Perelman, who was threatening a raid on Salomon, by investing $700 million in Salomon preferred. Berkshire negotiated an unusually high dividend rate, considering the tax advantages of preferred stock, of 9 percent, and it received the right to convert the preferred to common, at $38 a share. If it did so, Berkshire would own 14 percent of the common, more than any other investor. But right now it owns no common stock.
A story went around that Mr. Buffett viewed the investment as a "Treasury bill with a lottery ticket attached." He denied saying that, but it did capture the flavor of the investment.
Berkshire later made similar investments in a number of companies. Only one, Gillette, has done so well that the lottery ticket became valuable.
Even in a worst-case scenario, it is hard to imagine Berkshire losing money on its Salomon investment. Salomon has common shareholders equity of $3.2 billion, enough to cover lots of losses from fines and operating setbacks. Only if that were wiped out would the preferred be in jeopardy. If it is not converted to common, Salomon must begin buying it back in 1995, and finish doing so in 1999.

PUB-DATE: September 29, 1991

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1645 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 22-27

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
I.B.M.'s Strategy for the Future: Making Itself Indispensable 
 Last week, John Sculley, the chairman of Apple Computer, and James A. Cannavino, president of International Business Machines Corporation's personal systems group, explained their companies' joint strategies. They would release a powerful new operating system, called "Pink," which Apple developed. It will run on a new generation of flashy PC's the two companies would develop from I.B.M.'s chips. Also last week, I.B.M. announced a pact with the Thinking Machines Corporation, a maker of massively parallel supercomputers. Thinking Machines would modify its machines so they could plug into I.B.M.'s mainframes. I.B.M. would also supply Thinking Machines with chips. The announcements give a glimpse of how I.B.M. envisions the future -- as a network linked to supercomputers, through chips, mainframes and software I.B.M. controls. If it works, that puts I.B.M. everywhere.
 
A Foreign Stake in Time Warner?
 
Last week Steven J. Ross, chairman of Time Warner Inc., told shareholders that "serious and meaningful discussions were under way," with a potential foreign partner. A deal could be made before the end of the year, he said. Wall Street liked that. Time Warner's stock jumped $1.375 to $82.625. Time Warner, one of the few big American media companies not to take its orders from abroad, is sitting on a load of debt. Though it reduced what it owes by 22 percent this summer in a rancorous stock offering, the company still owes $8.5 billion. That, and the recession, have constrained growth and eaten into Time Warner's operations. Two weeks ago the company said it would lay off 600 editorial employees. The collective salaries of those employees, analysts were quick to point out after last week's meeting, equaled just half of Mr. Ross' annual compensation. Time Warner's stock finished the week unchanged.
 
A Costly Call for Bell Atlantic
 
When the Bell Atlantic Corporation announced last week it was buying Metro Mobile CTS Inc., a cellular telephone provider, it was a testament to its faith in the future. Like most cellular systems, Metro Mobile does not turn a profit, is loaded with debt and has few real subscribers. Bell Atlantic will pay nearly $2.5 billion for the company. Metro Mobile has 11.5 million potential subscribers in its service area (which includes children who don't drive yet), but so far only 180,000 have signed up -- slightly more than 1 percent. Bell Atlantic will pay what seems like a high price for all those potential subscribers -- $202 to $206 each. That is considerably higher than the last big deal: The Comcast Corporation's acquisition of the Metromedia Company's system last Spring at $193 per potential subscriber. Did Bell Atlantic pay too much? No, said Raymond W. Smith, Bell Atlantic's chairman. "It's worth a lot more than what we paid for it," he said.

Logo of a New Generation?
 
When what you sell is mostly sugar and water, you had better be good at marketing it. Last week the Pepsi-Cola Company made a move designed to do just that. It unveiled a snazzy new logo which it hopes will convey youth, vigor and -- by inference -- tell people Pepsi is everything it thinks rival Coca-Cola is not. It also hopes the new logo will be powerful enough to break through the visual clutter of the supermarket aisles. But not everybody thinks the new logo (a modified version of the old Pepsi bull's-eye) is all that dazzling. "The guy sitting next to me on the airplane said that it looks like the Korean flag," said Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark, a beverage consulting firm in Los Angeles.

Help for the Unstealthy Stealth
 
The end of the cold war may have caused cartographers to redraw their maps, but it has scarcely affected the Senate. Last week an amendment to stop the purchase of the B-2 Stealth bomber lost in a close vote. That was good news for the Northrop Corporation, which makes the plane and could sell 75 of them to the Air Force for $60 billion. The Senate is letting the B-2 fly even though its mission -- to sneak past dense clusters of Soviet radar -- is moot, as there is no longer a Soviet Union. The Senate also chose to ignore tests that said the Stealth shows up on radar. Don't worry about the radar, said the Air Force, it can be fixed. How much will that cost?

The Final Frontier: Tourism
 
In what could be called one of the century's more dubious scientific experiments, a crew of eight scientists were sealed inside the Biosphere in Oracle, Ariz., last week. The zoo-like $150 million glass structure was financed by oil heir Edward P. Bass (Edward's brother Sid is the businessman). Biosphere is filled with 3,800 species of plants and animals. As the experiment progresses, tourists will pay $9.50 to peer inside. If successful, Biosphere could start a theme park trend: Humans along with animals locked inside an exhibit.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Ammunition for Japan-Bashers
 
There are two schools of thought in Washington over what to do about Japan. One says Japan is just another country. The other says Japan is fundamentally different: An underdeveloped capitalist country with an overdeveloped industrial base. That school says watch out for tricks. Those in the Japan-is-different camp got some aid last week from the General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress. The G.A.O., said 22 of 52 American companies interviewed reported difficultly or delays at least once when they tried to buy vital, high-tech computer devices from Japanese suppliers. Some of these delays led to big losses by the American firms. Japanese companies dismissed the report. "It contains very broad and vague allegations with some anecdotes sprinkled within," said David A. Huichital, of Nikon Precision, a division of Japan's Nikon Corporation.

A Scandal's Casualty
 
The scandals in the Japanese financial markets have made investors uneasy about investing there (the same can be said for New York, lately). Japan's biggest firms admitted wrongdoing but barely got a slap on the wrist. A few high-fliers took pay cuts -- briefly. But last week, after trying to tough it out by taking a pay cut of his own, Ryutaro Hashimoto, Japan's Finance Minister, is said to have told his party's leaders he would step down. Mr. Hashimoto has refused to comment.

Oil Prices Steady -- For Now
 
With batteries of Patriot missiles arriving in Saudi Arabia for what could be round two of Operation Desert Storm (if all goes wrong) the oil markets are nervous. Prices have been gyrating throughout the week to levels between $19 a barrel and $22 a barrel. To calm that market, Saudi Arabia said last week at the O.P.E.C. meeting in Geneva that it wanted to increase production by 10 percent. The goal, the Saudi delegation said, is to keep oil prices at about $19 a barrel. But many of O.P.E.C.'s other members objected. They want Saudi Arabia to cut its output. But "the Saudis got what they wanted and the others walked away empty handed," said Bahman Karbassioun, an oil economist. Unless there is war, consider the markets calmed.

Who Is Protecting Whom?
 
A Japanese typewriter manufacturer operating in the United States, Brother Industries (USA) Inc., asked the Commerce Department to protect it against competition from Smith Corona Corporation, a British controlled company also operating in the United States. Smith Corona uses a lot of parts from Singapore in its machines, but Brother uses more parts from abroad. The Commerce Department threw out Brother's request.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Faith in the Future Wanes
 
If the economy is snapping back to life, as the Administration says it is, why are all those consumers so fearful? According to the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index, Americans have been losing faith in the future since June. The index, which measures consumer optimism, is a useful forecasting tool. Contented consumers buy, while gloomy ones shun all but the necessities. The index slipped from 78.0 in June to 76.1 in August and 72.1 in September. For consumers, the angst is over their pocketbooks. "The prime worry is jobs," said Fabian Linden, the director of the study.

No Air in Detroit's Tires
 
The United States still may be a car-culture country, but Detroit is not quickening very many pulses right now. Sales of American-made cars and trucks dropped 16.3 percent in mid-September. The annual selling rate since Labor Day, was 6.4 million vehicles. Though that is an increase from the period before (sales were at a 5.4 million annual rate just before Labor Day) it is still well below last year's 7.8 million rate.

Consumers Are Staying Stingy
 
Consumers may be dipping deeper into their pockets, but most of what they are coming up with is fluff. According to the Commerce Department, consumer expenditures in August nudged up an almost imperceptible 0.1 percent. Though personal income did slightly better -- it crept up 0.4 percent in August -- those gains were modest as well. The problem is that because consumers account for two thirds of economic activity, their reticent spending habits mean tepid growth at best.

An Unusual Way to Add Figures
 
The Administration has a novel way of reading the numbers. When the Commerce Department said last week that orders for big-ticket, durable goods fell by 3.8 percent, the Administration said: Don't worry. Take last month's numbers, combine them with the figures from the month before and average them together. If you do that, the statistics show "solid gains," said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. To an economist like Mr. Boskin, if your feet are in the oven and your head is in the freezer, on average, your temperature must be O.K.

HEADLINE: Offshore Banking Gets New Scrutiny With B.C.C.I. Scandal

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: GEORGE TOWN, Cayman Islands

 BODY:
For years, while other Caribbean islands concentrated on building resort hotels and duty-free shopping centers, a handful of tiny British possessions have quietly taken it upon themselves to become centers of international finance.
In less than two decades, the most spectacularly successful of the bunch, the Cayman Islands, have gone from being a well-kept secret of divers and deep sea fishermen to a tax-free and secret-keeping haven for most of the world's leading banks. The banks are attracted by the scarcity of requirements about financial reserves and waiting periods, as well as the absence of taxes. 
 Affluent Cayman Islanders can now boast that foreign-owned businesses registered on the island outnumber its 26,000 inhabitants.
But in the aftermath of the scandal surrounding the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, many residents of these prosperous slivers of coral and sand are wondering if the world's economic powers, eager to avoid future problems with lightly regulated offshore financial centers, will squeeze them out of business.
"Realistically, we have to say this is not going to help," said Nicholas J. Duggan, immediate past president of the Cayman Island Bankers Association. "B.C.C.I. will certainly increase the pressure on us, just as it has heightened awareness in the industry of the need for the highest standards."
Already, banking experts say, the United States and British Governments, the European Community, the Council of Europe, the Group of Seven and other leading international bodies have begun discussing measures to tighten regulation governing the world's offshore financial centers.
Although this island's strict confidentiality laws have kept many details of B.C.C.I.'s operations here shrouded in secret, banking experts say its George Town offices booked billions of dollars in international loans, many of them never to be repaid.
Like many of its other offices around the world, B.C.C.I.'s gilded headquarters here are now padlocked. A Cayman judge recently granted owners of the bank a three-month postponement of liquidation proceedings to come up with a rescue plan, but many doubt that such a plan will ever be carried out.
The region's offshore banking centers "were really shocked by the way this scandal developed and has continued to unfold," said Anthony P. Maingot, an expert in Caribbean affairs at Florida International University in Miami. "Now everybody is trying to get in the business of showing the world that they are aboveboard, but that is virtually impossible. Why do you think there is interest in offshore secrecy?"
B.C.C.I. had an affiliate here known as the International Credit and Investment Company. At first, regulators believed that it housed B.C.C.I.'s considerable charitable activities worldwide. But now, regulators here and in the United States believe it a hush-hush operation that covered up B.C.C.I.'s bad loans and trading losses.
Last year, even before the B.C.C.I. scandal broke, the British Government moved to reassert direct control over financial affairs in the neighboring islands of Montserrat, Anguilla and the Turks and Caicos.
In the late 1980's Montserrat, with a population of scarcely 12,000, suddenly became home to more than 350 offshore banks, many of them founded by Americans with little more to show than fancy stationery and a post office box. In the wake of the British action, only about 50 banks were left.
"There will be immediate pressure to raise the standard of operations or close the portions of the offshore business where small countries are unable to comply with the higher standards," said Bruce Zagaris, a Washington lawyer who edits the International Enforcement Law Reporter, a publication that often focuses on money laundering and other financial crimes.
"For places like this, there is a delicate balance involved," Mr. Zagaris said. "If you tighten up too much, and keep adding to the layers of paperwork you require, there is going to be a dislocation of their business."
Hearing talk like this, Cayman Islanders have become worried about new moves to regulate their financial institutions, which could scare off some of their estimated $300 billion in deposits. A public relations drive has begun, featuring advertising supplements in foreign publications, like Financial Times, the British newspaper.
"Excluding B.C.C.I., the problems with our banks are few and far between," said Mr. Duggan of the Banking Association. "Metropolitan countries try to close the loopholes we live by on a daily basis, but people of high net worth will always find the vehicles we offer them attractive."

HEADLINE: Good for the Gap, Not for Society

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Washington's Mistaken Apparel Policy" (Forum, Sept. 1) is an example of a concept much more important than "giving mills an incentive to compete in the global marketplace." We are talking about the reasons why our standard of living is in decline. 
 There are obvious advantages to the author's company, the Gap, in obtaining fabric and apparel from countries whose wage is 50 cents a day, as opposed to American wages of $5 to $10 an hour. Meanwhile, the American worker replaced by the third-world worker is without a job. His or her company is probably in contraction or out of business. The textile mills that supplied it are probably a shadow of what they once were, like their fiber supplier. All no longer purchase the software or the hardware they once needed, nor use freight lines or pay taxes the way they once did. Is there any wonder the American economy is in decline?
We spent 40 percent of our apparel dollars on imports in 1990. How much of ourselves do we want to give? We could give Don Fisher, the author, what he wants if we could figure out how to pay wages here at the level of Indonesia or Pakistan. What is good for Gap stockholders may not be good for American society.
 
LEN FISHMAN
Roslyn Heights, N.Y., Sept. 9

HEADLINE: Style Makers;
Bob Evans, Fashion Designer

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO

 BODY:
Bob Evans designs evening wear with a difference. No floating clouds of chiffon. No grand ballgowns. His specialty is sportswear: jackets, blouses, skirts, pants and bustiers that can be mixed and matched just like daytime sportswear. The difference is dressy fabrics.
"The women I know dress that way," said the 39-year-old designer. "They mix their day and night clothes, wearing a favorite jacket with a satin skirt. Unless they need an occasion dress, women today dress down." 
 He offers each style in several colors so each store can buy his collection differently. They can decide on a cardigan jacket, say, and offer customers a choice of a short, straight skirt, or a pleated skirt, slim pants or wide-legged pants. Tops include bustiers, tanks and surplice-wrapped blouses.
Some styles come in satin and others in chiffon so a woman can develop an evening wardrobe by mixing a few pieces in different ways. For women who prefer dresses, there are short-strapless and off-the-shoulder styles with loose coats.
Mr. Evans did not plan to become a fashion designer when he studied economics at North Carolina University. But a job in a fashion photographer's studio led to modeling, and then one day he whipped up a pair of black moire evening pants and sold them to Henri Bendel. Suddenly, he was a designer.
He found it easier to run his business on a custom basis, which he did for six years on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. But he wanted to do ready-to-wear. He set up a showroom on Seventh Avenue in May and will give his first formal show in August. His clothes have been ordered by 20 boutiques. Prices range from $200 to $1,300.

HEADLINE: Market Magic;
But Just Who Is That Fairy Godmother?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
SOMETHING called free-market capitalism has been declared the winner by a knockout in the former Iron Curtain countries, fanning hopes of prosperity for millions of people who have labored in vain, when they labored at all, under the centralized paralysis of Communism.
But there is no such thing as a free lunch -- Capitalist Lesson No. 1 -- and many countries are learning that "the free market" is in large measure shorthand for transitions involving cultural dislocation, unemployment, production problems and economic and political confusion. This is true in Poland, in the vanguard of Eastern Europe's transition to capitalism, where the unemployment rate today is above 10 percent, and in Argentina and Mexico, where in the shadow of capitalism's victory, politicians are preaching free markets in place of the state capitalism that was once the popular solution to Latin America's chronic hard times. 
 It is also true to some extent in the place that holds capitalism's patent, the United States of America. Basic questions about how much of what kind of capitalism to introduce at what stages in the Soviet Union and elsewhere have helped to set American economists to questioning the most recent results of the free market at home. A still developing but highly critical view of Reagan and Bush Administration economic policies, driven partly by conservative scholars, says that America's free market system has shown it cannot deal, by itself, with such explosive problems as rising poverty, the urban underclass and inadequate public schools.
Among many other questions, economists are also wondering whether free market capitalism as practiced in the United States can generate as much wealth for Americans as the German or Japanese models do for people in those nations. "There is not some glorious theoretical synthesis of capitalism that you can write down in a book and follow," said Robert M. Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a Nobel laureate in economics. "You have to grope your way."
The groping shows up in the United States in various forms. University courses in comparative economics are suddenly very popular. New efforts are being made to measure the potential payoff to the economy from more public works projects, a potential that was minimized in the 1980's. And economists who have concentrated on broad theory are becoming more concerned with "micro" aspects of the market -- what makes it tick.
 
American vs. Japanese
 Why, for example, do Japanese car factories in the United States produce what many consumers rate as better quality cars than American-owned factories? (One answer: Japanese management techniques.) Or, what form of ownership makes a corporation most effective: the American approach, in which numerous shareholders delegate management to non-owner executives; or the Japanese system, in which various companies in a group own each other, making a core of executives, in effect, both the owners and the managers?
"With the ideological struggle over Communism out of the way, these differences are becoming more magnified," said Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist. Perhaps most important, economists and sociologists are questioning a prime tenet of classical capitalism, one that has held sway in the United States from the Carter Administration in the 1970's through those of Presidents Reagan and Bush: that the marketplace should be largely ungoverned, left to the millions of people who operate in it, each seeking profit or some other material satisfaction. The by-product of such self-seeking, theoretically, is ever greater national wealth and a rising standard of living for everyone.
That has not happened. While virtually no American economist today doubts that self-seeking and the pursuit of profit must play a major role in any capitalist market economy, they are increasingly arguing that the marketplace alone, with its complex of self-centered attributes, is not enough for the United States.
"The most obvious market failure is the failure of the marketplace to provide jobs for a substantial part of the young black urban group," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist and a leader of the American Economic Association. "This really goes beyond economics, into the nature of culture and how we organize both our government and our private sector." Mr. Gordon notes, for example, that in Germany, a national apprenticeship program inserts millions of young people into jobs and eventually careers, rather than letting them fend for themselves after high school.
Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, a research organization funded by business, is also skeptical about the free-market mentality. "I would not question the importance of the profit motive, but I just don't want to surrender the whole system to it," he said. "When you preach profit and self-interest, people increasingly behave that way."
Sharpening this concern is the change taking place in the old Communist nations. Clearly, free markets are more effective than arbitrary central planning in channeling resources into producing what people most want. What's more, some think that buccaneer capitalism, with all its lack of concern for job security and worker welfare, might be the best way to instill a jugular instinct in people just making the transition to capitalism. "You get the impression that at the outset there is no other alternative," Mr. Solow said.
But different standards are called for in mature industrial societies like the United States, Mr. Solow said. Here, free markets and social welfare must be balanced. Even Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economist and adviser to the Polish Government, agrees. Mr. Sachs is well-known for counseling Eastern Europe to leap into free market capitalism, although the immediate consequences are likely to be rising unemployment and shrinking social programs.
"The comparisons arising from Eastern Europe are feeding into the American debate," Mr. Sachs said. "A mature industrial society can and should extend unemployment payments to people whose benefits expire; we can afford it," he said, referring to the bill now in Congress that President Bush has threatened to veto. "We can also afford to provide adequate health coverage across the board. But the Eastern European societies are impoverished and restructuring the economies has to take precedence over social aspirations."
Reflecting this distinction, American economists increasingly are noting that the American economy is not simply a free-standing phenomenon, driven by humans calculating their best interests, detached from society. Other impulses and social goals, such as sharing income with the poor, training unskilled workers, organizing low-cost health care, excelling at technology and competing effectively with Europe and Japan, also shape American capitalism. When such concerns became pressing enough in the past, government took on a bigger role in meeting them.
"We have to recognize that there is no such thing as economics, only government and economics; political economy is the right term," said Eliot Janeway, an economic consultant. That recognition, always in the minds of many economists, is coming gradually to the fore, said Lawrence Summers of Harvard, currently serving as chief economist at the World Bank in Washington. "Some Government involvement that seemed flaky a decade ago seems less so today," he said, such as Federal subsidies for high-tech research.
Indeed, laissez-faire capitalism waxes and wanes, alternating with periods in which the Federal Government gets a bigger role. Herbert Stein, a senior fellow at the conservative American Enterprise Institute, views these alternating periods as a demonstration of American capitalism's ability to adapt without noticeably inhibiting the marketplace.
The 1920's exalted the free market's power to generate steady economic growth and widespread prosperity. The Depression brought Roosevelt's New Deal programs to ease some of the suffering. Then, immediately after World War II, there was a reaction against too much Government. In 1948, the Revenue Act and the Taft-Hartley Act, for example, modified taxes and put limits on union power, undoing a little of the New Deal. In fact, from the war's end until 1960, no new regulatory systems were established, Mr. Stein said.
But when the Soviet Union in 1957 launched Sputnik, new doubts arose about American capitalism's capacity to maintain the nation's leadership in technology, and Government once again stepped in. From then until the Carter Administration, its role in the economy expanded rapidly. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration became a huge center of research that benefited many industries. Numerous social programs were born, among them Medicare, Head Start and the Job Corps.
The reaction to this in the 1980's held that Government's involvement in the economy had become bureaucratic and wasteful. New stature was attached to the theory that minimally regulated markets not only made commerce more competitive, but also would raise living standards and solve social problems. Because that has not happened, Mr. Stein, for one, believes that the nation is, or should be, on the eve of a new cycle.
 
Retarding the Change
 "I have felt that we are going to have another cycle, with increased interest in the Government helping to solve the problems of education, income distribution and the urban underclass," Mr. Stein said. "I had thought people would want a government that promised to do these things and accomplish something. Well, this Administration has found an outlet for that public desire in foreign policy, while at home it is still dragging its feet."
Undoubtedly, the historic victory of capitalism over Communism is helping to retard the change to a larger role for Government in the United States. So is the initial success of Mexico's incursion into free markets, with its emphasis on privatization of state industries and open borders with the United States. But Christopher Jencks, a Northwestern University sociologist, argues that as the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe venture into capitalism, their old concerns over welfare and income equality will be reasserted -- prompting Americans to be more concerned about these same issues at home.
Senator Paul Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat who is chairman of Congress's Joint Economic Committee, agrees. "The Eastern countries are putting the question of what they want to take out of the Western industrial nations and what they want to reject," he said, "and now that there is no longer any over-arching competition between free markets and command economies, we are being forced into the same considerations."

HEADLINE: Bush Rewrites the Nuclear Rules

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SENSING that the nation and the world had arrived at a moment when history must be seized by the throat, President Bush abandoned his cautious and incremental approach on Friday night and in a single speech proclaimed the transformation of the security apparatus that has shielded Americans for 40 years.
In what historians surely will rank as one of the most momentous steps even in these revolutionary times, Mr. Bush simply granted much of what the Soviet Union had long sought, including elimination of tactical nuclear weapons from American forces abroad -- among them troop units stationed in Europe and Asia and Navy ships at sea. 
 It was the most one-sided cut in nuclear armaments ever announced by a great power.
Mr. Bush, whose aides have been insisting for months that no new arms talks were likely for a considerable time, offered to open discussions at once with the Soviet Union about eliminating one of the most dangerous kinds of missiles, the long-range behemoths that carry a number of nuclear warheads.
There was more.
All strategic bombers, such as the immense B-52's with their globe-spanning range, will be pulled off round-the-clock alert status, and their bombs will go into storage. The intercontinental missiles scheduled to be eliminated under the treaty signed in Moscow only two months ago and not yet submitted to the Senate will be taken off alert, too, and neither short-range attack missiles nor mobile launch long-range missiles will be developed as planned.
The President demanded nothing from Moscow in return, but he expected a great deal. Senior officials said he hoped to spur the Soviet Union to follow suit and destroy its own ground-based and sea-launched short-range nuclear weapons, sharply reducing its stockpiles at a moment when the very shape of the country is changing and the danger of such weapons falling into the hands of extremists is ever-present.
 
Challenge and Exhort
 No more "Trust, but verify," a la Ronald Reagan; the new American operating mode is to challenge and exhort, as did Mr. Bush in declaring that the United States must "provide the inspiration for lasting peace."
Pressed for economic resources, Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin quickly promised reciprocal action, but the views of the Soviet military, already reeling from purges and reorganizations, was less clear.
Much of what the President did constituted a bow to the inevitable, given dwindling Soviet strength and Congressional pressure for more arms cuts. It also had clear political benefits, presenting him as the master of world strategy as he prepares for a campaign against a Democratic Party bereft of candidates with foreign-affairs credentials. But it was done with a visionary fervor that brought gasps of surprise from some of his fiercest critics.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Cardinal Glemp's Visit Points Up the Polish-Jewish Rift

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
It was symptomatic that when Jozef Cardinal Glemp, Roman Catholic archbishop of Warsaw and Primate of Poland, arrived in the United States to visit Polish American communities, his first official event was a meeting with a dozen Jewish religious leaders.
"A thousand years of history were in that room," said Rabbi A. James Rudin of the American Jewish Committee, after hearing the Cardinal condemn anti-Semitism and express regrets that a homily he delivered in August 1989 might have fostered stereotypes of Jews and Judaism. The homily had followed a protest by Jewish demonstrators who entered the grounds of a convent adjacent to the site of the Auschwitz death camp. 
 A thousand years of history were also outside the room, it seemed. Some Jewish leaders, feeling that Cardinal Glemp's remarks still fell short of a retraction or an apology, boycotted the Sept. 20 meeting in Washington, and a handful of Jewish protesters picketed.
The Cardinal's two-week visit -- he will be in New York on Oct. 6 -- is set against the background of dramatic breakthroughs by the Polish Catholic Church to combat anti-Semitism, but it also began a week after hoodlums hurled bottles at the Warsaw synagogue.
The relations between Poles and Jews are filled with bright spots and dark shadows but, above all, with pain.
Poland and Poland's Jews flourished together in the late Middle Ages and the early modern period. For centuries, the vital center of Jewish life was in Poland. Driven from the Rhineland and Bohemia by the Crusades, the Black Death and persecution, expelled in 1492 from Spain, drawn by the promises of Polish rulers, about three-quarters of world Jewry came to reside in Poland.
Here, from the 15th to the middle of the 17th centuries, Polish Jewry enjoyed a golden age of relative freedom, material prosperity and intellectual and religious creativity. Here, as times grew more harsh and Poland was torn by war, partitioned by its neighbors and racked by the onset of modernity, the great movements of modern Jewish existence arose: Hasidism, socialism, Zionism.
The story ended horribly for Poland, and even more horribly for Polish Jews, all but a tiny remnant murdered. Poles and Jews were both victims of the Nazi death machine -- the former targeted for cultural and political subjugation, the latter for annihilation.
But even that suffering has more often divided than united the two peoples, overlaid as it is with bitter memories and a mutual sense of being wronged. Many Jews think of Poland as a land of almost universal and unremitting anti-Semitism. Poles counter with an image of an island of tolerance and hospitality where Jews had prospered. To qualify these descriptions is to risk being considered disloyal to those who have suffered and died. Discussions quickly enter minefields.
Poles sometimes feel that the historical onus of the Holocaust has been cruelly shifted from Germany's shoulders to theirs, and bridle at suggestions that they did too little. In no other nation was aiding Jews so severely punished by the Nazis, they point out; yet no other nation is more represented among the "righteous Gentiles" commemorated in Israel for rescuing Jews.
 
Stigma and Economic Jealousy
 Unfortunately, this position is undermined by a defensiveness that minimizes realities Jews cannot forget. Although Jews and Christians long co-existed in separate communities by mutual choice, that separation was never free of anti-Jewish religious stigma and economic jealousy, sometimes expressing itself in riots.
Although much of the greatest violence against Jews occurred in once-Polish territories under Czarist rule, anti-Semitism persisted in periods of independence as well. In the 1890's it became a component of the nationalism advocated by the National Democratic Party of Roman Dmowski. In 1945 and 1946, even after the Holocaust, pogroms broke out, with Communist connivance, it is believed, but also with Catholic acquiescence.
Until recently, says Lucjan Dobroszycki, a senior associate at YIVO Institute for Jewish Research in New York, Jewish and Polish scholars have viewed this past with almost totally different eyes. Dr. Dobroszycki warned against misunderstanding the Jewish condition in Poland before World War II, when Jews, 10 percent of the population, were an economically and culturally powerful force. For much of Polish history they had been the bulk of the middle classes, from shopkeepers and artisans to great manufacturers. They served as stewards for Polish landowners. Between the wars, a third of Poland's lawyers and half of its doctors were Jewish. Jews were well represented in Poland's Parliament.
With the exception of a restriction on kosher slaughtering, Poland had no anti-Jewish legislation in 1939. Some universities, which were self-governing, had quotas. Violence was largely the work of small fascist groups, and was opposed by the government.
At the same time, economic and psychological hostility was rising. Dmowski's xenophobic and anti-Semitic attitudes spread well beyond his party's ranks.
Only in the last few years have Poles had the freedom and psychological security to discuss openly how all this relates to the Holocaust. In 1987, the Polish Catholic weekly Tygodnik Powszechny published an essay by Jan Blonski, a professor of Polish literature, arguing that Poles "must stop haggling," that coming to terms with the past would begin with confessing a moral complicity in what had made genocide possible.
Professor Blonski's essay was fiercely challenged, but the debate it opened was as much about the future as the past. Today, Poland has the strange phenomenon of what is often called "anti-Semitism without Jews," the use of a malevolent, conspiratorial "other" to vent resentment at change and stigmatize proponents of a more open society.
Last week, Maciej Kozlowski, Deputy Chief of the Polish Mission to the United States and a former contributor to Tygodnik Powszechny, expressed his concern that these discussions will be curtailed by Polish reactions to the sharp criticism of Cardinal Glemp.
"I hope that the great work done in recent years between Catholics and Jews, and so many others of good will, won't be jeopardized," he said.
