HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Cloaked in Humble Origins, Democrats Make an Entrance

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Early in "All the King's Men," the candidate Willie Stark is given some valuable advice: "Just tell 'em you're gonna soak the fat boys and forget the rest of the tax stuff."
As the 1992 Presidential campaign gets under way, Democratic consultants use more delicate language but the gist of their advice is much the same: Populism and class-based appeals are being retrofitted for the 1990's. Almost every candidate for the Democratic nomination places himself firmly on the side of The People -- in 1990's populism, this is generally referred to as the middle class -- and against an economic or governmental elite that is, at best, insensitive to their plight. 
 Everywhere he goes, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa rails against the policies of George Herbert Walker Bush, wringing every aristocratic nuance from the name. (A contrast to the simple, Midwestern Tom Harkin, who proudly proclaims himself the son of a coal miner and an immigrant mother.)
Mr. Harkin is not alone. Among the candidates, humble roots are flaunted, and "fat boys" are scorned.
Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia attacks the Washington elites in both parties who have bollixed the Federal budget and left the middle income taxpayer with the bill. And Governor Bill Clinton of Arkansas blasts the high-rollers on Wall Street who mismanaged their companies and landed softly with their golden parachutes -- while the White House looked the other way.
The new populism is fed by the recession, but also transcends it. One of the most prominent theoreticians is Kevin Phillips, a conservative analyst, who argues in "The Politics of Rich and Poor" that the policies of the 1980's produced extraordinary concentrations of wealth at the top of society and will lead, inexorably, to a reformist backlash. Democratic polltakers, like Geoffrey Garin and Stan Greenberg, say middle-class Americans feel increasingly stretched and neglected.
Mr. Garin said, "It's not really about jealousies; it's about people wanting to get ahead and feeling that nobody in the status quo is thinking about how to help them do that." This helps to explain all the talk from the Democrats about college scholarship programs, tax breaks for the middle class, reforming the health care system, improving the schools, upgrading the skills of the work force and generally improving the competitiveness of American industry. In many ways, this year, this is a gentle, suburbanized populism.
Sometimes there are outright class appeals, but there is also a queasiness at the approach -- after all, it conflicts with the notion that this is a classless society, happy and fluid and free. Republicans are quick to accuse the Democrats of practicing class warfare; Democrats say their opponents attack economic populism because it works. In fact, Republicans have long had a vulnerability on these grounds: 62 percent of those surveyed last June said they believed the Republicans favored the rich, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll of 1,424 adults.
The budget negotiations last fall offered a test of these economic appeals: Some Republicans are still shaken by the success the Democrats had in casting Mr. Bush as a President unwilling to raise taxes on the rich. The legislation extending unemployment benefits has offered Congressional Democrats similar opportunities and in recent days they have been lining up to denounce Mr. Bush's opposition to their bill.
But at least in Presidential elections, Republicans are experts at countering these attacks by casting Democrats as a different kind of elite: Big Government people who support social engineering through measures like hiring quotas; Ivy Leaguers who smirk at traditional values like patriotism; smug liberals with an uncontrollable urge to cut America's defense. The 1988 campaign against Michael S. Dukakis was a textbook example of this.
So this time around, Democrats are talking a lot about traditional values -- indeed embracing them with new fervor.
In 1988, while the Democrats did little to inoculate Mr. Dukakis against a charge of cultural elitism, Republicans were careful to blunt the image of Mr. Bush as an aristocrat. He talked about his affection for pork rinds and country music. He quoted Clint Eastwood. He was a regular guy.
His opponents hope to remeind the voters of Mr. Bush's roots -- "born on third base and decided that he'd hit a triple," as a former Texas Agriculture Commissioner, Jim Hightower, put it. But can Mr. Harkin, or anyone else, turn the President into George Herbert Walker Bush once again?
Charles Black, a top Republican strategist, says no. "He's been President for three years," he said. "They're seen as genuine, down-to-earth people. It's going to be hard to turn him into a Greenwich, Conn., Wall Street banker who doesn't know any real people."
Kevin Phillips asserts that the elitist attack still has power against Mr. Bush, but he sees a strong Republican counteroffensive this time. "The new strategy is Kuwait, crime and quotas," Mr. Phillips contends.
And there are risks for the Democrats in this new populism. For example, much of the voters' anger, some political professionals say, is against Government -- and Democrats still control one of the three Federal branches, one whose members, it was recently disclosed, bounced thousands of personal checks. "You've got to be careful about where you aim the populist gun, because you might shoot yourself," said Will Marshall, head of the Progressive Policy Institute, an offshoot of the Democratic Leadership Council, which tries to push the party to what it considers the political center.
Democrats must also take care that they are not perceived as simply being anti-rich, rather than pro-middle class. "I think we learned a lesson -- and that is that every American wants to be rich, but no American wants the Government to protect the rich at the cost of everyone else," said a House Democratic strategist.
Mr. Phillips thinks the Democrats are still searching for the right language. Mr. Harkin's appeal, the battle of the small towns against the big interests, for example, seems uniquely suited for the Midwest. While Mr. Phillips says he is convinced that the movement is indeed coming in the 1990's, he adds, "The new populism isn't there yet."
 
 
 
Poor? They were so poor that . . .
The regional accents differ, but as the Democratic Presidential candidates begin their campaigns, the theme of humble beginnings is a constant. Following are some early variations.
 
 
 
Gov. Bill Clinton
'Nearly half a century ago, I was born in a little town called Hope. My mother, unfortunately, had been widowed three months before I was born. I was raised for four years by my grandparents, while she went back to nursing school. They didn't have much money, and I spent a lot of time with my great-grandparents and by any standard they were poor.'
 
 
 
Senator Tom Harkin
'I come from the wrong side of the tracks. My father was a coal miner who didn't even have an eighth grade education. My mother was an immigrant with no formal education. My parents raised six kids in a small, two-bedroom house. And I was the youngest. My father was 54 years old and working on W.P.A. when I was born. We were poor. But my parents instilled in us those traditional values.'
 
 
 
Representative Dave McCurdy
'I am deciding whether to run for President. It is a daunting task for a man raised in Oklahoma, middle America, by two parents who worked in a factory, were union, went to church and only aspired to give their children a better life. They did not leave me riches. No, they left me something far better. They taught me the values of hard work, individual responsiblity and family.'
 
 
 
Gov. L. Douglas Wilder
'As the grandson of slaves, I read about the Constitution, and I knew America and Virginia wanted more for me and my friends than did the politicians in power at that time -- and history has proven us right. As a soldier in Korea, I knew my fight and that of my fellow soldiers -- many of whom never returned home -- against communism was also a fight against the denial of freedom everywhere: and history has proven us right.'

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
An Era of Change Challenges France's Self-Confidence

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
FOR three decades after France lost its empire, the cold war enabled successive French presidents to keep alive the myth that it remained a great power. It had an independent nuclear deterrent, it was the political leader of the European Community, it was influential in the Middle East and it had a special relationship with Moscow that it frequently used to pique Washington.
But the events of the last year have badly shaken France's self-confidence abroad. The country now feels intimidated by the growing political power of a united Germany, it seems unsure how to handle a turbulent Eastern Europe, it has lost clout in the Arab world and it is uncomfortable with the United States as the sole remaining superpower. 
 President Francois Mitterrand has not helped things by gambling badly at several key moments -- trying to slow the pace of German unification, offering a face-saving deal to Iraq on the eve of the gulf war, appearing ready to accept the Soviet coup as a fait accompli. And this in turn has made the 74-year-old President a convenient scapegoat for the demise of French "gloire."
Yet France's troubled search for a new place for itself abroad might not matter to ordinary Frenchmen were it not accompanied by a simmering crisis of identity -- a loss of direction -- at home. And for this, Mr. Mitterrand is also blamed.
Last week, a new poll showed Mr. Mitterrand's approval rating had dropped to 46 percent, a five-year low. Two weeks earlier, another poll said 61 percent of those surveyed considered the President "worn out" after 10 years in office.
It could be, of course, that Mr. Mitterrand is just going through a bad patch and will, as before, bounce back. In 1986, his Socialist Party lost legislative elections and he was forced to "cohabit" with a conservative Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac, for two years; still, he won re-election to a new seven-year term in 1988.
Now, with his new Prime Minister, Edith Cresson, faring poorly, the prospects are again for a conservative victory in legislative elections in 1993, although no one would be surprised if the Socialists won the presidency again in 1995.
Yet the reasons for France's malaise today run deeper than party politics. Indeed, so indifferent are most French to the political debate that only 33 percent of registered voters cast ballots in a by-election last Sunday.
Disenchantment with politicians has been partly fed by several scandals over illegal funding of different parties. There is also the problem that no new leaders have emerged in the last decade: lined up against Mr. Mitterrand are still Mr. Chirac, former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and the extreme rightist Jean-Marie Le Pen.
But, perhaps most of all, many French voters no longer think they have a clear political choice. Since 1983, when Mr. Mitterrand abandoned a disastrous experiment with nationalizations, his economic policies have moved steadily to the right so that today they are virtually indistinguishable from those advocated by conservatives. And if the opposition took office, it too would find French monetary policy is largely defined by the German Bundesbank, while many other economic decisions are taken by the European Community.
All this has become relevant in recent months as solid economic growth has given way to recession. Now the social costs of recent overall prosperity -- a high rate of unemployment and a permanent squeeze on workers' wages -- are more difficult to hide. Strikes, particularly of public services ranging from transportation to hospitals, are on the rise. Discontent among the country's long-cossetted farmers is bubbling to the surface. But the Government has no alternative economic model to offer.
On one subject, immigration, there is intense debate. Yet, for lack of a coherent response from the country's politicians, the discussion has only added to uncertainty about the future.
Until the mid-1970's, Arab and African immigrants were welcomed as temporary workers, but by the mid-1980's it was clear they had come to stay. And as they brought their wives from home and had children of their own, the emergence of new ghettoes in many urban neighborhoods fed French hostility toward third-world immigrants.
 
Ethnic Diversity
 Today, the growing reality of an ethnically diverse society -- 4 million of France's 55 million inhabitants were born abroad -- is seen as one more threat to the French way of life. And the trend is likely to continue. Poverty and high birth rates in North Africa have created millions more potential immigrants. Similarly, the economic plight of many Eastern European countries makes France very attractive to unemployed youths. And on Jan. 1, 1993, the European Community's 12 members are to dismantle their internal borders.
In recent months, politicians have scrambled to catch up with public opinion and Mr. Le Pen, who has long called for repatriation of illegal and unemployed immigrants, has had the satisfaction of seeing others move toward his position. Mr. Mitterrand himself has said France has reached "the threshold of tolerance" on immigration. Mr. Chirac gambled by publicly complaining about "the smell and noise" of immigrants. Last week, Mr. Giscard d'Estaing said France was experiencing "an invasion" of immigrants. But no new policy has emerged.
As with immigration, then, France today seems unsure how to handle change. Ordinary citizens worry about recession and unemployment, about falling educational standards and rising immigration. Prime Minister Cresson alarms them by talking heatedly about Japan's economic "takeover," while Foreign Minister Roland Dumas whispers about German influence embracing Eastern Europe.
Last week, President Mitterrand was at least able to flex French muscles by sending troops to restore order after an army mutiny in Zaire. But, back home, no one seemed too impressed.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
From Albany, a Vision of a New New York City

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
One worn thread ties together the psychic and economic recovery of New York City that began in 1976 and the groping for solutions 15 years later. When Gov. Mario M. Cuomo unveiled his own blueprint for revival last week, Donald J. Trump's name was barely mentioned.
In 1976, the nation's bicentennial celebration and the Democratic national convention produced their share of euphoria. But it was Mr. Trump's bargain-basement investment in buying and then renovating the faded Commodore Hotel on 42d Street in Manhattan into the gleaming Grand Hyatt that, more than any single physical symbol, helped trigger the building boom that followed. Mr. Trump cannily played on City Hall's desperation to reduce his risk with property tax abatements. But his hotel renovation was a private investment. 
 Today, Mr. Trump is living on an allowance. Private development has evaporated. And it is government, personified by Mr. Cuomo, that is plunging into the void to jump-start the economy and generate jobs. One goal of his blueprint is to build confidence, if not necessarily the edifices themselves, with government's good offices and its direct investment. Among the re-packaged projects that would be expedited by Mr. Cuomo is Riverside South, which is owned by Mr. Trump.
While the Governor's lofty presentation last week was intended to rally glum business, labor and civic leaders with his tangible vision of a "New New York," its most enduring legacy could turn out to be his prescription for an assumption of local Medicaid costs by the state. While the speech may have appeared to cast him temporarily as Mayor Cuomo, it presents Mayor David N. Dinkins with another opportunity to demonstrate leadership in negotiating labor concessions and other savings that would pry hundreds of millions of deficit-closing dollars a year from the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation.
 
A Goal of Recurring Revenue
 "Historic" was Mr. Cuomo's word of choice in the speech he first delivered Monday night and embellished with a Jackie Mason-style tutorial on municipal bonds when he presented it to a second audience of opinion-makers the next morning. His remarks looked ahead, but also evoked New York City's last fiscal crisis which, Mr. Cuomo explained pedantically, was resolved largely with financial devices to bridge a recurring budget gap rather than with catalysts for economic development that would guarantee recurring tax revenue.
Mr. Cuomo's predecessor, Hugh L. Carey, left a concrete legacy, too, but will be best remembered for intervening to save the city from itself. Mr. Carey created the M.A.C. to borrow on the city's behalf and the Financial Control Board to circumvent the Mayor. Mr. Cuomo is chairman of the control board, but has been reluctant to invoke its full power because he would be perceived as compromising the city's first black Mayor.
Next week Mr. Dinkins goes before the control board to deliver a progress report on the four-year financial plan that the city is revising to address what Mr. Cuomo discreetly called its "vulnerability." Negotiations between the Dinkins administration and municipal unions have stalled; the teachers' union contract, which a year ago prompted angry demands for comparable increases from other labor leaders, expires tomorrow. Moreover, two major initiatives by the Mayor's Management Advisory Task Force are also problematic: a proposed user fee for sanitation services, which appears too regressive in its present form; and a recommendation to impose tolls on the free East River bridges, which which is likely to be a tough sell.
 
City Quibbles
 City Hall officials, scrounging to bridge projected deficits, are grateful to the Governor, but consider his Medicaid proposal too stingy because of its lengthy timetable and point out that it addresses only one of the so-called structural imbalances in the budget that the control board identified last spring. (The Governor himself acknowledged that "there will be more to do, especially in the field of criminal justice, health and social services.") Also, city officials are skeptical about some specifics of the economic development package, although they cannot afford to spurn any help, whether it is abstract or concrete. It is easy to quibble with some of the components -- Mr. Trump's project on the West Side may saddle the state with costly obligations for new parkland; the proposed airport train is less desirable than a direct link to midtown, although it would be financed by an airline passenger tax, and a downtown bus terminal might be more relevant than the partial resuscitation of a Second Avenue subway line.
Reflecting on the 1970's, Robert A. Caro, the Pulitzer-prize winning author of "The Power Broker," a biography of Robert Moses, the impresario of public works, once recalled: "There was a vacuum -- an almost absolute vacuum -- in planning and executing large-scale projects after the fiscal crisis. I'd have hoped that the gap would've been filled by public officials, and hopefully by a Mayor."
It wasn't, for the most part. And this time, a Governor is trying to fill the gap again. "There was a time when we looked to public officials to provide leadership in New York," Mr. Caro said the other day. "The Governor I thought of when I read Cuomo's speech was Alfred E. Smith. He was absolutely unafraid to tackle the biggest problems with solutions on a broad scale. If Cuomo does provide it and follows through, the state and the country will find something they are desperately looking for."

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Cuomo on Finance? Don't Ask

 BODY:
ADDRESSING the Association for a Better New York last week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo spoke softly and carried a big shtick. He delivered a Jackie Mason-style monologue, outlining the mandate of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was created during New York City's 1975 fiscal crisis to borrow on the city's behalf; the role of its chairman, Felix G. Rohatyn, and the fact that the M.A.C., supported by private bond rating analysts, among them Hyman Grossman of Standard & Poor's, has suggested that the city pare expenses before the M.A.C. releases money generated by refinancing its bonds. Here is an excerpt:
 
 Nobody knows what M.A.C. is. It's wonderful. No matter where you go, nobody knows what M.A.C. is. What's M.A.C.? What's his name? Royton. Philip Royton. No, we don't have a Philip Royton. No, I know the guy. M.A.C. He's a banker. No, it's not a bank. It's us, it's the state. It's a bank. Well, you said it wasn't a bank. Well, it's like a bank. It's the Municipal Assistance Corporation. We invented it.
M.A.C., that's the state. They borrow money. Why did you trust the state to borrow the money and not the city? Because we took the sales tax from the city and we used that as a guarantee. Why didn't the city take the sales tax from the city? What are you asking me for? It's so complicated, I don't remember.
So what does M.A.C. do? M.A.C. borrows money, gets it cheaper than anybody. Why? Nobody knows why exactly. It's government just like us, capable of the same stupidities, absurdities, miscalculations. But somehow they've worked it out because Royton's clever and his friends -- who are nameless, to show you how clever they are, when things go wrong Royton gets the blame.
M.A.C. is sitting there with a lot of money. They've got bonds -- they paid 9 percent, 10 percent, 12 percent. They can now get bonds at 8 percent. So what? You sell the one bonds, you get the other bonds, you save money. Great. What do you do with the money? Nothing. They sit there and they say, 'You want it, beg us.' So we go and we beg.
Even if M.A.C. didn't say it, the raters are saying it. Who are these raters? Nobody knows. They're another group. Hy Grossman. Who is he? From Jersey. He's a rater. He can hurt us? Oh, he can kill you. How? He can say you can't borrow. Why? What's the difference? If they say you can't borrow, you can't borrow. If they say the investment's no good, the investment's no good. Why do they do that? I don't know. Someday, I'm going to quit this business and learn all the things that made me crazy while I was in it.

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARM PLAN;
Excerpts From Briefing at Pentagon: 'It Will Make the World a Safer Place'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a briefing at the Pentagon today by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Also at the briefing was Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
 
CHENEY STATEMENT
 Last night the President spoke to the American people and outlined his initiative for changing the size and the shape of the nuclear arsenals that belong to both the United States and the Soviets. . . . 
 This morning I have signed the execute order taking our strategic bomber force and our Minuteman II missile force off alert status, thereby implementing the first part of the President's decision announced last night.
 Before I get into specifics, I'd like to make a few points that I think need to be emphasized about the President's initiative. First of all, it is, in my opinion, the single biggest change in the deployment of nuclear weapons since they were first integrated into our forces in 1954. It will make the world a safer place. It will allow us to rely more on defenses in the future with respect to our relationship with the Soviet Union.
 These moves also challenge the Soviets, both the central Government and the republics, to do what we're doing by responding with initiatives of their own. If they follow through, as the President called upon them to do, they will not only shrink the world's nuclear arsenal, they will also free themselves of the expensive drag on their economy, which they do not need and cannot afford.
 The President's initiative has two main goals. First of all, it makes the world's arsenal of nuclear weapons significantly smaller and the world safer, and secondly, it gives the Soviets the incentive they need to shift their country away from the business of cranking out nuclear weapons and toward the work of building democracy.
 There is good reason to take these steps now. The world's in a new era of promise that started nearly two years ago with the collapse of the Berlin wall. The Warsaw Pact is history. Soviet forces are pulling out of Eastern Europe. The Soviet Union has reduced its military forces and made those that remain more defensive. And of course, we have recently signed landmark agreements affecting both conventional and strategic systems.
 The defeat of the coup last August by the people of the Soviet Union led to a new form of government in the union, one in which the republics are gaining increased influence over weapons and deployments. This gives an opportunity to move toward a safer, more stable relationship with the new Soviet Union.
 The leaders of the Soviet Union have expressed profound skepticism themselves about the massive strategic nuclear arsenal and the resources that they have continued to invest in maintaining that force. Both Presidents Gorbachev and Yeltsin have talked about their desire to reduce nuclear arsenal. We want to give them an opportunity to do this, to match their words with their deeds.
 The President's program includes initiatives that fall into two broad categories. First, changes in our own force posture and our modernization programs, changes which we are calling on the Soviet Union to match, and second, a set of initiatives which we hope to undertake with the Soviet Union to improve the stability and safety of the nuclear arsenals on both sides.
 The President's proposals were developed in consultation with General Powell, with the Joint Chiefs and myself. These initiatives have our full and unqualified support. They are in fact built on the new defense strategy the President announced in August of 1990, a course the department is already pursuing in its force budget and planning process.
Now on the specifics, let me briefly remind you of the key elements of the President's initiative. . . . The elimination of ground-launched tactical nuclear weapons, the withdrawal of tactical nuclear weapons from our ships at sea, standing down strategic bombers from alert, which we've accomplished this morning, standing down the ICBM's slated for de-activation under Start, canceling the Peacekeeper rail garrison program and the small ICBM mobility program, canceling SRAM II, simplifying our strategic command and control system under a new strategic command, proposing with the Soviets the joint elimination of multiple warhead or MIRVed ICBM's, cooperating with them to permit the deployment of non-nuclear missile defenses, and finally, cooperating on efforts to enhance the safety, security and command and control of the nuclear systems.
I noticed in some of the commentary after the President's speech a lot of talk about how much would be saved. It's important to make a distinction between savings that can be achieved in the short term, which are, as you can see here, not that large, but over the long term, over the lifetime of these programs, we obviously save significant money.
 If we cancel the rail-garrison mode for Peacekeeper, over the life cycle of that program, we save $6.8 billion. So far, we've obligated about $2 billion. The '92 budget request calls for us to spend $260 million on that program.
 If we cancel the mobile part of the small ICBM, again, over the life cycle of the program, we don't have to build the mobile launchers for that system, we save over $11 billion. Savings in '92, $115 million.
 If we cancel the short-range attack missile, SRAM 2, total life cycle cost if we were to build and deploy 700 missiles would have been $2.2 billion. Savings in '92, $177 million.
 Now, again, I cannot say today that we will save precisely that amount of money in fiscal year '92. We've still got a lot of work to do in figuring out what program termination costs are involved, et cetera. But there are over the long term, clearly savings, funds that will not be spent as a result of having canceled these programs.
 
Future Pacts With Soviets
 With respect to our efforts to pursue additional agreements with the Soviets, clearly foremost among those has to do with the agreement to -- or the proposal to eliminate MIRVed ICBM's, multiple land-based ICBM's. We would propose doing this within the context of the protocols established in the Start treaty already. What would be required here is to agree upon a timetable, if agreement can be reached with the Soviets . . .
 The second of the proposals that will require negotiations clearly deals with defenses. We continue to believe that the recent experience in the Gulf, in the Middle East, is a reminder of the importance of being able to deploy defenses against ballistic missiles in the future. While a Patriot system was effective against the limited Iraqi threat, we think it's absolutely essential in the years ahead to develop and to deploy advanced theater missile defenses against the more sophisticated threats we foresee and to be able to defend the United States and our friends and allies and troops deployed overseas against this threat.
 So the President has called upon the Soviet leadership to join with us in finding ways to allow the deployment of non-nuclear defenses against limited ballistic missile strikes. We think this is in the Soviet interest as well as in our own, and we're hopeful that we will be able to accomplish increase in mutual security if we can in fact consummate this proposal.
 The last of the initiatives, of course, has to do with cooperative work on measures to enhance the security of existing nuclear inventories, specifically focusing upon the safe and environmentally sound destruction of those systems upon command and control and upon the safety and security of those systems to insure that they don't fall into the wrong hands or that there are no unauthorized launches.
 I want to emphasize that as we put forward a sweeping package here and move to dramatically change our overall nuclear posture, that here in the department we have carefully considered the consequences of these reductions from the standpoint of being able to maintain the nation's security. I am absolutely confident based upon the work that we have done that we can have confidence that our security and that of our allies is protected even with these initiatives, that we will retain sufficient nuclear forces, and that we are committed to keeping them up to date and effective. The world has changed, but insurance is still a good idea, and under this plan, we believe we will have enough.
 The President's initiatives have set the stage for the Soviets and for the United States to seize a historic opportunity and to assist the Soviet and republic leaders to make some dramatic decisions. We can correct the nuclear risk they face from their own weapons and improve the nuclear relationship we have with the Soviets. We must not wait. We must act now. We are eager and hopeful that we will receive a positive and a reciprocal response from the Soviet Union.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Talks on Arms at Sea
 Q. Mr. Secretary, is it correct that your proposal on the MIRVed ICBM's does not include the sea-based MIRVed ICBM's? And would the Administration be willing to enter into negotiations on that?
 CHENEY: It is correct that the proposal does not include sea-based ballistic missiles. We believe, have consistently argued and continue to argue that those sea-based systems are different than land-based systems; that a land-based missile with multiple warheads on it is a very ripe target for the other side and that there'd be a temptation in a crisis to launch rather than lose that capability.
 Sea-based systems are radically different. They're survivable, they're hidden, no one knows where they are. So it's just a different quality system. If you were to de-MIRV the sea-based leg, you'd also then be in a position where we're going to spend a lot of money buying one submarine that would have 16 missiles on it, each with one warhead. I mean, it gets to be a very expensive way to deploy the force.
 So the proposal is aimed specifically at encouraging the Soviets to reach an agreement with us which would eliminate what we believe is the remaining most destabilizing part of the forces on both sides -- -- that's multiple warhead system. They'd have to give up things like the SS-18. We'd give up things like Peacekeeper, and we'd have to download our Minuteman 3's.
 Q. Mr. Secretary, from their point of view, isn't that they would see that the United States would have an advantage, at least numerically, in the sea-based systems. Why wouldn't they want to engage you in negotiations on that?
 CHENE:Y Well, again, we just completed a lengthy negotiation through Start where the Soviets have in fact signed up for asymmetrical reductions. They have certain capabilities we don't have. They've got land-based mobiles. They've got the SS-25, which they would be able to keep under that proposal.; Iit wouldn't be affected by that proposal at all.
 They've had more of their systems over the years based on land, and we've had more of ours based at sea. But we think within the overall framework of the limitations that are provided for in the Start agreement, that it would be fair and equitable to move in this direction and it would eliminate one of the major sources of instability, which are those multiple warhead, land-based systems.
 
Soviet Control of Arms
 Q. Mr. Secretary, there has been concern in the Soviet Union since the coup and also concern in the United States since the coup about the control of such weapons in the Soviet Union, the fact that they're scattered throughout all the republics. How much of this initiative was based on concern by the United States, by the Administration, of just who has control of Soviet weapons?
 CHENEY: I think it would be fair to say we were confident through the coup, we're confident today, that the Soviets retain centralized control over their systems, that the possibility of an unauthorized launch or unauthorized individuals getting control of a nuclear weapon is relatively small today.
 What we can't be precise about is what kind of arrangements will exist in the future, two or three years from now. Are we concerned about a Soviet Union that is beset by significant difficulties, an area where there may be increased instability and where there are some 27,000 nuclear weapons? Certainly. But I don't think there's any sense of panic involved with that.
 It is an issue we want to address. We believe that we were given an opportunity as a result of the collapse of the coup because the forces in the Soviet Union that would have resisted this kind of package in the past have been discredited, are no longer in positions of authority.
 So we've got a problem, we've got an opportunity, and we think one way to address that is to provide the incentives that we are providing by virtue of our own unilateral actions to encourage the Soviets to do what they have indicated they want to do anyway, which is reduce the size of their stockpile. And General Shaposhnikov, my counterpart, has spoken to the issue, said he's prepared to pursue the elimination of tactical nuclear weapons. This builds on those kinds of sentiments.

HEADLINE: In California, a Big Battle Is Looming Over a Tiny Fish

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28

 BODY:
The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has proposed listing a tiny, nearly translucent fish as a threatened species, setting up what is expected to be another bruising environmental battle in the West.
The fish is the delta smelt, which grows to a length of only three inches and is found almost exclusively in the Upper Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta east of here, California's largest source of water. Scientists say its population has declined by 90 percent in the last 20 years, from 2.6 million to about 200,000. 
 In proposing on Friday that the delta smelt be given threatened-species status, the Fish and Wildlife Service rejected a recommendation from its field office in Sacramento that the fish be listed as endangered, which would have extended even greater protection. But a classification of only "threatened" could have enormous consequences for the water supply of millions of Californians.
The final decision on whether to list the minnow-like fish -- and, if so, what steps to take to protect it -- is not expected for at least a year, after a series of public hearings and Government review, said Gail Kobetich, a Fish and Wildlife biologist who has led a study of the issue. But the cry of agencies that depend on the delta's water is already being heard.
 
Pumping Appears the Problem
 With the help of huge pumps, the delta sends water to thousands of farms and 20 million urban dwellers throughout much of Northern California. To survive, the smelt requires a mixture of saltwater and fresh water, and scientists believe that the decline in its population is due largely to the pumping of too much fresh water from the delta's marshes, an activity that reduces the size of areas that the fish can use as spawning and nursery grounds. In addition, the pumps themselves may be killing large numbers of fish, Federal wildlife officials say.
As a result, it appears that the only way to save the species may be to curtail pumping, which could mean rationing the water that now flows freely from the delta. Andy McLeod, an official with California's Department of Resources, said the potential economic effect of such a reduction was unknown. But Jason Peltiar, manager of the Central Valley Project Water Association, which delivers water to three million urban residents and 20,000 farmers, said Federal protection of the delta smelt would be a "recipe for real disaster" in California water management.

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARM PLAN;
Trust Without Verifying

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
With his new arms control initiative, President Bush has done more than bring the United States nuclear arsenal more in line with the new world realities. He has thrown out the book on arms control.
Without any negotiation with the Soviet Union, under Mr. Bush's plan, 1,300 ground-based American artillery shells and 850 short-range ballistic missile warheads will be withdrawn and destroyed. About 500 nuclear weapons will be removed from ships and submarines at sea. 
 Because of their large numbers, small size and widespread dispersal, these tactical nuclear weapons are considered more difficult to keep under tight control, and the Administration is hoping that its initiative will inspire the Soviet Union to eliminate its tactical arsenal, some of which could fall into the wrong hands as the country fragments.
 
By Example, Not Agreement
 But the Soviet Government was not even informed of Mr. Bush's initiative until the last minute. The Administration plan is to conduct arms control by example, not by agreement: to start withdrawing the weapons and encourage the Soviets to follow suit.
Nor will the removal of thousands of nuclear weapons be subject to the stringent verification measures that Administration officials have previously insisted upon and that were codified in treaties. No inspectors will visit Soviet and American ships to determine that tactical nuclear weapons have been removed or pry into warehouses to see if nuclear artillery shells are hidden there. Ronald Reagan's oft-repeated dictum about arms control agreements was "trust but verify." Mr. Bush's initiative appears to ignore the second half of the prescription.
During the cold war, such an approach to arms control would have been considered beyond the pale. The fear was that the Soviets would pocket any American concessions and never reciprocate.
 
Too Radical, Until Now
 But even as the cold war wound down, the idea of reducing arms without formal negotiations or elaborate verification was considered too radical by most Government officials.
In 1984, Kenneth Adelman, then director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, wrote an article urging a process of informal but reciprocal actions to reduce the superpowers' arsenals, a concept dubbed "arms control without agreements."
George Shultz, Mr. Reagan's Secretary of State, was said to be most unhappy with Mr. Adelman's effort, which he feared could undercut support for moving along the formal arms negotiations with the Russians. But Mr. Adelman is a close acquaintance of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, a principal architect of the Bush Administration proposal, and the ideas voiced in the article echo through the new policy.
What has changed?
It is not that Pentagon officials question the validity of the old approach, which they say was appropriate to its time. Instead, they say that changes in the Soviet Union have made less structured arms control more desirable in many cases.
Under severe economic pressure, the Soviet Union has a motivation to cut its arms like never before. With its central authority on the wane and ethnic strife a common occurrence, the Soviet Government has powerful incentives to gather up and destroy its abundant stockpiles of tactical nuclear weapons. While the Government has control of its stockpiles today, the future poses some risks.
The Pentagon considers the problem too pressing to be dealt with by convening formal negotiations, with their time-consuming procedure of proposals and counterproposals.
Perhaps most important, American officials say, is that the new Soviet reforms mean that the United States need not insist on tough measures, that would have to be agreed on in detailed negotiations, to verify that tactical nuclear arms had in fact been withdrawn.
 
An Understanding
The informal arrangement that the Administration is encouraging is seen as an understanding between partners with a shared interest in preventing accidental or inadvertent war, not as a negotiation with a competitor whose penchant for cheating has to be checked though on-site inspection.
Pentagon officials also say that the changes in the political and social culture of the Soviet Union -- the increasingly independent press, outspoken leaders in the republics and a growing openness about military matters -- make it easier to track military developments and diminish the need for verification by inspectors.
The officials see this as especially true in the case of Soviet tactical nuclear weapons, because they do not have the range to threaten the American nuclear deterrent and are generally old systems, more dangerous to the Soviets themselves than anybody else.
But the United States still plans to carry out inspections of strategic weapons limits under the strategic arms reduction treaty signed this summer, which the White House plans to send to the Senate for approval shortly.
 
Too Much at Stake
 This is not to say that there is no longer a place for formal talks. The Soviet Union, as the Pentagon often points out, is the only nation with the capacity to destroy the United States. There is simply too much at stake in some strategic moves to make them unless they are understood by both sides and carefully scripted in advance. If land-based missiles that carry multiple warheads are to be eliminated, as President Bush proposes, it will be through negotiation. Most likely this would be done as an amendment, or side agreement, to the newly completed strategic arms reduction pact.
The Bush Administration also wants to engage the Soviets in talks on the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, to amend it to allow more than one site for ground-based interceptors, as well as a limited deployment of space-based interceptors. The aim would be to deploy an anti-missile system that would defend against an accidental launch, or small attack, without invalidating the Soviet nuclear deterrent.
Such a system would be a far cry from Mr. Reagan's vision of making nuclear weapons impotent and obsolete. But it would entail additional spending on the part of the United States and the cash-strapped Soviet Union. While the Administration hopes for Soviet concurrence it has pointedly not ruled out going it alone if Moscow balks at the idea of building new anti-missile defenses.
But even with these important qualifications, Mr. Cheney was not minimizing the importance of the new approach on eliminating ground-based tactical arms, removing tactical nuclear weapons from ships at sea and reducing the alert rates of strategic forces.
"We clearly, in terms of moving unilaterally, have taken a different approach than I would have advocated even a few months ago," Mr. Cheney said. "And that involves specifically unilateral acts that we hope the Soviets will reciprocate."
"I think the prospects now for the Soviets responding are far brighter than they've ever been before," he said, "and we think we can avoid the kind of long, drawn-out negotiations that have so often in the past resulted in delays actually in taking down systems while both sides waited to see what they could get for taking down those systems during the course of negotiations."

HEADLINE: Zaire Leader to Take Foes Into Coalition

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 28 (AP)

 BODY:
President Mobutu Sese Seko and opposition leaders agreed today to form a coalition government after five days of rioting that led French and Belgian troops to evacuate foreigners.
It was the first time in the 26 years of Mr. Mobutu's rule that he had agreed to share power with the opposition in this Central African country. The collapse of the former Belgian colony's economy, brought on in part by widespread corruption, weakened his grip on power. 
 France, another former colonial power in Africa that maintains a major role on the continent, said it refused to provide aid unless Mr. Mobutu agreed to the new government.
 
Government of National Crisis
 More talks were scheduled for Sunday, when ministers were to be named for the so-called government of national crisis.
Paris began scaling back its military forces but indicated that it might leave troops in the country after the evacuation of Americans and other foreigners who wished to go. Hundreds continued to fly out today.
The meeting at Mr. Mobutu's marble presidential palace marked his first talks with the opposition since mutinous soldiers led bloody rioting on Monday and Tuesday in Kinshasa that spread to other parts of the country.
At least 60 people died in Kinshasa, but the real figure could be three times higher. At least 1,750 people were wounded, said the Paris-based relief agency Doctors Without Borders.
A French paratrooper was the only foreigner confirmed to have been killed.
French and Belgians held key points of Kinshasa today, and the city was mostly calm. Kinshasa's international airport, controlled by the European soldiers, reopened to civilian traffic on Friday.
During his five-hour meeting with the opposition, Mr. Mobutu, 66 years old, also agreed that a national conference on democratic reforms that broke up in bitterness earlier this month could reconvene on Tuesday.
 
New Prime Minister Expected
 It was expected that Etienne Tshisekedi, leader of the opposition group Union for Democracy and Social Progress, would be named Prime Minister on Sunday.
Mr. Tshisekedi, 58, was interior minister before Mr. Mobutu seized power in a military coup in 1965.
He refused the job of Prime Minister when Mr. Mobutu offered it in July, saying it held no real power. But today he said he would accept.
France and Belgium, aided by American military transport planes, have sent 1,750 soldiers to Zaire to evacuate foreign nationals. The French Ambassador, Henri Rethore, indicated for the first time today that France might leave a military detachment in the country for up to two weeks after foreigners were removed.
"It depends on the evolution of the situation," Mr. Rethore told reporters. "We are here for the short term. There will be a number of French soldiers maintained in the coming days, and our presence is going to depend on the process that is undertaken."
Nearly 8,000 expatriates, including hundreds of Americans, have been evacuated since the French and Belgian troops began arriving on Tuesday.
The French Foreign Ministry announced the shipment of 40 tons of rice, cooking oil and flour to the capital to ease food shortages.

HEADLINE: For Americans and Filipinos, Basics of Life Are at Stake in Fate of Navy Base

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SUBIC, the Philippines, Sept. 25

 BODY:
Their memories of the base are starkly different, but the American sailors who lived or took liberty at the Subic Bay Naval Station and the thousands of Filipinos who repaired the American warships and swept the Americans' floors agree that a way of life is in jeopardy.
"Subic is paradise," said Robert Buttrey, a ruddy-faced 49-year-old retired Navy Seabee from Framingham, Mass., who married a Filipino he met while on duty at Subic, settled his family near the large American naval base and now owns an off-base saloon that bears his nickname, Bubba. 
 "But if the base goes," he said, taking another gulp of pale Philippine beer that retired Navy men insist is the only protection from the effects of these long, steamy nights in the tropics, "well, then this will all become a ghost town."
A few blocks away, up a rain-soaked stairway to the converted second-floor discotheque that now serves as a union hall, the threat by the Philippine Government to oust the United States Navy from the base has, it seems, become the only topic of conversation among the more than 20,000 Filipino civilian workers employed at the base.
Roberto Flores, the president of the union, the Federation of Filipino Civilian Employees, was hired as a utility man by the base in 1964, at age 19, at the equivalent of 49 cents an hour.
He said he remembered the days when the Americans "didn't even treat us like human beings" -- disciplining or dismissing Filipino workers with insufficient cause, forbidding Filipinos to speak their native language, routinely breaking into the storage lockers ofFilipino employees on the pretense of searching for stolen goods.
"They could be very rude," Mr. Flores said of the Americans. "There were many abuses when I first arrived at the base."
 
Decline in Discrimination
 Yet in the 20 years since the introduction of collective bargaining at Subic, "things have become much better," he said, insisting that most of his union's members bore no lingering resentment over the harsh treatment of Filipinos decades ago.
"The admirals at the base will act when we bring them complaints of discrimination," he said. "We want the Americans to stay. These are some of the best jobs in the Philippines."
The union represents every type of civilian worker at the base, from mechanics and secretaries to the teams of Filipino janitors who, for most of the last three months, have been sweeping up the tons of volcanic ash dumped on the base in June by nearby Mount Pinatubo.
Virtually all of the Filipino workers will find themselves without jobs if Subic is shut down, a fate they would share with thousands of other Filipinos who were employed by the United States Air Force at Clark Air Base, which was abandoned after the ash buried its runways, 50 miles southwest of here.
 
Reprieve for Life Style
 Whatever their reasons -- for the Americans, trying to protect a military life style of almost legendary bounty and comfort; for the Filipinos, maintaining economic survival in an impoverished nation -- there is the oft-stated hope here that somehow the Subic Bay Naval Station, at 14,400-acres the largest American military base in Asia, will be allowed to remain open.
It appears that their wish will be granted, at least temporarily.
In what many of its members described as a long-postponed demonstration of sovereignty, the Philippine Senate voted last week to reject a new American lease on the base.
But President Corazon C. Aquino, a proponent of the base, effectively overruled the Senate when she withdrew a year-old eviction notice on Subic and called for a national referendum on its future.
 
2,000 Retired U.S. Seamen
 The possibility that the Navy will remain has produced some cheer in the neon-flooded bars and dance halls of Olongapo and Subic, cities that border the base and cater almost exclusively to the American military and to a community of retired American seamen that is said to number about 2,000.
Several beers closer to sunrise, a small group of the retired sailors was still gathered in an Olongapo bar called the Watering Hole, swapping stories about what had made Subic Bay, to their minds, the most desirable post anywhere in the United States Navy.
"It's been said that this is an adult Disneyland," said Martin Tubbs, a 50-year-old retired warrant officer from Houston who is the manager of the bar, which also serves as Branch 213 of the Fleet Reserve Association, an organization of mostly retired American sailors. He does not quibble with the Disney comparison.
"I first saw Subic in 1961, when I was a 20-year-old sailor, and I loved it," Mr. Tubbs recalled wistfully, remembering a time when Subic had a reputation as one of the wildest liberty ports in Asia, a reputation that grew to legend when American warships docked here during the Vietnam War.
"I retired two years ago from the Navy and went to Los Angeles," he said. "But after a while, I decided I had to come back here to live, because my friends were here and because the life is so good."
For generations of American sailors, he said, Subic had made possible a way of life that could never be duplicated on a Navy salary back home: Spacious houses with what are now $20-a-week maids; private white-sand beaches along the bay dotted with private cabanas and gently swaying palms; stables and horse trails close to the pristine shoreline; privileges at a well-manicured, professional-quality 18-hole golf course, and a seemingly endless supply of available women and cheap beer.
There are other American naval bases in Japan and on the Pacific islands of Guam and Okinawa; but they have fewer amenities, and many American sailors consider the living costs there prohibitively high.
"Subic is the only place I've ever been where the beer is cheaper off base than on," Mr. Tubbs said.
For married sailors and their families, the base has long offered fine schools and every sort of entertainment, including movie theaters and several Government-subsidized restaurants. There is a McDonald's and two outlets of Baskin Robbins Ice Cream, which are closed for now because of damage from the volcanic ash.
 
Men Love It, Women Hate It
 "Despite all the advantages, I still don't think the wives of American sailors ever looked on Subic as a good assignment," said John J. Stauffer, an industrial arts teacher at the base's George Dewey High School, named for the American admiral who defeated the Spanish fleet in Manila Bay in 1898.
"Subic's reputation has always been that the men love it and the women hate it," said Mr. Stauffer, who has been teaching at the base for 25 years, and who has seen many Navy marriages ruined when an American sailor became enchanted with one of the Filipinas employed as hostesses at the honky-tonk bars and dance clubs, with names like Love Disco and Hot Lips, that surround the base.
"I can think of maybe a dozen different families in which I first taught a sailor's American children and then, maybe 10 years later, I taught his second set of kids by a new Filipino wife," Mr. Stauffer said.
There are so many marriages between Filipinas and American sailors at Subic, as many as 15 a week, that the Navy sponsors what is known as the bride school, a series of seminars on American culture for the wives-to-be.
 
Intermarriage and Bias
 John Godard, a 34-year-old Navy operations specialist at the base who is married to a Filipina, said he thought the frequency of American-Filipino marriages had "helped prevent discrimination against Filipinos from becoming a big problem."
I think the Filipinos really like us, and we like them so much that we marry them," he said.
At the union hall, Domingo A. Jadloc, a 37-year-old Filipino who is a crane inspector on the base, said he had come to believe that after working at Subic for more than a decade that "there are two kinds of Americans, one type that causes problems for the Filipinos, another type that wants to solve the problems."
"There is still discrimination," he said, recalling a recent incident in which an American supervisor on the base called together Filipino employees and told them in so many words that "I am the boss, the Americans are the leaders, and the Filipinos are the followers."
Yet he said incidents of discrimination had become increasingly rare. "I have many good friends who are Americans," Mr. Jadloc said. "They come to my house, I go to theirs."
 
Top Pay From the Navy
 The United States Navy is a much-desired employer in the Philippines, where the per capita annual income is less than $700, making it one of the poorest nations in Southeast Asia.
At Subic Bay, the average salary for Filipino civilian workers is about 35 pesos an hour, or about $1.30, double or triple what most people earn in the cities that adjoin the base.
"Subic is our bread and water," said Mr. Jadloc, who supports a wife and four children on what is, by Philippine standards, a handsome salary of about $5,000 a year.
"If the base closes, I will have to find work outside my country, maybe in Australia or Canada," he said. "I would say 99.9 percent of the workers at the base want the Americans to stay. There are no other jobs like this in the Philippines for me."

Sailors patronized a bar in Olongapo in 1985. The city caters to the military and a community of about 2,000 retired American seamen. (Susan Meiselas/Magnum Photos)

HEADLINE: Bush's Arm Plan;
Cheney Orders Bombers Off Alert, Starting Sharp Nuclear Pullback

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ordered the military today to put into effect President Bush's plan to eliminate about 2,400 short-range nuclear weapons on land and sea in Europe and Asia, a move that could save $20 billion over the next two decades.
Under the directive, Mr. Cheney also ordered that long-range bombers and some long-range missiles end their 24-hour alert, and that several nuclear missile programs be canceled. 
 The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell, who spoke with Mr. Cheney at a joint news conference this morning, said the first step -- removing 40 long-range bombers fueled, equipped and armed with "several hundred" nuclear weapons off alert status -- would be done by the end of the day. [Excerpts, page 12.]
General Powell said it would take only 24 hours to reverse the order, if ever needed, as he and Mr. Cheney provided additional details on Mr. Bush's surprise announcement on Friday night in which he outlined the most one-sided nuclear arms cuts taken since the onset of Soviet-American nuclear rivalry in the postwar years.
A senior Pentagon official said the entire process of removing the tactical nuclear weapons -- storing some and destroying others -- could take between 18 months and three years to complete. While the military might ultimately save as much as $1.5 billion a year in weapons costs, procurement experts said the short-term expense of paying termination costs to military contractors could reach $500 million in the next two years.
 
U.S. Team to Brief Soviets
 The Administration's cuts reflect the quickly changing geopolitical landscape, with the fall of Soviet control in Eastern Europe and the weakening of the Soviet Union, the foe against which America's arsenal was always aimed.
In his speech Mr. Bush called on the Soviet Union to respond in kind by also getting rid of its short-range nuclear arms.
Indeed, after a conversation with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union on Friday, President Bush said today that he would send a team of American experts to the Soviet Union to review details of his plan. Administration officials did not disclose the team members or their backgrounds.
Mr. Cheney said the two main goals of the President's plan "makes the world's arsenal of nuclear weapons significantly smaller" and "gives the Soviets the incentive they need to shift their country away from the business of cranking out nuclear weapons and toward the work of building democracy."
"Given their collapsing economy, they really have no choice but to significantly cut back on their military capabilities," said Mr. Cheney.
 
Destroying 1,300 Shells
 The Administration plan drastically reduces the number of short-range nuclear weapons on land and at sea in Europe and Asia. The weapons, with ranges of 10 to 70 miles, were developed in the 1950's as a battlefield weapon to counter the numerical superiority of the Soviet ground forces.
Under Mr. Bush's plan, the United States would destroy 1,300 nuclear-tipped artillery shells and 850 Lance missiles, rockets with ranges of about 70 miles. About 1,700 of the 2,150 weapons are in Europe and will be sent home to be dismantled, Mr. Cheney said. The artillery shells include 155-millimeter shells and two types of eight-inch shells. The howitzer launchers will also be destroyed.
About 500 nuclear bombs and depth charges will be taken off ships and attack submarines, and about half will be destroyed once sent home, Mr. Cheney said. Among the weapons, the approximately 100 Tomahawk cruise missiles at sea will be removed and stockpiled for future use.
Several hundred older nuclear depth bombs for Navy anti-submarine planes will also be eliminated.
 
Bombers Off Alert
 The order also calls the nation's strategic bomber force -- 40 of the 280 planes are always on 24-hour readiness -- off alert. The fleet of B-52's and B-1B's are stationed at 12 Air Force bases. Maintenance crews will reclaim the planes, remove the weapons for storage and return the planes to a normal schedule, Mr. Cheney said.
Mr. Cheney's order set in motion several actions to cancel or speed the dismantling of an older long-range missile as well as several other strategic weapons being developed.
The 450 single-warhead Minuteman 2 missiles scheduled to be deactivated under the Start treaty, will be taken off alert status immediately. Mr. Cheney said the missiles would be dismantled once the treaty is ratified, probably sometime early next year, rather than when the full reductions of the pact take effect in seven years.
 
Savings Seen in 3 Years
 Mr. Cheney said that by canceling three strategic programs in development, the Pentagon would save as much as $20 billion over the expected life of the program.
The director of the Defense Budget Project, Gordon Adams, a nonpartisan research organization here, said that would amount to about $1 billion to $1.5 billion a year over 15 to 20 years. But he said the savings would represent less than 1 percent of the Pentagon's budget in those years.
Mr. Adams said any savings would not be achieved for two or three years, after the Pentagon paid military contractors $500 million estimated to be the termination costs.
Under Mr. Cheney's directive, the United States would cancel the following programs:
*The mobile portion of the MX missile system -- 50 missiles with 10 warheads each -- saving $6.8 billion over the life of the program. The missiles would remain in silos rather than be put on rail cars that could be dispersed in a nuclear attack.
*The mobile portion of the single-warhead Midgetman system, 300 truck-carried launchers, saving $11.2 billion.
*The short-range attack missile -- SRAM-2 -- which would be fired by bombers to blast holes in Soviet air defenses and attack other targets. A version of the missiles was to have deployed in Europe to build up American nuclear capabilities there. The Pentagon estimated savings from terminating the program at $2.2 billion.
 
New Strategic Command
 But the Bush Administation has not ruled out the possiblity of developing a new air-to-ground nuclear-tipped missile. Given public pressures now that is unlikely to happen, arms-control experts said.
Mr. Cheney also directed General Powell to create a new United States Strategic Command, which would assume operational control over strategic nuclear weapons now assigned separately to the Air Force and the Navy.
The new command, to be based in Omaha, would supplant the Strategic Air Command there now. The command of American nuclear forces would alternate between a four-star Navy admiral and Air Force general.
 
Talks on MX
 While not included in Mr. Cheney's order to the military chiefs today, President Bush's plan also calls for Washington and Moscow to enter talks aimed at eliminating ground-based long-range ballistic missiles.
Under such a proposal, negotiators would build off the recently signed strategic arms treaty, which reduces the long-range arsenals of both countries by about one-third, to reduce the number of warheads each missile could carry.
After the strategic arms treaty, the United States, for instance, would still retain about 2,000 warheads on 550 launchers. If talks were successful, Mr. Cheney said, the MX missiles with their 500 warheads would no longer be deployed, leaving 500 Minuteman 3 missiles with three warheads each. Going to a single-warhead missile would drop the total to 500 warheads on 500 missiles, he said.
The Pentagon would also seek technical cooperation with the Soviets on the safety and security of nuclear weapons -- a key concern since the failed coup. Tightened command and control procedures over the weapons, and environmentally sound methods of dismantling and destroying them, would also be discussed.
General Powell said that with the threat of a conventional Soviet attack on Europe gone, the unilateral reductions in tactical nuclear forces made sense.
 
Better Conventional Arms
 "We believe this is a very sound package that enhances the security of the United States," said General Powell, who met with Mr. Bush and the four service chiefs at the White House Friday morning to discuss the plan.
The increasingly lethal nature of United States conventional arms -- from the stealthy F-117 to precision-guided bombs -- has bolstered the argument in military circles that the short-range nuclear weapons were outdated.
"Increased capability associated with conventional weaponry in recent years has, to some extent, inclined us in the direction of getting rid of tactical nuclear weapons," said General Powell.
Although the United States has taken the first step in slashing its mobile and harder-to-control nuclear bombs and missiles, President Bush and his advisers today renewed their pledge to modernizing what remains of the nation's land, sea and air nuclear triad.
 
Avoiding Cuts by Congress
 If anything, arms-control specialists said, the Administration has created with its actions an environment that it hopes will ward off attempts in Congress to make deeper cuts in its two prized strategic programs, the Stealth bomber and the anti-missile defense system, "Star Wars."
Mr. Cheney reaffirmed support for the Administration's plan to open talks with the Soviets to allow five or six ground-based sites to position anti-missile missile launchers, and later develop space-based sensors. The existing anti-ballistic treaty bans sensors in space and permits only one ground launching site.

HEADLINE: Small-Town South Clings to Jewish History

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT GIBSON, Miss.

 BODY:
There's just one sour note in the small miracle that occurred here when Temple Gemiluth Chassed, the 100-year-old Moorish-Byzantine synagogue on Church Street, was saved from the wrecking ball and lovingly restored.
Port Gibson has no Jewish community left to worship there. 
 As Jews around the world celebrated their heritage over the recent holidays, one of the most unusual chapters in that history was winding down in small Southern towns like Port Gibson, once home to perhaps 60 Jewish families. In dozens of small towns like it, a hybrid culture of matzo ball gumbo and kosher grits flourished and then disappeared as young people left for the cities, never to return.
 
Years Too Late
 Efforts are now being made to salvage the artifacts and memories of the Dixie Diaspora in small towns from Pontotoc, Miss., to Donaldsonville, La., to Blytheville, Ark.
"We're trying to save it before it disppears, but we're already 20 or 30 years too late," said Macy B. Hart, who heads the two-year-old Museum of the Southern Jewish Experience in nearby Utica, Miss., and whose own parents are the only Jews in Winona, Miss.
"We have many communities that are down to one or three or five Jewish people left," he said, "and they have the weight of maybe 100 years of community on their shoulders.
"So what we're moved to do is to help those communities go from extant to extinct with dignity, so we don't lose it all."
Mr. Hart is used to puzzled stares from people at the thought of Jews in the small-town South. But Jews were among the earliest settlers in the region and were integral parts of its history.
Eli N. Evans, who grew up the son of a Jewish shopkeeper in Durham, N.C., when it was a small tobacco town and who later wrote "The Provincials: A Personal History of the Jews in the South" (Atheneum, 1973), said: "Jews were not aliens in the promised land. They were blood and bones, part of the story, and they've been part of the story all along."
There is no single story of Jewish immigration to the South. Jews came from across Europe with the earliest settlers in the 1700's, landing directly in Charleston, S.C., Savannah, Ga., or New Orleans, and from New York and other Northern cities after the great Jewish migrations of the 19th century.
But if there is a dominant theme it is the story of Jewish merchants -- first peddlers and then shop owners -- who helped create a merchant class in the rural South and then saw their communities wither and die as their children left.
"The story of the Jews in the South, at least a major part of it, is the story of fathers who built businesses for their sons who did not want them," Mr. Evans said.
That story played out in Port Gibson earlier than in the region as a whole, but its outlines are familiar.
The first Jews came to Port Gibson in the 1840's from German states and Alsace-Lorraine. They were itinerant peddlers, carrying their wares in 75-pound packs on their backs. Then, as Port Gibson began competing with Vicksburg and Natchez in both commerce and the glory of its antebellum homes, the Jewish community became a bulwark of the town's economy, and newspaper advertisements were filled with names like Bernheimer, Marx, Meyer, Cahn, Traxler and Ullman.
 
A Moorish Dome
 In 1859 congregation Gemiluth Chassed, a name that can be roughly translated as House of Kindness, was formed by 22 members, meeting at the Odd Fellows Hall and Masons' Lodge. In 1889, its leaders called for the building of a temple, saying, "Our Christian fellow-citizens often ask why the Israelites have no church."
By 1892 they had built a distinctive brick synagogue with stained glass windows and an incongruous Moorish dome. It was a centerpiece of a community life that was at once discreetly separate and distinctly Southern, like a Jewish ladies' Japanese lunch at which, according to a report in the local paper in 1902, Rosa Marx was awarded a beautiful gauze fan as the most popular young lady.
But Port Gibson's population, now about 2,400, peaked around the beginning of the century. Soon the Jewish children began leaving for Memphis or New Orleans or Baton Rouge, and stores began passing out of Jewish hands.
A building on Main Street still bears a sign reading H. Frishman-Red Goose Shoes, but the building is now occupied by Mississippi: Cultural Crossroads, a community center mostly serving the town's predominantly black youth.
Mr. Hart said the disappearance of the Jewish communities reflects both the economic decline of many Southern small towns and the traditional educational aspirations of many Jews.
 
Unlikely Saviors
 The last services were conducted in the synagogue in 1978, and it was scheduled to be demolished for a parking lot for the adjacent gas station in 1987 when it found saviors in Bill and Martha Lum, he a Methodist, she a Catholic. The two, who both grew up on cotton plantations, bought the synagogue and are restoring it. Its 100th anniversary will be marked by a celebration on Oct. 20.
"It's part of the heritage of this town, and we just couldn't stand to see it destroyed," Mr. Lum said. "The Jewish heritage is deep rooted here, and that's where we all come from, after all, back to Abraham."
In nearby Natchez, home of one of the grandest small-town synagogues, members of the dwindling Jewish community has turned the deed to their synagogue over to Mr. Hart's museum so it can be preserved when the community can no longer care for it.
Once 141 families, the community is down to 18 people, mostly elderly, with one school-age child.
"We joke and say the average age of our congregation is extinct," said Jerry Krouse, who drives his daughter, Keely, 100 miles each way to Sunday school in Baton Rouge each week.
 
Relics of an Era
 Much of the culture that is already gone can be seen at Mr. Hart's museum, which was built after receiving a $500,000 grant in 1986 from the Plough Foundation of Memphis. It is on the grounds of Union of American Hebrew Congregations' Henry S. Jacobs Camp, which serves children and adults in Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, Alabama and western Tennessee.
Among its exhibits are Ner Tamids or eternal lights, from defunct synagogues in Port Gibson, Laurel, Miss., and El Dorado, Ark. There is a pulpit from a synagogue in Jackson, Miss., a majestic oak ark from a synagogue built in 1868 in Vicksburg and Torahs from Laurel, Port Gibson and Greenwood, Miss.
And there are photographs and artifacts that dramatize the passing of an era: the synagogue in Donaldsonville that is now an Ace Hardware store; the synagogue in Morgan City, La., that was later used as a Mormon church; the signs of Jewish business that were once fixtures of small-town squares throughout the South.
 
Jews Found Respect
 That disappearing culture is quite different from what outsiders might have expected. There was anti-Semitism in the South to be sure. The most infamous case was that of Leo Frank, an Atlanta Jew who was convicted of murder and lynched in 1915 for the killing of a young girl. He was posthumously pardoned in 1986 after evidence indicated he was innocent.
But many experts say the South was attractive to Jews because the religious fundamentalists there were respectful of Jews, whom they viewed as "the people of the Book," in contrast to attitudes in the urban North.
"I maintain the Leo Frank case was an aberration," said Louis Schmier, a history professor at Valdosta State College in Georgia who is writing a book about Jews in Georgia. "There was anti-Semitism, but the majority of the Christian population admired their Jewishness and almost demanded it of them."
He recalls a story from Unadilla, Ga., where city officials were upset that a local Jewish businessman kept his store open during the Jewish holidays.
"He was told by the Mayor the City Council was going to pass an ordinance demanding that he close because if he was going to be accorded the respect of being a Jew, he had to act like one," Professor Schmier said.
 
Assimilation vs. Distinctiveness
 More common than overt discrimination was a delicate dance between assimilation and distinctiveness. Mr. Evans remembers an affecting chapter of his grandmother's diary entitled, "The Loneliest Days Were Sundays" about the feeling of separateness that pervaded small-town life.
For many, the solution was intermarriage and the dissolution of Jewish identity. For others, like Mr. Hart, who well remembers the isolation of small-town Jews, the result was a fierce need to reclaim a Jewish identity.
Often, the contradictions are never quite resolved.
After meeting with the Lums at the synagogue, Mr. Hart had lunch with Celia Starnes, one of two descendants of the Jewish community left in town.
Mrs. Starnes is married to a Baptist but wears a gold necklace with her first name in Hebrew. She does not go to synagogue, but when Mr. Hart asked if she was observant she answered, "In my heart I am." She said the salvation of the temple was "the answer to all my prayers."
And though her children were not raised as Jews and the three oldest are practicing Baptists, she said she thought her youngest daughter, who lives in Jackson, was open to Judaism. At least she hopes so.
"I think she's Jewish by instinct," she said.
