HEADLINE: New Goal for New York: Tourist-Friendly Image

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Imagine a day when tourists arriving at New York airports might actually have a pleasant experience, even if they speak no English. The baggage cart might be free, instead of requiring a $1.50 deposit before anyone has even had a chance to get to a currency- exchange window.
There might be signs in the terminal in other languages giving foreign visitors a clue what to do next. They might not face a barrage of aggressive offers from often-illegal taxi drivers eager to take them for long rides into New York. And as they gaze out their taxi windows at the city's glorious skyline, they might not find themselves distracted by mounds of litter collecting on marginally grassy strips along the road. 
 Call them dreamers, but a group of the city's most prominent business executives, along with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, are determined to make that vision a reality. Tommorrow they will announce a new program called Gateway America, which is intended to make New York City, yes, a nicer place to visit.
The program comes not a moment too soon. Tourism is weak throughout the United States this year, and the New York region is suffering at least as much as other areas. Airport arrivals are down 11 percent compared with last year, and Broadway attendance is off by about the same percentage.
To make matters worse, other cities and states are responding with ambitious ad campaigns promoting their areas, and many of those campaigns are targeted at foreign visitors who have traditionally been one of New York's most important and most reliable markets.
"There is significant competition from other parts of the country," said the chairman of the group, Robert Nederlander, also the chairman of the Broadway-based Nederlander Organization and the managing general partner of the New York Yankees. "We have an advantage, and we should take care of that advantage."
The object is to improve visitors' first impressions of the New York region and to make it easier for them to avail themselves of cultural, entertainment and other opportunities. The motives are hardly altruistic. Stanley Brezenoff, executive director of the Port Authority, estimates that if the program brings 10 percent more tourists to the area, it could pump $1.5 billion into the economy at a time when that is sorely needed..
"Tourism is one of the principal engines of the economy in this region," he said.
 
Information Kiosks
 The goals of the Gateway America committee are ambitious. If its initiative is fully carried out, foreigners arriving at local airports will be able to go to information kiosks where friendly people speaking several languages will offer brochures detailing the week or month's cultural events. Interactive videos will give arriving passengers a further inkling of available activities.
Instead of getting hopelessly lost on buses or subways, visitors will be able to read transportation signs in several foreign languages. If they choose to take taxis, their drivers will have received training in the importance of being polite and hospitable. And their rides into the city will be much more pleasant: The sides of the roadways will be cleaned up, and possibly -- gasp -- even beautified.
Once they have settled in, the visitors will find that their hotels also have foreign-language brochures listing current events. And the hotel staffs will have received friendliness training. There will be more currency-exchange locations across the city, and they will be noted on maps.
If visitors get lost, police officers in tourist areas will be able to look up addresses and phone numbers in an updated guidebook that will be distributed through the police force. The police, too, will have been trained in the importance of assisting visitors.
It is a tall order for a group that has been allocated just $225,000 of seed money by the Port Authority. The hope is that the stature of those involved will get the effort off the ground.
Besides Mr. Nederlander, others on the executive board are Mr. Brezenoff; Howard Stringer, president of broadcast news at CBS; Lewis Rudin, president of the real-estate firm, Rudin Management, and Martin Segal, head of the New York International Festival of the Arts.
Without much financial backing, the leaders of this group expect to encourage others in business and government to make certain their goals are implemented. Mr. Brezenoff has committed his authority to making sure there are kiosks at airports and more signs in foreign languages. The police, hotels and taxi-driver groups can begin hospitality training without great expense, he said. And banks will want to introduce more currency-exchange locations in their own interests.
"There has to be an effort to get everybody in the businesses that touch travelers -- whether it's hotels, taxis, theaters or banks -- to be more aware that they have to go beyond what they normally do to make visitors feel more welcome," Mr. Rudin said.
 
No Goods to Declare
 Mr. Rudin helped found the original Gateway Improvement task force, which was established in 1983. Among the results of that task force was an improved customs and immigration area at Kennedy International Airport and the familiar red-green system through which international passengers arriving with no goods to declare can pass without inspection.
An area where significant financing is needed is in the cleaning up of highways from the airports. Mr. Rudin acknowledges that the city's budget is tight and that efforts to get corporations to adopt portions of the roadways have so far not met with great success.
Despite some obvious limitations, the new initiative is likely to be welcomed. "It's a good no-frills effort," said Mitchell Moss, a professor of urban planning at New York University's Wagner School of Public Service. "It will bring New York into the 20th century."

HEADLINE: As More Tiny Infants Live, Choices and Burden Grow

SERIES: Smallest Survivors: Dilemmas of Prematurity/First of three articles.

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The baby in the plastic case lies swathed in a Mickey Mouse blanket whose cartoon characters dwarf him in size. One month after birth, he has already suffered major bleeding in his head, requiring brain surgery, and still needs a respirator to breathe. Born almost four months prematurely, weighing just over a pound, the baby is sustained by a battery of tubes and machines.
His skin is thin as parchment and his eyes are sealed shut, but he is clearly a human child. A minuscule blue and white stocking cap prevents heat loss through his head. 
 "Could you turn off the respirator on this baby?" asked Dr. Harry Dweck, director of neonatal intensive care at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. "Could you? I couldn't. If his parents asked me to do it, I'd go to court."
 
Life at $2,000 a Day
 Intensive care for premature infants is now keeping alive more and more infants born very early in pregnancy. But the cost is immense -- more than $2,000 a day -- and the emotional burden on parents immeasurable. Many surviving infants who weigh less than 750 grams, about 1 pound, 10 ounces, at birth turn out to have physical or mental disabilities, but there is no reliable way at present to predict the outcome. For doctors and parents the treatment of these babies thus creates ever more difficult economic and ethical dilemmas.
Dr. Dweck says he has seen infants like his patient become normal children, although he admits the chances that the survivors will be normal are less than 1 in 4.
The remainder suffer brain damage. "Some are handicapped and are a great burden to their families and to society," Dr. Dweck said, a note of sadness in his voice. It is a price he considers worth paying, and he never pulls the plug if there is a remote chance that treatment will help.
Fifty miles away, at the neonatal intensive care unit at University Hospital of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, Dr. Leonard Kleinman adopts a more pragmatic approach. "If a baby survives a major head bleed, we'll tell the parents he is almost surely going to be damaged and he's suffering a great deal and we don't think we should do anything more," said Dr. Kleinman, the hospital's director of neonatal intensive care.
Although health care economists have recently focused their attention on intensive care for the elderly, in fact most hospitals spend far more treating the very very young. The stakes are higher, too, since a premature baby who survives intact gains a lifetime, while an infant who survives with terrible damage may require decades worth of high-cost care. To complicate matters, the most premature infants, the ones who can run up bills close to half a million dollars, are also the least likely to be helped.
Doctors and parents who must weigh these vexing options have found no uniform answer. So the baby who is kept in intensive care for months at one hospital might be allowed to die at birth elsewhere.
"It's a matter of style," said Dr. Alan Fleischman, director of neonatal intensive care at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, noting that some doctors feel they must treat 100 babies aggressively if there is a chance of saving 1. "I don't buy that: creating 1 normal child by creating 99 who are handicapped and disabled.
"We argue endlessly about which is worse: a healthy baby in heaven or a damaged baby on earth," he said. "I say neither is good, but we're going to make mistakes in both directions." Dr. Fleischman said he believed the major problem today was that babies who will not benefit from intensive care are overtreated, even when the parents do not want aggressive care.
 
The Costs
Care More Costly Than New Heart
 Premature infants stay in high-tech wombs for about the same length of time that they should have remained in their mother's: four months for the most premature, who are born at 24 weeks gestation and weigh in the neighborhood of 500 grams, or slightly over a pound. "Above 700 grams there is a clearly a great benefit to intensive care," Dr. Fleischman said. Below 700 grams, or about 1 pound, 8 ounces, things get murky. Many of the very low-birth-weight babies succumb to lung failure or severe bleeding in the brain, since these organs have not fully matured.
Dr. Michael Rie, an intensive care specialist at the University of Kentucky in Lexington, said, "The hundred highest users of Medicaid dollars in each state are preemies who end up for months on ventilators and end up with cerebral bleeds and extremely lousy outcomes."
For insurance reimbursement, the New York State Department of Health considers infants weighing below 750 grams to be the most expensive type of patient to care for, three times as costly as a person with serious burns and 20 percent more costly than even a heart transplant patient.
Almost 50 percent of babies born weighing from 500 to 750 grams, or 1 pound, 2 ounces to 1 pound, 10 ounces, will survive and, of these, the majority will have neurological damage. From 750 grams to 1,500 grams, 3 pounds, 5 ounces, about 85 percent will live and the great majority will have no impairment. Above 1,500 grams, which has historically defined the upper boundary of very low-birth-weight infants, babies have an excellent chance of emerging from intensive care fully intact.
In contrast, just 10 years ago, it was a rare child born under 1 pound, 8 ounces who even survived, and before the early 1970's, when neonatal intensive care units began operating, few children under 2 pounds survived. But as advances allow medicine to save more and more babies, the demand for neonatal intensive care has risen and existing units are bursting at the seams. Babies born prematurely to women who use crack or have had no prenatal care have swelled the demand.
As a result, most neonatal intensive care units have removed walls to squeeze in a few more beds, and hired nurses to work overtime. Most operate at more than 100 percent of their licensed capacity.
Dr. Dweck, whose intensive care unit serves five counties north of New York City, said he had to turn away 250 babies each year.
 
The Caretakers
For Some, Home Will Be Hospital
 While pediatricians say that babies in need ultimately find a hospital that can squeeze them in, the crunch has led some to call for more public financing and others for a more "rational" use of existing beds.
"Last week there was a 900-gram baby at a community hospital who we knew we could help, but we were horribly overcrowded," Dr. Kleinman said. "Meanwhile, we had a preemie with severe brain damage who hadn't moved in three weeks taking one of our beds. I'm not sure that's fair."
Some beds are occupied for months or years by the growing number of severely brain-damaged children or children on respirators who, saved from death in the intensive care unit, are too chronically ill to go home, or even move to a regular hospital bed.
A 1990 New York State Health Department report on neonatal services in New York City found that in the larger units an average of two beds were occupied by such children, sometimes for years.
Situations like these are leading people to question whether millions of dollars should be spent on intensive care to the tiniest infants, who are unlikely to live.
In Oregon, where the Legislature is developing a priority list of various medical treatments to guide Medicaid financing, intensive care services for infants under 500 grams ranked 708 of 709 treatments, meaning it would not be covered. Dr. Kleinman said he "generally agreed," although he worried that techniques for treating them would not improve if no one was allowed to try. But many are appalled by the thought. "If you were told that anyone over 75 years old with a stroke couldn't get care, how would that sound?" Dr. Dweck said. "That's how I feel about the 500 grammers."
He said he would resuscitate fully any baby who shows signs of life at delivery regardless of gestational age or weight. In contrast, Dr. Kleinman said he did not routinely try to save babies under the 500-gram mark, but permitted the doctors who worked for him to try if they thought the baby had a chance.
"We generally keep them warm and let them expire by themselves" he said. "These are not viable babies, and it's crazy to do anything more."
Others said they withdraw treatment but only once it becomes clear that their efforts would be futile. Decisions to withdraw care are usually made after consultations between doctors, nurses and parents, but if these parties disagree, the treatment usually continues. If the parents and the doctors remain at odds about the proper course of treatment, the baby is sometimes moved to another hospital.
 
Beyond Survival
Long-Term Ills And Impairment
 For doctors and parents, decisions on care of premature infants are inevitably tortured affairs, complicated by the impossibility of determining the ultimate fate of any given infant. While doctors know, for example, that about 40 percent of babies weighing 600 grams at birth, about 1 pound, 5 ounces, will apparently be normal at one year, they have few clues as to which babies will fall into which group. And no one knows if babies who have normal brain examinations at 1 year will be developmentally normal at 6 or 7.
"Moms are constantly asking me, 'Is my baby going to be O.K.,' and I have to say if you line up 100 babies here I can't tell you which will be doing well by kindergarten," Dr. Dweck said. "That's what makes it difficult for me to withdraw treatment in a willy-nilly fashion.
But others say that while this may be true at birth, once premature infants experience certain complications, their odds of leading normal lives become smaller and smaller. The most serious problem is bleeding in the the brain, which occurs in about 75 percent of babies under 1,000 grams, about 2 pounds, 3 ounces.
In many cases it will be mild and have no obvious long-term consequences, but specialists say that in about one-quarter of the cases the bleed will be severe, compressing important brain structures that in the short term leads to seizures and strokes and in the long term to permanent damage.
"In these cases the decision is not about death," Dr. Fleischman said. "It's about severe impairment. We know the child will be severely impaired, it's only the level that's hard to predict."
He said that in such cases he recommended that care be withdrawn, although he said he would continue at the parents' request.
The intensive care units for infants are technological marvels in miniature. At Westchester Medical Center, each tiny infant bed takes 13 electrical outlets and 3 gas lines, for oxygen and suctioning secretions from the baby's mouths and lungs. Laboratories now perform dozens of biochemical tests on a few drops of blood, tests that five years ago would have required a full vial -- a 20th of a premature baby's blood volume -- to complete.
New drugs released this year, called artificial surfactants, can improve the breathing capacity of the infant's normally stiff lungs. But some experts worry about overuse.
Studies on infants with respiratory distress syndrome have shown that the drug can decrease the length of time on a respirator for infants over 750 grams and can improve survival in babies from 500 to 750 grams. But, encouraged by the drug's manufacturers, many doctors are using the drug in babies who are well but are felt to be at risk of developing respiratory distress.
Even more worrisome to health care economists has been the proliferation of a hugely expensive artificial lung that sits outside the body, called ECMO, whose benefits for infants remain largely unproved. Also designed to rescue infants with severe breathing problems, it pumps blood out of the infant, saturates it with oxygen, and returns it to the body.
 
Ending Treatment
Of Morality And Legality
 Also driving doctors to aggressively save the tiny infants are fears. What if they withdraw treatment and the baby survives -- and is left even more damaged?
Dr. Dweck tells of a baby who was transferred to Westchester County Medical Center with trouble breathing and with signs of brain damage because of lack of oxygen. He had not moved for 10 days. "The parents and all four grandparents wanted the ventilator discontinued," Dr. Dweck said. "If I withdraw treatment and the baby lives, how much additional damage will I have done?"
And many worry about legal obligations in the wake of the Baby Doe cases of the mid-1980's when pediatricians were told they could be prosecuted under child abuse and neglect laws for withholding or withdrawing care from sick infants.
Although pediatricians like Dr. Fleischman insist that the law permits them to stop treating infants when treatment is clearly futile, many remain cautious. In a 1988 survey of neonatologists, half said they had performed treatments that they thought were not in a baby's best interest because of legal fears.
Dr. Fleischman said, "I am really concerned when I see a doctor who won't stop treatment when a baby is no longer benefiting."
But Dr. Rie said: "You have to go soft on pediatricians. Remember in the mid-80's there was 800 number to call if you thought a pediatrician was bumping off a kid."

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Win or Lose, Democrats Frustrated by Bush Veto

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Congress is mounting three serious challenges to President Bush's streak of 22 successful vetoes, contesting him over unemployment benefits, civil rights and abortion counseling. But however those bills are settled, the results will not threaten the powerful White House strategy of saying no to Congressional Democrats first and negotiating later, if at all.
It is a strategy that breeds and thrives on partisanship in Congress, and one that often leads to no legislation at all. But at a time when there are few great problems that both Mr. Bush and the Democrats are committed to solving, that seems a small loss, one high-level Administration official said Friday. Congressional leaders see it differently, saying the lack of give and take results in domestic drift. 
 The three upcoming attempts to override vetoes are all on Congressional initiatives that the Bush Administration has treated as unnecessary, or worse.
 
Heavy on Politics
 The Administration has derided extending unemployment benefits for up to 20 weeks as needless in an economy that it says is improving. Both houses are expected to send the bill to the White House on Tuesday, and their votes will be laden with constituent politics, as well as national politics.
The civil rights bill, a measure to make it easier to sue in cases of alleged job discrimination, has much less political impetus behind it. The Administration does have a narrower bill of its own, but it is generally believed by lawmakers to prefer criticizing Congressional measures as likely to promote hiring quotas, a campaign issue for 1992, to getting a law enacted. The House passed the bill in June; the Senate is expected to take it up in two weeks.
The abortion counseling vote is a direct challenge to Administration policy. Both houses have voted to prohibit enforcement of an Administration regulation banning federally financed family planning clinics from telling pregnant women about abortion options. A House-Senate conference has not gotten down to work on aligning the bills.
 
Still a Powerful Tool
 History suggests that Mr. Bush's streak will be broken sometime. But even if the President loses one, the veto will not cease to be a powerful tool in his hands. Wielded with skill, it has helped keep the focus off domestic issues and on foreign policy, and it has frustrated Democrats in their continuing efforts to define themselves.
Republicans in Congress have gained almost as much as the Administration. The veto strategy has united them and given them purpose. In each house, Republicans have more votes than the one-third plus one needed to sustain a veto, but not enough more that they don't have to work at it.
Sometimes the threat of a veto has led to compromise on legislation that both sides found tolerable.
Mr. Bush likes to say that the veto power can bend Congress to his will. After telling an East Brunswick, N.J., fund-raising dinner on Tuesday that the Democratic legislative agenda amounted to "a bunch of garbage I will not sign," he added, "I'll continue to veto the bad stuff until we get good bills."
But persuading the Democrats to shift their position or modify a bill has been a relatively rare use of the veto. As Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, said Friday: "It's essentially a negative tool. It's a club, not a rapier."
If the Administration and the Republicans in either house count enough votes to sustain a veto, Mr. Gingrich said, they can "just say 'go away' " when Democrats push for action.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, views the veto just as seriously. He calls it "the most underestimated power in the American political system." He said Mr. Bush used the veto to "prevent others from dealing with the nation's problems, even though he himself offers no solutions to those problems."
Mr. Mitchell's description fits fairly well the Administration position on extending unemployment compensation for three million people who have been out of work at least half a year. Mr. Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, has repeatedly maintained that the recession is ending and that no bill is needed.
The Democrats probably have enough House Republicans with them for the two-thirds vote to override the compensation bill. In the Senate, 13 Republicans voted for the bill last Tuesday, but if Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, can get four of them to switch, and he says he can, a veto will be sustained.
Neither of the other two issues is quite so central to the Democrats' identity as helping the unemployed. Indeed if the civil rights bill is enacted, it will be a case of the Republican initiative of Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri overcoming the "quota bill" contentions of the Administration.
When that bill comes up in about two weeks, Democrats hope to deliver all their 57 Senators, and Mr. Danforth hopes to find at least nine Republican allies. He has six publicly committed so far.
But that will not be the end of it, because the House vote in June for a tougher bill was less than a two-thirds majority. Mr. Gingrich said he was sure that if the Senate passed the bill with veto-proof strength Mr. Bush would return to arguing that the bill fosters racial quotas, the argument he used against the House bill but then muzzled until last week.
The abortion issue is even less partisan. Republicans have taken the lead against their President in both houses. Congress is turning increasingly to favor abortion rights, and this particular issue, with its overtones of free speech and medical ethics, is probably the toughest for the anti-abortion forces to win.
But the veto strategy affects far more than these three bills. It has dimmed the Democrats' self-image as the party that offers solutions.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, acknowledged the problem. But he argued, "We were elected to do what we think is in the highest and best interests of the country, and not to tailor those votes because we can't see it through easily to a conclusion."
He continued: "In order to define the differences between the parties, we have to put on his desk what we think the country should do and if he vetoes, try to override."
But Mr. Gingrich said Mr. Bush's use of the veto "forces the Democrats to confront whether they want to be legislators or press-release artists," able to make a point but not to enact a law.
However the situation is labeled, making the point becomes increasingly important as the elections near. For example, Democrats plan to try to pass an income tax bill with a pro-middle class, anti-rich tilt early next year, even though they know it will be vetoed.
Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Long Island Democrat who has been the chief House sponsor of the extended unemployment benefits bill, even observed that if somehow Congress won all three upcoming veto fights, that might be a curse in disguise because the public would expect more of Congress than it would be able to deliver.
Thomas Mann, director of Governmental Studies at the Brookings Institution, observed that the Democrats may "probably be better off not overriding." In defeat, they can claim that Mr. Bush prevented a problem from being solved. In victory, the public gets to judge whether their solution has actually solved anything.
"Sometimes the worst thing you can do is get your bill passed," Mr. Mann said.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Opportunity Knocks in Europe

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The stock market picked up momentum in the third quarter, as the average stock fund gained 6.1 percent through Thursday. Small stocks kept chugging along, rising 10.2 percent as a group, according to Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J.
 Among specialty funds, the health-and-biotechnology group was the leader, rising 17.8 percent, with financial services funds (up 10.6 percent) and science-and-technology funds (up 9.6 percent) also performing well. 
Next were the funds that invest in European stocks; they were up 8.2 percent. This was a sharp turnaround from their negative showing in 1991's first half. But even with the big third-quarter gain, the 23 European funds have risen only 3.5 percent so far in 1991, compared with the average stock fund's gain of 21 percent.
 The fund managers say the poor showing is a natural reaction to the "Europhoria" in 1990's first half after the Berlin Wall crumbled. The burst of optimism in early 1990 came "full circle, to pessimism in early June" of 1991, as the costs of German unification became clear, said John R. Hickling, who manages the $314 million Fidelity Europe Fund. But investors' perceptions "have improved somewhat since then," he said.
 Moreover, the dollar has been strong relative to European currencies. So while markets abroad have performed well in local terms, the returns for United States investors have lagged. Further problems were the turmoil related to the Gulf crisis -- Europe is largely dependent on outside sources of energy -- and fears related to the unrest in the Soviet Union.
 The picture now looks much brighter. Managers of six of the largest European funds -- most of which posted third-quarter gains of 9 or 10 percent -- are uniformly optimistic. They say the prospects for European growth are excellent.
 For one thing, most European economies are nearing the bottom of recessionary phases and are poised for strong stock market rallies. For another, the markets represent good value in terms of price-to-earnings ratios, stock prices relative to book value and cash-flow measurements. Then there are the long-term themes: the development of Eastern Europe and the unification of the European Community.
 The European funds' lackluster performance in the last year "to my mind, is an opportunity," said Albert J. Alan, who manages the $600 million Merrill Lynch Eurofund. Glenn Wellman, manager of the $130 million Alliance New Europe Fund, offers a caveat. He said, "Because exchange rates and markets have been volatile, I would urge shareholders to take an intermediate-range view of growth prospects in Europe -- two to five years -- and ignore the short-term volatility there."
 John R. Legat, manager of the $1.4 billion GT Europe Growth Fund, predicts the growth rate in the former East Germany will be between 5 and 10 percent next year, and he expects other Eastern European economies to pick up in 1992 and 1993. Such growth would be "a positive for demand for goods and services that Western Europe can provide," he said. He particularly likes three German engineering and equipment manufacturers: Siemens, Linde and Mannesmann.
 Like other managers interviewed, Mr. Legat has a higher percentage of his fund's holdings in British stocks than in any other single nation. His British issues are heavy in defensive stocks to weather the recession. One favorite is Tiphook, a transportation and shipping container rental company.
 Mr. Hickling of Fidelity is pursuing European cyclical stocks, especially in Britain, to benefit from the improving economies there. Three favorite British retailers: Kingfisher, Dixons and Tesco.
 Mr. Wellman has 10 percent of the Alliance portfolio invested in business and trade-related services, to capitalize on the removal of European trade barriers by the end of 1992. He likes Ericsson, a Swedish telecommunications equipment manufacturer, and Racal and Cellnet, British telecommunications companies. Another large portion is committed to distribution and transportation -- notably Tripcovich, an Italian trucking company, and Frans Maas in the Netherlands.
 Mr. Alan's two biggest holdings are banking and insurance, which he says are interest-rate sensitive industries that will benefit from falling interest rates in Europe. He likes two French banks -- Credit Lyonnaise and BNP -- and AMEV, a Dutch insurer.
 William F. Wendler, vice president of Rowe Price-Fleming International, which manages the $103 million T. Rowe Price European Stock Fund, also likes interest-rate sensitive companies, particularly Eurotunnel, which is building the English Channel tunnel, and EuroDisney, which is building a theme park outside Paris. He also likes Hochtief, a German construction company.
 The largest holdings of the $71 million FSP European Portfolio, part of the Denver-based Invesco funds, include Astra, a Swedish pharmeceuticals company. The fund's manager, Steven A. Chamberlin, says Astra is showing strong earnings growth. He also likes stocks that stand to profit from the recovery in the United States economy, especially Ahold, a Dutch food retailer with United States production subsidiaries.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
It's Time to Stop Poking Along at 55

BYLINE: By DONALD L. PEVSNER; Donald L. Pevsner is a Miami attorney, consumer advocate and columnist.

 BODY:
Driving 70 miles per hour on the national Interstate System of highways and 60 to 65 m.p.h. on rural Federal and state highways used to be legal and safe. Now armies of police lie in wait for motorists who do it, bringing fat revenues to the states and to insurance and radar-detector companies. But the economic rationale for the 55 m.p.h. limit no longer exists nor do valid safety grounds. It's time to raise the speed limit.
In 1973, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries created a temporary, artificial oil shortage worldwide. As people panicked on long gas lines, Congress ordered a maximum national speed limit of 55 miles per hour. Billions in Federal highway funds would be cut off to states that defied it. This "temporary" measure, billed as a fuel-efficiency move, became permanent in 1975. But it has produced mass civil disobedience, engendering contempt on the part of citizens that resembles nothing so much as their reaction to the Volstead Act and Prohibition. 
 An unholy trinity of special interests gets rich from the enforcement of this law.
States reap vast rewards. Indeed, enforcement reeks of being strictly revenue-driven. Driving 70 miles per hour in a 55 m.p.h. zone in Colorado will cost $64; in Florida, $112. In 1990, one state trooper, who likes to hide at the bottom of a hill on the Pennsylvania Turnpike in rural Westmoreland County, wrote $640,000 worth of speeding tickets.
Automobile insurance companies gouge policyholders when it comes to speeding violations. One nasty ploy against newly ticketed policyholders is to refuse to renew them at standard rates, often driving them into higher priced subsidiaries, surcharge schemes or state assigned-risk plans. The nation's two largest auto insurers, the State Farm Mutual Auto Insurance Company and the Allstate Insurance Company, have set up units to underwrite drivers who have received as little as one ticket in the preceding three years -- at rates about twice those charged by their "clean record" divisions. Other auto insurers take similarly Draconian measures.
Radar-detector manufacturers sell more than $300 million worth of units annually, while their corporate cousins sell costlier clocking devices to the police. In this "Star Wars" contest, the consumer is paying for both sides.
There are excellent reasons to get rid of the 55 m.p.h. limit. There is no oil shortage in the world today, nor does any responsible official predict one. Today's cars are twice as fuel-efficient as their counterparts in the 1970's. Furthermore, the highway safety argument does not hold for the Interstate System, which was designed for speeds of at least 70 m.p.h. in non-urban areas.
Last year, two respected Federal Highway Administration traffic-safety engineers, Samuel C. Tignor and Davey Warren, concluded that most speed zones were posted 15 m.p.h. below the maximum safe speed; that, on average, speed limits are set too low to be accepted as reasonable by most drivers, and that the posted speeds make violators out of motorists who drive reasonably and safely. Further, they said, increasing speed limits would not result in still-higher speeds; it would increase compliance, so enforcement could be targeted at the truly high-risk driver.
Interstate speed limits should return to 70 m.p.h., with lower exceptions in congested urban areas and in terrain provably unsafe at 70. Priority should be given to removing the 55 m.p.h. rural Interstate limit in eight Northeastern states; most others went to 65 m.p.h. after Congress revised the 1974 law in 1987. Non-urban Federal and state highways should have 60 to 65 m.p.h. limits, following the counsel of safety engineers instead of revenue-hungry politicians. Politicians supporting the status quo should be voted out.

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1; Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1882 words

HEADLINE: Homeowners Said to Face Rise in Costs To Clean Up Environment

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

 BODY:
HOMEOWNERS across New Jersey can expect the cost of sewer, water and garbage-disposal services to nearly triple on the average by 1994 because of regulations aimed at cleaning up the environment, a newly released state study says. As a result, the study concludes, municipalities may be forced to raise taxes or cut services.
Business groups hail the study, saying it lends support to their argument that business has borne a larger share of the cost of protecting the environment than have municipalities and property owners. Municipal organizations and consumer groups are less sanguine. The study, they say, is further evidence of the mounting tax burden on state residents. 
 "This study is dismal for us," said William Dressel, the chief lobbyist for the New Jersey State League of Municipalities. "It is the worst news at the worst possible time."
The findings of the study point up several of the crucial issues that will frame the environmental debate of the 1990's. To what extent will individuals be willing to alter habits to protect the environment, like forgoing cars in favor of mass transit? At what point does the electorate, already chafing under the burden of soaring education and auto insurance costs, begin to reject more stringent environment policies and the lawmakers who enact them?
The study is seen as important because Gov. Jim Florio has made a clean environment one of his administration's priorities. But the study was not being well received by those who had struggled with the administration over its $2.8 billion increase in state taxes to balance the state budget and over changes in school aid.
The study, which was commissioned in 1989 by what is now the State Department of Environmental Protection and Energy but made public only several weeks ago, says that environmental regulations on sewage treatment, water supplies and garbage disposal will have cost the average household $159 more each year between 1990 and 1994, a total of $795 more for the period. The average annual cost for those services will rise to $1,227 in 1994 from $432 in 1989.
The 158-page study was conducted by Policy Planning and Evaluation Inc., a consulting company in Herndon, Va.
 
Ban on Dumping Sludge in Ocean
 John W. Hazen, a legislative analyst for the state environmental and energy agency, said the costs mentioned in the study were the cumulative result of regulations for the required secondary treatment of sewage, as well as rules in a 1990 state law that banned the dumping of sewage sludge in the ocean as of last March.
Mr. Hazen said six major utility authorities in the northern part of the state had had to incur higher costs for sludge disposal by sending it to landfills out of state. Future regulations on the beneficial disposal of sludge, like composting, might some day bring those costs down, but Mr. Hazen could not say if that would be before 1994.
Other costly regulations, he said, are those being put into place to close 300 overburdened landfills and to assure monitoring to prevent future offsite contamination or illegal dumping. The state, he said, is establishing regional transfer stations for out-of-state garbage disposal, and the planning and construction of secure sanitary landfills in New Jersey are translating into higher costs for disposal.
Also, he said, regulations governing the closing of contaminated private and municipal wells, or on the overpumping of underground water supplies in areas like Ocean, Monmouth and Camden Counties, are causing water rates to increase as new sources are found to replace the old ones.
The study notes that other major environmental costs, for the control of auto and industry air emissions, for example, are not included.
Warning of "rate shock" for local officials and taxpayers, the study concludes that "some municipalities may have to increase taxes and/or reduce levels of municipal services over the long run" to pay for complying with the regulations.
Scott A. Weiner, Commissioner of the state environmental agency, said the cost evaluation of the study "underscores the seriousness of the types of policy and financial commitment decisions facing society, like who should be paying for environmental protection and what should be paid for."
Hal Bozarth, the executive director of the Chemical Industry Council of New Jersey, said the study was "one more arrow in our quiver" in the council's argument that individuals and municipalities that generate pollution must share the cost of controlling it.
 
'The Public Will Get a Taste'
 "We have been saying for some time that sooner or later, the public will get a taste of what environmental protection is all about, and this study is it," Mr. Bozarth said. "The responsibility for a cleaner environment does not just fall on industries like ours, but on communities and individuals."
Edward Lloyd, a lawyer for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, said, among other things, that the study should have emphasized conservation as a means of reducing the cost of water supplies, but that it had not. The study recommended the regionalization and privatization of sewer and water systems and garbage disposal, as well as an unprecedented campaign by the state environmental agency to achieve pollution prevention as a means of reducing future costs for these services.
Specifically, the study recommended steps like preserving more open space and wetlands, both of which help abate flooding and prevent pollution, thereby saving capital costs for systems like reservoirs and pollution controls.
The prevention of casual disposal of household toxic chemicals, including used oils and paints, was also recommended by the study as a means of reducing the cost of sewage treatment and the toxic cleanup of solid waste landfills. The study recommended developing a long-term plan of environmental priorities, taking into account the amount of state grants needed to put new regulations into effect, the retirement and issuance of debt and the existing debt burden on communities.
"Once a plan is prepared," the study said, "it would be possible to change priorities in a more enlightened manner."
 
$10 Billion in Improvements
 Improvements to sewer, water and garbage-disposal systems will cost almost $10 billion between 1990 and 1994, the study said. And whereas New Jersey residents were spending an average of 1.25 percent of their annual gross household incomes for sewer, water and garbage services in 1989, the study said, they will spend an average of almost 1.8 percent in each of the five years. Residents in communities of 50,000 or more people will spend 2.3 percent, up from 1.9 percent in 1989, the study said.
Mr. Dressel said the State League of Municipalities had recently concluded a hard-fought and successful battle to keep local property taxes down by arguing for a more equitable financing of state aid to public schools through the Quality Education Act.
"The cost of environmental regulation is as big if not bigger than the education issue," he said. "Local taxes are going to go sky-high."
Becky Taylor, a spokeswoman for the state environmental agency, said the study "had somewhat been on hold for a year or so" and was not released until just last month. Ms. Taylor said that the former Environmental Commissioner, Judith Yaskin, "took a look at this thing and was very unhappy that it only gave one side of the equation, environmental costs, and not the benefits of a cleaner environment."
Commissioner Weiner felt the same way, Ms. Taylor said, but "finally decided to release the study, even though he felt it might be a disservice to the public." She added, "That is why the Commissioner added the prologue to the study."
 
A Bureaucracy Bogged Down
 The study said the state environmental agency in 1989 was a bureaucracy bogged down by its own very costly and time-consuming permitting process, as well as a plethora of regulations that municipalities generally found out about only at the last moment and seldom had a chance to anticipate.
Mr. Weiner states in the prologue that the study was in response to national concerns about environmental costs, as well as "a growing number of appeals received from municipal officials throughout New Jersey for relief and assistance in meeting environmental mandates."
In an interview, the Commissioner said the departmental reorganization that he began upon taking office seven months ago was already bearing fruit in that it addressed some of the study's criticisms of his agency. Among the changes under way, Mr. Weiner said, was the appointment of assistant commissioners to more closely oversee and to revise the agency's policies on the permit process, enforcement and toxic cleanup.
Mr. Lloyd, who is also director of the Rutgers Environmental Law Clinic in Newark and a longtime observer of environmental agencies, said it was "too early to tell" if Mr. Weiner's reorganization of his department had produced a more responsible and efficient agency that could streamline its sluggish operations of the past.
 
'A Lot Has Changed'
 "But my concern now is whether the costs and the study are valid because they were made based on regulations of policies in place in 1989," Mr. Lloyd said. "A lot has changed since then in the solid waste area, for example, including a more effective recycling effort statewide and the state's change in policy from wanting to build many incinerators to building only a few on a regional basis."
Ms. Taylor said the state environmental agency could give "no realistic estimate" of whether the higher costs predicted in the study for 1990, the first year, had actually materialized.
"We would have to do a lot more work," she said. A second phase of the study, looking at the benefits of a cleaner environment, will be completed in about a year, she said.
Mr. Weiner declined to speculate on specific economic benefits of the cleaner environment, saying only that cleaner air, water and communities were more attractive to business and industry and to prospective developers.
Jim Sinclair, the first vice president of the Business and Industry Association of New Jersey, said businesses paid 40 percent of the taxes in the state and were not pleased that environmental costs and therefore property taxes would continue to rise. He said there was an atmosphere of overregulation in the state, one of the criticisms contained in the report.
 
Federal Cutbacks a Factor
 Dave Kehler, president of the Public Affairs Research Institute in Princeton, said the higher cost that municipalities were being asked to bear for environmental regulations would result from the sharp decline in Federal grants to states that had been common in the 1960's and 70's. These grants financed such things as the construction of sewage treatment plants, he said.
"State and local governments in the last decade have not responded well to these Federal cutbacks," Mr. Kehler said. "They thought that political pressure would reverse the federalism policies, but it did not. The states and municipalities did not have a plan B."
Mr. Kehler added, "It is important to realize that these costs represent a real issue, as opposed to a political one."

HEADLINE: New York Seedy

BYLINE: By Hanna Rubin; Hanna Rubin writes frequently about New York City.

 BODY:

LOW LIFE
Lures and Snares of Old New York.
By Luc Sante.
Illustrated. 414 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux.
$27.50.  
 If the city's financial crisis is making New Yorkers long for the old days when policemen walked the beat, the El rattled up Third Avenue and a drink cost six cents, they should think again. According to Luc Sante's "Low Life: Lures and Snares of Old New York," the cop was on the take, vice lurked under the iron girders and the drink was probably a Mickey Finn.
Mr. Sante chronicles the city's seamy underside between 1840 and 1920, from the woeful physical condition of the tenements to their residents' various criminal activities -- drugs, prostitution and gambling each get a chapter -- to the city's largely cosmetic efforts to contain its worst excesses. Grinding poverty trapped new immigrants as they stepped off the boat. Life in the tenements was tawdry and brutal. Some families could not afford a room in a cellar and ended up in hellholes like the notorious Old Brewery, an abandoned factory in lower Manhattan where hundreds camped out without basic sanitation, light or air. Recreational pursuits ran to rat baiting and "dime museums," a tony moniker for permanent freak shows featuring tattooed men and risque tableaux.
Women's options were limited to piecework, sweatshops or prostitution, Mr. Sante writes, but men who did not want to mortgage their youth to the factories could ply any number of illegal trades. The Whyo gang, whose members roamed lower Manhattan in the decades after the Civil War, offered to blacken eyes for $4, break an arm or a leg for $19 or chew off ears for $15. Crooked gambling operations also flourished after the war, with hundreds of establishments springing up to cater to the seemingly bottomless cupidity of the marks. Patrons were often fleeced before they even reached the tables. Many of the gaming houses, saloons and sporting establishments routinely served drinks laced with chloral hydrate, then robbed the customers while they were under the influence.
Where amid this mayhem were the forces of law and order? When they weren't duking it out with one another -- the rival Municipal and Metropolitan police forces held an epic battle in 1857 that left 52 policemen injured -- they harvested protection from the local madams, streetwalkers, thieves and fences. Politicians were, if anything, more corrupt than the police force. When Tammany Hall ran Asa Bird Gardiner for District Attorney in 1897, the slogan of his successful campaign was "To hell with reform."
"Low Life" captures the rollicking atmosphere of city life during the period. In his first book, Mr. Sante, a freelance journalist, moves along swiftly, rarely bogging down in numbers, chronologies or social history. He quotes primary sources sparingly, at times sacrificing the flavor of the era. Instead, he favors anecdotes and character sketches like his portrait of John Allen, a former divinity student who decorated his house of ill repute with religious paraphernalia and held prayer meetings for his girls. At times this tour-guide approach clashes with the events, as in his description of the antiabolition riots of 1834, a vicious outbreak of racism that destroyed black churches and homes. Still, Mr. Sante reclaims an essential piece of the city's past, one that should reassure contemporary New Yorkers. This is far from the worst of times.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
'Harlot's Ghost' Is Revising Fiction's Role as Cheap Date

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN

 BODY:
In the pricing of American books, Hemingway has traditionally taken a back seat to historians, and a reader is likely to spend more for a fix-it book or a collection of inspirational ditties than for a book by Proust.
But when Norman Mailer's new novel "Harlot's Ghost" hit the bookstores last week with a price tag of $30, readers were put on notice that they may soon have to start paying what novels actually cost to produce. 
 The book is the first work of popular fiction to cross the $30 threshold, and it took a leap to get there. The closest-priced novels are selling for a full $5 less. The publisher, Random House, said it had no choice but to charge that much, because at nearly four pounds "Harlot's Ghost" weighs as much as a roast that could feed eight people, and at 1,328 pages it has more heft than the average King James Version.
"Even at this price, it's underpriced," said Bruce Harris, who is in charge of sales at Random House. "It costs a lot to produce a book this size. It had to be done."
If Random House gambled correctly and readers make the book a best seller, people in the industry say, other publishers will push up the prices of their novels, even ones that do not match the formidable dimensions of "Harlot's Ghost."
There does not seem to be a hard and fast reason why nonfiction has traditionally been priced higher than fiction. Publishers say that people buy fewer copies of nonfiction, so the production costs are ultimately higher, and that the audience for nonfiction has generally been more affluent than the fiction audience and thus more willing to spend money.
Until recent years, moreover, there was a long-held feeling within the industry that publishers are somehow morally obliged to keep novels within the financial reach of most readers -- even at the risk of losing money -- because literature is a "product" that cannot be copied and sold like knockoff suits for a cheaper price.
But publishers say they can no longer be oblivious to market realities. With the recession and with more and more publishing houses being bought up by multinational corporations that demand balanced budgets, publishers in the last few years have begun to think and act more like business people.
 
'An Underpriced Commodity'
 The $30 novel is not a statement or a gamble, they say. It is as realistic as a $10,000 economy car, a $7.50 movie ticket and a $2 ice cream cone.
"Books cost this much to make," said Barry Lippman, publisher at Macmillan Inc. "There's no other place a publisher recoups his money but in the cost of the book. And books are an underpriced commodity from a pure product point of view."
Mr. Lippman points to a study showing that the price of books had risen very little over the last decade, compared with the price of, say, an Ivy League education, a car, a movie or a house.
By his calculations, the average price of a house has risen 83 percent, to $140,000 in 1990, from $76,400 in 1980; the price of a Ford Thunderbird has gone up 157 percent, to $17,480 from $6,808, and movie prices have increased 114 percent, to $7.50 from $3.50. Meanwhile, according to Mr. Lippman's chart, hard-cover fiction has risen 64 percent, to $17.95 from $10.95.
 
Likelihood of Discounts
 Many readers who buy the new Mailer book will not even pay the full $30 list price, because the large chain bookstores generally sell books at a discount, particularly if a book either is a best seller or has big expectations.
A spokeswoman for the Barnes & Noble book chain said its stores would sell "Harlot's Ghost" at a 15 percent discount, or $25.50, and would double the discount if the book made The New York Times best seller list.
Random House did not come easily to its decision to price the book at a record $30. And despite mixed reviews, executives there are not publicly questioning their choice. They took a similar, much-discussed gamble with a nonfiction volume last year when they priced a book based on the PBS television series "The Civil War" by Ken Burns, at $50, far above the nonfiction standard. It became a best seller.
Setting the price for the Mailer book was one of the first big decisions for Harold Evans when he took over as publisher at Random House earlier this year. "There was a lot of cold feet about doing it," Mr. Evans recalled, "a feeling that a $30 novel would put people off."
 
'Unthinkable' Cutbacks
 So, the internal hand-wringing began. Could Mr. Mailer be persuaded to trim the manuscript? The idea was "unthinkable" to the book's editor, Jason Epstein, Mr. Evans said. Could the text be set in smaller type with tighter margins to cut the number of pages? "I thought it was a bad idea," Mr. Evans said. "It's really a beautiful book and very easy to read this way."
Mr. Evans casually polled booksellers about the price. Some winced, he said, but most said that the $30 novel was an inevitability and that of all contemporary authors, Mr. Mailer was the best one for the gamble.
"If ever there was a book that you would risk breaking the $30 price barrier with, this is it," said William S. Lofquist, a publishing analyst at the United States Department of Commerce. "You've got the huge size of the book; you have a great, very hot subject -- the C.I.A. -- and you have a dynamite author who's a name brand, like Colgate."
After running through and rejecting a host of ways to cut the production costs, Random House decided to leap over the $30 breach. "At the end of the day," Mr. Evans concluded, "Mailer is worth it."
 
200,000 Advance Orders
 Booksellers also seemed to think the risk was worth it. In all, they placed advance orders for 200,000 copies of the book.
Stuart Applebaum, a vice president at Bantam Doubleday Dell, said he still remembered the "hue and cry" when Delacorte priced James Clavell's novel "Noble House" at $19.95 in 1981. "People were saying then that this is going to destroy the hard-cover fiction industry to have a novel at such a high tariff," Mr. Applebaum said. "And the industry survived, and here we are with a $30 upper limit."
As pleasures go, reading a novel -- even one with a $30 price tag -- is still relatively cheap. A two-hour movie at $7.50 a ticket ends up costing about 6 cents a minute, while Mr. Mailer's book, read at a pace of about two minutes a page, runs about a penny a minute. And when measured by weight, "Harlot's Ghost" comes out at just under 50 cents an ounce, while the same amount of Beluga caviar fetches about $55.

D1); Despite its $30 price, "Harlot's Ghost" is attracting buyers at the Doubleday Book Shop on Fifth Avenue in midtown Manhattan (John Sotomayor/The New York Times) (pg. D9)

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Rose 22% Last Month

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools rose 22 percent in August from the previous month, according to the monthly report of the Association for Manufacturing Technology. It was the third consecutive monthly increase, but orders remained below the level of a year earlier, the trade group said.
The report, to be released on Monday, found that machine tool orders rose to $235.7 million last month, from $193.3 million in July. But the September level was 15 percent lower than the September 1990 figure, when orders totaled $276.8 million. 
 The August increase was led by a jump in orders for metal-forming tools, which more than doubled from the July level. So far this year, machine tool orders have totaled $1.6 billion, down 17.3 percent from the comparable period last year.
 
Indicator of Growth
 Machine tools are precision machines used to manufacture metal products, ranging from cookware to weapons. Although the industry is relatively small, its activity is considered an important indicator of the strength of industrial production.
"We remain cautiously optimistic since orders are up for the third month in a row and cancellations are at their lowest level in over seven years," said Albert W. Moore, president of the industry association.
Mr. Moore said he was also encouraged by recent economic data.
"Capacity utilization rates have been inching upward, creating a climate for increased capital expenditures," he said.
The trade group, based in McLean, Va., said shipments of machine tools fell 14 percent in August, to $183.3 million, from $212.8 million in July, and dropped 21 percent from $231.4 million in August 1990.
The group said export orders totaled $31.4 million in August, a decrease from July's $43.1 million total but up substantially from the $16.7 million posted a year ago. Export shipments totaled $30.8 million in August, down from $40.5 million in July and $34.2 million a year earlier.
Orders for metal-forming tools were $109.30 million, more than double the July level of $47.7 million. They were $48.3 million a year earlier.
Domestic orders for forming tools were at $87.1 million, about three times the level of the previous month. Shipments for metal-forming tools slid to $46 million, from $63.4 million a month earlier and $75.6 million a year earlier.
Shipments of metal-cutting tools fell to $137.4 million, 8 percent below the July total. Orders for metal-cutting tools also fell in August, to $126.4 million, 13 percent below the previous month and 45 percent below a year earlier.
The trade group said the August backlog of orders was $1.36 billion, up from $1.31 billion. The August 1990 backlog was $1.61 billion

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
As Election Year Nears, Bush Counts on the Fed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
President Bush held an economic summit conference of sorts last week, and the bond market rallied. The continued soft economy that prompted the conference may be good news for interest rates. But some credit market analysts say economic growth might not come as soon as Mr. Bush would like, with a Presidential election year drawing closer.
The meeting seemed to underscore what appears to be a working assumption at the White House: monetary policy will provide enough stimulus to produce real growth in the economy of 2 to 2.5 percent over the next 13 months. Yet the assumption that the Federal Reserve board can provide the cure, these analysts said, is a big gamble. 
 Problems generated in the 1980's, ranging from real estate to the "credit crunch" to the continuing shrinkage of the service sector, are "structural weaknesses that are not amenable to changes in monetary policy," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh.
"And people are beginning to sense that what we are experiencing is not just a normal cyclical fluctuation," Mr. Robertson added. "I think we are facing a period of economic growth that will be much slower and much less steady than has been the norm since World War II."
 
Weak Outlook for a Voting Year
 With only one exception over the last two decades, the economy has been clipping along at about a 5 percent growth rate when voters went to the polls to vote for a President. The exception was 1980, when the economy contracted slightly.
That year, Ronald Reagan asked Americans if they were better off than they had been four years earlier, and the electorate responded by spurning Jimmy Carter and giving Mr. Reagan and his running mate, George Bush, a sweeping victory.
Thus, by election-year standards, 2 percent growth would be exceptionally modest. And given current conditions, "I would say Mr. Bush's chances are no better than 50-50" that such a level of growth will be achieved, said Joseph Carson, chief economist of Chemical Bank.
And those odds apply, Mr. Carson said, only if Washington provides some fiscal stimulus to the economy. With a budget deficit that could climb close to $400 billion during the fiscal year that begins tomorrow, however, most analysts are assuming that the hands of the President and the Congress are tied.
 
A 'Financial Straitjacket'
 Without some tax relief, Mr. Carson said, household incomes will remain strapped. "I don't know," he said, "if interest rates could fall low enough to get the household sector out of the financial straitjacket they are in."
Aside from lowering interest rates, Administration officials seem to believe that more pressure from the Fed and less stringent regulation will prod banks to pick up the pace of lending. That assumption is also flawed, some economists said.
"To the extent there is a credit crunch, I don't think it is being caused by excessive regulation," said Lawrence Chimerine, a senior adviser to Data Resources Inc., an economic forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass. "The fact is, banks just can't take risks," he said. "At this point, expecting regulators to turn things around is the same as expecting the Fed to turn things around."
 
Tight Bank Credit Continues
 Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said regulators' demands that banks increase capital were necessary for the industry, but "it takes time" to meet those requirements.
In the meantime, "we are seeing some of the weakest, if not the weakest, credit creation by depository institutions since the early 1950's," Mr. Kasriel said. "It's a very troublesome situation," he added.
While many have their doubts, some economists said the Fed would be able to deliver the 2 to 2.5 percent growth that it and the Administration would like to see over the next year.
Since mid-1989, the Fed has eased monetary policy 13 times, and short-term interest rates have fallen by 47 percent, noted Robert Barbera, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers. "That is a little bit less than average" the amount the Fed has eased in past recessions, he added.
 
Fed Still Has Maneuvering Room
 "The Fed is still in the easing process," Mr. Barbera said, "and history suggests that in the next three to four months we will have a significant recovery," with above-average growth for two to three quarters.
"I don't think the President has anything to worry about on the economy," said Jerry L. Jordan, a senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "I think they have their 2 percent to 3 percent growth in the bag."
And yet, if most forecasts are correct, economic data that are expected this week are not likely to provide much solace to Mr. Bush or his lieutenants.
September employment data, expected from the Labor Department on Friday, will be the event most awaited by credit market participants.
Most economists are projecting that the unemployment rate rose in September by one-tenth of a percentage point, or more, from the 6.8 percent level of August, and that non-farm payroll employment rose by only 40,000 or 50,000. Although employment gains of any size are welcome, an increase in that range would not be synonymous with a rapidly recovering economy.
If payrolls did expand by 50,000 in September, the total number of new jobs added since April, when the recession is now thought to have bottomed, would amount to only 160,000, said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst for the Chase Manhattan Corporation.
In past recoveries, the rise in payroll employment over a similar period of time is around 500,000, Mr. Fine added.
"For a recovery, that is very, very weak," he said.

HEADLINE: Weak Dollar Magnifies Gains of Foreign Stock Exchanges

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
World markets continued to move sideways in the third quarter. The Mexican, British and French exchanges led a sluggish pack, but the biggest gains came to those investors who made the best of a slipping dollar.
Of 24 world stock markets listed on the Financial Times index, only 8 rose by at least 1 percent measured in their own currencies. But with the dollar falling 7.8 percent against the mark and about 3.1 percent against the yen, 18 of the 24 rose in terms of the dollar. 
 Since their rally earlier this year, following the quick end to the Persian Gulf war and short-lived hopes for a strong economic recovery in the United States, the markets have been mostly lackluster. With central banks remaining generally tight-fisted, European markets edged up 2.9 percent for the quarter, compared with rises of 4.5 percent in the United States and 1.8 percent in Japan.
Mexico's topping the list hardly came as a surprise in a year in which the Bolsa de Valores, as Mexico City's bourse is known, has risen 111.6 percent. Hong Kong's exchange was a distant second with 33.3 percent growth for the year, followed by the exchanges in Sweden, Spain, Australia, Denmark and France. The stock markets in Britain, South Africa, Ireland and Switzerland have also risen more than 20 percent this year.
 
Gloom Turned to Confidence
 If anything was remarkable about Mexico's performance, it was that the Bolsa rose a bit more slowly -- 22.76 percent -- despite improving prospects for a North American free-trade agreement, the ruling party's victory in state and legislative elections on Aug. 18, and the successful sale of Mexico's biggest bank a week later. Its good long-term prospects aside, some analysts are growing uneasy about how Mexico will finish the year, given demand for money that has pushed overnight interest rates to about 30 percent.
In Britain, long months of gloom gave way to all-time highs in the stock market. The economy rebounded quickly after the Government, which must call national elections by June, cut interest rates sharply. With consumer spending and other confidence indicators up, the market rose 8.14 percent -- and 16.05 percent in dollar terms.
In France, expectations of a drop in the nation's high real interest rates and a sense that the economy has hit bottom helped to fuel a similar rise. And while the French Bourse jumped 7.37 percent when measured in francs, the gain was 15.55 percent when converted into dollars.
Across most of Europe, the attempted Soviet coup in August was scarcely visible in the markets as the quarter ended. "The effect of the coup was really like a summer storm," said Gavin R. Dobson, president of Murray Johnstone International in Chicago. "If you'd gone on vacation the Friday before and come back a week later, you'd have seen no net effect." Finland's market was perhaps the exception. It sits firmly at the bottom of the index's rankings for the year, tumbling 15.33 percent in the quarter .
 
Outside Europe, Mixed Results
 Beyond Europe, the news of the quarter was mixed. In Hong Kong, where huge airport and harbor projects are hinting at the dimensions of a new economic future under Chinese control, the stock market rose 6.83 percent, and 7.06 percent in dollar terms.
In Singapore, the market fell 5.1 percent, but less than 1 percent in dollar terms.
In the second quarter, South Africa's indexes reached or surpassed all-time highs; this quarter, the market did not move at all, except for an 8 percent rise in dollar terms.

HEADLINE: Small Stocks Did Best in Quarter, as Impatient Investors Looked for Growth

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
During a quarter in which the large stock exchanges advanced only modestly, the over-the-counter market showed robust growth.
"The over-the-counter market led the way," said Laszlo Birinyi, the head of Birinyi Associates, the Wall Street research firm. 
 He said the over-the-counter market gained more than 10 percent in the third quarter, compared with gains of about 4 percent for the other exchanges and indexes. The Dow Jones industrial average gained slightly less than 4 percent for the period.
 
Frustrated Investors
 With billions of dollars pouring into the stock market, investors are growing increasingly frustrated by the lackluster movement of Big Board stocks. "The spirit is willing, but the flesh is somewhat reluctant," Mr. Birinyi said.
He said investors had become spoiled by the prolonged bull market. "Now we are going back to eking out gains," he said. "The prevailing spirit here is frustration."
Hugh A. Johnson, the director of investment strategy for the First Albany Corporation in Albany, said, "The performance of the markets, with the exception of some of the small-capitalization issues, has been guarded, trendless and friendless.
"People are finding better value in the over-the-counter market," Mr. Johnson said.
Several experts said the strength of the over-the-counter stocks was unlikely to be a passing fancy. "When small-company stocks come to life," Mr. Johnson said, "and begin to outperform the market, that outperformance tends to last not months, not days, but years."
 
Years of Neglect
 Jack A. Sullivan, a principal with Van Kasper & Company , a San Francisco-based investment firm, noted that the strength in the over-the-counter market followed years of neglect. "The Nasdaq's terrific performance shows that there has finally been a recognition that some of the smaller, entrepreneurial companies in this country have really learned how to manage their businesses," he said.
He said investors were increasingly interested in ferreting out companies in which the chairman is the founder and largest shareholder. "That's the kind of company investors are paying for," he said.
Mr. Sullivan cited the Advanta Corporation, a financial-services company based in Horsham, Pa., as one company with high insider ownership and a strong growth rate. The company's stock rose 83 percent in the quarter, to $30.
The flip side of the enthusiasm for the smaller companies in the over-the-counter market is a growing impatience with the performance of the large-capitalization companies traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Many Big Board stocks are now considered too expensive, and investors are increasingly nervous that the companies will be unable to post earnings increases commensurate with the run-up in their stock prices earlier this year.
"There is intensifying concern that we will not get a strong enough recovery in the economy and earnings to valdidate those large-capitalization stock prices," said Mr. Johnson of First Albany.
 
'A Lot of Blow-ups'
 The concern is starting to show up in the brutal treatment accorded to stocks that disappoint investors.
"There were a lot of blowups this week, where individual stocks were taken out and shot," Mr. Sullivan said on Friday. He pointed to the fate of Community Psychiatric Centers of Laguna Hills, Calif. The company's stock plunged more than 27 percent on Friday when it reported third-quarter earnings of only a penny a share. The stock was the second-largest-percentage loser on the New York Stock Exchange during the quarter.
"At some point, there is an exhaustion of the willingness to wait for earnings," he said, pointing to the sharp drop of Community Psychiatric shares as a sign of "the beginning of the unwillingness to extend the hope."
Gene Seagle, the director of technical research for Gruntal & Company, said investors were easily flustered by earnings disappointments or bad economic statistics. "The bullishness is skin deep," he said. "You scratch that outside skin and you begin to see a little bear fuzz come through."
Still, Mr. Seagle said the market's ability to shrug off the failed coup in the Soviet Union and the Salomon Brothers Treasury-bidding scandal was a testament to the underlying strength in stocks.
 
4,137 Gains in Quarter
 Of 4,137 stocks tracked by Media General Services, 2,476 showed gains for the quarter, as of Friday, compared with 1,490 stocks that declined. Another 171 issues were unchanged for the quarter, which ends today. The Media General ranking is based on Friday's closing prices, and only includes stocks that were selling at $5 or more at the start of the quarter.
On the Big Board, 1,008 stocks were up for the period, while 533 lost ground. The issues of 55 companies were unchanged.
The biggest gainer on the Big Board was the Triton Energy Corporation in Dallas, which rose 127.6 percent, to $43.25. The shares continued to climb in excitement over the potential of a large Colombian oilfield discovered earlier this year.
Eljer Industries, a plumbing supplier based in Plano, Tex., was the Big Board's biggest loser. A proposed takeover by the Jacuzzi unit of Hanson P.L.C. of Britain fell apart in June after the company disclosed that it faced significant product-liability losses.
"The deal is dead," said Robert F. Costello, Jr., an analyst with Widmann, Siff & Company in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He said the company's product-liability problems were related to damage caused to buildings by leaky pipes made by Eljer.
 
Big Amex Gain
 A natural-gas discovery in Louisiana led to the largest increase on the American Stock Exchange. The stock of Plains Resources Inc. of Houston jumped 274 percent, to $19.63.
The shares of 261 companies rose during the third quarter on the American Stock Exchange, while 219 stocks were down and 14 were unchanged.
The Immune Response Corporation was one of the many biotechnology companies that fared well during the quarter. The company was the largest percentage gainer on the over-the-counter market, closing Friday at $32, up nearly 200 percent.
In over-the-counter trading, 1,207 stocks rose during the quarter, while 738 stocks fell and 102 were unchanged.
