HEADLINE: In Paris Protest, Farmers Sing Blues

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 29

 BODY:
Angry over falling prices for their products and fearful that change in Europe will hurt them still more, the farmers of France marched in the tens of thousands through Paris today to dramatize their warning that the French countryside is slowly dying.
Many wooed Parisians with gifts of wine, sausage and cheese, while others wore regional costumes and played music from home to add color. 
 But the message of the 200,000 marchers was uniformly grim. "We need help -- that's the message," a ruddy-faced farmer from the Loire Valley said. "Rural France is in despair."
 
Many Near Bankrupcy
 The latest crisis, brought on by two years of drought and aggravated by a 25 percent drop in wholesale prices, has left thousands of cattle, sheep and dairy farmers close to bankruptcy.
And, as always in France, many of the marchers are looking to the Government for help.
But for the country's million farmers, the future alarms them the most. They are facing new competition from Eastern Europe, while the European Community is debating changes in its common agricultural policy that would sharply cut subsidies to French farmers.
So by organizing today's demonstration, which opposition leaders on the left and the right rushed to support, the farmers hoped to display a political strength that the Socialist leadership of President Francois Mitterrand dare not ignore just months before crucial local elections.
The Government's reaction to the march has stirred interest far beyond France, because on it may also hang the fate of the community's agricultural policy, community trade with the former East bloc and a new round of global trade-liberalization talks sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
France Has Most to Lose
 Until now, the French Government has stood by its farmers. This month, it infuriated its European partners by vetoing the entry of 550 tons of additional meat from Poland into community countries. As a result, a plan by the community to sign agreements to aid Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary was postponed.
Within the 12-nation community, France is not alone in opposing a big cutback in farm subsidies. But as Europe's largest food exporter, it has the most to lose and has resisted cuts most strongly. In France, it is argued, agriculture goes far beyond simple economics to embrace an entire way of life.
At the same time, without concessions by the community, there is no hope of completing the Uruguay round of trade talks under the international General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The talks broke down in December after the community, led by France, rejected sharply lower farm-price supports demanded by the United States and other food exporters.
But France is now under mounting international pressure to give way. European governments with smaller interests in agriculture question the effectiveness of community subsidies worth $50 billion a year. Many countries are also frustrated that a GATT accord to liberalize $1 trillion in trade is held up by the agricultural dispute.
 
Community Is Denounced
 Most farmers today, as they left hundreds of rural communities before dawn for the drive to Paris, recognized that much more was involved than a new petition for help from the Government. Many banners denounced the European Community.
"The discussions in Brussels are a true disaster for European farmers," said Raymond Lacombe, the head of the National Federation of Farming Unions. "One gets the impression that Europe is on its knees before the United States. It seems ready to give in on everything."
The strategy of the organizers of today's march, though, was not simply to protest but also to win the support of Parisians by underlining links between town and country and, most of all, by reminding them that the essence of France's "art of living" lies in its countryside.
Before farmers gathered to march between the Place de la Nation and the Place de la Bastille, with 10,000 policemen on hand to discourage troublemakers, many set up stalls in different neighborhoods to offer tastes of their products and to make their case directly with Parisians.
"What is France without its villages?" a farmer from the central region of Correze asked. "It is city neighborhoods and alienation. Why do the French like going to the countryside? Because that's where they find their roots."
 
Farmers' Ranks Decline
 Yet despite the prosperity of farmers in the north and west, the countryside has steadily been losing out to "progress" since World War II. In 1940, 40 percent of the French lived in rural areas; today only 7 percent do. In 1970, the country still had 2.4 million farmers; now there are a million and the estimate for the year 2000 is 700,000.
The steady depopulation of the countryside is only one sign of change. As has been the case elsewhere in Europe and in the United States, the character of many communities has also been transformed by tourists and weekend homes. And the children of farmers, seeing no hope for the future, head increasingly for the cities: today, two of three farmers are more than 45 years old.
If the changes being discussed in Brussels are approved, the crisis for small farmers will get worse because, without subsidies and price supports, many are likely to go out of business. Already, because of the drop in prices since 1988, many are unable to keep up loan payments.
And their anger is spilling over. Three weeks ago, to escape a farmers' protest, President Mitterrand called off a trip to a country town. Several Cabinet ministers have been pelted with tomatoes and eggs by farmers.
Lined up against the farmers, though, is the logic of modernizing a European agricultural policy that not only finances them to produce surplus food -- at present, there is a 900,000-ton beef "mountain," reflecting lack of demand -- but also obliges European consumers to pay more than world market prices.
But with opposition leaders like the former President, Valery Giscard d'Estaing; the former Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac, and the far-rightist leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, all wanting to be seen with the marchers today, the Government seemed in no mood to confront the farming lobby.
The Agriculture Minister, Louis Mermaz, who has suggested that European stockpiles be used to feed the Soviet Union, said the demonstration would help French negotiators, who are trying to block a radical change in the community's agricultural policy.
"The rural world has expressed its intense desire to survive," he said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The Outlook For Rails Is Still Mixed

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH PLATTE, Neb.

 BODY:
"As far as the recession, it's over for us," Pete P. Locke, the manager of terminal operations for the Union Pacific Railroad said as he looked over thousands of rail cars being sorted at the Bailey rail yard.
The railroad's traffic has risen 3.7 percent since January. In August, the increase slowed to 1.1 percent, but some goods surged. 
 Coal was up 11 percent; consumer goods like appliances, tires and plastic goods were up 11.3 percent, and containers and trailers carried on flat cars surged 19.2 percent.
At the yard here, about halfway between Omaha and Denver, cars full of grain, coal and other commodities and cars carrying truck trailers and ship containers were being rearranged into trains that would be sent on to various parts of the country.
Several other railroads, including the Santa Fe and the Illinois Central, have shared in the growth. But over all, the industry is still waiting for more sustained signs of a turnaround. Car loadings since January have been flat.
"It's very mixed," said Graeme Lidgerwood, the railroad analyst at the First Boston Corporation. "The industry has basically bottomed out, but we're not out of the woods yet."
Joel Price, an analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said it was too early to declare a recovery. "In all honesty, the third quarter does not tell me a thing," he said. Industrywide car loadings for the last 11 weeks, he said, were down 2.2 percent.
The recent announcement by the Soviet Union that it plans to buy a million metric tons of grain may cause a blip in the traffic figures soon, Mr. Price said, but he remains cautious.
"The auto business is below normal," he noted. "The coal business is down less than it has been. There is nothing there yet that gives you a clue."
Since the rail industry now closely tracks the trends in the overall economy, he said, it was a good indicator of the mixed signals that abound over all. And that uncertainty makes railroad stocks vulnerable.
The rail group has done better than the market this year, rising roughly 34 percent, compared with 17 percent for the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks.
Thus leading rail stocks have been favorites of investors.
[Conrail has risen from $40.25 at the beginning of this year to $71.375 at Friday's close in trading on the New York Stock Exchange; CSX rose from $31.75 to $51.50; Norfolk Southern from $41.75 to $53.875; Union Pacific from $70.63 to $92.375 and Burlington Northern from $28.75 to $35.25.]
"If the economy does not improve, if the Christmas season turns out be disappointing, then the stocks are somewhat vulnerable," Ms. Lidgerwood added.
But should the rebound in traffic spread to the other railroads, the industry stands to live up to investor expectations.
Almost every big railraod has reduced its operating costs considerably during the recession. Crew sizes have been cut, and altered work rules have enabled the railroads to use their workers more efficiently at rail yards and in maintenance crews.
The railroads have spent heavily on computers to improve their ability to control the flow of traffic and have adopted fiber-optic cables to improve communications. All are also pressing to change their management style, which in the past focused mostly on running a railroad. Now the primary goal is keeping customers happy.
The changes have not gone unnoticed by investors -- particulary large institutional managers who have loaded up heavily on rail stocks.
"There is a keen awareness in the marketplace that there is a lot of operating leverage when traffic improves," Ms. Lidgerwood explained.
And some developments that could help some railroads appear to be likely in the near future. The shipments of grain to the Soviet Union have not as yet begun in the big volumes that are expected to start soon. And the conversion of many East Coast and Southern utilities to low-sulfur coal, which is mined in the West, particulary the Powder River Basin in Wyoming, is expected to lead the surge in the movement of coal. The main railroads to benefit are expected to be the Union Pacific and Burlington Northern in the West and the Norfolk Southern and CSX in the East.
Thus even if the short-term economic trends do not deliver the anticipated profits, the long-term trends are favorable.
And some railroads -- like Union Pacific -- are benefiting now.
"Traffic has picked up drastically," Mr. Locke of Union Pacific said. "Grain is up. Stores are adding their Christmas goods."

HEADLINE: ESTIMATE ON GOLD WORSENS OUTLOOK FOR SOVIET UNION

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 29

 BODY:
In a development that adds more gloom to the Soviet Union's economic outlook, a key economic policy maker has announced that the nation's gold reserves are far smaller than the West believed.
As the Soviets prepare for a tough winter amid fears of widespread hunger, sharply lower reserves would mean the Government has a far smaller cushion to help make the payments on its $70 billion in foreign debt and to provide for emergency imports of food and other goods. 
 Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the architect of plans to move toward a market economy, said Friday that the Soviet Union had 240 metric tons in official gold reserves, worth about $3 billion. That is less than one-fifth of what many Western officials estimated.
 
Decades of Secrecy
 For decades, there has been official secrecy about the gold reserves, which the Kremlin regarded as a strategic asset. In disclosing figures, Mr. Yavlinsky may have hoped to increase pressure on the West to provide debt relief and food aid.
Many Western officials have hesitated to support vast economic aid to Moscow because they believe the nation has huge official gold reserves, worth perhaps as much as $25 billion.
The estimate of $3 billion in reserves is very much at the low end of private Western estimates, most of which have exceeded $10 billion. In Washington, a United States Treasury official who insisted on anonymity said the department could not confirm the accuracy of Mr. Yavlinsky's remarks.
 
No Decisions From U.S.
 The Treasury official said the United States was reviewing the Soviet Union's debt situation but that no decisions had been made.
Mr. Yavlinsky, in an interview broadcast on Soviet television, said Moscow had sold two-thirds of its gold reserves last year to help finance imports and pay interest on its debt. Some experts suggested that the Soviet Union had pledged gold reserves as collateral on loans, which could help explain why the price of gold did not shift strikingly last year, as it would have if so much gold had been sold.
The deepening Soviet economic crisis has been underscored by the grain harvest, which is falling below already pessimistic estimates, and by inflation, which is soaring.
Food supplies are declining at the same time that Government printing presses are working around the clock to print rubles -- a mixture that is fueling inflationary pressures. Fifty- and 100-ruble notes are being put back in circulation; former Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov, one of the coup plotters, had ordered them confiscated in a ham-handed effort to fight inflation. In addition, some Soviet officials say the Government will soon begin printing 500-ruble notes for the first time.
Central bank officials say the amount of money in circulation could surge to 240 billion rubles by January, up from 136 billion at the beginning of this year. Increasing the inflationary pressure, the monetary overhang -- the money people are forced to save because there are not enough goods to buy -- soared to 186 billion rubles on Sept. 1, up 40 percent from 132 billion last Janaury.
 
Unleashing Inflationary Forces
 All this is unleashing explosive inflationary forces. At present, inflation is estimated to be running at 100 to 250 percent, and some economists say it could soar to 1,000 percent, especially if the fraying trade ties between the republics worsen the supply situation.
The food situation has alarmed Soviet officials. They note that the wheat harvest is running far below last year's levels. The Government said 148.4 million metric tons were harvested by the fourth week of September, down 27 percent from 203.6 million tons at the comparable time last year.
Soviet officials say the disappointing harvest underlines the urgency of their appeal for $14.7 billion in emergency food aid for the winter.
"We shall not be able to survive the winter without some Western deliveries," Leonid Abalkin, a senior economic adviser to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said Friday in a speech in New York.
After forecasting a grain harvest of 190 million tons, many Soviet officials now fear that this year's harvest, scheduled to end in mid-October, will fall below 170 million tons, down sharply from 230 million tons last year.
Many economists attribute the decline to overall government and economic disarray, as well as poor weather, and the increased difficulties in getting students and soldiers to participate in the harvest. In a nation where statistics cannot always be trusted, some experts suggest that farms are deliberately underreporting their harvest to make it easier for them to hoard grain or to sell it on the black market.
Compounding the food problem is the system of distributing goods, which is deteriorating rapidly in the wrangle over who has authority over what. One Moscow newspaper cited a K.G.B. document that said St. Petersburg was receiving three-fifths of the food it needed.
 
Excitement Giving Way to Gloom
 With each passing day, the excitement that resulted from the defeat of last month's coup is giving way to gloom over the economy. In Moscow and other cities, many stores are closed because there is nothing to stock their shelves. In stores that have goods to sell, huge lines fan out onto the sidewalk.
One factor behind inflation is that banks in the Soviet republics are freely issuing credits to money-losing companies to keep them in business and to meet their payrolls, which has forced the Soviet central bank to print billions of rubles to back those credits. As workers clamor for raises, the Government's budget deficit is expected to soar to close to 300 billion rubles, or 15 percent of the gross national product.
"Everyone from miners to teachers wants raises and bonuses," Mr. Abalkin said. "If we don't do it there will be a social explosion. We are printing money on three shifts, on weekends, and still don't have time to finish the work. We are even short of the special paper needed for printing money."
 
Price of Milk Up Sharply
 When milk is available in state stores, it sells for 60 kopecks a liter, a considerable sum in a nation where the average monthly wage for a government worker is about 300 rubles. In the private markets, milk sells for 3 rubles, or five times the rate at the state store. State food stores, where the nation's poor pensioners shop, are finding it increasingly hard to obtain supplies because farmers divert as much produce as possible to private distribution, which pays them far more.
The surge in inflation will make the conversion to a market economy far more difficult. As happened in Poland, the Soviet Government is likely to have to clamp down on the money supply and raise interest rates to stabilize inflation. But as happened in Poland, that could cause a jolting recession in an already desperate economy. Economic output plunged 12 percent in Poland in 1990, the year the post-Communist Government sought to bring triple-digit inflation under control.
Most economists predict Soviet industrial output will be down 15 to 20 percent this year from last year. There are numerous factors: government disarray, the initial moves to a market economy, the aging of the nation's capital stock, and the sharp drop in trade with Eastern Europe.
Many economists say the economic situation will grow worse because of trade frictions between the republics and a lack of economic coordination.
"I think that in December, national production will be 50 percent of what it was last December," said Anders Aslund, director of the Stockholm Institute of Soviet and East European Economies. "It's no longer so easy to get people to obey orders. One has to ask, for example, whether the railway system will continue functioning."

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARMS PLAN;
In Moscow, Usual Reaction To Bush Arms Plan Is Muted

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 29

 BODY:
President Bush's sweeping arms initiative has played softly in the country that in principle stood most to gain from it, partly from old habit, partly from mixed feelings and partly from simple fatigue.
No newspapers were published today, though both the Russian republic and national television news programs carried reports on the development. The main news program declared the initiative to be the main event of the last week, while the Russian program, Vesti, said the American move "gives the Soviet Union a chance to get rid of its tactical weapons." 
 There were no further reactions from Soviet officials. On Saturday, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared the initiative "very positive," and other officials said they expected Moscow to reciprocate in kind.
A Tass commentary likewise suggested that the Soviet Union would be eager to match the American reductions. "It's no secret that leaders in the center and in the republics are seriously concerned over the presence of a huge nuclear arsenal, so the unilateral initiative of the head of the White House is most timely," wrote Gennadi Petrov, a foreign-affairs commentator for Tass.
 
Little Reaction in Streets
 There was little immediate reaction in the streets. But that was not entirely surprising among people long taught to let others worry about international affairs and besieged with enormous problems far closer to home.
Those who did comment often gave a sense of feeling that the importance of the American initiative lay less in reducing the American military threat, which in any case has ceased being a major concern, than in giving Soviet leaders an opening to withdraw the thousands of battlefield nuclear weapons scattered among the republics.
"At a moment when a Chechen might attack a Georgian and a Georgian might attack a Tatar, tactical arms can be very dangerous," said Yevgeny P. Petritsky, a reporter from the Moscow suburb of Elektrostal. Continuing reports of tensions in Tadzhikistan, Georgia, Moldavia and elsewhere across the nation seemed to underscore the point. But these troubling reports, coupled with growing concerns over food and fuel supplies as leaves turn golden and temperatures drop, seemed a far more immediate concern than some distant and increasingly theoretical threat.
 
Memorial for 3 Youths
 The main event in Moscow was an outdoor memorial service marking 40 days since the deaths of three youths killed during the coup. The bells and chants of the Russian Orthodox ceremony under gray, drizzly skies seemed also to mark another stage in the passing of the euphoria that came with the collapse of the coup.
Many people here seemed struck by their own lack of interest when a questioner asked them about it. Some attributed it to habit. As one Muscovite said, "We've been raised on the idea that somebody up there will come up with the right reaction, and Gorbachev did it already."
Others said that a progression of disarmament agreements had largely taken the novelty out of the process, and that nuclear war had long ceased to be a major fear.
"Since 1986, when Gorbachev first came out with a program of disarmament, the process has become habitual," said Sergei A. Zverev, an assistant to Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the senior Soviet economist.
He added: "I also remember an article in The New York Times three weeks ago in which somebody wondered whether Americans should take the Russians seriously any more, whether they were equal partners in the international arena. This move comes not from greater trust, but because the parity is broken, because we're not a serious factor."
Besides, Mr. Zverev said, he had just returned from standing two hours in line for butter.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An outdoor memorial service was held in Moscow yesterday marking 40 days since the deaths of three youths who were killed during the failed coup attempt. A woman lit candles in memory of the victims. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARMS PLAN;
Bush's New Tack: An Offer to the Soviet Republics

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
In addition to rewriting the rules of arms control with his landmark announcement on Friday, President Bush took a major step toward fundamentally altering the broader Soviet-American relationship as the political order in Moscow weakens in the wake of the Kremlin putsch.
In form at least, Mr. Bush's decision to eliminate most short-range nuclear weapons, take American bombers off alert status and offer to negotiate cuts in multiple-warhead missiles seemed to follow the traditional way of doing business: The American head of state made proposals to the Soviet Union, and the Soviet head of state, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, replied. 
 But it was the first time in such a major state-to-state initiative that Washington also dealt directly with the republics' leaders, especially Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian federation.
Whatever Mr. Gorbachev decides to do about the Soviet Union's short-range nuclear weapons, the United States is hoping that some republic leaders will act on their own to destroy those arms stored on their territory.
 
Inviting Reciprocity
 And though the White House was trying to take advantage of whatever is left of Moscow's central authority, Mr. Bush chose to take unilateral steps and invite reciprocity specifically because he did not want to become engaged in negotiations with the weakened Soviet Government.
That was a major step toward taking the initiative in molding change in the Soviet Union. The question now is whether Mr. Bush can translate that boldness into other areas, including economic relations, where the biggest obstacle may not be a lack of vision but a lack of money.
Certainly, the President seemed to recognize in acting Friday that the political ground was eroding under his policy of propping up Mr. Gorbachev and the Moscow Government.
"It will be increasingly hard to deal with the center in this sort of head-of-state-to-head-of-state way and have it mean much," a senior American policy maker said today. "If you need any evidence to that effect, I would simply point out that we communicated with Boris Yeltsin right after we got the word to Gorbachev about the President's initiative."
 
Doubts on Gorbachev's Future
 As Mr. Bush gropes for safe passage through this volatile period in Soviet affairs, his advisers are increasingly convinced that time is running out forMr. Gorbachev, his friend and fellow summiteer. "If Gorbachev is smart, he'll use the arms control initiative to demonstrate how indispensable he is," the senior official. "But I still think that he would just be stalling for time."
The arms control proposal may temporarily relieve the pressure on Mr. Bush to show greater initiative in other aspects of Soviet-American relations.
Mr. Bush's senior advisers are already presenting the case that the President made a discrete move in a confined area, and that this was not a signal that he will abandon his cautious approach to direct economic assistance. "You cannot take what we did and apply it across the board," an official said.
But the President will have to confront the argument that if he can act so decisively in arms control, he could do the same thing when it comes to promoting economic and political reform in the Soviet Union.
"That needs a multiple effort from Tokyo to Brussels, said Robert Legvold, head of the Harriman Institute at Columbia University. "And for that to happen, the Americans have to lead because it's not going to be led by Bonn or by Tokyo." .
 
Arms Control Re-emerges
 The sudden re-emergence of arms control was striking after a week in which the visit to the United States by Leonid M. Kravchuk, the Ukrainian leader, seemed to symbolize how Soviet-American relations were moving to an economic footing.
But if Mr. Bush returned to familiar territory, he did so in an unconventional way and at a time when many Administration officials believe that they will not have much longer to capitalize on their relationship with the central authority in the Soviet Union.
"We tried to take advantage of the fact that at least temporarily, the coup simply wiped out the top echelon of the conservatives who were negative about arms control, negative about the relationship in general," a senior official said.
But he added: "Right now, they are going in the other direction. The centrifugal forces are predominant in the Soviet Union."
Mr. Bush's actions were a conscious attempt to manipulate Soviet internal affairs in an almost unprecedented way, by trying to influence the debate over who will have control of Soviet nuclear weapons. Washington hopes that the leaders of the republics where short-range nuclear weapons are stored -- Russia, the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Kazakhstan -- will now destroy those weapons on their own authority.
Mr. Legvold said: "If we had negotiated with the center on this, it would have been largely irrelevant and, even worse, counterproductive. You have to have the support of the Russian, Ukrainian and Kazakh leaders."
The President's attempt to capitalize on the weakened Soviet power structure is all the more striking because that weakness is at the heart of his reluctance to promise major economic assistance to the Soviet Union.
Mr. Bush argues that the United States cannot commit such aid while it is unclear who will receive it and what the relationships will be between the republics and what is now the central Government.
 
Two Different Fields
 A case can be made that economics and arms control are vastly different.
"Presidents have unusual power in the area of nuclear weapons, even beyond the general powers of foreign policy, since as commander-in-chief he can say things unilaterally and Congress would have a hard time saying no," said William G. Hyland, editor of the journal Foreign Affairs and a former White House national security aide in the Nixon and Ford Administrations.
But economic relations are not something a President can dictate. Mr. Bush has enormous influence, but he has been reluctant to use it to promote investment in the Soviet Union as it now stands, hoping that there would be at least some economic confederation with which the United States could do business.
A senior official said: "We're going to have to find ways to change our relationship with a structure that we can't define clearly, a diffusion of sovereignty."
Still, Mr. Legvold argued that Mr. Bush could apply the same boldness that he showed on Friday to economics, not by offering money but by doing essentially what he did with nuclear weapons -- taking unilateral steps that invite reciprocity.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "What the Terms Mean"
A glossary of nuclear weapons terminology.
 
Ballistic missile: A missile that travels outside of the atmosphere for part of its flight and approaches its target as a free-falling object.
 
Battlefield weapons: See tactical.
 
Cruise missile: A low-flying missile that looks like a flying torpedo, it is powered by an air-breathing engine and is armed with eighther nuclear or nonnuclear warheads. The current generation of cruise missiles, which are subsonic, can be launched from the ground (GLCM's), sea (SLCM's) or air (ALCM's).
 
Intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM): A land-based missile that has a range of more than about 3,400 miles. The Soviet SS-18 and the American Minuteman are examples.
 
Long-range weapons: See strategic.
 
Multiple independently targetable re-entry vehicle (MIRV): One of several warheads carried by a single ballistic missile that can be directed at separate targets.
 
Submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM): A ballistic missile launched from a submarine.
 
Strategic: A term used to describe nuclear weapons that have range considered intercontinental, or more than 3,400 miles.
 
Tactical: Tactical weapons are short-range systems used on the battlefield.
 
Throw weight: The amount of weight a missile can carry to its target.
 
Verification: The process of determining whether a party is adhering to the terms of an agreement. Means of verification include surveillance satellites.

HEADLINE: Ukraine Chief Faces Hurdles In Quest for U.S. Recognition

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

 BODY:
In a pointed exchange with American scholars the other day, President Leonid M. Kravchuk of the Soviet Ukraine resisted pleas that he quickly phase out the traditional Communist system of price controls.
"There would be a social explosion," he told his questioners, who urged him to abandon the controls and other vestiges of the Communist centralized economy in an effort to institute a free-market system in his republic. 
 William W. Hogan, a Harvard University expert on the Ukraine's economy, firmly disagreed. "They did it in Poland, and there was no social explosion," he said.
Mr. Kravchuk would not budge on the economic issue, and when the conversation turned to the topic of nuclear arms stationed on Ukrainian soil, he avoided giving a precise answer about the future of these arms. Saying he wanted the Ukraine to be a nuclear-free zone, he added that he opposed transfer of those weapons to Russian or other Soviet soil and declined to be specific about any plans he had to destroy them. Further, while claiming at least partial jurisdiction over these weapons, he said he would insist on taking part in any decision to use them.
 
Hurdle for Ex-Ideologist
 The meeting with the scholars at Harvard's Ukrainian Research Institute, part of a six-day tour by the Communist Party's longtime top ideologist, was one indication of the hurdles Mr. Kravchuk faces in seeking to gain diplomatic recognition for the Ukraine from the American Government and to persuade investors and others that he has shed his past, including more than 30 years as a Communist Party member who rose to the leadership of the republic's party.
The visit also highlighted the quandary President Bush faces as he considers whether to recognize the independence of the Ukraine and other breakaway Soviet republics.
Mr. Kravchuk hoped to nudge the Bush Administration away from its desire to support President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's central Government and also from its opposition to a splintering of the Soviet Union. But Administration officials said that while Mr. Bush had a productive meeting with Mr. Kravchuk on Wednesday, before Mr. Kravchuk went on to Boston, Chicago and New York, Washington will wait for the Ukrainian referendum on independence and the presidential election, both scheduled for Dec. 1, before it seriously considers diplomatic recognition.
Mr. Kravchuk is considered the leading presidential candidate, although support for at least one opposition candidate appears to be growing, one Administration analyst said.
 
A Tailored Message
 The Ukrainian leader renounced his long affiliation to the Communist Party, which he joined in 1958, only after the failed coup last month. His response to the coup appeared cautious, ambivalent or even supportive. He has since become a strong proponent of Ukrainian independence.
Mr. Kravchuk carefully tailored his message to American audiences. He pledged his support for liberty and human rights to a gathering of students at Harvard University, argued that the Ukraine needs unfettered free enterprise when he spoke to officials at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, promised Ukrainian-American scholars that they will be granted greater access to historical archives, and told a group of religious leaders in New York yesterday, after Mr. Bush made his broad nuclear initiative, that he wanted the Ukraine to become a nuclear-free zone.
"We're on the road to a free economy and a free life," he told a group of business leaders and prominent Ukrainian-Americans at a breakfast in Chicago Saturday. "The ideological differences that used to divide us no longer exist."
 
Security Precautions
 After the meeting, he visited a Ukrainian cultural center, where he was serenaded by schoolchildren. But when he drove through the large section of Chicago where many Ukrainians live, he took an unpublicized route because of fears of demonstrations.
In his meeting with President Bush at the White House on Wednesday, Mr. Kravchuk insisted that the United States would eventually have to recognize the Ukraine and the other breakaway republics. He said that while his country did not need food aid, it needed help in distributing and exporting what they produce.
His plea for technical aid to convert scores of arms factories into plants that can produce consumer goods appeared to strike a sympathetic chord at the White House.
At his appearances, Mr. Kravchuk took sometimes contradictory positions on nuclear weapons based in the Ukraine. At a luncheon at the National Press Club in Washington on Thursday, he said: "Control over nuclear weapons should be exerted from the center. However, the Ukraine should participate in this control because they are on its territory."
He said he wanted to make the republic a nuclear-free zone, and told an audience at Harvard on Friday -- before President Bush made his sweeping move on reducing short-range nuclear arms, partly because of concerns about control over those arms in the Soviet republics -- that he favored a rapid destruction of the weapons.
But in Chicago the next day, he said it would take seven years to destroy the 130 nuclear weapons in silos on Ukrainian soil, which he said are to be destroyed under the Start treaty. He said there were 46 other nuclear weapons on Ukrainian soil, without specifying whether they were short range or long range. Before the 46 remaining can be eliminated, he said, "We'll have to conclude another treaty."
 
Views on Independence
 "Deep in his heart, the President is ready to think of Ukraine as an independent state," Mr. Kravchuk said, recalling his 45-minute discussion with Mr. Bush in an interview in Chicago Friday night. "He's waiting for the referendum. He told me that."
Asked if any such commitment was made, a senior Administration official said: "The President said, 'Right now, certainly not.' "
Mr. Bush told Mr. Kravchuk that the United States would strengthen direct ties with the Ukraine by sending the Peace Corps and technical economic advisers in the coming month, Administration officials said.
Mr. Kravchuk has given priority to one-on-one meetings with executives of several corporations, including Monsanto and Coca-Cola, in which he has told them they would be better off investing in Kiev than Moscow.

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARMS PLAN;
The Gun Uncocked At Bases

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KNOB NOSTER, Mo., Sept. 29

 BODY:
In an underground capsule on Whiteman Air Force Base, Lieut. George Farfour was on the alert Friday evening, as usual, near the knobs, switches and dials that could send nuclear missiles shooting from beneath the farm fields of western Missouri and toward the Soviet Union.
The cramped, submarinelike control room is also equipped with a television, and the 27-year-old missileer, as missile crew members are called, had it turned to President Bush's address. 
 As he listened to the announcement of nuclear cutbacks, his eyes grew wide. He turned to his partner in the capsule, Capt. Scott McCormick, who was taking his turn to sleep. "Sir," he said, jostling him awake, "I think there's something you should know about."
The official word came Saturday morning on a printer inside the capsule. The essence of the message: uncock the nuclear gun.
 
'Great Day for Missileers'
 "You could hear all this revelry," said Captain McCormick, referring to the intercom system that links five control capsules. "And someone said loudly, 'This is a great day for missileers.' "
For three decades, the nation's nuclear weapons have been geared to fire at a moment's notice. But after the President's orders to "stand down" from constant alert status, the crews programmed the controls on Saturday in a way that would make it impossible for them to launch the missiles without carrying out a complicated and time-consuming procedure. A crew member likened the action to "taking the keys out of the car's ignition."
Despite the removal of the alert status, the missile crews will continue to work 24-hour shifts in the control centers, monitoring the safety and condition of the missiles.
But their posture is relaxed, and at bases around the country, service personnel spent the weekend adhering to it. Nuclear-tipped bombs were removed from Air Force jets, and the planes were moved to hangars. Nuclear weapons were taken from submarines. Many of the nuclear bombs are to be destroyed.
When the weight of the news finally hit him, Captain McCormick said he felt a welter of emotions. "It made me think: 'This is what we've been here for. This is why we've been doing our jobs.' It made me hopeful to think about world peace."
 
Boredom and Terror
 Work inside the missile control capsules has been described as hours of boredom that could be broken by moments of sheer terror. And for those who have been trained to unleash nuclear weapons, always vigilant for "the unspeakable," as Lieutenant Farfour called it, no order could have brought more joy.
"Our job is to prepare for an action that we never want to take," said Lieutenant Farfour, who wore a blue jumpsuit with a patch that bears the symbol of the Strategic Air Command, a clenched fist gripping a lightning bolt and an olive branch. "There are usually very few ways to measure how well we do. It's hard to measure a deterrent. It's not like on the battlefield where you can see a victory. Well, for us, this is victory."
The new nuclear weapons posture will mean changes for the Strategic Air Command near Omaha, where Air Force officials issue directives from an underground center. Starting next year, the center will be called the Strategic Command, and will be run by both the Navy and the Air Force.
"The underground control center will continue to be a hub of activity around the clock," said Maj. Don Planalf, a spokesman for the Strategic Air Command. "But some of the changes are yet to be sorted out."
The changes are the latest significant move to relax the nation's nuclear weapons readiness. In 1968 the Government brought down the B-52 planes that had stayed constantly aloft since 1957, and put them on "alert" status. The airborne command center, which had been kept in the sky in case of military attack, was brought down last year.
 
Corn, Beans and Warheads
 At the Whiteman Air Force Base here, about 60 miles southeast of Kansas City, 15 underground capsules have served as control centers for 150 nuclear missiles buried in the surrounding countryside. Each control center is operated by two-member crews who work together in 24-hour shifts.
Above the control centers are small buildings that look like surbuban ranch houses. A basketball hoop stands next to some sites. The nuclear silos are under Federal land amid fields of corn and beans. Cyclone fences surround each missile site, with posted warnings to stay away.
For people who live in the region, the presence of the nuclear missiles has always raised some concern that it would be a prime target in a war. "Everyone always figured we'd get hit right away," said Chad Davis, who works at a service station near Warrensburg. "So this makes it a little safer. But now people are a little worried that they'll cut back on the base. That's the strongest part of our economy."
A fleet of B-2 bombers is scheduled to begin operation next year at Whiteman, where 3,400 men and women are stationed. And missile crew members say they are prepared for the possibility that alert status could return. "Our mission isn't over," said Captain McCormick. "Once we feared the British, then the French, then the Soviets. Times will change. But we're always going to have to be ready."
In training to be missile crew members, the officers are instructed to ponder the enormity of their actions, if they should be called upon to launch the nuclear weapons. They are instructed about the devastation that nuclear missiles would cause. And they are told to search their souls: "Is this something you really want to do?" they are asked directly.
"You have to know," said Lieutenant Farfour, "that when you launch, you're probably going to get hit yourself."
When his shift ended, he called his younger brother, James. "Did you see the President?" he asked. "Well, I was carrying out those orders."
And his brother replied, "I'm just glad that this is the order you got."

HEADLINE: Governments Reach Second Settlement With Exxon in Valdez Spill

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: JUNEAU, Alaska, Sept. 29

 BODY:
A second settlement has been reached in the government lawsuits against the Exxon Corporation over the nation's largest oil spill, a spokesman for Gov. Walter J. Hickel said today.
Details of the settlement are being withheld until a formal announcement on Monday, said the spokesman, Eric Rehmann. 
 An earlier settlement, announced in March, fell apart when a Federal judge rejected a plea in the criminal charges against Exxon and the Alaska House voted down the entire agreement. Negotiations between Exxon, the state and the Federal Government resumed this month; the criminal trial is scheduled to start Oct. 7 in Federal District Court in Anchorage.
An Exxon spokesman in Texas, Bill Smith, declined to comment on the new settlement, and a Justice Department spokesman in Washington, Doug Krovisky, said he was unaware of any settlement or announcement.
 
A Spill and Its Sequels
 The criminal charges and civil suits arose from the March 1989 accident in which the tanker Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in Prince William Sound when she slammed into a reef. The oil killed many thousands of marine birds and mammals. It was devastating to the region's native villages, where most residents still live off the land and sea.
Under the previous settlement, Exxon and a subsidiary agreed to plead guilty to four misdemeanors and pay a record $100 million fine. Two felony pollution charges would have been dropped.
Exxon would have paid $900 million over 11 years to restore damaged natural resources. That money would have settled the state's civil claims against Exxon and any future claims by the Federal Government. But it would not have affected private lawsuits seeking a total of $59 billion in damages from the company.
The settlement would have been the largest of an environmental damage case in United States history. It would have provided immediate cash to continue the spill cleanup and would have avoided long and costly court battles.
Opponents argued that the criminal fine was inadequate considering Exxon's wealth and the damage its tanker caused, and that the settlement's true value would have been far less than $1 billion because of the effects of inflation over the 11-year payout period.
Pressure has been building on Exxon to settle the government litigation. In the past two weeks, fishermen, landowners, cannery workers, Alaska natives and other private interests agreed to drop their lawsuits against the state and Federal Government. That meant a united front of plaintiffs suing Exxon.
Lloyd Miller, an Anchorage lawyer who represents several native Alaskan corporations and villages in litigation against Exxon said he did not know the details of the settlement. But he said he thought its amount would be about the same, with a shift in the way it is allocated, so more money would go toward criminal fines and less the civil settlement.
"I think everybody is going to be concerned about the bottom line," he said. "There's still oil out there and they're real worried that there may not be enough money in the settlements to do the kind of monitoring and restoration that will need to be done for the next two decades. When all the lawyer stuff is put aside and all the posturing is put aside, you've got to have enough money to do the job because Exxon's not going to be doing it."
In exchange for dropping the lawsuits, the governments agreed to give the private plaintiffs access to their research on the spill's damage and Exxon's liability.
Joseph Hazelwood of Huntington, L.I., the ship's captain, was accused of drinking on shore before the tanker left Port Valdez, but he was acquitted of state charges that he operated the ship while intoxicated.

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARMS PLAN;
Monetary Fund Warns Of Shortage in Savings

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund is increasingly concerned about a worldwide shortage of money for productive investments like building factories and says that unless industrial nations cut military spending and curtail trade subsidies, the world economy will suffer.
"The present tendency toward recovery could be affected," said a senior official, presenting a stronger and gloomier vision of the world economy than only a few months ago. "A number of investment projects would have to be abandoned." 
 The official, who spoke on behalf of the financial institution but insisted on anonymity, addressed reporters on Friday afternoon before President Bush's call on Friday evening for the sweeping elimination of entire classes of nuclear weapons now deployed or under development. The official spoke on condition that his remarks not be reported until this evening. An aide to the senior I.M.F. officials said his remarks were not linked to the President's.
On a separate subject, the official said that the monetary fund remains ready to offer special associate status to the Soviet Union as soon as it applies, an action that would allow the international financial institution to provide wide-ranging technical advice but not the large-scale financial assistance that Soviet authorities have sought. The Soviet Union has applied for full membership instead, which would allow it to borrow heavily.
 
Bush Wants No Cuts
 President Bush said in his speech on Friday that his measures were intended to improve security rather than to save money, and might actually cost money in the near term. "Given the ambitious plan I have already proposed to reduce U.S. defense spending by 25 percent, we cannot afford to make any unwise or unwarranted cuts in the defense budget I have submitted to Congress," he said.
The senior monetary fund official said that if the industrialized world does not increase its overall savings rate, preferably by shrinking military spending and as well as trade subsidies that now force many governments to borrow heavily, not only industrial countries but developing countries will suffer.
The official said that new spending policies in the developed world are especially important now because changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe coupled with peace in the Middle East have created an extraordinary opportunity for global prosperity. But too much money is being spent on military forces and protectionist trade practices instead of being invested to produce more resources, he added.
"If we want to make sure that these opportunities don't vanish, but are transformed into real improvements for people, then we will have to be active in convincing governments to go to better governance and to address these issues of unproductive spending," he said.
Michel Camdessus, the monetary fund's managing director, has delivered similar but less strongly worded warnings in recent speeches. If all the countries now spending a high percentage of their economic output on the military were to match the world average instead, annual worldwide savings of $140 billion would be generated, Mr. Camdessus told an audience in Geneva in July.
Protectionist agricultural policies cost the world another $299 billion in 1990, he said in the same speech.
 
Turnaround on Eastern Europe
 The monetary fund is an immensely powerful institution with 155 member nations. It requires certain fiscal and monetary policies of several dozen less developed countries that receive its loans, sets rules for the international monetary system and provides the economic statistics and forecasts used at the annual meetings of President Bush and leaders of six other industrial democracies.
Until now, the International Monetary Fund has tended to downplay the concerns of some economists that the opening up of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, coupled with the adoption of more free-market policies in developing countries, would lead to a global shortage of savings. The same senior official who addressed reporters on Friday discounted such worries in his last semiannual briefing in April.
The normal operation of international credit market will insure that savings do match investments in the coming years, the official said Friday. But the shortage of savings in the developed world means that this matching may take place at higher interest rates, he said, so that fewer investments will be made worldwide.
"We do believe this negative adjustment, through higher interest rates, can be avoided but not without efforts" to limit military and other unproductive spending, he said.
Richard F. Grimmett, a defense specialist at the Congressional Research Service, said worldwide military spending as a percentage of global economic output has already been falling from a peak of 5.7 percent in 1982 and 1983, when the war between Iran and Iraq was at its height. The end of that war and the decline of cold-war tensions had pushed this figure down to 5.0 percent by 1988, the most recent year for which complete and reliable figures are available, he said.
The world produced $20.64 trillion worth of goods and services in 1988 and spent $1.03 trillion on the military, Mr. Grimmett said, citing figures from the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

HEADLINE: Athens Journal;
2,500 Years Old, and My, How the Child Has Grown

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, Sept. 29

 BODY:
"Poor democracy," said Virginia Tsouderas with a sigh. "Is there any other word that has been so widely misused?"
As a member of the Greek Parliament she was raising a glass this weekend as Athens celebrated what is being called democracy's 2,500th anniversary. 
 With representatives from more than 40 democracies in attendance here at the cradle of the concept, music and declamations echoed over the very hills where Athenians of all classes began to argue as equals and learned to challenge their rulers in ways no land had ever seen before.
Declaring democracy to be robust, expanding and more topical than ever, the Greek President, Constantinos Karamanlis, said the notion was so laudable that "even totalitarian regimes -- people's republics, dictatorships -- oppress their people in the name of democracy."
The three days of festivities here that ended on Saturday were only the start of a chain of ceremonies, lectures and exhibits planned in many other countries, including the United States, over the next two years.
"Rule by the people" emerged in stages in Athens during the sixth century B.C., but the commemorations focus on the work of Cleisthenes, the Athenian who established the framework for a direct democracy that was to last more than 200 years. He was widely hailed this week as the man who defied his powerful fellow aristocrats and insured free speech, equality before the law and everyone's right to share power in the assembly of all citizens. Still, women and slaves in ancient Greece were not considered citizens.
 
The Details Don't Matter
 Behind the oratorical flourishes here, scholars continue to disagree about the exact moment of Cleisthenes's constitutional reforms. Those who hold to the year 508 B.C. say that the current celebrations have come a year too early. But some of Cleisthenes's followers, members of Parliament and other democratic envoys from around the world, seemed unconcerned about such details.
"Beautiful, oh how very beautiful," said Nancy Ellis, the sister of President Bush and leader of the United States delegation, Friday night as she walked along the Pnyx, the rocky platform where ancient Athenians used to hold their popular assemblies.
Others, too, seemed in awe as the nearby temples of the Acropolis were set aglow in golden floodlights, the full moon rose in a cloudless sky and the Speaker of the Greek Parliament began to address the crowd from the stone podium where, he recalled, Solon and Pericles had stood before him and set a new course for all of Western civilization.
This audience, though, was certainly better behaved than the ancient Athenians, a contemporary citizen noted, because the ancients in full assembly would argue and yell for hours and sometimes days on end. On this Friday night there was quiet as actors read ancient texts and documents that sprang from them, including the Magna Carta of England, the American Declaration of Independence and France's Declaration of the Rights of Man.
"There is no question that there is a direct connection between the American democracy and the most successful democracy of the ancient world," said Frank Frost, of California, a professor of ancient history. "Athenian democracy was well studied by the fathers of our own Constitution, who were much better read than our present-day politicians."
For the organizers, dealing with so many democrats has not been easy. "First of all, we had the problem of whom to invite," said Marios Rafael, the meeting coordinator. "How do you judge which is a democratic country? Even Qaddafi says he is a democrat, but if he comes, others do not."
Greece settled the matter by inviting the member countries of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and the members of the Council of Europe. As a result, the meeting brought together representatives from systems as old as the Magna Carta and as young as the August coup in Moscow. No House or Senate members from the United States attended. Many other parliaments sent their Speaker or president, some of whom arrived with retinues worthy of autocrats.
"I don't want to be unkind," Mr. Rafael said, "but a lot of delegations brought more people than we invited. It caused a lot of headaches."
There were frowns as the American delegation sped in limousines up the Pnyx Hill while the representatives of other countries were made to abandon their cars and climb. "Some democracies are more imperial than others," sniffed a delegate from Spain.
Not surprisingly, amid so many legislators there was talk of redefining and reshaping democracy and debate on questions like: how democratic is it, really, to intervene in another nation in the name of democracy?
One discussion over drinks in the presidential palace gardens concluded that one extreme, the direct democracy of the Athenians, was far too unwieldy for modern times, but that the other extreme, the United States, the world's largest representative democracy, had strayed too far because "its elections are now for sale."
Another group of representatives tried to draw a link between the ancient city-state and today's resurgent nationalism in many regions. The group, made up of Europeans, postulated that the days of the super-state may be numbered, even as it is being born in Europe. As more regions demand autonomy, the politicians suggested, the hour of the mini-state may be at hand.
 
The Food Has Improved
 On an earthier note, Greek members of Parliament at a buffet table decided that today's representatives ate better food than their predecessors, the Councilors of ancient Athens, who got free meals at the Prytanion, or the House of the Councilors.
"I think they ate lima beans and dried figs and things like that," said one member, reaching for salmon and beef slices.
"Right!" replied a colleague. "Remember Socrates at his trial, when he was asked what punishment he proposed for himself instead of the death sentence, said, 'Feed me at the Prytanion for the rest of my life.' "
The celebrations here have not proved to be a boost for the morale of Greeks, who are in the midst of an economic crisis and witnessing the corruption trial of former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and four Cabinet ministers. Although the events have been duly reported in the press, they have been largely formal ones involving few citizens of this capital, which today suffers almost every disadvantage of an overgrown city and few of its benefits.
"Still, I want to be here," said Amanda Clarke, an American historian exploring Greece. "This is the place where people first struggled with the question of the rights of the individual versus the interests of the whole group. We are still haggling over this today. And Athens is a good place to think about this."

(Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSH'S ARMS PLAN;
Inside Churches, Few Cheers And Some Jeers on Arms Plan

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON

 BODY:
In Bonn, Moscow and Washington, President Bush's announcement of unilateral cuts in nuclear arms may be seen as momentous and historic. But at the Pilgrim Baptist Church in Chicago, where people scurried along dark corridors to choir rehearsal and to usher- board meetings, yesterday was just another Sunday, not the second chapter in the new world order.
Children in navy suits, crisp white dresses and gloves passed the collection plate, deacons announced a bake sale and midweek prayer service and the news that some nuclear weapons would soon be eliminated merited not a word from the guest preacher, the Rev. Yvonne Lee Wilson. Only when pressed did members even vaguely recall that President Bush had made some remarks about nuclear weapons. 
 Mr. Bush's proposal was seen by some of the 500 congregants at this all-black church on the South Side as just another pronouncement from an often-mistrusted President, not a turning point in history. And many worried that Mr. Bush's action was coming too late to rid the world completely of nuclear arms.
"They never should have made them in the first place," said James Edwards, a retired school custodian who is a church usher. "It's for God to destroy the earth, not man."
 
How to Spend the Savings
 Around the nation, as bright fall mornings dawned and people made their way to church services, concerns like homelessness and unemployment seemed greater preoccupations than the proposal, which was announced Friday night. Few preachers even mentioned the proposal and what it could mean. Many of their members were cautious about declaring the arms race over, citing uncertainty about how arms reductions would be verified, and whether other countries not party to the proposal -- Iraq, for example -- might upset the world all over again.
Still, if they allowed themselves to believe it might happen, some had specific proposals for how to spend the money that would be saved by shrinking the American nuclear arsenal.
"There'll be a huge savings that should be spent on housing all over urban America, where it's needed," said Adam Clayton Powell 4th, a former New York City Council candidate who was interviewed outside the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem.
"He could buy food for the homeless," said Victor Chalk, a homeless man and a member of the New Hope Baptist Church in Seattle's Central District, an area beset with gang violence, crime and high unemployment. "I've got people of all races helping me out. Do you think he would?"
Mr. Chalk's pastor, the Rev. Robert L. Jeffrey, focused on the arms reduction proposal in his sermon. Addressing himself to Mr. Bush, the minister shouted: "You are neglecting us. You are cutting bombs without cutting poverty. You are selling us on 'Star Wars' and the B-2 bomber, and you are neglecting the 34 million people on poverty in this country."
Others wanted to be sure the United States would properly manage its role in the new world order, whatever it turned out to be. "We have to be ready to move forward with peace," said Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., who spoke briefly of improved chances for global peace during his sermon at the Riverside Church in Manhattan.
Some thought arms reductions were the natural result of political changes in the Soviet Union. Antonio L. Argiz, a Miami resident who went to the 11 o'clock Mass at The Epiphany Church there yesterday, said he thought the President should have made the offer earlier. "He waited far into the scenario," Mr. Argiz said. "Now Russia has no country; there is no power base there."
Mr. Argiz predicted that fewer nuclear weapons would mean diminished global tension, but added: "Not all the problems of the world have been solved. There is still world hunger and turmoil in the Middle East, where anything can cause that situation to blow up."
Others felt the proposal itself held risks for American security. "I don't think we should be too far out front in getting rid of the things God has given us to protect ourselves," said Ivor Mae Barefield, a retired school psychologist who attends Pilgrim Baptist Church in Chicago. "We need some kind of backup."
Beatrice Evans, interviewed outside the Wieuca Road Baptist Church in Atlanta, had some of the same worries. "I'm still very suspicious about the motives of some countries," she said. "But we have ways of finding out what capabilities they have."
Her pastor, Dr. Paul A. Basden, spoke of a changed but hardly trouble-free world. "We can't be naive now and pretend all of the threats have been eliminated," he said. "But the U.S.S.R has been dissolved and I don't think the arms reduction is a hoax. We have good reason to celebrate."

HEADLINE: Zaire's Dictator Agrees to Share Power With Foe

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Sept. 29

 BODY:
President Mobutu Sese Seko, who has held absolute power in this impoverished Central African country for 26 years while amassing a personal fortune, today agreed to let an opposition leader form a new coalition government that could mark the end of his autocratic reign.
President Mobutu's agreement to share power was first announced Saturday night and confirmed when a deadlock in negotiations over the choice of a new prime minister was broken today. 
 The accord followed a week of looting and violence touched off by mutinous soldiers angered because they had not been paid. Discontent had been rising for months, however, as the country reeled from a severe economic crisis and as opposition leaders pressed to have Zaire join the democratic trend sweeping much of Africa.
 
Mobutu to Keep Title
 After 10 hours of talks today with opposition leaders, President Mobutu agreed to allow Etienne Tshisekedi, his fiercest adversary since 1980, to become Prime Minister and form what is being called a crisis government. Under this arrangement, General Mobutu would remain head of state with as-yet undefined but apparently diminished powers.
Five Mobutu loyalists would have posts in an 11-member coalition government under the accord, with the remaining posts going to the opposition.
The two sides are to meet again Monday for the third successive day to try to agree on Cabinet posts.
 Despite hope stirred by the developments, there appeared to be a strong prospect of further political chaos . Delegates to a democracy conference gathered outside the talks at Kinshasa's marble palace and vowed to kill any opposition leaders who allowed President Mobutu to remain in Government even as a figurehead.
The protesters blocked the entrance to the center where the talks were held and then swarmed around President Mobutu as he arrived. They shouted "dictator" and "thief" when he ventured into the crowd, wearing his trademark leopard-skin hat, and tried to explain the reasons for forming the coalition. Inside, the delegates did their best to ignore the turbulence, dining on smoked salmon and drinking Champagne for lunch.
The delegates were angered at being left out of the talks. They said the national conference, whose 3,000 delegates are scheduled to reconvene Tuesday in a continuing effort to chart a path to democracy, should instead manage the transition.
 
Talks Began Seven Weeks Ago
 The current political negotiating process started seven weeks ago, but because of a dispute over the selection of delegates, it bogged down. Opponents charged that President Mobutu filled the lists with his own supporters.
Only the major opposition parties are involved in talks on forming a new government. Many of the leaders of those parties have served under President Mobutu at one time but have since broken with him.
In an apparent effort to re-establish control over the military, President Mobutu announced the dismissal of his army Chief of Staff, Gen. Manzembe Mayibanga, and ordered a complete restructuring of the armed forces. The general was replaced by the current head of military intelligence, Gen. Mahele Liyeko, officials said.
Last Monday, about 3,000 Zairian paratroopers touched off widespread rioting and looting as they went on a rampage after the Government had failed to pay them for months. They closed Kinshasa's airport and Congo River port, looting stores and private housesmostly owned or rented by Zaire's wealthy expatriates.
As the pillaging and unrest spread, France and Belgium flew in hundreds of special troops to evacuate their citizens from the former Belgian colony.
The national radio station said today that 117 people had been killed and nearly 160 others injured in the wave of rioting that swept through this dilapidated city and elsewhere in the country. The streets were deserted at nightfall, with soldiers scattered along the roads enforcing a dawn-to-dusk curfew. Most stores and offices in the capital were shuttered, and the airport remained closed to commercial traffic.
 
Figurehead Status Possible
 Opposition figures and Western diplomats interviewed this weekend were reluctant to give a timetable for what many consider the inevitable downfall of President Mobutu. But several diplomats suggested that his fortunes had sunk so low that he might now be persuaded to remain in power as essentially a figurehead, presiding over a transitional government until elections are held.
"This is incredible -- Mobutu has committed political suicide," said Olivier Kasongo, an opposition leader who was among the hundreds who gathered this morning at the conference center where President Mobutu and opposition leaders held their talks.
A senior Western diplomat with extensive experience in Africa said: "It is not in our interest that Mobutu suddenly disappear. What may replace him is unclear, and meanwhile, the situation could prove chaotic."
Even if the differences between the President and the opposition can be bridged, it is not clear how the people of Zaire will react as they face an economic crisis of unprecedented proportions.
One sign of the continuing deterioration of the security situation here was the sudden and unexpected departure of the entire European staff of the Inter-Continental Hotel. Soon after the rioting began last week, troops from the presidential guard surrounded the hotel. Not long afterward, several hundred French, Belgian and other expatriates sought refuge there.
On Friday night, however, marauding soldiers from the presidential guard reportedly moved to the tree-lined streets near the hotel, using rifles or pistols to shoot out padlocks and smash down doors. Apparently fearing that the attacks might spread to the hotel, the foreign staff fled this afternoon.
In all of sub-Saharan Africa, Zaire has one of the worst reputations for official corruption and economic mismanagement. According to African and Western diplomats, as well as numerous scholars on Zaire, President Mobutu has used his position to make himself one of the world's richest men. Critics estimate his personal fortune at $4 billion.
Even his harshest critics, however, give him high marks for having woven together a nation out of nearly 250 often-feuding ethnic groups. He has achieved this through a mix of political acumen, personal appeal and strong-arm tactics.
 
Economic Policy Faulted
 But his economic leadership is held in far lower regard. In early 1990, the Government abandoned an economomic recovery program devised by the International Monetary Fund. At the same time, Government spending ballooned. The resulting budget deficit helped push annual inflation in Zaire to an estimated 900 percent to 1,000 percent, its highest level since 1960, the year of independence from Belgium.
Meanwhile, because of deficit spending and a sharp decrease in the availability of foreign exchange, the national currency, the zaire, has depreciated rapidly against the American dollar. In January 1990, the zairecq traded at about 300 to the dollar; the official exchange rate is now about 19,000 to the dollar.
Workers typically earn in a month the money needed to survive just one week, and many have second jobs. Many Zairians complain that they have no money to buy anything, and if they did, there is little in stores to buy.
When confronted with accusations of corruption and mismanagement, the 60-year-old leader has insisted that he is a victim of disinformation. He has also blamed external factors like weak commodity prices for the growing civil strife and the country's sharply deteriorating standard of living.
 
Hundreds of Millions From U.S.
 President Mobutu's Government has received hundreds of millions of dollars from the United States since he seized power in a 1965 military coup. The Central Intelligence Agency is said to haveworked closely with President Mobutu for years. Historians have written that American officials knew about, and some say even helped, his successful coup. The takeover followed five years of bitter factional fighting in the country among Marxists with Soviet ties, pro-Western moderate reformers, and a neo-colonial leadership in what was then Katanga province, in the nation's south.
In particular, Zaire's role as a conduit for arms for United States-backed rebels in Angola led by Jonas Savimbi virtually assured continuing support for the Mobutu leadership. At the same time, President Mobutu has maintained strong ties with Belgium while developing relations with France and South Africa.
But amid allegations of a massacre of 12 university students by security forces in May 1990, and possibly several times that number, the United States Congress voted in December to cut all military and economic aid to Zaire.
If President Mobutu should leave the political scene, the leading candidates to fill the vacuum are thought to be Mr. Tshisekedi, the head of the largest opposition group, the Union for Democracy and Social Process, and a former Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Nguza Karl-i-Bond. Both have been accused at various times of having been co-opted by President Mobutu; however, Mr. Nguza has also felt the President's wrath, serving years in prison when he fell from official grace.
In 1967, Mr. Tshisekedi was instrumental in writing a document that helped set up President Mobutu's one-party state, but in 1981, he was one of 13 members of Parliament who broke with the leader. They signed a letter accusing the Goverment of corruption, human rights abuses and the stifling of democracy.
Mr. Nguza has also had a checkered career. In the late 1970's after serving as prime minister, he became one of President Mobutu's severest critics and in 1980 was sentenced to death for treason. The sentence was later reduced to a long prison term. Mr. Nguza later testified before a United States Congressional committee investigating reports that President Mobutu had embezzled aid funds from the United States.
Nonetheless, in 1986 President Mobutu sent Mr. Nguza to Washington as Zaire's Ambassador to the United States.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has agreed to a governing arrangement that could mark the end of his autocratic reign. He talked with reporters before he met with opposition party members yesterday. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A6)
 
Chart: "Zaire at a Glance"
 
LAND
Zaire occupies the major part of the Congo River basin and a small part of the Upper Nile Basin, covering 905-365 square miles. It is the third-largest country in Africa, after the Sudan and Algeria, and is about the size of the United States east of the Mississippi River.
 
POPULATION: 35.3 million
(1990 est.)
 
ECONOMY
Though it has huge mineral resources, including large copper deposits, Zaire has suffered the collapse of its infrastructure and economy with the Government unable to pay the salaries of civil servants and foreign creditors refusing additional aid.
 
HISTORY
King Leopold II of Belgium hired the English explorer Henry Stanley in 1878 to conquer a large area in Central Africa, and the newly created Congo Freee State became the King's personal property in 1885. In 1908, it was made a Belgian colony.
 
Belgium granted independence on June 30, 1960, but turmoil immediately followed, including a Belgian-backed uprising in Katanga province that led to United Nations intervention.
 
Hundreds of thousands of Zairians died in uprisings in the country's first five years. Including its first Prime Minister, Patrice Lumumba, who was slain in 1961 after his ouster the previous year. On Nov. 24, 1965, Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu was named President after a coup; he later changed his name to Mobutu Sese Seko. In 1977 and 1978 Zairian invaders from Angola were repulsed with Western suport.
 
President Mobutu, whose Government received substantial amounts of American aid, was accused of enriching himself while stripping the country of its wealth. He ruled virtually unchallenged until 1990, when demands for democracy forced him to agree to legalize opposition parties.
 
Sources: Associated Press; Europa World Yearbook; The World Almanac and Book of Facts) (pg. A6)
